instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not here to talk. I'm here for those documents.
output: We'll see about that. We'll see about that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I believe the killer is Wuunferth the Unliving.
output: That's quite an accusation. I assume you have proof?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Thalmor? What Thalmor?
output: The one who calls himself Ancano. He seeks information about the Eye, but what he will find shall be quite different. His path will cross yours in time, but first you must find that which you need.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not the first to come see you?
output: No, though you may be the last. The one who calls himself Ancano has sought my knowledge as well, through very different questions. Your path differs from most. You are being guided, pushed towards something. It is a good path, one untraveled by many. It is a path that can save your College. I will tell you what you need to know to follow it further.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do I need?
output: You, and those aiding you, wish to know more about the Eye of Magnus. You wish to avoid the disaster of which you are not yet aware. To see through Magnus' Eye without being blinded, you require his staff. Events now spiral quickly towards the inevitable center, so you must act with haste. Take this knowledge to your Arch-Mage.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Anoriath.
output: The wood elf may run a stall in the city, but he retreats to the plains outside Whiterun to hunt. Kill him there, and no one will bear witness...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Beitild.
output: She separated from her husband several months ago. Now the two run competing mining operations. Beitild's angry and desperate. A fighter.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Deekus.
output: He's an Argonian layabout, likes to scavenge shipwrecks. My guess is he'll run if threatened. Or swim, if given the chance.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Safia.
output: Ah, yes. The pirate captain. A ruthless she-devil, by all accounts. Deadly with a blade. This is my final contract, and certainly the most challenging. Be careful with this one, my friend. And let's not forget her crew - loyal and bloodthirsty, the lot of them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Helvard.
output: He's the housecarl of Falkreath. You know what that means? He's the bodyguard to the Jarl himself. So be careful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Narfi.
output: He's a hapless beggar living in some ruins just outside the village of Ivarstead. Easy even for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Maluril.
output: He's dangerous. Very dangerous. A rogue Dark Elf mage doing research into Dwarven artifacts should be both respected... and feared. Just not by you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Hern.
output: He's a vampire, and has blended into human society for years. He's never far from his female companion, Hert. Also a vampire. The contract is for the male, Hern. But you'll probably have to contend with the female, too. So for Sithis' sake, watch yourself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Ennodius.
output: He lives just outside Anga's Mill, in the woods. He was once the miller. Now Papius is just a paranoid recluse who thinks someone is out to get him. And he's right.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Agnis.
output: Your political affairs are your own, but any allegiance you may have in the ongoing war could very well affect your access to Fort Greymoor. She's a maid. Old, and feeble. But with this contract it's much more a matter of "where" than "who."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Lurbuk.
output: He is, by all accounts, the worst bard in all of Skyrim. Apparently so many people sought his death, Astrid had to hold a lottery to determine the client.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Ma'randru-jo.
output: He's an accomplished wizard. And, locating him may be challenging, as he travels with the caravans.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Companions are werewolves?
output: Not all of us, just the members of the Circle. We shouldn't be talking about this anyway.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is Wuuthrad?
output: It was the blade hefted by Ysgramor when he returned to drive the elves out of the old Skyrim. It was the blade hefted by Ysgramor when he returned to drive the elves out of the old Skyrim. Without that axe, this whole land would be overrun still. Without that axe, this whole land would be overrun still.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Silver Hand?
output: A group of werewolf hunters who have gotten wise to our little secret. They've made it their mission to hunt us down, but we are hunters ourselves.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The killer has struck again.
output: Oh, isn't that a shame. And here I am in the Bloodworks. Looks like you aren't such a sharp investigator after all.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Calixto Corrium was the real killer.
output: I'm glad you were able to correct your mistake. I'll release Wuunferth immediately.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

input: The killer must still be out there.
output: Obviously. You should visit the Bloodworks to talk to Wuunferth -- we need to figure out where the evidence went wrong. Obviously. You should visit the Bloodworks to talk to Wuunferth -- we need to figure out where the evidence went wrong. Obviously. instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How will I know when to awaken?
output: I will watch over you as you slumber to ensure your safety. If I deduce anything is amiss, I will use my arts to bring you back. Otherwise, I am uncertain what will end your Dreamstride. Perhaps when Vaermina's curious appetite has been filled.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who is the Daedric Lord Vaermina?
output: Vaermina resides in a strange realm known as Quagmire... a nightmarish land where reality shifts upon itself in seemingly impossible ways. From her citadel at the center, she reaches forth to collect our memories, leaving nothing in return apart from visions of horror and despair.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd be happy to help.
output: Thank Mara. I was afraid I'd never be able to convince you. Allow me to gather the materials I need for my ritual, and then I will meet you outside the ruins.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know where we can find the Torpor?
output: I believe there is a laboratory in the east wing. If we proceed there, we should be able to locate a sample.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will The Dreamstride feel like?
output: Thanks to all of these odd principles, there is quite a lot of debate as to whether this is really a dream or just the machinations of Vaermina. Those around you will perceive you as normal and you will find the words you utter may not be your own. You'll be viewing the memory of another through your own eyes and with your own body.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: "White-Gold Concordat"? What's that?
output: The Great War... only thirty years past and already ancient history to most people. Seems to me like it just ended... it's never really ended for me. But to answer your question, the White-Gold Concordat was the fancy name they put on the peace treaty between the Empire and the Thalmor. It ended the war and saved the Empire to fight another day. Also trampled on the sacred name of Talos, and gave the Thalmor free reign to stamp out Talos worship throughout the Empire.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's so important about me being Dragonborn?
output: Dragons are coming back, and you're a born dragonslayer. That's all you need to know right now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't change the subject.
output: Soul gems are the subject, friend. They're used in enchanting, then they break. Except one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Look, I'm willing to pay. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: A few coins for my soul? If only you understood the irony.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Look, I'm willing to pay. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: I don't think you understand. I'm not answering questions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't believe in fate.
output: Perhaps that is what you are meant to believe. To better serve your role as Azura's champion. Do not fight it. Azura's prophecies always come to pass. To deny them is to go headlong into the darkness with no light to guide you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: A priestess of Azura sent me. (Persuade)
output: Azura? Gods, it's all finally coming back to haunt me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you all alone here?
output: Yes. There were others at first, but Azura's visions tested everyone's faith. One by one, they left. Afraid to know their own future. But I refuse to abandon the shrine. The visions are a gift. Azura warns me of tragedy, war, death before it happens. I won't leave her guidance.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Soul gems? Why are you asking?
output: That's what caused all the trouble. Soul gems are used in enchanting, but they break afterwards. Except one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where did this shrine come from?
output: My people, the Dunmer, built it. We fled from Morrowind after Vvardenfell erupted almost 200 years ago. Those of us who were faithful to Azura were given a vision that led us away from the island before the worst came. This shrine is our thanks to her. That none will forget that she watches over us all.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: They're for enchanting, correct?
output: They are. Except the gem is always consumed. They're frail. Except for one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I misspoke. Forget I asked.
output: That's for the best.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there an elven mage here that studies stars?
output: Did you say an "elf" and "stars"? I hope you don't know what you're asking.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there an elven mage here that studies stars?
output: "An elf that studies stars"? Where did you hear about that?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there an elven mage here that studies stars?
output: Studies stars you say? Why, there hasn't been a mage doing anything related to stars since.... Oh....

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there an elven mage here that studies stars?
output: Why specifically stars? Wait, you aren't referring to... No, there's no way you would know about that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there an elven mage here that studies stars?
output: I know plenty of spells that produce light, but stars? Hmm. There was that problem a few years ago, but that couldn't be related.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there an elven mage here that studies stars?
output: Stars? You wouldn't be referring to that incident a few years ago? I still say that exile was far too harsh.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there an elven mage here that studies stars?
output: Why would anyone bother to study stars? Well, unless you're talking about that artifact that got all those... dimwits thrown out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there an elven mage here that studies stars?
output: Studies stars? I remember the last time the word "stars" was flown through the Hall of the Elements. Bad things had happened.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Would you believe I was given a vision?
output: Well, I've certainly heard worse things. I think the man you want to talk to is Nelacar. He was exiled a few years ago, bad research. Still hangs around the Frozen Hearth.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Would you believe I was given a vision?
output: You were given a vision? Are you serious? Whatever. The person you probably want is Nelacar. He's in the Frozen Hearth. Be careful, he was exiled from the College for a reason.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Would you believe I was given a vision?
output: No. I wouldn't. Why don't you head into town and get a drink at the Frozen Hearth? I hear old Nelacar still has a room there. He knows a lot of stories, that one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Would you believe I was given a vision?
output: Vision? What vision are you talking about? Oh, no matter. You should head to the Frozen Hearth and speak with Nelacar. It's his story to tell, and I wouldn't want to discredit him by talking behind his back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Would you believe I was given a vision?
output: You should go into town and talk to an elf named Nelacar. He was involved in the whole mess.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Would you believe I was given a vision?
output: Yes, I did. I shouldn't be the one to tell you about this. There's an Altmer named Nelacar in the Frozen Hearth. Believe me, he'll know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: MS12SharedInfo
output: Just a man's life work, is all. I've finally derived the location of the White Phial, but this doting busybody won't let me get it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Would you believe I was given a vision?
output: Oh no, I'm not talking about that. I'm not being blamed for saying something out of place. Again. If you want to know, ask Nelacar. He's staying at the Frozen Hearth. Knows the whole sad story.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Would you believe I was given a vision?
output: Almost the opposite. The College got rid of something... someone, that was too much trouble. There's an Altmer named Nelacar staying at the inn outside the College. You should ask him about it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is it? What happened?
output: Officially, nothing. Why don't you head into town and get a drink at the Frozen Hearth? I hear old Nelacar still has a room there. He knows a lot of stories, that one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is it? What happened?
output: Well, it's a... minor stain on the College's reputation. One of many, unfortunately. You should head to the Frozen Hearth and speak with Nelacar. It's his story to tell, and I wouldn't want to discredit him by talking behind his back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is it? What happened?
output: It was a few years ago. A few of the mages got overconfident and were exiled. They had no talent, anyway. I hear one of them, Nelacar, still hangs around the Frozen Hearth. Guess he has no where else to go, poor thing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is it? What happened?
output: There was some bother about a group of mages being exiled. I can't remember what the details were. I think one of them came back. Nelacar. Stays at the Frozen Hearth, but I don't know why. He's not welcome in the College.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is it? What happened?
output: You shouldn't ask me. There's an Altmer named Nelacar in the Frozen Hearth. He's the one to talk to.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is it? What happened?
output: Oh, no, I'm not falling for that one again. Next thing I know, I'm getting yelled at for saying something inappropriate. If you're so curious, talk to Nelacar, in the Frozen Hearth. He can tell you the whole sad story.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is it? What happened?
output: The kind of things that even the College won't tolerate. Things that can get a wizard exiled for life. There's an Altmer who's staying at the Frozen Hearth. Nelacar. You should speak with him, if you're so curious.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I didn't agree to anything. Talk. (Intimidate)
output: Just calm down. I'll tell you everything.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I didn't agree to anything. Talk. (Intimidate)
output: Do you think muscling me is going to work? I'm a wizard. An old. Elven. Wizard. Think about it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did Skjor call this my Trial?
output: I watch you to make sure you are honorable.  If you are honorable and strong, then I can call you sister.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did Skjor call this my Trial?
output: I would hope that's obvious. Do well here, and you'll be a full member of the Companions.  Fail, and it won't matter anyway.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who was this scholar?
output: One of those icebrains who wanders the land getting people's hopes up.  From my view, I don't think we'll find anything here.  You'd better hope there's still a chance for you to prove yourself, though, or this Trial might last longer than you'd like.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who was this scholar?
output: A smart man came and told us about a blade piece.  Skjor thinks you should find it, and I'm supposed to watch you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You think you know how to repair the Phial?
output: I have some thoughts. There are three crucial elements. Some may be easier to find than others. On the top of the Throat of the World is a patch of Unmelting Snow. No heat can touch it. Then we need the tusk of a mammoth, ground to a fine powder as only the giants know how. The final step is tricky. It requires the briar heart from a Forsworn of the Reach. If you can bring me these materials, the Phial can again be made whole.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is that my job?
output: You've shown yourself useful so far. All these lunks are too afraid of Haldyn to head in before the fog's cleared. So if you're willing to perform one more service for the Company, we could put this matter behind us for good. Take out Haldyn, and we'll handle the rest.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I received your letter.
output: Good to hear. You can be a difficult man to find. Thankfully those couriers are tenacious.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I received your letter.
output: Good to hear. You can be a difficult woman to find. Thankfully those couriers are tenacious.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Never mind.
output: Hmph. Hmph.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I am not your champion, monster.
output: Who do you think brought Septimus here? Who do you think protected you on your journey to open the box and loose my knowledge on this world? Your free will is an illusion. Whether you acknowledge me or not is your own business. But I will be in your mind.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want with the Elder Scroll?
output: Ooooh, an observant one. How clever to ask of Septimus. This Dwemer lockbox. Look upon it and wonder.  Inside is the heart. The heart of a god! The heart of you. And me.  But it was hidden away. Not by the Dwarves, you see. They were already gone.  Someone else. Unseen. Unknown. Found the heart, and with a flair for the ironical, used Dwarven trickery to lock it away. The scroll will give the deep vision needed to open it. For not even the strongest machinations of the Dwemer can hold off the all-sight given by an Elder Scroll.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So I'm free to leave?
output: Yes, you're innocent. As innocent as anyone can be in this city. I guess we also owe you something for locking you up. Here, my family's ring. And everything the guards confiscated from you. Now if you'll excuse me, I have a mine that needs new workers to fill it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Now what?
output: Well, are there any questions before we begin?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't have any more questions. What would you like me to do?
output: Ah, yes. Hmm. Well, why don't you see if you can assist Arniel Gane? He's one of our scholars, here working on cataloging our finds. Any enchanted items will do; the usefulness of the enchantment is irrelevant. If you find anything, the class can look it over. I expect he'd appreciate some help in locating any additional magical artifacts here in the ruins.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't have any more questions. What would you like me to do?
output: Find Arniel Gane. He's somewhere in the northern section of the ruins. He'll show you what to do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not quite ready to go inside yet.
output: No? I daresay we don't have all day.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not quite ready to go inside yet.
output: Still? If I have to wait much longer, you may need to just bury me here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Emissary Elenwen was asking for you inside. (Persuade)
output: The Emissary? What's this about? Wait... who are you? Intruder!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to see Madanach.
output: You ready to pay the toll? One shiv.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's your shiv.
output: Then find one. That dung heap Grisvar's been known to make a few.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need more details about Goldenglow.
output: Then out of the clear blue, Aringoth stops sending us our cut. Mercer was... well, angry to put it kindly. Goldenglow Estate brought in a mountain of gold for the Guild. You could almost call it our sweetest deal. So we send in Vex and find out he's hired a bunch of mercenaries to guard the place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the catch?
output: The catch is that you can't burn the whole place to the ground. That important client Mercer mentioned would be furious if you did.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How about some skooma instead? (Bribe)
output: Ah, now that's a good idea. Head on in. But don't try anything in there. Madanach is smarter than you think.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do I destroy the bee hives?
output: They're built like small fortresses to resist the weather, but their one weakness is flame. Besides, nothing tells the people of Riften we mean business better than a huge column of smoke.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What should I do about Aringoth?
output: The Guild has a lot riding on this. Don't make me look foolish by mucking it up. Maven prefers that Aringoth remains alive, but if he tries to stop you from getting the job done, kill him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who cares, we're the Thieves Guild.
output: That's not how things work around here. The Guild depends on an arrangement of influential people to keep things running smoothly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about the Goldenglow job.
output: Goldenglow Estate is a bee farm; they raise the wretched little things for honey. It's owned by some smart-mouth wood elf named Aringoth. We need you to teach him a lesson by burning down three of the estate's hives and clearing out the safe in the main house.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I can't kill Grisvar without a shiv.
output: Ah, Borkul muscle one out of you on your way in? Fine. Take this one.

input: We have evidence of necromancy, and found his amulet.
output: I don't want to believe it. Wuunferth has been a trusted friend to Ulfric for many years. It pains me to see that the whispers had truth to them.  Wuunferth shall be apprehended. I thank you for your diligence in getting to the bottom of this matter. The streets of Windhelm are now safe.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm trying to find out who did this. I was hoping you'd help.
output: Well... all right. What exactly do you need to know?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have authority in this matter, and need your cooperation.
output: Well... all right. What exactly do you need to know?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

input: I guess Calixto was wrong.
output: Eehh.. Calixto and his books are often confused about such matters. It happens to the best of us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think I'll hold on to it for the time being.
output: Suit yourself. It's only of value to collectors, though. Good luck finding anyone else who will appraise it that highly!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why can't the guards help?
output: They say they're too busy with the war -- I say what good is winning a war if we're still terrorized by one of our own?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you want to find your daughter's killer or not?
output: I've had enough troubles recently. What is it that you're after?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Another? This has happened before?
output: Susanna's the third. It's always the same: young girl, killed at night, body torn up. Susanna's the third. It's always the same: young girl, killed at night, body torn up. instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It sounds like the court mage has been experimenting.
output: Wuunferth. There have been rumors swirling about him for years. As long as I can remember. But he's a dangerous man. It's why they call him "the Unliving." I wouldn't approach him directly. This information needs to go straight to the steward. He'll listen to you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Shouldn't the court mage have it?
output: Wuunferth? Bah. It's purely ceremonial, and he has no use for it. Besides, I wouldn't want to be the one to give it to him. Gives me the creeps. They say he dabbles in necromancy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found one of your journals, all about necromancy.
output: Necromancy? I am a member of the College of Winterhold, in good standing! They haven't allowed necromancy for hundreds of years!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Could you use some help?
output: If you want to help, ask some of these gawkers if they saw anything useful.  If you want to help, ask some of these gawkers if they saw anything useful.  If you want to help, ask some of these gawkers if they saw anything useful.  If you want to help, ask some of these gawkers if they saw anything useful. instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So what can we do now?
output: I've been noting a pattern to when the killings happen.  Now that we know they're tied in to some sort of necromantic ritual, I think I know when the next might occur. Let's see. From a Loredas of Last Seed until a Middas of Heartfire... it will happen soon. Very soon. Keep watch in the Stone Quarter tomorrow night. That's almost certainly where the killer will strike next.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found your journals and amulet where the Butcher worked.
output: My what, now? I've never kept a journal, I can assure you. What exactly did this amulet look like?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found this poster in Hjerim.
output: I've been trying to put those up around the city, to warn people. Have them keep their eyes open. But someone keeps taking them down. You say you found it in Hjerim? Friga's old place. Let's go have a look around there. I've got a feeling about this one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: MS11ViolaToHjerimExclamationPoint
output: Follow me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: MS11ViolaToHjerimExclamationPoint
output: I'll meet you over there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm sorry to have troubled you.
output: Good day.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can the rest of the people not care?
output: Oh, they care all right. Just none of them thinks to do anything about it. They say I'm just snooping around bothering people, but I'm trying to save lives!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You have yourself a deal, sir.
output: Wonderful. This will be a splendid addition to my private collection.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Eight-sided. Jade, ringed with ebony. A worn carving.
output: I know it well. Or at least, I've heard of it. I would wager that carving once depicted a skull. That is the Necromancer's Amulet, of legend.  It appears you were at least half-right. There is necromancy at the heart of this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ready to check out the house?
output: Let's go. I'd rather not stay out here alone any longer than I have to.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm sorry to trouble you, but I have some more questions.
output: I'm sorry -- she was very dear to me, and it's rather painful to think about.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm sorry to trouble you, but I have some more questions.
output: I'd rather not talk about my daughter, if you'll excuse me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know anything about this amulet?
output: Let me see... ah, yes. This is the Wheelstone. It's an heirloom symbol of the power of Windhelm.  Traditionally it's carried by the court mage. I would... eh... be interested in acquiring it. If you're willing to part with it, that is. For a piece like that, I could pay... 500 gold?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know anything about this amulet?
output: The Wheelstone? Have you decided to sell it, yet?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to investigate her house, but I'll need the key.
output: Hjerim? Well, I'm not sure what you think you'll find there, but you're welcome to have a look.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there a story behind that burned down house?
output: Hroggar's house? It burned down not too long ago. It's a real pity about his wife and kid. The screams woke half the town. Most folk won't go near it now for fear it's cursed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: With his own wife and child inside?
output: That's what they say. See, he's living with Alva now. That started the day after the fire. It ain't right, movin' in with a new love the day after your kin die like that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And of course they can't prove he murdered them.
output: Aye. Our Jarl would sure like to know if he did though. Might even pay to find out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did the fire start?
output: Hroggar claims it was a hearth fire. Some folks say Hroggar started it himself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm listening...
output: I knew you looked like a clever one...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm no thief.
output: Of course not! Thieves take what is precious. Thieves steal. We just take what will not be missed. What no one needs anymore. Maybe we take some weapons and stop a few deaths. Who would call that thievery?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What would happen to sailors on the boat?
output: Don't worry about them. We'll make sure they wash up safe. Maybe they'll even pay us for the heroic rescue from their sad crash.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Setting up a wreck? I should turn you in to the guards.
output: Turn me in? For what? What crime's been committed? I'm just making idle talk about what would most undoubtedly be a tragic event... A tragic, and very, very profitable event.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Okay, so what's your offer?
output: With the war, many more ships come through these docks. Loaded with weapons and pay, but few people. And they pass through dangerous waters. We have an interest in one of those boats, the Icerunner. The Solitude Lighthouse will be guiding it in... but if its fire were to go out, the Icerunner would run aground.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I put out the Lighthouse fire.
output: The effects have already been felt. The Icerunner has failed to dock on time. Without the Lighthouse, the Icerunner will have swung wide of the western shoal and run aground on the eastern coast. My sister Deeja will be at the wreck with our Blackblood Marauders. She knows to expect you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did you see that?
output: I... I swear I felt something rather strange just then. What just happened?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm trapped in here!
output: How in the world did that happen?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Some sort of ghost or apparition appeared. It spoke to me.
output: I'm afraid I didn't see anything...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I pulled an amulet off the wall.
output: Really? Perhaps the amulet is important somehow. Is there some way you can use it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this thing?
output: I have no idea! This is amazing. Absolutely amazing. The Arch-Mage needs to be informed immediately. He needs to see this for himself. I don't dare leave this unattended. Can you return to the College and inform Savos Aren of this discovery? Please, hurry.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It said something about danger ahead, and the Psijic Order.
output: The Psijic Order? Are you quite sure about that? That's very odd. And danger ahead? Why that doesn't make any sense at all.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You want me to steal it?
output: Well let's not put it like that. Wouldn't want the Thieves Guild catching wind of us, eh? Nah, just creep in and have a go at taking it out. I'll be here, and pay you half of what my man in Riften promised for it. You'll be helping out an old beggar, and the Divines smile on that sort of thing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did you say something about money?
output: Aye, a whole heap of it. You see that Temple? Way up there? All them women, keeping to themselves. Won't let poor Degaine in, no. Not even for a look.  But they've got a treasure in there. Gold statue, size of a child. Who knows what they use it for, but I know what I'll use it for.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm here to bring you to the Temple in Markarth.
output: Then it is true what they said? I am touched by the gods?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've brought your Sybil.
output: You... you found her? I can't believe it. Let the girl come with me and we can begin her preparation. I will send word to her family that she is in good hands. You've truly earned the Blessing of Dibella, child. Prostrate yourself before her altar, and she will bestow her gift.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for a young girl who lives around here.
output: Damn it, man, are you trying to taunt us?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to speak to you about Saarthal.
output: Please don't tell me that another one of the apprentices has been incinerated. I have enough to deal with right now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We found some sort of... orb. Tolfdir wanted you to see it.
output: I... see. I trust that Tolfdir will provide a more... specific explanation.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We've found something in Saarthal, and Tolfdir thinks it's important.
output: Very well, I trust that you wouldn't be here were it not significant.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did you say you were missing?
output: My Alembic. I need it for some research, and can't seem to find it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You look like you could use a hand.
output: Well, yes. This is rather embarrassing, but it seems I've misplaced something.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found what you were looking for.
output: Ah, yes! There it is! Thank you so much.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Both sides respect the Greybeards. They will listen.
output: Even the Greybeards must bend to the winds of change, it seems. So be it. Tell Ulfric and General Tullius that the Greybeards wish to speak to them. We will see if they still remember us. Paarthurnax has made the decision to help you. This is the road we have to walk.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: One of his dragon allies could tell us...
output: Yes, of course! But how to force a dragon to talk to you... There is one possibility. But... no, the Jarl would never agree.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Jarl <Alias.ShortName=Jarl> won't help me while the war rages.
output: I see. The dragon will lead you to Alduin, but without the Jarl's help...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Jarl? What are you talking about?
output: Do you know Dragonsreach? The Jarl of Whiterun's palace? Its name is no accident. The palace was originally built to hold a captive dragon.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So if I could lure a dragon into Dragonsreach...
output: You might be able to trap him there, exactly. You'd require the Jarl's cooperation, of course. That might not be easy to come by. You must trust in the rightness of your cause, and the strength of your Voice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: But I thought there weren't any dragons until Alduin came back.
output: Oh, this was back in the days of Olaf One-Eye, thousands of years ago. In those days, dragons could still be found among the remote mountain peaks. Before the Blades wiped them all out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need your help. I need to capture a dragon.
output: We are not warriors. What is overlooked in the Dragonborn is not permitted to any other followers of the Way of the Voice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need your help. I need to capture a dragon.
output: Ah! Dragonsreach! There are many difficulties, but I cannot think of a better plan. Although I fear the Jarl may not be easy to persuade. Remember, the Way of the Voice trains you for more than battle. Indeed, we believe that battle is the least of its uses. May the strength and truth of your Voice serve you well. Breath and focus.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I learned the Dragonrend Shout.
output: Alduin... we heard the Dragonrend Shout from here... you defeated him?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, but he escaped. I need to find out where he went.
output: I feared as much. I thought it was him we saw flying east after your battle.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who is Mehrunes Dagon?
output: Ah, an excellent question. Mehrunes Dagon is the Daedric Lord of Change, Destruction, and Ambition. Dagon's Mythic Dawn cult killed the Septim Dynasty and opened the Oblivion Gates into Tamriel. They called it the Oblivion Crisis.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want to know more about the Razor.
output: The Razor is Mehrunes Dagon's personal artifact. It has always heralded bloody change and carnage. It's held many names: Dagger of the Final Wounds, Bane of the Righteous, the Kingslayer. The Mythic Dawn worshipped Dagon as a god. Having his Razor would be invaluable to my collection.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the problem?
output: The "problem" is your disrespect for the laws of this land. It's time to face the Jarl's justice. The "problem" is your disrespect for the laws of this land. It's time to face the Jarl's justice. The "problem" is your disrespect for the laws of this land. It's time to face the Jarl's justice. The "problem" is your disrespect for the laws of this land. It's time to face the Jarl's justice. The "problem" is your disrespect for the laws of this land. It's time to face the Jarl's justice. The "problem" is your disrespect for the laws of this land. It's time to face the Jarl's justice. The "problem" is your disrespect for the laws of this land. It's time to face the Jarl's justice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You caught me. I'll pay off my bounty. (<CrimeGold> gold)
output: Smart man. Now come along with us. We'll take any stolen goods, and you'll be free to go. After you pay the fine, of course. Smart man. Now come along with us. We'll take any stolen goods, and you'll be free to go. After you pay the fine, of course. Smart man. Now come along with us. We'll take any stolen goods, and you'll be free to go. After you pay the fine, of course. Smart man. Now come along with us. We'll take any stolen goods, and you'll be free to go. After you pay the fine, of course. Smart man. Now come along with us. We'll take any stolen goods, and you'll be free to go. After you pay the fine, of course. Smart man. Now come along with us. We'll take any stolen goods, and you'll be free to go. After you pay the fine, of course. Smart man. Now come along with us. We'll take any stolen goods, and you'll be free to go. After you pay the fine, of course.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I submit. Take me to jail.
output: I guess you're smarter than you look. I guess you're smarter than you look. I guess you're smarter than you look. I guess you're smarter than you look. I guess you're smarter than you look. I guess you're smarter than you look. I guess you're smarter than you look.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd rather die than go to prison!
output: Then pay with your blood. Then pay with your blood. Then pay with your blood. Then pay with your blood. Then pay with your blood. Then pay with your blood. Then pay with your blood.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The girl is just taken from her family?
output: It's considered a great honor for the family. Their daughter will never know hardship, and the goddess blesses them with great bounty.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why is this all such a secret?
output: We prefer not to announce that the Sybil has died until we can introduce the new one. People like to know that we're connected to the goddess.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is a Sybil?
output: The Sybil of Dibella spends her entire life in direct communion with the goddess. From the time she's a little girl to the moment she expires, she is a direct connection with the heavenly mother.  From her reverie, we know the mind of our god. We have had a vision of the next Sybil, living in a village to the north. She must be brought to the temple for her reverie to begin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for a young girl who lives around here.
output: Damn it, woman, are you trying to taunt us?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you talking about?
output: Our daughter, Fjotra, was taken from here. The Forsworn descended and... they didn't touch anything else. Just our little girl.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where did they take her?
output: It was the Forsworn from Broken Tower. Never been much trouble before. What's it to you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Anything else in it for me?
output: You, my dear, can earn the Blessing of Dibella. You'll find men to be more pliable in the future... or more vulnerable.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Anything else in it for me?
output: Have you heard of the Blessing of Dibella? It can help you with the wooing of women, if that's your aim. Typically we avoid bestowing it upon men, but for the Sybil's escort, we could make an exception. Or give you strength if you happen to offend one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your daughter is the Sybil of Dibella.
output: She... really? That's... I wouldn't have dreamed. Of course, we need her in Markarth, then. I'll come with you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I just want her to be safe.
output: That's... that's good of you. If you were to save her, I would be very grateful. I don't think there's anything I could give you, though...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll buy an amulet of Mara. (200 gold)
output: Here you are. Now remember, people in Skyrim respond to deeds. You will find more people interested in your love if you help them. Good luck. Mara bless you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll buy an amulet of Mara. (200 gold)
output: Lost the last one I gave you? Very well, here you are. Mara keep you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll buy an amulet of Mara. (200 gold)
output: I'm sorry, but even Mara's Temple needs coin. We will have a symbol ready for you when you come back with enough gold.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to have a wedding at the temple.
output: You wish to be married? It's good to see love blossoming, even during these difficult times. Your wedding will be held tomorrow, from dawn until dusk. Don't be late, you don't want to miss your own wedding!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did you need me to do?
output: Use the gloves to clear the focal points. Return to me when you have finished. I thought I made this rather clear.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe some other time.
output: I see.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: All right, I'll help.
output: Very well. These specially enchanted gloves will allow you to delve directly into the focal points for these energies. Please exercise caution. This is not a procedure without possible... consequences. Return the gloves to me when you have finished. Go to each focal point and remove whatever impurities you may find there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do these "energies" need to be cleansed?
output: As you may be aware, the College has gone to great lengths to purify and enhance the natural energies of the world. This both enhances our connection to the realm of magic, and eliminates possible interference from outside sources. These energies, on occasion, become... polluted. Effort must be made to see that they are kept pure, clean. Do you wish to aid in this cleansing?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there any College business I can assist with?
output: There may be a matter in which your... skills... could be useful. The various points of focus for magic energies around the College have become polluted, and need cleansing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there any College business I can assist with?
output: The magical energies underneath the College still require purification. Your assistance would be most useful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did you say you were missing?
output: A book of mine. I was at least halfway through, and wanted to finish it, but apparently I put it down somewhere.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your focal points have been, uh, cleansed.
output: Yes, they have. I can feel the difference already. But of course, I'm far more in tune with these sorts of things than most. Thank you. I appreciate your assistance.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Just tell me what to do.
output: The dawn surely opens upon you, child. You must bear its light that all may see.  Mara has reflected an image to me. At the foot of the throat and young woman... almost a girl... her fickle love must resolve itself. This is the prayer heard by the goddess and relayed to her servants. Return when she has seen her path. I will entreat Mara on your behalf. The village of Ivarstead. The woman, Fastred.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: May I receive her blessings?
output: To receive the touch of Mara, you must first act as her hands in the world. Explore the facets of the infinite jewel.  Not all can hear the broad echoes of deepest dawn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I helped the forlorn lovers of Markarth.
output: The goddess smiles at your efforts, child. The dawn shines bright upon you. You have seen the young, fickle love of youth, and helped a more seasoned love find its way.  There is one final aspect we wish for you to explore. For a strong love can withstand storms and even survive death. Take this symbol of Mara. She will guide you to the wandering souls of two whose love was so great that their entwinement binds them to this world.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your daughter asked me to speak to you.
output: Oh my. Probably something about the men. We all wish we had her problems. Now, don't tell my husband, but I don't have any problem with Bassianus. Even if it means her leaving Ivarstead, I want Fastred to be happy. If they just snuck out of town together, I could manage my husband.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's from Calcelmo. Please.
output: I'm not sure what this is all about.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Which of the Eight Divines do you serve?
output: We are devoted to the Goddess Mara, who gave mortals the gift of love that they might have a hint of eternity. Her blessings are many. To love is to know the true nature of the gods.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: She probably appreciates assertive men.
output: What did you call me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I helped the long-dead lovers find each other.
output: Your efforts have helped illuminate the entire province. I trust by now you've achieved a higher comprehension of love. Carry the blessings of Mara with you, so the rest of the province may shine with her glories.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: (Give poem)
output: This is... lovely. Calcelmo wrote this... about me? I never knew he had such feeling in him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you have to lose?
output: Ysmir's beard, you're right! No fish was ever caught by staying away from the shore. I'm off to see her!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: She said that you should elope.
output: I always had a feeling she liked me. More than that brute Jofthor, at least. Jofthor... what about him? He'll come after us and... it will be unpleasant.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That seems like a lot of money.
output: Come back when you've got the gold, then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He cares about you.
output: Clearly. I've never even thought of him in that manner. I wish that I was as skilled with words as he. Here, take him this letter. I may not be as eloquent as he is, but I hope he understands.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: About that poem....
output: Are you prepared to receive my golden words?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll buy it. (200 gold)
output: Wonderful. I'll write it out so you won't forget it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do you want her to stay so badly?
output: Look around here. There's not much left. If all the young people leave, what happens to Ivarstead? Used to be a good-sized town, but folks have been moving to Riften for a while now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a letter from Faleen.
output: This is... more than I could have hoped for. Have you really done this for me? I have to see her. Please, excuse me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a poem I'd like you to read.
output: Pardon me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Boti said to talk to you about Fastred.
output: Oh, my love. How I long to take her away from all of this. Why did Boti send you to me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll talk to your parents about it.
output: Oh, thank you so much! It's wonderful to have someone around who understands.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You think she'll get over it?
output: You know how children are. Her fancies change with the moon. And like always, the boy lacks any kind of spine. He'll need some convincing. A little push and this would all be simpler.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I hear you lost Fastred.
output: Oh, Fastred. I'm not sure what happened. One moment she's smiling at me, the next I can't even meet her eyes. I'll bet Bassianus would know what's going on. He understands women.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you know I was coming?
output: I prayed to Mara and she spoke to me in a dream. She said a stranger would appear to help me. Is that you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes. What's troubling you?
output: My parents are being impossible. Bassianus wants to marry me. And I think I love him. But he wants to move to Riften afterwards, and my father won't allow it. He only cares about this stupid town, but Bassianus makes me happier than anyone ever has. My mother's not any help, either.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, I do.
output: Then you know what a beauty she is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've been sent by Mara to aid you.
output: Eh... You see... I've been thinking about Faleen quite a bit. You know Faleen? I was beginning to lose faith that any help would come.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm sorry, I don't know her.
output: Well, suffice to say she is resplendent, but not without resolve. Striking, in all senses.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your daughter asked me to speak to you.
output: I'm sure I know what this is about. She thinks she's in love with Bassianus and wants to leave town. With him. Let me tell you how I see it.  Until a few months ago, the girl was head over heels for Klimmek. Wouldn't stop talking about him. Now if I thought she was really in love with Bassianus, that would be one thing. But she's a child. It will pass.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No. Never mind.
output: (bark)

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about the Briar Heart.
output: The final tempering of the Phial was performed with a type of old magic that's been lost since the Dragon War. The nearest modern incarnation of it is the strange rituals practiced by the Forsworn. With the heart of one of their Briar Warriors, I can lock the Phial's magic into its physical form.  It's difficult to explain to the layman -- forgive me if I begin waxing alchemic.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about the Unmelting Snow.
output: On top of the Throat of the World is a patch of snow that's never melted. They say the Greybeards taught it to ignore the sun, and heat simply washes over it. The original Phial was made from this snow. We'll only need a small bit for the repairs.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about the Mammoth Tusk Powder.
output: The ivory produced by those beasts is as hard as iron. But the giants have found ways to make it yield. They're able to grind it down so fine that it can be infused into the lattice of packed snow. The finished material has the delicate nature of fresh powder snow, but the strength of the hardest steel.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It was like this when I found it.
output: Figures -- I doubt you have sufficient knowledge to harm the Phial even if you wanted to. Either way, this is the end of it.  Now if you'll excuse me, I'm not quite in the mood to entertain guests. I trust you can show yourself out. Here's for your trouble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes. Let me show you.
output: (woof)

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need you to do something.
output: (bark)

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where did he go?
output: Somewhere up north, in the ice fields. Said he found some old Dwemer artifact, but... well, that was years ago. Haven't heard from him since.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He's dead?
output: Oh no. I hope not. But even I haven't seen him in years, and we were close. Became obsessed with the Dwemer. Took off north saying he had found some old artifact. Haven't seen him since.  Somewhere in the ice fields, if you want to try to find him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you heard of a pirate crew called the Blood Horkers?
output: Know about them? Lad, you're looking at them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What else can you tell me about these pirates?
output: They call themselves the "Blood Horkers."  They've been around as long as I can remember, but only recently focused on our ships. A dastardly group, but they're more than simple brigands. Shrewd. Clever. Not to be trifled with.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is Hroggar your father?
output: You know him? He made my favorite dolly, but I can't find her. Are you sure you aren't a stranger?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: Helgi. But father says I'm not supposed to talk to strangers. Are you a stranger?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No. I'm a friend. Do you know what happened to your house?
output: The smoke woke me up. It was hot and I was scared, so I hid. Then it got cold and dark. I'm not scared anymore. But I'm lonely. Will you play with me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: If I do, will you tell me who set the fire?
output: We have to wait for nighttime though. The other one is playing too, and she can't come out until then. Okay! Let's play hide and seek. You find me and I'll tell you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You mean me, don't you?
output: I certainly do. Since you went so far as seek out the Augur for advice, I thought you'd be more enthusiastic.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So no one knows the Staff's location?
output: No one here does. The Synod seemed convinced it was somewhere in Skyrim. They inquired about the ruins of Mzulft, but that's all I remember. I suppose if you're intent on looking for the staff, there's a chance they might be in Mzulft yet. Just don't expect them to be cooperative. It sounded like they were heading there, though they were rather secretive about why.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What should I do next?
output: A most impressive attitude. Keep this up, and you'll do quite well for yourself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have important information for you.
output: Really? And what might that be?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You mean me, don't you.
output: I seem to recall Mirabelle mentioning the staff somewhat recently. Why don't you see if she can tell you anything? Something as specific and ancient as the Staff of Magnus... I'm not sure we'd ever find something like that... I'm quite pleased with your progress, you know. You've certainly proven yourself to be more than a mere Apprentice. Well done. This circlet once proved invaluable to me. I hope it can be of use to you now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Augur referred to it as the Eye of Magnus, not me.
output: The Augur? Just what have you gotten yourself involved in? Whatever is going on, whatever you're up to... Be very careful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Arch-Mage Aren said you'd mentioned it recently.
output: I see. Well yes, I suppose I did mention it, though I'm not sure what he expects me to tell you. I only brought it to his attention a few months back when the Synod showed up here looking for it. They were apparently under the impression we were keeping it in a closet somewhere.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's connected to the orb we found.
output: And how do you know this?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It may be connected to the Eye of Magnus.
output: The "Eye of Magnus"? I can appreciate that this... thing, this Orb... It's very impressive. Very unique, and definitely worth studying. But let's not jump to any conclusions, or assign it importance beyond what we're certain of.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know anything about the Staff of Magnus?
output: Well now that's an odd question. Why in the world would you be asking?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Synod?
output: Mages based out of Cyrodiil. They fancy themselves the Imperial Authority on magic these last few hundred years. It became clear they're trying to hoard powerful artifacts, looking to consolidate power. My understanding is that all they really do is make noise in an attempt to curry favor from the Emperor. Lots of politics, little magic. I was quite surprised to find them on our doorstep. They seemed amiable enough, but their line of questioning made me... uneasy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I spoke with the Augur of Dunlain.
output: Did you really? And he specifically mentioned the Staff of Magnus? I... I'm impressed with your initiative. Of course, someone will need to follow up on this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We need to find the Staff of Magnus.
output: I'm sorry, what? Well... I'd certainly love to have such a powerful staff, but I'm not really sure that any of us need it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry. So, the Staff of Magnus?
output: Well, it's said to be very powerful. Has the capacity to store an incredible amount of magical power, as the story goes. The only time I've heard it mentioned was when those Synod characters showed up some months ago looking for it. But it's more myth than anything at this point. I've no doubt that it actually exists, but no one has seen it in what, decades? Longer? I'm not sure.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: TGLarcenyShared
output: Well, well. I was looking for this little beauty. If you happen across any other unusual trinkets like this, be sure and bring them to me. I promise it'll be worth the effort.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Shall we see what your father thinks of this letter?
output: Okay, okay! All I know is that Idolaf made some effort to find out what happened to him, but was told to stop asking questions. He got some letter from the Legion and has left it alone since then. I'll prove it to you, all right? I'll get you the letter. Just... meet me at the statue of Talos, and don't tell anyone about this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Of course I'll join you.
output: I'll round up what men I can, and meet you outside Northwatch Keep. We'll get in and out as fast as possible. I'll see you there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Calm down. I'm not working for anyone.
output: No? So you don't know anything about my brother? Then what are you doing here?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want to know about Thorald Gray-Mane.
output: What makes you think I know anything? Everyone knows he's dead and gone!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't know your brother.
output: Thorald... Thorald Gray-Mane? Fighting for the Stormcloaks, disappeared and believed dead? You really don't know anything about this, do you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do you know this?
output: I used some contacts in the Legion, asked some questions. Was told I should mind my own business.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found your letter to Olfina.
output: You what? Oh no. No, no, no. This can't be happening. Please, you can't tell anyone. It must remain a secret! I'll do whatever you want.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this place?
output: That's privileged information. Now move along.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: If Thorald is alive, where is he?
output: Last I'd heard, he'd been carted off to Northwatch Keep. Ever heard of it? If you go in there, you don't come out. Ever. Here, see for yourself. This is the last word I received. I'm telling you, he's gone for good.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't know what you're talking about.
output: A likely story. They won't even do their own dirty work now, eh? Well, you won't get the better of me! Now tell me where my brother is!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I didn't mean to alarm you. Why are you so tense?
output: Because they've got Thorald locked away somewhere, and if they find me here I'll disappear too! I am not going to let that happen!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds like you need some help.
output: I can't do this all on my own. Are you... are you offering to help me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Thorald Gray-Mane?
output: What's there to say? You go against the Empire, you wind up dead. Thorald got what was coming to him. Best not to ask too many questions about it. People might get the wrong idea about you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Thorald Gray-Mane?
output: Between the two of us, his family is better off thinking he's dead. Thorald and I have history, all right? We used to be friends. So I looked into it when he disappeared. I found out the Thalmor have him. And they don't let anyone go. So I've kept my mouth shut. Like I said, his family is better off believing he's gone, because he's never coming back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Thorald Gray-Mane?
output: He fought on the wrong side, and he paid for it. That's all I have to say.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Thorald Gray-Mane?
output: Oh come on, leave it alone. He's gone. There's no use in talking about it anymore. I wish everyone could just get past that and get on with their lives.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Thorald Gray-Mane?
output: It's been a while now. I miss him, but it's clear he's not coming back. He knew what he was getting into. I don't... I don't blame anyone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Some Necromancers were attempting to summon and bind Potema.
output: Potema herself? Please tell me you stopped them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Falk sent me to talk to you about Potema.
output: Ah Potema. Former queen of Solitude and one of the most dangerous necromancers in recorded history. She was responsible for the Empire's near collapse almost five hundred years ago. I believe I have a book about her...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do I need to know about Potema?
output: Any resident of Solitude can tell you, she was the deadliest person ever to come out of Skyrim. Queen of Solitude, granddaughter of Emperor Uriel Septim II, five hundred years ago. Her fight for succession nearly tore the empire apart. After twenty years of fighting, she had raised armies of the dead, led by vampire generals. If she returns to power, nobody could stop her.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do I need to know about Potema?
output: A curious figure. Unrepentantly evil and nasty, of course, but also astonishingly brilliant, and obviously quite a necromancer at her end. She was always so close to being Empress, but despite her machinations, it was never to be hers. Ironically, if she were alive today, she'd be the only living member of the Septim bloodline. By all rights, she would now be Empress.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've taken care of Potema.
output: Without you this would have been a disaster. I should have paid more heed to Varnius' warnings.  I won't make that mistake again. You've done a great thing, today. It doesn't matter who you support in the war; Potema would have been a blight on the land for both sides.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there any College business I can assist with?
output: I need some more supplies. Can you help out with that?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe some other time.
output: Some other time? That's not going to help me much, now is it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there any College business I can assist with?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What sorts of things?
output: I know that he still worships Talos. That he hates the Thalmor almost as much as the Stormcloaks do. That he worries about being chased from Whiterun. That he... that I'm...  that I don't have the same mother as my brother and sister.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there someone behind the door?
output: But I forgive you for not knowing who I am. Few hear my whispers anymore. I am Mephala, the Lady of Whispers. I tug at the web of connections between mortals. Love, hatred, loyalty, betrayal. The boy was good at sussing out secrets. You, I expect to take a more active role. Regrettably, I cannot reach your plane so directly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do you know these things?
output: This castle is old. Lots of places nobody's been in a long while. Places where you can overhear things. See things. And the Whispering Lady.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's the Whispering Lady?
output: She won't tell me her name. I've gotten good at listening to keyholes. At the door in the basement, I hear her talking to me. I thought I was caught, but she started telling me even more secrets.  But I can't open the door.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where is this door?
output: In the basement. Trust me, you'll see it. I bet she'll talk to you, too.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want me to do?
output: First, you must open this door. A piece of my power has been locked away behind it, and even my eyes cannot see past the seals. I'd much rather it be in the hands of an ambitious and talented person such as yourself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Laelette?
output: Now there's a mystery. She ran away when the war started. Her husband, Thonnir, was devastated. No note or nothin'. I'm pretty sure she up and joined the Stormcloaks.

output: I get the message. Here, take your gold. I hope you choke on it! Not Lady Dibella? No, please! I can't lose her!

output: How I envy you. I can only imagine the excitement of seeing history through the eyes of another! Sadly, I am resigned to just reading of its wonders through my research of the Skull.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: I thought I was clear regarding the dangers that awaited you within the Dreamstride. However, this hardly matters any longer as you appear to have exited unscathed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Haldyn?
output: We used to think the pirates had an army of battlemages at their side. As it turns out, it was just one. Haldyn. I've since learned more about him. The most dangerous sort of man -- quick to anger, but patient in exacting vengeance. He also has a fearsome control of Destruction magic.  I wish you the best of luck.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Shatter-Shields?
output: A very powerful family in Windhelm. Wouldn't surprise me if they were in league with the pirates, somehow. They run a private shipping operation, and would love to have the docks to themselves.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any proof of that?
output: Not yet, no. But perhaps an intrepid person such as yourself could help with that. They have a dark elf who oversees their operations. Suvaris Atheron.  She's meticulous to a fault, and keeps a logbook with every transaction she makes. If it were to somehow end up in my hands, I wouldn't argue.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's it mean to be Dragonborn?
output: I don't know much. Only the old tales about the ancient heroes who would use the Voice to defeat the enemies of Skyrim. They say the Emperors used to be Dragonborn, but that all ended when Martin died during the Oblivion Crisis. The Greybeards can tell you much more than I can. They're the masters of the Way of the Voice and taught Tiber Septim himself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's it mean to be Dragonborn?
output: The only thing I remember is the old story of Tiber Septim being called Dragonborn by the Nords, before they switched sides and joined the Empire. No doubt those Greybeards up at High Hrothgar will talk your ear off about it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Greybeards?
output: They live in seclusion on the slopes of the Throat of the World, the great mountain of Skyrim. They're masters of the Way of the Voice. If you really are Dragonborn, they're the ones who can teach you how to use your power.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Greybeards?
output: Near as I can tell, a bunch of ancient Nord hermits who live on top of a mountain. Never heard of them talking to anybody before. If they really do want to talk to you, you'd better go find out what they want. You never know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Shouts?
output: But only the Greybeards study the Way of the Voice any more. If you can Shout... you need to talk to them. In the old tales, Nord heroes would use the power of their Voice to Shout down the gates of cities and strike down their enemies.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Shouts?
output: Old Nord folk tales always talk about Shouting their enemies to pieces. I always thought it was just a myth. If you think you might be able to do that kind of thing, the Legion could certainly use your help. Go talk to the Greybeards, see what they can tell you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: Azura has given me the gift of foresight. I had a vision of you walking up the steps to this altar long before you were born. You have been chosen to be her champion. I know it is unexpected, but do not worry. It will all unfold as she has predicted.

output: Yes, from what I've heard I expect Tolfdir will be occupied for some time. Hmm, that is a problem, isn't it? I suppose someone else will need to look after the Apprentices for now.

output: Well, perhaps it's time for some independent study. Check with Urag gro-Shub in the Arcanaeum. See if he's aware of any references to this... thing that you and Tolfdir found. I'd like to know as much as we can about it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
