instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have returned with Shagrol's Hammer.
output: But... What of Yamarz? I see. He did not survive. He... He died well?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: AstridConfrontListenerResponse1
output: Then what in Sithis' name is going on? Cicero spoke to the Night Mother, but she spoke to you? Is this just more of the fool's rambling?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've heard you dabble in necromancy.
output: I beg your pardon?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who is this Orthorn?
output: He was an Apprentice here at the College. Not very skilled, but got involved with a group of mages who took a liking to him. When they left, he took off after them. Stole supplies and books from the College, I suppose as a way to ingratiate himself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to learn about something we found in Saarthal.
output: I know what you want. Word travels fast around here. Discovered some big mystery, huh? Well you don't even need to ask. No, I don't have anything for you. Not anymore, anyway.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why are these mages in Fellglow Keep?
output: Let's just call it a "difference of opinion" with the College. They were interested in research that goes outside the bounds of what the College allows, so they were... persuaded to leave.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You don't have anything that can help?
output: I said not anymore. Orthorn stole a number of books when he ran off to Fellglow Keep to join those Summoners. Some kind of peace offering. I think one of those volumes may have had some relevant information. If you want them, you'll have to talk to Orthorn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've been told to kill you.
output: And I would deserve it, wouldn't I? I can't stop you if that's what you want to do. Hircine is too powerful. But if you spare me, I can be a powerful ally to you. And I would promise to never return to civilized life. I know now that I can't live among people.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The last of the hunters is dead.
output: Thank you for your help. I will make my home here, away from anyone I might hurt.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I hear you attacked a little girl.
output: Believe me, it wasn't anything I ever intended to do. I just... lost control.  It's all on account of this blasted ring. I tried to tell them, but none of them believe me. A little girl is dead because of me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I will spare your life.
output: Thank the gods. Now let's deal with these other hunters. We hunt together!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm here to deliver a message.
output: Ooh, ooh, what kind of message? A song? A summons? Wait, I know! A death threat written on the back of an Argonian concubine! Those are my favorite. Well? Spit it out, mortal. I haven't got an eternity! Reeaaaallllyyyy? Actually... I do. Little joke. But seriously. What's the message?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can I find your master?
output: Last I saw him, he was visiting a friend in the Blue Palace. But no one as mundane as the Jarl. No, no... such people are below him. No, he went into the forbidden wing of the palace, to speak with an old friend. Said it had been ages since they had last had tea. Oh and you'll need the hip bone... it's very important. No entering Pelagius' Wing without that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who is your master?
output: He is a great man, but one rarely praised! He rules twin empires that span the length and breadth of our minds! All know him, but few can name him! But... he has forbidden me from saying his name. He says it distracts him, and woe to those who draw his ire. But you will know him when you see him. He's the one who made me like this!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Falk asked me to check it out.
output: I'll make an exception for you, but do not bring anything out when you leave. Too many dark deeds transpired in those halls...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Falk asked me to check it out.
output: If you really want to... Just be careful of the ghost! He snuck up on me once and scared me sick. It took a week for me to feel better...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Falk asked me to check it out.
output: Well... I suppose in that case, it's okay to let you in. But only briefly. Be careful, and come right back!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you need?
output: My master has abandoned me! Abandoned his people. And nothing I say can change his mind. Now he refuses to even see me. He says I interrupt his vacation! It's been so many years... Won't you please help?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to get into the Pelagius Wing.
output: Absolutely not. That wing has been sealed for hundreds of years, and for good reason. They say the ghost of Pelagius the Mad still haunts it. Ghost or not, there are reminders of his dark rule that are best left buried away.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to get into the Pelagius Wing.
output: Not on your life. It's dangerous in there, and Falk doesn't even like me and Erdi going in every year to clean out the spiders.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to get into the Pelagius Wing.
output: Oh, I'd get in trouble for that. It's not allowed. Besides, it's scary in there!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here are the books that went missing.
output: Well, well. And you seem to be in one piece! Thank you. I'll look these over, and inform Mirabelle if I find anything relevant.  "Night of Tears", eh? I remember this one. Well, isn't that interesting. Did you read it yourself? If I recall it correctly, that has some interesting implications. You should mention that to Tolfdir. And... here. I suppose you've earned these.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where do I begin?
output: Head to the Bannered Mare in Whiterun and look for Mallus Maccius. He'll fill you in on all the details.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You've got a deal.
output: Don't come back until every one of those things are dead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How about we skip the conversation?
output: You're a firebrand, aren't you? It's about time Brynjolf sent me someone with business sense. I was beginning to think he was running some sort of beggar's guild over there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there anything we can do?
output: Mercer thinks he knows a way to identify this new thorn in our side. He wants to meet with you right away. And if I were you I'd hurry. I've never seen him this angry before.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maven said you're expecting me.
output: I'm going to keep this short 'cause we've got a lot to do. Honningbrew's owner, Sabjorn, is about to hold a tasting for Whiterun's Captain of the Guard and we're going to poison the mead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Brynjolf said you wanted to see me.
output: So you're the one that burned down Goldenglow Estate. Do you have any idea what that little stunt you pulled is going to cost me? I'm amazed you even bothered to show your face here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: All I know is that your people need you to return.
output: Oh, pardon me. Were you saying something? I do apologize, it's just that I find myself suddenly and irrevocably... I mean, really. Here you stand, before Sheogorath himself, Daedric Prince of Madness, and all you deem fit to do is... deliver a message? How sad. Yaaawwwwnn.... Bored!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was asked to retrieve you from your vacation.
output: Ha! No matter! Honestly, I don't want to know. Why ruin the surprise? But more to the point. Do you - tiny, puny, expendable little mortal - actually think you can convince me to leave?   Were you now? By whom? Wait! Don't tell me! I want to guess! Was it Molag? No, no... Little Tim, the toymaker's son? The ghost of King Lysandus? Or was it... Yes! Stanley, that talking grapefruit from Passwall. Wrong on all accounts, aren't I? Because that's... crazy. You do realize who you're dealing with here?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why don't you leave your master?
output: Oh, you just don't understand. Without him, I am not free! Without him, I am doomed! All of his empire shall fall into chaos...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're a madman.
output: But only half right. I'm a mad god. The Mad God, actually. It's a family title. Gets passed down from me to myself every few thousand years. Now you. You can call me Ann Marie. Jolly good guess! But only if you're partial to being flayed alive and having an angry immortal skip rope with your entrails. If not... Then call me Sheogorath, Daedric Prince of Madness. Charmed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think I made a mistake coming here...
output: Oh, no no no! No mistake at all. What you made was a choice. Granted, not a very wise choice, but these things happen. Ah, the folly of youth... You know, you remind me of myself at a young age. All I cared about was riding narwhales and sleeping in honeycombs and drinking babies' tears... Ah, but there I go, waxing poetic about my misspent youth. Now where were we? Ah yes. You're the mortal messenger. An I am...?  Word of advice if you ride a Narwhale. Mind the pointy end. Honestly. Have you any idea?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm afraid I don't know, sir.
output: Wrong! Sheogorath, Daedric Prince of Madness. At your service. Actually, you do. Sort of. I am a part of you, little mortal. I am a shadow in your subconscious, a blemish on your fragile little psyche. You know me. You just don't know it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can I get to your master?
output: He stays in the Pelagius Wing of the Blue Palace. The doors are locked, and only Falk Firebeard can grant entry. But I hear the maids, Una and Erdi, know how to enter it for cleaning. Surely they can help for such an important matter?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So you need me to bring him back?
output: Yes, but don't try to use force! He's far too mighty. He'd crush you like a clay doll, or drop you from the sky, or simply eat your brain right up! Oh, but he probably won't do those things to you. Probably. Just remind him to come home, and... there'll be no fighting or unpleasantness. Probably. He's just a little confused at the moment, is all. Knowing my master, he may very well reward you for bringing him to his senses!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you need?
output: Without his guidance, our homeland is falling apart. North wages war against south! The holy flame flickers and dies! We need his return. Oh, but... I'm sure he'll repay you when he comes to his senses! His favor is a powerful, powerful thing. And so very worth any... inconveniences.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So does that mean you'll leave? Or not?
output: Now that's the real question, isn't it? Because honestly, how much time off could a demented Daedra really need? So here's what I'm going to do. I'm going to leave. That's right. I'm done. Holiday... complete. Time to return to the hum drum day-to-day. On one condition. You have to find the way out first. Good luck with that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Simple.
output: Is it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: WhiterunInnkeeperRumorsBranchTopic
output: The Companions? In Jorrvaskr? They're recruiting new members, from what I hear.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, and here's what was in the safe.
output: At least you remembered one of the things I asked. Let me see that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll take the ring to Hircine.
output: Oh my. You would do this for me? Here, take it. I don't want anything to do with this wretched thing anymore. Seek out the beast. He wanders these woods. Bring him down and... well, the Lord of the Hunt should smile on you. I wish you luck, but should leave here while I still have my skin.  Should our paths cross again, I will remember your kindness. Farewell.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What ring?
output: This is the Ring of Hircine. I was told it could let me control my transformations. Perhaps it used to. But I'll never know. Hircine didn't care for my taking it, and threw a curse on it. I put it on... and the changes just came to me. I could never guess when. It would be at the worst times. Like... with the little girl.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who died?
output: Our daughter. Our little girl. She hadn't seen her tenth winter.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What kind of transformations?
output: I'm sure you've heard of men who shift to beasts under the influence of the moons.  I am one of them. A werewolf. It's my secret, and my shame. That's why I wanted the ring... it was said to give men like me control. Now I may look like a man, but I still feel the animal inside of me, as strong as ever. I don't suppose there's a point in keeping the secret if I'm going to die in here anyway.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did this make you attack the girl?
output: I had just come into Falkreath. They needed some help working the mill, and I thought that would be something safe. Something I could do. But this pitiful, limited body wasn't meant for hunting. Slow. No claws. Weak, mashing teeth for chewing cud. I held in my rage as long as I could. But it boiled inside of me. She looked so fragile. Helpless prey. And then... I... I feel terrible about what happened. About what I did. It would probably be best for everyone if I just went away. When I saw the little girl, I was just... I could feel it coming on. I could taste the... I needed to hunt.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who did this?
output: Sinding. Came through as a laborer. Seemed like a decent man. He's stewing in the pit while we figure out what to do with him, if you've got the stomach to look at him. What could drive a man to do something like this?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did she die?
output: She was... he ripped her apart. Like a sabre cat tears a deer. We barely found enough of her to bury.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Okay, what's the catch?
output: Ha! I do love it when the mortals know they're being manipulated. Makes things infinitely more interesting.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think I'll make my own way from here.
output: If I make it back to Solitude, I'll put in a good word for you with General Tullius. If I make it back to Solitude, I'll put in a good word for you with General Tullius. The Legion could sure use someone like you. Good luck. The Legion could sure use someone like you. Good luck.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds good. Let's go.
output: Stick close. Damn rebels could be anywhere. Don't worry, though. General Tullius will have them on the run soon enough. Stick close. Damn rebels could be anywhere. Don't worry, though. General Tullius will have them on the run soon enough.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That dark elf called you a war hero.
output: I killed a lot of High Elves in the Great War, and I didn't die. I guess that makes me a war hero. The "Great War"... there was nothing great about it. Thousands died on both sides, and where did it get us?   Did we really save the Empire? Or did we just plant the seeds for Ulfric's uprising, and another war?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think all folk should be welcome here.
output: And you're right, at least as far as I'm concerned. Don't let Ulfric or some of these other short-sighted Nords bother you. Most of us are happy to welcome newcomers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes. Outsiders like me have no place here.
output: That's just what Ulfric wants you to think. If that's what you really believe, then you're a fool. Never had much patience for fools, myself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No. Skyrim's big enough for everyone.
output: Good. Too many Nords in this town have been listening to Ulfric's narrow-minded words. He's tough, loyal to his men and a good leader, but if you're not a Nord, Ulfric will never trust you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes. Anyone who's not a Nord is a trespasser.
output: Is that so? You ought to join the Stormcloaks, if you haven't already. Seems to me they're a bunch of narrow-minded bigots, just like you. Meantime, you best steer clear of me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ever think of moving to Morrowind?
output: Not a day goes by that I don't think about returning to the ancestral home of my people. Still, even with the rough treatment we've had at the hands of Ulfric and his lot, I've got ties here. It's probably more trouble to pack up and leave than it is to stay. Besides, Ambarys can't run the cornerclub on his own.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any bedlam jobs?
output: I always have bedlam jobs. Just remember to hit them fast and don't let them see you. Feel like going for it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any bedlam jobs?
output: Of course. Don't forget to keep out of sight, it doesn't count if they catch you red-handed. You ready?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any bedlam jobs?
output: Taking an easy job, eh? Well, go and do some damage. Just stick to the shadows and keep out of sight. Want to go for it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the Gray Quarter?
output: Windhelm is divided into four quarters. The Gray Quarter is the one that's home to all the city's Dark Elves. If it looks to you like an impoverished slum, that's because it is. Ulfric prefers that we live in squalor. He has nothing but disdain for anyone who isn't a Nord. He tolerates us, but that's the extent of his hospitality.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why help the dark elves?
output: Help the Dark Elves? Oh, you must have heard me talking to Malthyr. The Dark Elves live in a run-down slum called the Gray Quarter. Ulfric's content to keep it that way.  I guess they think I can open Ulfric's eyes to their plight, and get him to lift a finger on their behalf. I'm trying, but Ulfric is set in his ways. For him, there's two kinds of people in this world -- Nords, and the folk beneath them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the situation?
output: We are ready to mount our final attack. We are ready to mount our final attack. We are ready to mount our final attack. We are ready to mount our final attack. We are ready to mount our final attack. We are ready to mount our final attack. We are ready to mount our final attack.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd rather die than go to prison!
output: Skyrim has no use for your kind. Skyrim has no use for your kind. Skyrim has no use for your kind. Skyrim has no use for your kind.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd rather die than go to prison!
output: So be it. So be it. So be it. So be it. So be it. So be it. So be it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready.
output: Very well. Empty the vessels into the sconce near the throne, then sit in the throne. When you have done so, I will unbind Hevnoraak. He will awaken in a weakened state, but the lich is still to be reckoned with. Be ready.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What was I doing again?
output: Find the three vessels within Valthume, then return to me. With these we can defeat him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What am I going to do with these?
output: In life, Hevnoraak drained his own blood from his body. His goal was to transfer his power back into himself after death, becoming a powerful lich. The vessels contain that very blood. Empty them and you remove any chance he has of regaining his former powers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: This seems dangerous.
output: More dangerous than you know. Left alone, however, he will awaken when he has grown too powerful to be stopped. This is the only way to be sure.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You sent me a message about Wolf Skull Cave?
output: Yes, old friend, I'm afraid it's not good news. When you broke up the binding Potema escaped. We've encountered some of her minions. Styrr says she's still in spirit form or we'd all be dead already. You've already done us a service in stopping the binding, but I need you to go talk to him, to see if Styrr can tell us what to do next.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've brought the Phial, but it's damaged.
output: This... it matches every description of the Phial that I've found in lore. But if it can't hold liquid, there's no way of knowing. How did you manage to damage it, then? This is what I get for not retrieving it myself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have the materials you requested.
output: Thank the gods. I'll get to work on the Phial straight away.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was happy to help.
output: Even though the Phial was damaged, I still think your efforts deserve reward. Now, if you'll pardon me, I'm going to tend to Nurelion. I can make his final days a bit less painful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Think he'll give me trouble?
output: Trouble? He's one of the most stubborn lizards I've ever met! You have your work cut out for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You can drop the act now... Gajul-Lei.
output: Oh, wait... did you say Goldenglow Estate? My apologies. I'm sorry to say I know very little about that... bee farm, was it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How is Gulum-Ei an asset to the Guild?
output: Gulum-Ei works in the East Empire Company Warehouse. He helps maintain all of the shipments of goods that goes in and out of Solitude. That means he has the pick of the litter from some of the finest goods to grace Skyrim's shores. He isn't exactly in the Guild, but he pays us a cut of all the stuff he lifts from the warehouse.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where do I begin?
output: Gulum-Ei is our inside man at the East Empire Company in Solitude. I'm betting he acted as a go-between for the sale of Goldenglow Estate and that he can finger our buyer. Get out there, shake him down and see what you come up with. Talk to Brynjolf before you leave if you have any questions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You think Gulum-Ei will give me trouble?
output: There are thieves and then there is Gulum-Ei. No honor, no code at all. He'd shake your hand and stab you in the back at the same time. The cut he's supposed to provide the Guild has dwindled as of late. He says pickings in the warehouse are slim, but I'm certain he's lying. Keep your eyes on him, he's quite crafty.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: If he's betrayed us, I'll kill him.
output: No, no. Mercer wants him alive, for now. Just keep on his tail and he's bound to step into something he can't scrape off his boot. Stubborn or not, he's the only contact we've got at the East Empire Company.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: East Empire Company? Who are they?
output: A mercantile group that has established ports all over Tamriel. They pretty much dominate the whole shipping industry. The Emperor himself supposedly backs them, which means they have fairly unlimited resources... so don't get their feathers in a ruffle.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was told you wanted to see me right away.
output: Ah, there you are. I've consulted my contacts regarding the information you recovered from Goldenglow Estate, but no one can identify that symbol.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You acted as a broker for its new owner.
output: Maybe I did, maybe I didn't. I can't be expected to remember every deal I handle.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: If I get information from Gulum-Ei, what then?
output: Just head right back to the Guild and get the information to Mercer. Nothing else is more important. If you discover Gulum-Ei's holding out on us and has more loot stashed away than he claims, we'd find that information quite valuable as well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to know more about Azura.
output: She is the Goddess of Dawn and Dusk. Azura sees into the Twilight of the future, and guides her followers through it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You saw her?
output: No, I found her horse. Don't worry, I've taken care of it... she won't be using it to escape. Let's get moving, I want to catch her inside while she's distracted. Take the lead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You want me to lead?
output: I'm sorry, I was under the impression I was in charge. You're leading and I'm following. Does that seem clear to you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And Gallus?
output: The last thing I saw was Karliah dumping his body into a opening atop the ruins; an unceremonious end for a remarkable man. To this day I've regretted allowing her to escape, even if it meant I had died trying. I owed Gallus that much.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Karliah.
output: Gallus trusted her too much and let her get too close. She was a stubborn Dunmer... always had to do everything her way. But she was also the best... bringing in more coin a month than some thieves heist in a year.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So Karliah took on both of you alone?
output: Karliah was a master marksman and her greatest weapon was the element of surprise. I was lucky... she missed my heart by mere inches. I staggered away from the ruins and my vision began to blur. It's then that I realized the bitch had poisoned her arrows.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So, they had a relationship.
output: If you want to call it that, yes. Me? I think she was softening him for the kill. Gallus would call her his "little nightingale." He was absolutely smitten by her.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Understood.
output: Just make certain you keep your eyes open. Karliah is as sharp as a blade. The last thing I need is you blundering into a trap and warning her that we're here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did Gallus die?
output: Twenty-five years ago I was standing outside these very same ruins. Gallus told me to meet here but he wouldn't say why. When I arrived, Gallus stepped from the shadows. Before he uttered a sound an arrow pierced his throat. Before I could even draw my blade, her second arrow found its mark in my chest.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did she kill him?
output: Greed? Jealousy? Spite? Who can say what drove her to such an iniquitous act. One thing's certain. I intend to find out before she draws her last breath.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any supplies I could take?
output: Of course. Take what you need. But what's all this about? What are you two doing here?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the problem?
output: You assaulted one of my family members. I've come to accept your apology.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't care.
output: Come again?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't care.
output: I am prepared to deal with your insolence...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't care.
output: Fine. Then it will be an honor to kill you for your offenses against my kin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry.
output: I trust this is the last I'll hear of your violent outbursts.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened to Nurelion?
output: He is gone. But thanks to you, he died knowing his life's work was not in vain.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm sorry to hear that.
output: As am I.  You acted very nobly in helping my master realize his life's work. Thank you for that. As for myself, I've always been content to simply be an alchemist.  I fear keeping the Phial would just remind me of Nurelion's obsession, and how it consumed him. Here, keep it. You are as much a part of its legend now as Curalmil was. I hope it brings you the happiness that my master desired.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm sorry.
output: See that it doesn't happen again. See that it doesn't happen again. See that it doesn't happen again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Fine. Take it. (Pay 50 gold)
output: See, that wasn't so difficult, was it. See, that wasn't so difficult, was it. See, that wasn't so difficult, was it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You have.... But I don't care.
output: No? Do you care about rotting away for a month in a cell? No? Do you care about rotting away for a month in a cell? No? Do you care about rotting away for a month in a cell? Ah, but nobody wants that, right? Painful for you, annoying for me. So, you pay my fine... and you walk away. Ah, but nobody wants that, right? Painful for you, annoying for me. So, you pay my fine... and you walk away. Ah, but nobody wants that, right? Painful for you, annoying for me. So, you pay my fine... and you walk away.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not paying you a bribe.
output: Is that so? Well then, I'll have to charge you with disturbing the Jarl's peace. Is that so? Well then, I'll have to charge you with disturbing the Jarl's peace. Is that so? Well then, I'll have to charge you with disturbing the Jarl's peace.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want me to say to this monk?
output: Find out why he's here, and what he wants.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't understand what's going on.
output: Really? Well, allow me to clarify the situation. I'd like to know why there's someone claiming to be from the Psijic Order here in the College. More importantly, I'd like to know why he's asking for you specifically. So we're going to go have a little chat with him, and find out exactly what it is he wants.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want with me?
output: I need you to come with me immediately. Let's go.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's going on? What happened to everyone?
output: I'd simply like to talk to you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So you're the Augur of Dunlain?
output: I am that which you have been seeking. Your efforts are in vain. It has already begun. But those who have sent you have not told you what they seek. What you seek.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is it you want me to do?
output: Now, you are going to speak to this... Monk... and find out why he is here, and then he will be removed from College grounds.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you ever heard of the Augur of Dunlain?
output: The Augur? Really? Well, it's certainly not my place to say anything about it. I think you'd better go see Mirabelle Ervine.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you ever heard of the Augur of Dunlain?
output: The what? No. No, I'm quite sure I have no idea what you're talking about. I suggest you mind your own business and return to whatever it is you do here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you ever heard of the Augur of Dunlain?
output: Well now, there's a name I haven't heard in some time. My goodness, it's been years since I've spoken with him. I suppose he's still down in the Midden, but I haven't checked. Are you going to see him? Do tell him "hello" for me, won't you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where is Karliah now?
output: I don't know. When I asked her where she was going she just muttered "Where the end began." Here, take the Goldenglow Estate Deed as proof. And when you speak to Mercer, tell him I'm worth more to him alive.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm keeping the deed. Any objections?
output: Karliah didn't even want it, she wanted to keep the sale a secret. I can see how well that went. Consider it a gift to ensure your silence. That thing seems to be bringing me nothing but trouble anyway.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He said Goldenglow was purchased by a "Karliah."
output: This is grave news indeed, she's someone I hoped to never cross paths with again. No, it.. it can't be. I haven't heard that name in decades.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why has she returned?
output: Karliah and I were like partners. I went with her on every heist. We watched each other's backs. If only we knew where she was... I know her techniques, her skills. If she kills me, there'll be no one left that could possibly catch her.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me first, and then I'll decide.
output: All right, all right. It's Karliah... her name is Karliah.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We?
output: Yes, I'm going with you and together we're going to kill her. Prepare yourself and meet me at the ruins as soon as you can. We can't let her slip through our fingers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And you're helping her?
output: Help... ? No, no! Look I didn't even know it was her until after she contacted me. Please, you have to believe me!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Mercer doesn't have to know.
output: I see you wish to be reasonable, perhaps I misjudged you. The name of the person you want is Karliah.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You say that name like I should know it.
output: Mercer never told you about her? Karliah is the thief responsible for murdering the previous Guild Master, Gallus. Now she's after Mercer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Isn't murder Dark Brotherhood territory?
output: I have a long-standing arrangement with the Dark Brotherhood. If I need someone in the Guild taken care of, we do it ourselves. We both agree it's best to keep these matters in house.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Gulum-Ei also told me she was a murderer.
output: After we discovered what she'd done, we spent months trying to track her down, but she just vanished. Karliah destroyed everything this Guild stood for. She murdered my predecessor in cold blood and betrayed the Guild.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Gulum-Ei told me she said,  "Where the end began."
output: There's only one place that could be. The place where she murdered Gallus... a ruin called Snow Veil Sanctum. We have to go out there before she disappears again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are the Nightingales?
output: They were a secret cabal of the three top rogues in the Thieves Guild. No one knew their identities. Some people say they watched over the group, others say they were reserved for the most elite jobs. I don't really know. It wasn't until recently that I heard Mercer Frey and this Dark Elf named Karliah were a part of that group.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're going to be the Sybil of Dibella.
output: I've heard stories about the wonders of the great Temple in Markarth.  But I never dreamed that I would even get to see it. I am honored to be called for this duty. Please, lead on.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: (bark)

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Follow me.
output: (bark)

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: MS12Hellos
output: I'm so close to the answer...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any supplies I could take?
output: Like I said, I'm glad to help in any way I can. Help yourself to whatever you need, within reason.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready to take the oath.
output: In joining the Legion, you'll be taking an oath binding you to the service of the Emperor and thus to every citizen of the Empire. Are you prepared to make that commitment?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do I get to Whiterun from here?
output: Just head north - you can't miss it. Just head north - you can't miss it. It's the capital of Whiterun Hold, the biggest and the best of the nine holds of Skyrim. But don't take my word for it. It's the capital of Whiterun Hold, the biggest and the best of the nine holds of Skyrim. But don't take my word for it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do I get to Whiterun from here?
output: Cross the river and then head north. You'll see it, just past the falls. When you get to Whiterun just keep going up. When you get to the top of the hill, you're at Dragonsreach, the Jarl's palace.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DB05PlayerWeddingResponse
output: Well, more like the public reception. It should be a lovely affair. You'll mingle with the guests, eat some cake... stab the bride. Oh yes. You've got to kill the bride. At her wedding. And they say romance is dead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why isn't the Emperor attending the wedding?
output: Hmph. He had a trip to Skyrim planned for months, and canceled at the last minute. Much to his cousin's dismay. Seems the Emperor realized his presence would necessitate a more direct role in the ongoing hostilities. A role he was, obviously, unwilling to take. All that will change with his cousin's murder. Everyone will think it was motivated by the conflict between the Imperial Legion and Stormcloaks. And the Emperor will be forced to come clean up the mess.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is the White Phial?
output: A legendary bottle, forged in the days when Skyrim was just starting its turn to ice. A small container, made of the magically infused snow that first fell on the Throat of the World. It is said that the Phial will replenish whatever fluid is placed inside of it. For an alchemist like myself, it is the most pure expression of my art. To create from nothingness is... poetry.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why is the Phial so important to you?
output: I have spent my entire life searching for it.  It brought me all the way to these frozen reaches from the warm embrace of Summerset Isle. Entire years spent in libraries. Seeking out tiny villages with local legends that contain but a whisper of a hint of the Phial. I even named my shop after it, hoping that it might attract anyone who had heard of it. And now it's within my grasp... but the Eight, it seems, have chosen me for their amusement. ... for in my current condition, I'll never be able to lay my hands on it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: If you tell me where it is, I can get it for you.
output: You would do that? It's good to know there are some people out there who are willing to help an old man. It's buried with its maker, Curalmil, in a long forsaken cave to the west of here. Please... don't dally. I've wasted enough time arguing with my useless assistant here. Curalmil was a crafty one, even in death. You would need the skills of a master alchemist to reach his resting place. Luckily for you, I've already made the mixture. Here, take it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: MS12Hellos
output: May the Eight guide you to the Phial...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: MS12Hellos
output: Please hurry -- I fear my master doesn't have much time left.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Actually, she's a vampire. She planned to enslave the town.
output: I assume you have proof? Can't go making accusations like that without proof.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Alva set the fire. She's the murderer.
output: Alva? Didn't think she had it in her.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have Alva's journal.
output: So it's true. That traitorous bitch! Morthal owes you a debt. Morthal is still in danger. The journal mentions Movarth, a master vampire I thought was destroyed a century ago. I'll gather together some able-bodied warriors to clean out Movarth's lair. They'll be waiting outside for you to lead them. Here. You were promised a reward for solving the crime, but I need one more favor from you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did she need to die?
output: We were supposed to find a sacrifice. Human sacrifice. I told her I couldn't do it and she attacked. I've done horrible things living here, but never taken an innocent life. I couldn't just find some person for them to kill.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you need a sacrifice?
output: The Initiation. My mother is going to become one of those things. I can't be a part of that. Gods, I can't run away from this. I have to stop her.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did I say anything about where I left a staff?
output: You mentioned something like that... when you were running off with my goat! Tell you what - you bring back my goat, and maybe I'll give a damn about your staff.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Now, what did I say about that staff?
output: You said a whole lot of nonsense about selling Gleda to hire a priestess for some big event. There was a bit of talk about some staff you had in safe keeping. Never said where, but you sure didn't have it with you!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready for some extra work.
output: I handle the fishin', numbers and bedlam jobs... the ones with the more personal touch. If break-ins are more your thing, go talk to Vex.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready for some extra work.
output: Let me make this plain and simple. No more jobs until you pay Vex. No get to it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready for some extra work.
output: You're not getting anything until you pay the Guild back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready for some extra work.
output: I handle the burglary, shill, sweep and heist jobs. Most of them involve breaking and entering. If you don't like that kind of work, talk to Delvin. He runs the more up-close and personal jobs.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready for some extra work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any heist jobs?
output: The owner of this place just inherited an heirloom from a relative. You want in?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any heist jobs?
output: Sure. A client's relative lost this item in a gambling match and they're paying us to get it back. So much for fair play, huh?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any heist jobs?
output: The owner of this shop stiffed us on their last protection payment, but we're taking it anyway. You want to help us on this one?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any heist jobs?
output: 'Jiit caravan brought this shop a nice piece from Elsweyr. Think you can break into their strongbox and get it for us?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any heist jobs?
output: Got a client in desperate need for this item. He won't say what it's for, and we don't care. Can you take this one?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who is Hircine?
output: Do you not know the Daedric Lord of the Hunt?  He revels in the chase, and also gave the "gift" of lycanthropy to mortals. A powerful force, not to be crossed. As I learned too late.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I am answering your summons.
output: Shout for us, Dragonborn. Then we may have time for questions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You want to help me kill the vampire?
output: I want vengeance for my wife! Vengeance for Laelette! We're marching on Movarth's Lair whether you come with us or not.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm answering your summons.
output: We will see if you truly have the gift. Show us, Dragonborn. Let us taste of your Voice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You call me Dragonborn. What does that mean?
output: First, let us see if you truly are Dragonborn. Let us taste of your Voice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: That's right. College of Winterhold, just north of town. Hard to miss.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready for more training.
output: Your quick mastery of a new Thu'um is... astonishing. I'd heard the stories of the abilities of Dragonborn, but to see it for myself...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I thought it was this easy for everyone.
output: No. Indeed not. But beware that your skill does not outstrip your wisdom.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does it mean to be "Dragonborn"?
output: What you have already learned in a few days took even the most gifted of us years to achieve. Dragons have the inborn ability to learn and project their Voice. Dragons also are able to absorb the power of their slain brethren. A few mortals are born with similar abilities -- whether a gift or a curse has been a matter of debate down through the centuries. Some believe that Dragonborn are sent into the world by the gods, at times of great need. We will speak more of that later, when you are ready.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Alduin's Wall.
output: Alduin's Wall was created by the ancient Akaviri Dragonguard, the forerunners of the Blades. One of the lost secrets of the Blades. Where they recorded all they knew of Alduin and his return. Part history, part prophecy. Its location was lost for centuries, but I know where it is: Sky Haven Temple, an ancient Blades sanctuary, hidden within the crags of the Reach.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We need to talk.
output: You... Dragonborn? Is it really true?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We need to talk.
output: So Delphine keeps up the fight, after all these years. I thought she'd have realized it's hopeless by now. I tried to tell her, years ago...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Thalmor have found you. We have to get out of here.
output: Yes, yes, so you said. But so what? The end is upon us. I may as well die here as anywhere else. I'm tired of running.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're talking about the literal end of the world?
output: Oh, yes. It's all been foretold. The end has begun. Alduin has returned. Only a Dragonborn can stop him. But no Dragonborn has been known for centuries. It seems that the gods have grown tired of us. They've left us to our fate, as the plaything of Alduin the World-Eater.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We need to talk.
output: I know, I know. I'm hurrying.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want of me?
output: Your continuing aid to Septimus renders him increasingly obsolete. He has served me well, but his time is nearing its end. Once that infernal lockbox is opened, he will have exhausted his usefulness to me.  When that time comes, you shall take his place as my emissary. What say you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: I am Hermaeus Mora. I am the guardian of the unseen, and knower of the unknown. I have been watching you, mortal. Most impressive.

output: Aye, that's the work of Septimus Signus.  He's the world's master of the nature of Elder Scrolls, but... well. He's been gone for a long while. Too long.

input: What now?
output: Now you have my Oghma Infinium. It contains the knowledge of the ages as revealed to Xarses, my loyal servant. For hundreds of years it's been shut away from the world. Septimus was a useful tool for unleashing it. Now it is in your hands. Let us work wonders together...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: Be warned. Many have thought as you do. I have broken them all. You shall not evade me forever.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: There's a pack of werewolf hunters camped nearby, at Gallows Rock. The Silver Hand. I think you've met them before.  Lead on. Skjor's already scouting ahead.  We're going to slaughter them. All of them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How could that have happened?
output: He was one of the strongest we had, but numbers can overwhelm. He should not have come without a Shield-Brother. Get out of here. I'm going to make sure we got the last of them, and see if there's any information to be gotten from the bodies. You and I have work to do. The Silver Hand will tremble at our sight.

input: So what's the part you're not telling me?
output: Dragons aren't just coming back, they're coming back to life. They weren't gone somewhere for all these years. They were dead, killed off centuries ago by my predecessors. Now something's happening to bring them back to life. And I need you to help me stop it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Maven Black-Briar.
output: She's an absolute pleasure to work for! In fact, I almost feel guilty accepting pay from her. Why, just this last week I was commenting to my fellow meadery workers just how lucky we are to be working for such a charitable family.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Glad you're so happy.
output: Sure am! I thank my lucky stars every time I look to the night sky that Maven took me in and gave me this opportunity.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You mentioned Nivenor.
output: Nivenor is my wife. How I was ever able to meet such a gorgeous creature is one of life's mysteries. We're... at odds about my charity. She thinks the people in this town have become lazy and expecting a handout. I try to include her in my lessons from Maramal over at the Temple of Mara, but she prefers to shop instead. Different strokes, eh?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What makes Black-Briar Mead so special?
output: Lady Maven's been developing the secret recipe for Black-Briar Mead over the last several decades. She uses a very secret blend of spices, fresh honey from Goldenglow Estate and specially constructed aging casks to ensure the best flavor. Even when you get to the last sip in your flagon, it'll taste just as good as the first!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're involved with the meadery?
output: Yes, actually. I'm partnered with Maven Black-Briar. I put up a chunk of the gold she needed to get the place off the ground. We've been staggeringly successful so far. In fact, I'm almost surprised how quickly she's generated business for us. My name may not be on the label, but some of my blood, sweat and tears are in every drop. Uh, figuratively of course.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There are worse things than being fired.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can you tell me about the wedding ring?
output: Every Argonian wedding proposal band is supposed to have three flawless amethysts as part of their design. Two of the gems, the ones on the outside, represent the couple to be married... one for the husband, one for the wife. The amethyst in the center represents The Hist, the entity that all Argonians consider a sacred part of our lives.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You mentioned you served special drinks?
output: Three in fact. They're my own recipe. Brought them over here from my days as a bartender in Gideon. First is the "Velvet Lechance" which is a mixture of blackberry, honey, spiced wine and a touch of nightshade... perfectly safe, I assure you. Second, we have the "White-Gold Tower" which is heavy cream with a layer of blended mead, lavender and dragon's tongue on top. Last, and only for the bravest of souls, we have the "Cliff Racer" which is Firebrand Wine, Cyrodiilic Brandy, Flin and Sujamma.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you a fisherman?
output: Only the best in all of Riften! I own Riften Fishery. Started out with a single fishing pole and now I have an entire building and two boats to my name. Not bad for a middle-aged Nord, eh? Too bad I haven't had the same success helping this city shed its poverty. Nivenor thinks I'm wasting my time trying, but I disagree.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could find those for you.
output: I was hoping you'd offer. I didn't think it was my place to ask such a favor of you. I thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you at odds with them?
output: Don't mistake my political beliefs as a substitute for my family values. They're still my parents, and I love them dearly. I just think they've let my sister's death skew their outlook on Ulfric and what he really brings to the table with this war. I'm not so certain that Ulfric's intentions are as noble as they think. I think Ulfric cares about Ulfric and the rest is a smokescreen. I'd... appreciate if you kept my opinion between us. The last thing I want to do is have my parents "lose" another child.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened to your daughter?
output: I trained our daughter Lilija as a healer... to one day tend the Shrine of Talos and replace me as a Priestess of Talos. When the fighting began over the White-Gold Concordat, she ran off to join the Stormcloaks. She had her father's fire, how could I say no? She died out there, only having tended to the wounded soldiers for a few months. We never even found her body... the Empire burned all the dead.

input: You look thirsty.
output: My friend, you are very perceptive! I have a powerful thirst that cannot be slaked! And none of the waiters will bring me a drink. Elenwen must have told them to cut me off, the frigid bitch. Afraid I'll cause another scene, I suppose...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He has a house in Riften?
output: Aye. A gift from the Black-Briars after they kicked the previous family out... place called Riftweald Manor. He never stays there, just pays for the upkeep on it. Hired some lout by the name of Vald to guard the place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, that's it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: (Remain silent)

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DB05PlayerWhoIsTargetTopic1
output: Her name is Vittoria Vici. She oversees the East Empire Company's business holdings in Solitude. The wedding is being held in that city, at the Temple of the Divines. Her death will cause an uproar, which is exactly what we want.   Vici is likely to address her guests frequently, as is the wedding custom. Kill her when she does that, and I promise you a significant bonus. Now go. And give my best to the bride.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He wasn't there, but I found these plans.
output: Shor's beard! He's going after the Eyes of the Falmer? That was Gallus's pet project. If he gets his hands on them, you can be certain he'll be gone for good and set up for life.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then we have to stop him.
output: Agreed. He's taken everything the Guild has left, and to go after one of the last greatest heists is just an insult. I've spoken to Karliah, and made amends for how the Guild's treated her. Now she wishes to speak with both of us. Quickly, we have no time to lose.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's missing from the vault?
output: Better question would be "what did he leave." Mercer took everything. Even all of our plans are gone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why don't you like camping here?
output: Our fires are visible for miles. We're in a low valley. Sitting ducks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you doing?
output: I'm searching for my Fenrig. He was marching with Gjukar's men, who they say were wiped out here. I've turned over every body, though, and I can't find him. Please help me look. He has a bright red beard and hair.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I helped the young lovers in Ivarstead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The last battle here was hundreds of years ago.
output: Are you a fool? Look at the bodies around you. Even if you're blind, surely you smell the blood.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: West, in the plains over the mountain.
output: We're expected to fight there tomorrow. Gjukar elected to camp here for the night. I don't like it, though.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

If you happen to recollect anything about the incident, you be sure to report to the captain of the guard. Hmm... If you happen to recollect anything about the incident, you be sure to report to the captain of the guard. I've got my eye on you. I've got my eye on you. I've got my eye on you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Give me the Key, Mercer.
output: What's Karliah been filling your head with? Tales of thieves with honor? Oaths rife with falsehoods and broken promises? Nocturnal doesn't care about you, the Key or anything having to do with the Guild.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: If anyone falls, it will be you.
output: Then the die is cast, and once again my blade will taste Nightingale blood!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: TG08BMercerOutroBranchTopic
output: When Brynjolf brought you before me I could feel a sudden shift in the wind. And at that moment, I knew it would end with one of us at the end of a blade.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't believe you. Nocturnal guides me.
output: Then it appears the shadows shroud more than your presence... they blind your wisdom as well. Our actions have always been one in the same; both of us lie, cheat and steal to further our own end.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The difference is I still have honor.
output: It's clear you'll never see the Skeleton Key as I do... as an instrument of limitless wealth. Instead you've chosen to fall over your own foolish code.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's not about Nocturnal. This is personal.
output: Revenge is it? Have you learned nothing from your time with us? When will you open your eyes and realize how little my actions differ from yours?  Both of us lie, cheat and steal to further our own end.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why plant the ring on Brand-Shei?
output: There's someone that wants to see him put out of business permanently. That's all you need to know. Now, you tell me when you're ready and we'll get started.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not sure what happened.
output: Then perhaps you care to explain why you are standing so close a dead body with your weapon drawn? Then perhaps you care to explain why you are standing so close a dead body with your weapon drawn? Then perhaps you care to explain why you are standing so close a dead body with your weapon drawn?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Force of habit, I guess.
output: I see... and this "force of habit," does it also compel you to murder? I see... and this "force of habit," does it also compel you to murder? I see... and this "force of habit," does it also compel you to murder?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not sure what happened.
output: Hmmm... You can go, but you stay on your best behavior now. Hmmm... You can go, but you stay on your best behavior now. Hmmm... You can go, but you stay on your best behavior now. I've got my eye on you. I've got my eye on you. I've got my eye on you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It sounds like Malyn got what was coming to him.
output: The College would agree with you, but do you have any idea how many innocent lives were cut short, just so Azura could have revenge? We're nothing to the Daedra. Pawns to move around, praise, and punish as they see fit.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to think about it.

We shall safeguard it... for now. You have our gratitude, Arch-Mage. You now have the opportunity to maintain your College, and carry on with your lives.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: Sigh... I'm not proud of it. I'm terrified of that place and Aunt Agna knows it. My Da locked me in there in a drunken rage when he left us... three days in there eating the offerings left for our dead before Aunt Agna found me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does Mara require more of me?
output: I see you are eager to carry the light. This is the prayer heard by the goddess and relayed to her servants. As you venture, Mara fills my mind ever more with visions of love in peril. Embers lie nestled in stone, needing only fuel to bloom to a flame that will warm all around them. Go to Markarth. There you'll find Calcelmo, wise, acid, and reclusive. Help him to emerge and state his intentions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have anything for me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: TG08BKarliahOutroBranchTopic
output: I can't believe it's over. Twenty-five years in exile and just like that, it's done. All that remains is to ensure the safe return of the Skeleton Key.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds like it will be a simple task.
output: I'm afraid it's not that simple. When the Skeleton Key was stolen from the Twilight Sepulcher, our access to the inner sanctum was removed. The only way to bring it back will be through the Pilgrim's Path.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then we'd best get started.
output: Brynjolf is needed back at the Thieves Guild to keep order while you're away. And I... I can't bear to face Nocturnal after my failure to protect the Key. I'm afraid you'll have to face the end of your journey alone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I take it you never used the Pilgrim's Path.
output: It wasn't created for the Nightingales. It was created to test those who wished to serve Nocturnal in other ways. As a consequence, I have no knowledge of what you'll be facing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Fine. Let me see if I can cut you down.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to hear it all one more time.
output: Fine. Whatever you want. Can't you just kill me and get it over with? There's this old man. I've seen him around Riften. I don't know where he lives. I don't know his name. Yes, he matches the description of this Esbern guy you're looking for. Maybe it's him. Maybe it isn't. That's all I know, okay?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds good, I'll follow you.
output: Whatever you want. But let's go, now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You've been very cooperative. Thanks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You go ahead. I'm not done here.
output: No problem. Thanks for springing me. I owe you. Look me up in Riften if you make it out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You go ahead. I'm not done here.
output: I guess you know what you're doing. I've got to find a way out of here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Hold on. You may know something important.
output: I damn well hope so. If it helps you twist them up, I'm glad to help. They're after some old guy named Esbern. Something to do with dragons, I gathered it from listening to them talk when they thought I was out. I've seen a guy in Riften who they seem to think is him. Not much to go on -- I don't even know where he lives, or his name. But they seemed pretty excited about it. That's it. Now, let's get out of here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No time to explain. Let's get out of here. (Free him)
output: Yeah, sure, okay. Come on, this way. I've seen the guards use it to get rid of bodies. It must lead somewhere.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not here to torture you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to talk to you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It isn't safe. Wait here.
output: Please, let me know if it seems safe to leave.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Bashnag is dead.
output: He is? I'm not sure how to feel about that.  Perhaps it's for the better.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why aren't you part of the coven anymore?
output: I left for a few days in Riften. When I came back Bashnag accused me of trying to sell him out to the Thalmor. I was cursed and chased off.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The way out is clear. Good luck.
output: Thank you. When I find my daughter, it will be thanks to you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can you make it out of here?
output: Bashnag cursed me. I can't cast a spell to save my life right now. I'll have to wait until the way out is safe.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why are you down here?
output: Thanks for getting me out of that. Bashnag's coven chased me out and left me for dead down here. Nobody lasts too long with the spiders. Please, will you help me get out of here? If the coast is clear, I'll make a break for it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're a necromancer?
output: I am, and I don't want to hear your moral judgments about it, either. I wouldn't have had to study in secret in the old days.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why were you in Riften?
output: My daughter was sent to the orphanage there when I stood accused of illegal necromancy. I had no choice. Run or die. I joined with Bashnag then, but I thought of Savela every day. So I snuck off, hoping to find and steal away with her. Only, she was gone. Shipped away to another orphanage, or adopted, or... I didn't know what else to do, so I came back, hoping nobody noticed I left.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Coven? What do you mean?
output: Bashnag's circle of mages. We - well "they" live here. They made it pretty clear that I'm no longer welcome.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You caught me. I'll pay off my bounty. (<CrimeGold> gold)
output: Good enough. I'll just confiscate any stolen goods you're carrying, then you're free to go. Good enough. I'll just confiscate any stolen goods you're carrying, then you're free to go. Good enough. I'll just confiscate any stolen goods you're carrying, then you're free to go. Good enough. I'll just confiscate any stolen goods you're carrying, then you're free to go. Good enough. I'll just confiscate any stolen goods you're carrying, then you're free to go. Good enough. I'll just confiscate any stolen goods you're carrying, then you're free to go. Good enough.
