instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to talk to you.
output: Let me do the talking.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to talk to you.
output: Not now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to talk to you.
output: Shut up, will you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let Ulfric have his way now. He'll have to give ground later.
output: Hmm. I guess I'll defer to your judgment on this one, but I think it's a mistake.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ulfric has a point. The Thalmor have no business here.
output: Maybe so, but we shouldn't be making concessions before negotiations even start. Makes us look weak.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, you're right. Elenwen should stay.
output: I'm glad we see eye to eye on this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I agree. We can't let Ulfric push us around. Elenwen should stay.
output: Well said.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let me see if I can bring him back on my own. Without bloodshed.
output: What? You, alone, reasoning with the Thalmor? That's madness, friend. You're serious, aren't you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You stay hidden. I'll take care of this.
output: Are you sure? I doubt you stand a chance against the Thalmor. I can have a group of men ready at a moment's notice. Many would be willing to help rescue my brother.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm sure. I'll bring him back myself.
output: Very well. I'll give you a chance. But if you can't do it, I will.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're right. We should work together.
output: Exactly. Together we stand more of a chance of making this work. Make your way to Northwatch Keep in Haafingar. I'll meet you near there, and we'll plan our assault.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do we do now?
output: We kill every Thalmor between us and Thorald, and we bring him out alive. Let's go.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll find the proof you need.
output: Anything, anything at all would be a start. Then we can figure out how to get to him. I'm sorry for doubting you, friend. You have my thanks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not sure I want to get involved in this.
output: Please, I'm desperate. This is my brother's life! I won't let them take it away! I beg of you, look for proof of Thorald's capture. The Battle-Borns have it, I just know it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, absolutely. What can I do?
output: I know that Thorald's not dead. I just know it. The Imperials have him, and are keeping him somewhere. But I don't know where. Those damned Battle-Borns... they know something. They're hiding it. They practically taunt us with it. They must have some sort of proof! I don't dare leave the house myself. So I need your help. There's got to be something in that house of theirs. I just know it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not even sure what's going on.
output: My brother, Thorald. He was fighting for the Stormcloaks, and went missing. Everyone assumes he's dead. But he's not. I just know it. The Imperials captured him, and they're holding him someplace. The Battle-Borns know where. I'd go and search their house for proof, but they want me too. I'd be captured, and then we'll never know what happened to him. So I need someone to find that proof for me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have proof that Thorald lives.
output: I knew it! Let me see, please! So... Northwatch Keep. Then we know where to hit them. The Thalmor? By the Nine, it's worse than I thought.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What sort of proof do you need?
output: Anything that confirms that Thorald isn't dead, but is being held captive. I know those Battle-Borns have it. They'd be hiding it, of course. Wouldn't want it to get out that they've been lying this whole time. But you might be able to butter them up enough to lower their guard.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You should be safe now.
output: I cannot thank you enough for rescuing me from this place. I suspect I'd never again see the light of day otherwise. But why would you risk your life for me, a stranger?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We're here to rescue you.
output: I never thought I'd see another friendly face again. We need to get to safety as soon as possible. Let's move.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you and what do you want with me?
output: I'm one of the last members of the Blades. A very long time ago, the Blades were dragonslayers, and we served the Dragonborn, the greatest dragonslayer. For the last two hundred years, since the last Dragonborn emperor, the Blades have been searching for a purpose. Now that dragons are coming back, our purpose is clear again. We need to stop them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's our next move?
output: The first thing we need to do is figure out who's behind the dragons. The Thalmor are our best lead. If they aren't involved, they'll know who is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've seen that dragon before, the one that got away.
output: Really? Where?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So how do we get into the Thalmor Embassy?
output: I'm not sure yet. I have a few ideas, but I'll need some time to pull things together... Meet me back in Riverwood. If I'm not back when you get there, wait for me. I shouldn't be long. Keep an eye on the sky. This is only going to get worse.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It was the one that attacked Helgen, when Ulfric escaped from the Imperials.
output: Interesting. Same dragon... Damn it, we're blundering around in the dark here! We need to figure out who's behind it all!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, you do.
output: Go ahead. Whatever you want to know. Nothing held back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about the dragons coming back?
output: Not a damn thing. I was just as surprised as you to find that big black dragon here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What makes you think the Thalmor are bringing dragons back?
output: Nothing solid. Yet. But my gut tells me it can't be anybody else. And now the dragons are attacking everywhere, indiscriminately. Skyrim is weakened, the Empire is weakened. The Empire had captured Ulfric. The war was basically over. Then a dragon attacks, Ulfric escapes, and the war is back on. Who else gains from that but the Thalmor?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's our next move?
output: We need to find out if the Thalmor are behind the dragons coming back. We need to get into the Thalmor Embassy, somehow...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do I find the Ratway?
output: If I have to hold your hand through everything, maybe you aren't cut out for this kind of work. It's under your feet, lad. Just follow the smell.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can't we talk here?
output: The walls have ears and you're being tested, lad. We'll talk in the Ragged Flagon.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can't we talk here?
output: The walls have ears and you're being tested, lass. We'll talk in the Ragged Flagon.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for an old guy, probably hiding out in the Ratway.
output: Yeah. I bet I know your guy. He's hiding out in the Ratway Warrens. Paying us good coin for nobody to know about it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for an old guy, hiding out somewhere in Riften.
output: Lot of people looking for him. Don't know his name, but he's paid good money for nobody to know he's down here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for an old guy, hiding out somewhere in Riften.
output: He's holed up in the Ratway Warrens. Be careful. You're not the only one looking for him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for an old guy, hiding out somewhere in Riften.
output: Huh. Lot of old guys around. I don't really know how I can help.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So the Thalmor think the Blades know about the dragons...
output: Ironic, right? The old enemies assume that every calamity must be a plot by the other side... Even so, we've got to find Esbern before they do. He'll know how to stop the dragons if anybody does. Do they know where he is?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: They seem to think he's hiding out in Riften.
output: Riften, eh? Probably down in the Ratway, then. It's where I'd go.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What would the Thalmor want with Esbern?
output: Esbern was one of the Blades archivists, back before the Thalmor smashed us during the Great War. You mean, aside from wanting to kill every Blade they can lay their hands on? He knew everything about the ancient dragonlore of the Blades. Obsessed with it, really. Nobody paid much attention back then. I guess he wasn't as crazy as we all thought.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Thalmor know nothing about the dragons.
output: Really? That seems hard to believe. You're sure about that?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who else is looking for Esbern?
output: Dangerous-looking elves who didn't give their names. Draw your own conclusions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for an old guy, hiding out somewhere in Riften.
output: Well... there is guy like that. He's paid good money for nobody to know he's down here, but I guess I can tell you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why'd you send me if you weren't going to believe me?
output: You're right, you're right. I just... I was sure it must have been them. If not the Thalmor, who? Or... what?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DB04AstridMotierreNightMotherTopic
output: No, she certainly wouldn't. And... for whatever reason, she chose to relay Motierre's information to you. I don't know exactly what's going on here, if you're the Listener, or this is some fluke, or what. But what we now have before us...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DB04AstridMotierreNazirTopic
output: I'm thinking we need that amulet appraised. I want to know where it came from, how much it's worth, and if we can actually get away with selling it. And, there's only one man who can give us what we need - Delvin Mallory. He's a fence, a private operator. Works out of the Ratway, in Riften. Give me the letter. Bring Mallory the amulet. Find out everything you can, and sell it if he's willing. He'll offer a letter of credit - that's fine. Delvin Mallory and the Dark Brotherhood have... history. He can be trusted.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Reporting for duty.
output: I need you to deliver some false orders to the Stormcloak commander in Dawnstar. I need you to deliver some false orders to the Stormcloak commander in Dawnstar. I need you to deliver some false orders to the Stormcloak commander in Dawnstar. But first we need to get our hands on some rebel orders to make the forgeries. But first we need to get our hands on some rebel orders to make the forgeries. But first we need to get our hands on some rebel orders to make the forgeries.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm the one the Blades have been searching for. I'm Dragonborn.
output: What's that you said? Dragonborn? Then... there really is hope after all? You'd better come inside. Quickly now. Thalmor agents have been seen in the Ratway.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Esbern? Open the door. I'm a friend.
output: What?! No, that's not me. I'm not Esbern. I don't know what you're talking about.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's okay. Delphine sent me.
output: Delphine? How do you... so you've finally found her, and she led you to me. And here I am, caught like a rat in a trap.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Open the door.
output: Go away!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yamarz told me to go to Malacath.
output: So, he says to petition Malacath for relief? Interesting.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What kind of spirits?
output: The kind that curse you, haunt you in the dead of night. There is nothing you can do, nothing anyone can do. Shagrol, once the leader of this tribe, unhappy with his demise, has dealt with Malacath himself to curse me, curse us all.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He didn't seem to think it would do any good.
output: Yes, but he offered it as an idea. Perhaps he hopes it will be helpful, but does not wish to risk personal failure. You should do as he says. Go to Malacath's shrine, northwest of here, and ask for his help. See what happens.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm sorry, what?
output: Spirits! Ghosts! I am cursed, haunted, and I can do nothing. Can you fix that? Of course you cannot. No one can. It is my lot as Chief of this tribe, and so I suffer quietly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yamarz must listen with the ears of the wind.
output: The ears of the wind? Malacath himself said this to you? But what does it... Ah! Yes! I see! A ritual is necessary! This message is for me. I understand now. I have work to do. You, I shall need your help. I need a Daedra's heart, at once! Quickly, quickly!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do I contact Malacath?
output: His shrine lies northwest of Largashbur. I am unsure that he will listen, but it cannot hurt.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He was just trying to get rid of me.
output: Perhaps. But he spoke of this "curse" to you, which means it has deeply affected him. It may be worth attempting contact with Malacath after all. Go to Malacath's shrine, southeast of Largashbur. See if perhaps he will aid us after all.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There must be something I can do.
output: You? An outsider? I'd sooner slit my own throat than accept help from you. To even consider it would be such a sign of weakness that I might as well abandon my tribe now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I understand you need help.
output: Atub! Meddlesome woman... You would help us? Help me? Tell me, outsider. Can you banish spirits? For that is what I need.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What sort of help do you need?
output: Our chief is weakened. He will not rest, will not sleep. He suffers, and so the tribe suffers. Yamarz is proud, and refuses to see that we need outside help. He needs someone to confide in. If it will not be one of us, perhaps it will be you. Go to him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does it matter?
output: Yes. For matters of such gravity, we need to know where you stand. Or who you stand with.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to learn the Shout used to defeat Alduin.
output: Where did you learn of that? Who have you been talking to?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The prophecy says I'm the only one who can defeat Alduin.
output: Ah, the prophecy. Be wary of prophecy. Some are meant as a guide. Some as a warning. Are you sure you can tell one from the other?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you an alchemist?
output: I'm aspiring to earn that title, yes. However, the road ahead is paved with loose cobbles and deadly pitfalls. Master Elgrim says I'm a natural; that I have a unique talent. But I fear his approval masks his intolerance for my mistakes. My errant formulas have cost Master Elgrim a fortune in ingredients; some of which are almost irreplaceable.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Actually, she's already dead.
output: Well, that's just about the best news I've heard all week. I was going to give this to whomever killed her for me, but I suppose you've earned it by bringing me this information. This key opens one of my drop spots in the basement of the meadery. Take anything inside you like.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That was the last of the ingredients.
output: Yes, Master Elgrim will be pleased I've restored his stock of these rare ingredients. I feel I owe a bit more than some meaningless coin for all your diligence. Here, this key unlocks my supply chest at Elgrim's Elixirs. Feel free to take what you need from time to time. I'll be refilling it once every few days or so.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any clues where I can find these ingredients?
output: Nirnroot is the easiest. It grows only by the water and makes a unique chiming noise. The only drawback is it won't regrow after harvesting. Nightshade is native to the pine forest and marshy tundra regions of Skyrim and has a distinctive starburst-like violet flower. Last we have deathbell which only grows in marshy tundra terrain. Its inverted bluish-purple flower bunches are unmistakable.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're serving only eight months for murder?
output: Mother thought I should be taught a lesson for airing the family's dirty laundry in public. Ah well. At least I have all the comforts of home during my stay. Well, except the touch of a woman of course. I mean, I've... taken care of many people for her in the past. What in Oblivion did she expect me to do?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any information on Svidi?
output: She was a young woman... buxom, with long flowing black hair. She used to sing the most lovely songs to me when we were courting. I've never heard a voice so beautiful. All that talent will go to waste when I'm finished with her.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why are you so fascinated by alchemy?
output: It's exhilarating to observe the effects of my potions on the body. Watching the heart stop... the eyes go blind. We're made up of thousands of parts with thousands of different functions all working in tandem to keep us alive. Yet if only a single part of our imperfect machine fails, life fails. It makes one realize how fragile... how flawed we are. You ask why I'm so fascinated? The irony... the irony that the same world that gave us life provides us the means to die.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What sort of ingredients do you need?
output: To restore Master Elgrim's supply I would need 20 deathbell, 20 nightshade and 20 nirnroot. Am I sensing that you may be interested in gathering these rare ingredients for me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You have nothing to fear from me. (Persuade)
output: I'm sorry, I don't know what you're talking about.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sure, I'll get them for you.
output: That means more time for my experiments and less time in the field. Much appreciated.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll help you find her.
output: That's the spirit. Find her and I promise you'll be well compensated.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, not right now.
output: Disappointing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Good luck finding her from there.
output: Amusing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I killed her for you.
output: Cut out the middleman, eh? Shrewd, very shrewd. You sure you don't have some Black-Briar blood in you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Stop lying or I'll beat it out of you! (Intimidate)
output: I've been hurt worse before.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Never mind. I was mistaken.
output: You idiot. You came all the way down here for that?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: When I find that bitch, I'm going to wring her little neck.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: Visit me anytime. I'm not going anywhere soon.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: I believe we're done.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: Out of my way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: Don't forget to check your supply chest from time to time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: My experiments can't be completed until you've brought me those ingredients. Do hurry.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: Now was it two parts giant lichen or three? Hm...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why shouldn't they trust you?
output: Dov wahlaan fah rel. We were made to dominate. The will to power is in our blood. You feel it in yourself, do you not? I can be trusted. I know this. But they do not. Onikaan ni ov dovah. It is always wise to mistrust a dovah. What is better - to be born good, or to overcome your evil nature through great effort? I have overcome my nature only through meditation and long study of the Way of the Voice. No day goes by where I am not tempted to return to my inborn nature. Zin krif horvut se suleyk.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Blades say you deserve to die.
output: The Blades are wise not to trust me. Onikaan ni ov. I would not trust another dovah.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Will I get a cut?
output: Of course you'll get a cut. We take care of our own. Now if you need any details on your marks, I'll be here. Get going.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't know why I bothered. This place is a mess.
output: If you were expecting a palace, then maybe you're not cut out for this line of work. Our methods involve secrecy and discretion. Now... if you're done bellyaching like a child, how about handling a few deadbeats for me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do I find the Ratway?
output: If I have to hold your hand through everything, maybe you aren't cut out for this kind of work. It's under your feet, lass. Just follow the smell.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I almost got killed!
output: No risk, no reward. That's the way it goes, so you better get used to it. Now... if you're done bellyaching like a child, how about handling a few deadbeats for me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's next, then?
output: Judging from how well you handled those shopkeepers, I'd say you've done more than simply prove yourself. We need people like you in our outfit.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: If there's more gold where that came from, I'm in.
output: That's the spirit! Larceny's in your blood... the telltale sign of a practiced thief. I think you'll do more than just fit in around here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's happening?
output: You made it! We need to get inside. Follow me!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's happening?
output: Come on! We need to get inside before that dragon comes back!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Thorald is safe.
output: Is he? You've saved him?! I must see him at once!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm afraid he's not here. He didn't think it was safe to return.
output: What? After all this, I can't even see him?  How... How do I know you're telling me the truth, and not just what I want to hear?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He said to tell you to "suffer the winter's cold wind."
output: "...for it bears aloft next summer's seeds." That's my boy. So it's true, then. For now, it's enough to know that he's alive. I can find peace in that. Thank you, dear friend. You've given me back my son.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You wanted something enchanted at the College?
output: Ah, you're from the College? I've been waiting for you. Please make sure this arrives in a timely manner. And don't scratch it up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You wanted something enchanted at the College?
output: Oh, good. I've been waiting for you. Here you go, it's all ready. Now, Sergius knows what I want. I'm hoping he can get it done quickly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you need help?
output: Not now! It's time to get back at these crows.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's the item you wanted.
output: I'll add it to the list of things I need to take care of. Thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there any College business I can assist with?
output: There are more books to be recovered and secured here in the Arcanaeum.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there any College business I can assist with?
output: There's more enchanting to be done. You can acquire whatever it is and bring it back here, and I'll take care of it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You wanted something enchanted at the College?
output: It's about time someone arrived. Here, make sure this is handled properly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You wanted something enchanted at the College?
output: Oh yes, that. Here you go. I hope this can be ready soon.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You wanted something enchanted at the College?
output: Yes, yes. Let's keep our voices down, all right? Just make sure this gets there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Forget it.
output: Hist spit on you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you all right?
output: No. I'm not. I feel like my scales are clawing into me. Maybe you could help an old Argonian out? I heard some of the sailors talking about how they stashed a bottle of Double-Distilled Skooma in the Gnisis Cornerclub. I just need a taste.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Someone giving you trouble?
output: Torbjorn Shatter-Shield. I wish someone would beat the coin out of his fat fists. He clings to every Septim. He says an Argonian's labor is only worth a tenth of a "proper Nord worker." My people are not slaves!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll get it for you.
output: Thank you. I'll be waiting for that bottle.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's your <Alias=QuestItem>.
output: Thank you so much. Here. Let me show you a thing or two about not attracting attention to yourself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry to hear that.
output: We will make do somehow. We always have.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want to talk to you about <Alias.ShortName=QuestGiver>.
output: Well, my friend, if you think those boots needs more coin, I'll make it happen. But I'm doing this for you, not them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want to talk to you about <Alias.ShortName=QuestGiver>.
output: Those boots aren't worth the septims I do pay them. I'm not giving them coin I could give to good, Nord workers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What if I talk to <Alias.ShortName=Target>?
output: You can try, but we've gotten nowhere talking to him ourselves.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Fine. Forget I asked.
output: That's what I thought.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe we can come to an understanding. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: Paying the wages yourself? Well, I won't say no to gold. By my family's honor, this money will go to the Argonian workers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe we can come to an understanding. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: What future?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: At least the Blades aren't keeping secrets from me.
output: Do not be so sure about that. Beware - the Blades may claim to serve the Dragonborn, but they do not. They never have. As for me, I kept from you only what you were not yet ready to know. Are still not ready to know, as your question reveals.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who I stand with is my business.
output: If you wish to stand alone, so be it. If you wish for our help, you'll answer my question.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there another way to defeat Alduin?
output: Perhaps not. But this Shout was used once before, was it not? And here we are again. Have you considered that Alduin was not meant to be defeated? Those who overthrew him in ancient times only postponed the day of reckoning, they did not stop it. If the world is meant to end, so be it. Let it end and be reborn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I wasn't expecting you to be a dragon.
output: I am as my father Akatosh made me. As are you... Dovahkiin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think you already know who I am.
output: Yes. Vahzah. You speak true, Dovahkiin. Forgive me. It has been long since I held tinvaak with a stranger. I gave in to the temptation to prolong our speech.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The dragons are terrorizing Skyrim. Don't you think they need to be stopped?
output: That may be what you are here for, Dragonborn. But stopping Alduin is one thing. Helping you wipe out dragons again is quite another. Dragons are part of the natural order of the world. The Blades thought to change the order to suit themselves, by wiping out the dragons. But again, we see that the natural order will be restored, one way or another. Perhaps we would have dragon allies against Alduin if the ancient Blades had not acted so arrogantly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're the master of the Greybeards?
output: They see me as master. Wuth. Onik. Old and wise. It is true I am old...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to learn the Dragonrend Shout. Can you teach me?
output: Drem. Patience. There are formalities which must be observed, at the first meeting of two of the dov.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to learn the Shout used to defeat Alduin.
output: Where did you learn of a Shout used to defeat Alduin?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So, can you teach me this Shout?
output: No. I cannot teach it to you because I do not know it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The prophecy says that only the Dragonborn can stop him.
output: True... But qostiid - prophecy - tells what may be, not what should be. Do you have no better reason for acting than destiny? Are you nothing but a plaything of dez... of fate? Qostiid sahlo aak. Just because you can do a thing, does not always mean you should.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why live alone on a mountain if you love conversation?
output: Evenaar bahlok. There are many hungers it is better to deny than to feed. Dreh ni nahkip. Discipline against the lesser aids in qahnaar... denial of the greater.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I like this world. I don't want it to end.
output: Pruzah. As good a reason as any. There are many who feel as you do, although not all. Some would say that all things must end, so that the next can come to pass. Perhaps this world is simply the Egg of the next kalpa? Lein vokiin? Would you stop the next world from being born?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know where I can find an Elder Scroll?
output: You are likely better informed than I. Krosis. No. I know little of what has passed below in the long years I have lived here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I never thought about it.
output: This is the most sacred mountain in Skyrim. Zok revak strunmah. The great mountain of the world.  Here the ancient Tongues, the first mortal masters of the Voice, brought Alduin to battle and defeated him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to learn the Dragonrend Shout.
output: Do you know why I live here, at the peak of the Monahven - what you name Throat of the World?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to learn the Dragonrend Shout.
output: Ah. I have expected you. Prodah. You would not come all this way for tinvaak with an old dovah. No. You seek your weapon against Alduin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You mean you were there?
output: Yes. There were a few of us that rebelled against Alduin's thur... his tyranny. We aided the humans in his overthrow. But they did not trust us. Ni ov. Their inner councils were kept hidden from us. I was far from here on the day of Alduin's downfall. But all dov felt the... sundering of Time itself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How could an Elder Scroll cast Alduin through time?
output: Vomindok. I do not know. Perhaps in the very doing they erased the knowing of it from Time itself. The dov are children of Akatosh. Thus we are specially... attuned to the flow of Time. Perhaps also uniquely vulnerable. I warned them against such a rash action. Even I could not foresee its consequences. Nust ni hon. They would not listen.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does the Dragonrend Shout actually do?
output: I cannot tell you in detail. I never heard it used. Kogaan. It was the first Thu'um created solely by mortals. It was said to force a dragon to experience the concept of Mortality. A truly vonmindoraan... incomprehensible idea to the immortal dov.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Using the Dragonrend Shout, right?
output: Yes and no. Viik nuz ni kron. Alduin was not truly defeated, either. If he was, you would not be here today, seeking to... defeat him. The Nords of those days used the Dragonrend Shout to cripple Alduin. But this was not enough. Ok mulaag unslaad. It was the Kel - the Elder Scroll. They used it to... cast him adrift on the currents of Time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You said you were going to answer my question.
output: Drem. Patience. I am answering, in my way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No. Dragons like mountains, right?
output: True. But few now remember that this was the very spot where Alduin was defeated by the ancient Tongues. Vahrukt unslaad... perhaps none but me now remember how he was defeated.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How does any of this help me?
output: Tiid krent. Time was... shattered here because of what the ancient Nords did to Alduin. With the Elder Scroll that was used to break Time, you may be able to... cast yourself back. To the other end of the break. You could learn Dragonrend from those who created it. If you brought that Kel, that Elder Scroll back here... to the Tiid-Ahraan, the Time-Wound...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's a pleasure to meet you.
output: Save the niceties for now. I have no intention of getting invested in someone who may be dead tomorrow. If you're still breathing in a few weeks, I'm sure we'll be the best of friends.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You will hear even more, I assure you.
output: Ooh, cocky. I give you three days before you screw up and someone runs a knife across your throat. But who knows? I've been proven wrong before.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: (Remain silent)
output: Ahh, going for the mysterious and brooding thing, hmm? That may work for your targets, but you'll find I'm not so easily impressed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to learn the Shout used to defeat Alduin.
output: So the Blades have survived yet another disaster of their own making, and continue to meddle in things they do not understand.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are we looking for?
output: Anything! Anything at all that might be of interest. That's why I adore this location... we have no idea what we're going to find. And if, along the way, my message about the dangers of magic should happen to sink in for a few students, that would be a happy coincidence.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found this amulet. It might be important.
output: You found what? Hmm. Well now. This is all very fascinating, but I don't recall asking to you to touch anything in here. I suppose you'd better show that to Tolfdir nonetheless. And please, ask before tampering with anything else.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's so important about this place?
output: We're particularly interested in the prevalence of magical seals placed on the tombs here. It's rather unlike anything we've encountered.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's a shame.
output: Fair enough.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DB04AstridHideResponse1
output: Be that as it may, we have no other choice. You need to remain unseen! Now go! Before they meet. And report back to me with whatever you learn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could deliver that for you.
output: Thanks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a delivery from <Alias.ShortName=QuestGiver>.
output: Ah yes, Adonato's new work. Shorter than I expected, but words must be judged on merit, not length. I'll look over this later. Why don't you take this, for your trouble?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're on. (Brawl - 100 gold)
output: All right. Fists only. And none of that magic stuff, either. Let's go!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're on. (Brawl - 100 gold)
output: I said a hundred gold! Damn broke elves and damn broke elf-lovers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What kinds of things should I bring?
output: If you actually want to get out alive, I'd bring whatever you need to move quietly, and kill quickly. You're asking me? She promised that she was sending someone who knew what they were doing...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll see you in Solitude after I meet Malborn.
output: Sounds good. Be careful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why are the Thalmor after you?
output: Before the Great War, the Blades helped the Empire against the Thalmor. Our Grand Master saw them as the greatest threat to Tamriel. At the time, that was true. Maybe it still is. So we fought them in the shadows, all across Tamriel. We thought we were more than a match for them. We were wrong.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Once I'm inside the Embassy, then what?
output: That's when the fun starts. You'll have to slip away from the party without raising the alarm. Then you'll need to find Elenwen's office and search her files. Malborn should be able to point you in the right direction.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How am I going to get into this party?
output: Let me handle that. You'll have a real invitation, don't worry. As long as you can act the part of a Thalmor toady, you'll get past the guards.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Just the short version.
output: They're the high elves that rule the Aldmeri Dominion. Sworn enemies of the Empire and everything it stands for. Thirty years ago, they invaded the Empire and came close to destroying it. They smashed the Blades in the process. Since then, they've been working to weaken the Empire any way they can.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Good to see you.
output: What? Something you're still confused about?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Good to see you.
output: Not here. Downstairs.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Just a minute. I think I left it on the cart.
output: Of course. Just bring it to me when you find it. Of course. Just bring it to me when you find it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's this contact of yours? You're sure I can trust him?
output: Don't worry about Malborn. He's not a dangerous character like you, but he hates the Thalmor at least as much as I do. He's a wood elf - the Thalmor wiped out his family back in Valenwood during one of their purges that we never hear about. Luckily they don't know who he really is, or he wouldn't be serving drinks at the Ambassador's parties.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Give me the long version.
output: They're the rulers of the Aldmeri Dominion - what used to be the Imperial provinces of Summerset Isle and Valenwood. The Thalmor take the arrogance of high elves to the extreme - they believe they are the rightful rulers of all of Tamriel. For a century or more, the Thalmor had been picking away at the Empire. Valenwood was the first, then the province of Elsweyr. But even the Blades didn't see the Great War coming. We underestimated the Thalmor, and they destroyed us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there a problem?
output: Of course not. Purely a formality. Now, I need to see your invitation. Of course not. Purely a formality. Now, I need to see your invitation.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why not just fight our way in?
output: So that's your plan, huh? Even if you could survive, by the time you got inside, whatever documents they had would be long gone. We're there for information, remember? Trust me, I've been doing this for a long time. My way is better.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That didn't take long.
output: I've been doing this a long time, remember? While the Thalmor's been looking for me, I've been watching them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What was that argument outside the Hall?
output: Ah, you saw that, did you? Life in Morthal has been troubled lately. The people are uncertain, restless. They merely look to the Jarl for leadership.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What was that argument outside the Hall?
output: There's news of rebellion against the Empire. Strange noises have been heard in the marshes at night. And then, the tragedy with Hroggar's home. The men simply seek wisdom. Everything will be fine.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You seemed upset about something.
output: The world's going mad, and our Jarl does what? She hides inside with her 'visions'. We need a leader, not some mystic!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You seemed upset about something.
output: How can I? She never speaks with us. She's allowed this wizard, Falion, to live in our midst practicing gods-know-what. And now there's talk of rebellion, and dragons? What help could Idgrod be against them? No, we can only rely on ourselves. You'd do well to remember that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do we do now?
output: I... I don't know. Ancano is gone, but whatever he's done to the Eye doesn't seem to have stopped. I have no idea what to do!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait, you want me to go do this alone?
output: Yes. I had Falk call you back because you were at the summoning, you have a connection to Potema now. You must deal with her. I can provide you with help for her minions though.  This should help you deal with the Catacombs themselves.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will you do now?
output: I don't know. Beem-Ja has looked after me since I was knee-high to him. I need to rest, and then I think I'm going back to High Rock. I don't know. Beem-Ja has looked after me since I was knee-high to him. I need to rest, and then I think I'm going back to High Rock.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here you go. (Show invitation)
output: Thank you, sir. Go right in. Thank you, sir. Go right in.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here you go. (Show invitation)
output: Thank you, ma'am. Go right in. Thank you, ma'am. Go right in.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I gave the marks to Haelga.
output: Oh I know. Isn't it wonderful? I bet she squirmed like a skeever when you pulled them out of your pocket. I think things are going to be a lot different around here from now on and I have you to thank for it. Here, I want you to have this. It was my father's but I'm certain you'll put it to good use.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe another time.
output: Yeah, you're right. Maybe it's not the best idea.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sure, I'll help you.
output: Oh, this is going to be great! Oh, this is going to be great! You need to get the Marks of Dibella from Bolli, Hofgrir and Indaryn. Not sure how you're going to do that, but try your best. You need to get the Marks of Dibella from Bolli, Hofgrir and Indaryn. Not sure how you're going to do that, but try your best. Then just confront Haelga with them and the rest works itself out. Then just confront Haelga with them and the rest works itself out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is skooma?
output: I'm not sure what it's made from, but I can tell you that once you've had a taste, you'll never crave anything else. The Dunmer came up with the stuff a long time ago. Very illegal and very hard to come by. I got mine off of a merchant ship in Solitude. Worst mistake I ever made.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: All right, I'll do it.
output: Good. Now get going.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're not coming?
output: That would be a bad idea. I'd be too likely to attract the wrong kind of attention. But they don't know you at all, yet.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you like working at the Riften Fishery?
output: Bolli is a good man, he pays us well and watches out for us. I used to work at the Black-Briar Meadery, but Indaryn and I never saw eye-to-eye. That elf has no patience at all. It's probably for the best anyway; I'm far better at fishing than working in a meadery.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any tips on who might accept these?
output: Almost anyone in Riften is in dire need of those missives. Speak to them, child. You will know who will listen and who will sin. A word of advice, keep away from the Keep and the city guards. They follow their own path and have already forsaken Her.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened to the shrine of Talos?
output: Now that the Imperial blight has poisoned Riften, the worship of Talos is strictly forbidden by the terms of the White-Gold Concordat. They can defile our shrine, they can arrest our people and they can silence our voices, but the Empire will never destroy our spirit. As long as we keep Talos in our heart, his legacy will never die.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry, can't help you.
output: Very well. I suppose I'll just curl up somewhere until this passes as usual.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I believe these are yours?

output: That's fine. We needed his help. Now we don't, and it's long past time for him to pay for his crimes. And he's not just any dragon. He was the right hand of Alduin. He committed atrocities so infamous they are still remembered, thousands of years later.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: I will not lie to you, there is some risk involved. The last time the Torpor was imbibed could have been decades ago. But I swear upon Lady Mara that I will do everything within my power to prevent any harm from befalling you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's amazing!
output: Quite amazing, yes. Alchemy and the blessings of a Divine distilled down into a ingestible liquid. Sadly, I have yet to see it function in person.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is that some type of potion?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Forget it! It could kill me!

Otherwise, the worst that could happen is a bad aftertaste. I swear upon Lady Mara that I would never let any harm befall you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's impossible.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Turns out he's a dragon. But he helped me.
output: It's true that his crimes are long in the past, but justice does not count the passage of years. It's true that his crimes are long in the past, but justice does not count the passage of years. All well and good. But did you know that he was Alduin's chief lieutenant in ancient times? Responsible for terrible atrocities? All well and good. But did you know that he was Alduin's chief lieutenant in ancient times? Responsible for terrible atrocities?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You know... what?
output: He's a dragon. Not just any dragon, but the right hand of Alduin, responsible for many atrocities during the ancient Dragon War. He's a dragon. Not just any dragon, but the right hand of Alduin, responsible for many atrocities during the ancient Dragon War.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What about Paarthurnax?
output: I'm afraid there's a further problem. A serious one. I've discovered who the Greybeards' leader really is. I'm afraid there's a further problem. A serious one. I've discovered who the Greybeards' leader really is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why does he need to die?
output: Here's the big picture. He helped Alduin enslave our ancestors. He may have betrayed Alduin in the end, but that makes him worse, not better. We can't afford to give Paarthurnax the opportunity to betray us in turn, and return to his old master.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why does he need to die?
output: Paarthurnax was the author of many atrocities during the Dragon War - crimes great enough to be remembered for thousands of years. True, he turned traitor to Alduin and helped overthrow the Dragon Cult, but that does not excuse or expiate his previous deeds. Whether or not he has truly repented, or merely acted to save himself, justice demands that he pay with his life.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Job's done, Brynjolf.
output: So I've heard. Thanks to you, this should be the last time they forget to pay. One small detail though - I need all of the gold they gave you. No one skims around here. Come back when you've got every last coin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why keep it a secret?
output: When the orcs invaded the temple, I fled. I left my brothers and sisters here to die.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I can bring it for you.
output: I hadn't asked you because I was afraid you'd say no. I appreciate your help. Here, I'm entrusting you with the dagger. Bring it to Andurs and he'll take care of the rest.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You tend the graveyard?
output: If you're trying to ask if I tend the hall of the dead alone, then the answer is yes. You think anyone around here is going to lift a shovel to help me? Guess again. "Leave the dirty work to old Alessandra." Look, I didn't ask for this job, I got stuck with it thanks to my father.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Good luck with that.
output: Yes. Perhaps one day I'll be able to make the journey, but for now I need to tend the dead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where exactly am I going?
output: Let's see. Last time I used the Dwemer Spoon was at my dear friend Boti's house in Ivarstead... Fellstar Farm I believe it's called. The orichalcum ingot should still be in Winterhold at the Frozen Hearth Inn. I don't know why I didn't just take it with me. And last is the soul gem. I left that one in Windhelm at the White Phial alchemy shop. It was a good trade too. Ah well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't understand a word of that.
output: You don't have to, because it's utter nonsense. It's never going to work. No, no, no. What I need to do is to reverse that. Draw the harmonic energy into the reagent and then apply it with the proper incantation. What was I thinking? It would never work that first way. Why didn't you tell me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I gave the dagger to Andurs.
output: I felt a caress on my cheek some time ago... I thought it to be a trick of the wind, but I think it was a message from my father. We've made peace with one another without even uttering a single word and I'm content for the first time in my life. I thank you. Here, please accept this as a token of my appreciation for your selfless action.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You totally lost me.
output: I'll tell you why you won't tell me. Because you were absolutely right not to. It's a fundamental rule of magic and it would be ridiculous. You can't draw from harmonic energy without a soul siphon. Since you're so well informed I'm certain you've solved the problem with thermic drift, right?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Nope, don't get it at all.
output: What's not to get? It's as simple as Traven's First Axiom of Magic... or was it Galerion's Law of Casting. Hmm. I'll tell you what, let me find out where that's from. I'll need to look through my library... and get you an answer. Umm... what were we talking about?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You appear to need help getting organized.
output: Yes, I could use some help with that. An assistant perhaps? No, no, no. Maybe a familiar. No, too messy. Well, at any rate, organization is not my strong suit. Not at all. I need as much help as I can get. In fact, if you could retrieve a few things for me, I could start on my next set of experiments.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe some other time.
output: A shame. Perhaps another time then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Point the way and I'll get them.
output: Excellent. I can't wait. Well... why are you still standing here? Oh, right. You need to know where they are! That would help.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did you need me to get?
output: As you can imagine, I tend to forget things often. Leave things around. I really must learn to put these things away. What I need is my Dwemer Stirring Spoon, my Orichalcum Ingot and my Grand Soul Gem. In fact, I could use them immediately. Bring those items back to me and I'll be happy to experiment on you. No, no... that isn't right. I'd be happy to reward you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How's your father to blame for your job?
output: My father was a Priest of Arkay. All my life was spent around the dead, being forced to learn the proper burial rituals and prayers. I never had any friends; who'd want to spend time with "the little weird girl who hangs around dead people?" So I grew up with a miserable trade. This is all I know how to do... prepare and inter the deceased.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What has you so preoccupied?
output: Someone actually interested in what I'm doing? Amazing! Well, allow me to explain. My experimentation involves a magical construct and a reagent that will allow the construct to maintain a field of permanent harmonic energy!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can you make peace with your father?
output: I'd like to make the journey to the Hall of the Dead in Windhelm and give my ceremonial dagger to Andurs, the caretaker. I believe once it's interred with my father's remains I'll be at peace with his memory.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have all your items for you.
output: Items? What items? Let me see those. Hmm. I'm not sure how you managed it, but these are exactly what I need to start my next set of experiments. Wonderful! Well, at least allow me to reward you for your uncanny foresight.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DB06GabriellaDragonBridgeBranchTopic
output: It's a small town, with one rather unique feature - it houses Skyrim's only Penitus Oculatus outpost. It was established by Commander Maro when he first arrived in Skyrim, several months ago. When he began preparing for the Emperor's initial visit.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's in it for me?
output: You can have anything except the scroll of course.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry, I can't help.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What kind of help do you need?
output: If Vokun is as powerful as I think, I may need a little help um ... dealing ...with him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: I'm Anska.  Are you here to help?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll help.
output: Great, with the two of us this should be easy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Help with what?
output: I've finally located Vokun's crypt! The scroll I'm looking for just has to be here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: "Bent a few folks' arms the wrong way"?
output: That's right. Whole group of the natives called the Forsworn rose up against the Nords. Drove them out. Then Ulfric Stormcloak came with his militia. That must have been a sight to see, him shouting folks to death. You'd think that'd be the end of it, but those Forsworn are still in the hills, and they're as wild as wolves.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the Markarth Incident?
output: It's the whole reason Ulfric revolted against the Empire. Well, the first reason anyway. Forsworn had taken over Markarth, and Ulfric and his men drove them out. Empire promised they'd be free to worship Talos afterwards. Pity no one told the Elves. Whole group of those Thalmor came and they demanded Ulfric's arrest.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Dwarves built this city?
output: That's right, at least according to them scholars. Stonework's clearly not Nord, that much is for sure. Old Elven fella named Calcelmo is up in Understone Keep's the one you want to talk to for more about that. Wrote all those books.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Forsworn?
output: Before the Nords came, we worshipped the old gods, had our own kingdom. Times have been good and bad since then, but some folks couldn't handle not ruling their own land. Those are the Forsworn. The Forsworn follow the old ways, but some of those were best forgotten. Blood sacrifices, communing with Daedra. It's the road to ruin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Markarth?
output: It's an old city. Legends say Dwarves built it first. Then after they vanished, the natives moved in.  Finally, the Nords took over around Tiber Septim's time. That bent a few folks' arms the wrong way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a delivery from <Alias.ShortName=QuestGiver>.
output: What's this? Oh, that's right, the timbers from Anga's Mill. I swear, that Aeri and her men would make fine Stormcloak recruits. Pity we can't spare the lumber to conscript them. Here. Take this. For your time and all that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's in charge of Markarth?
output: That would be Jarl Igmund. Young for a ruler of a Hold, especially the Reach.  Wasn't surprising he stayed loyal to the Empire. His father helped capture Ulfric Stormcloak after the Markarth Incident.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's in charge of Markarth?
output: Since the Stormcloaks took over, Jarl Thongvor is in charge.  It'll be lean times for the Reach with a Silver-Blood ruling it, that's for certain.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's a shame.
output: Yeah, yeah.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could deliver that for you.
output: Well, look at you, thanks. Take it to Voada, she handles all the dogs for the Jarl.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Markarth?
output: Don't fall.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've retrieved the scroll.
output: I cannot thank you enough for all of the help.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm just here for the books you took from the College.
output: What? The bo... Oh. Oh dear. Help me get out of here, and I'll help you find them. Please! I shouldn't have taken them, I know! It was stupid. I was stupid. It won't happen again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where are the books you stole?
output: I don't have them anymore. She took them... The Caller. She's the one who put me in here! Please, let me out of here!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So, you're Orthorn?
output: Yes, yes! Did Arch-Mage Aren send you? He sent you to rescue me, didn't he?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Job's done, Brynjolf.
output: You have wax in your ears? I said no one dies. We're not assassins. Well guess what... now you've inherited their debt. Don't come back to me until you have every last coin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Riften's Thieves Guild.
output: To call it a guild is ridiculous. How can people who would betray one another over a gold coin be considered part of an association? They're the worst kind. Even the Dark Brotherhood abides by a strict set of rules and tradition. These thieves are just rabble. What do you think?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why are you here, then?
output: Many years ago I lost my blade, "Grimsever," within a Dwemer ruin. I took it as a sign that I was wasting my days in search of wealth. You and I are alike. We seek challenge and great fortune. But for me, that's where the similarities end. You see, Riften is my great beast to be slain and my fortune comes from gratitude and trust.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened to you in Mzinchaleft?
output: I was adventuring in the depths of the ruins when I was attacked by a massive construct... like nothing I had ever seen. When the colossus struck, Grimsever was knocked from my grasp and I was wounded badly. It was only through blind luck that I was able to crawl away from the Dwemer abomination and make my way to the surface. I must have collapsed, because the next thing I remember is Aerin standing over me tending to my wounds.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened to your blade, Grimsever?
output: It was lost years ago in a Dwemer ruin. Without it, I feel almost as defenseless as a newborn. I don't think I'll ever be able to find a replacement.
