input: I'm looking for work.
output: Aren't you already running a job for Skjor? Come talk to me when you finish that up. Aren't you already running a job for Skjor? Come talk to me when you finish that up. Aren't you already running a job for Skjor? Come talk to me when you finish that up. Aren't you already running a job for Skjor? Come talk to me when you finish that up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you doing here?
output: There's no time! You have to get back to the College as fast as you can! Mirabelle is dead, and they're losing ground fast. I'd be there now if I hadn't seen... I had one of your 'visions', I think. Go on, get moving! I'll try and clear a path for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Job's finished.
output: Well it's about time! I had to stall the captain until you were finished.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Job's finished.
output: Why are you standing here then? I've told the captain of the guard we'll have the meadery cleared for the tasting and he could be here any minute.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: But you weren't killed... Not even once.
output: Yeah, but Twice-Killed has more of a ring to it!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And you lived?
output: Yeah, I was lucky though. After Vex tore the guy to pieces, she gave me a potion. If she hadn't of been there... Anyway, after I got back to the Guild, I decided to start calling myself Twice-Killed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Twice-Killed?
output: Got into a scrap a few years ago at the Ragged Flagon. Some idiot who stole himself a guard's sword and kept boasting about it. He's making too much racket and I'm trying to get Vex drunk. So I tell him to keep it down and he just runs me through.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: You didn't need to leave so soon.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: Give Vex a kiss for me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So prison is a Guild punishment?
output: Hey, if you're in good with Maven you've pretty much got it made. She's got friends in high places, and I don't just mean in Skyrim. So getting the guards to throw me in here as a "punishment" was about as easy as falling off a log.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why are you in prison?
output: Because big, bad Brynjolf doesn't like the way I play thief. Look, he says we needed coin, so I got coin. Who cares if people got hurt? Blood washes off septims. Now I'm sitting in here counting skeever droppings while he's drinking Black-Briar mead with Maven.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why strike now?
output: The Goldenglow Estate job has undoubtedly interrupted the supply of honey I need to make my mead. Sabjorn could use this interruption to his advantage and collect a larger share of the market. I can't have that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's your opinion of Markarth?
output: We'd be better off without the Silver-Bloods. They send their brute, Yngvar, to shake some coins from me every few days. And Betrid Silver-Blood is always asking for more potions to fuel Thonar's "ambitions." Gives him a temper fiercer than any bear.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have the <Alias=QuestItem>.
output: Stendarr's Mercy to you. If my Horgeir doesn't give up the mead this time, I'll hit him over the head with it. Here, for your trouble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What if I talk to <Alias.ShortName=Target>?
output: You're going to try to talk sense into that Orc? I'll believe it when I see it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Olda wanted me to steal this <Alias=QuestItem>.
output: Shor's Crown, that woman never gives up. I guess that's why I married her. You're a real friend saving this mead from her. Here, let me show you how to block a punch that might be coming from some angry spouse, huh?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want to talk to you about <Alias.ShortName=QuestGiver>.
output: What? Are you telling me how to treat my workers? Do you have any idea how much metal the Silver-Blood family wants us to smelt?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your husband drinking too much?
output: He promised me, swore on his ancestors, that he'd give up the mead. And what do I find out? He's been stashing drink in a cave nearby. He even has some wolves guarding it. I swear, I should just cut out his tongue. That would be the end of it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Fine. Forget I asked.
output: Idiot.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tough luck.
output: It's not luck, it's mead I'm cursing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Someone giving you trouble?
output: He's a damn tyrant. Always being goaded on by the Silver-Bloods to get more work out of us. They pay us next to nothing. We get beaten if we make a mistake, and where are our kind Nord rulers? What are they doing? Typical.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you own this smelter?
output: Me and Hathrasil mostly. Mulush barks at us all day, but I wouldn't call that honest work. A few people in the Warrens used to work here. Degaine broke some bones a while back. Eltrys quit. Cairine is too sick.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you own this smelter?
output: Mulush. Big Orc fella. Can't miss him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry to hear that.
output: Sorries don't help anyone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about the Forsworn?
output: Don't get involved in that nonsense. Just want to work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about the Forsworn?
output: We've lost a lot of good people to that damn crusade. Drive out the Nords, they say. Well, the Nord ain't driven out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe we can come to an understanding. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: I guess I can spare him a few beatings. Deal.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe we can come to an understanding. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: The only thing I understand is you bothering you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could get your husband's stash for you.
output: If you want to try, but I'll keep my dagger sharpened just in case. You can help yourself to any drink you find, but bring me the bottle of Dragon's Breath Mead. It's his favorite, so I know he has one there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Aren't you forgetting something?
output: What? Oh! How could I have possibly forgotten. Your reward, of course... of course. Here you are. So sorry about that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a purchase agreement for you.
output: Ah, Bolli finally got someone out here. Well it's about time. I've been waiting for weeks. Well, thank you for bringing it I suppose. Have a good day.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe another time.
output: Certainly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Okay, I'll do it.
output: Good. Kleppr will pay you as soon as you arrive with the letter. Here you are.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm here to pick up Harrald's sword.
output: Lazy good-for-nothing, isn't he? Sent you down here when I'm a stone's throw from the keep? Here's the sword. Tell Harrald to stop slaying walls and perhaps his blade will stay in better condition!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who buys all your fish?
output: I sell my catch across a good portion of Skyrim... it's worth its weight in gold to me. The only untapped market left is Markarth. However, I just got word that Kleppr at The Silver Blood Inn might be interested. If you're headed that way, I would appreciate you delivering a purchase agreement for me. You'd be paid, of course.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's the sword from Balimund.
output: Took your sweet time getting it to me. Here you go, for your trouble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe later.
output: Hmph. I should have known better than to ask a knave.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll get it for you.
output: Thank you. Do hurry please.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's none of your business.
output: Nid. If you wish me to answer your question, you must answer mine.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't believe in destiny. But I will stop Alduin.
output: And so, perhaps, your destiny will be fulfilled. Who can say? Dez motmahus. Even to the dov, who ride the currents of Time, destiny is elusive. Alduin believes that he will prevail, with good reason. Rok mul. And he is no fool. Ni mey, rinik gut nol. Far from it. He began as the wisest and most far-seeing of us all.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to stop Alduin.
output: Yes. Alduin... zeymah. The elder brother. Gifted, grasping and troublesome as is so often the case with firstborn. But why? Why must you stop Alduin?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DB01MiscGuardPlayerCiceroFramed1
output: Did he now? Did he now? Nobody pilfers property on my watch. Nobody pilfers property on my watch. My thanks for bringing this to my attention, citizen. Don't worry, I'll take care of it. My thanks for bringing this to my attention, citizen. Don't worry, I'll take care of it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The next world will have to take care of itself.
output: Paaz. A fair answer. Ro fus... maybe you only balance the forces that work to quicken the end of this world. Even we who ride the currents of Time cannot see past Time's end. Wuldsetiid los tahrodiis. Those who try to hasten the end, may delay it. Those who work to delay the end, may bring it closer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Only a dagger for the son of the Jarl?
output: If you must know, I was practicing in the yard when the guard I was sparring with feinted when I specifically told him to duck! My blade bit right into the stonework next to the keep and needed serious repairs. Thankfully our smith Balimund works wonders. In fact, if you'd fetch my blade from him I'd be most appreciative.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can you take a break?
output: Sure, my voice could use a rest. Sure, my voice could use a rest. Sure, my voice could use a rest. Sure, my voice could use a rest.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I make a request?
output: Sure, what can I do for you? Sure, what can I do for you? Sure, what can I do for you? Sure, what can I do for you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What better reason to act than to fulfill my destiny?
output: If you can see your destiny clearly, your sight is clearer than mine. Dahmaan - remember, Alduin also follows his destiny, as he sees it. But, I bow before your certainty. In a way I envy you. The curse of much knowledge is often indecision.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can I learn it, then?
output: Drem. All in good time. First, a question for you. Why do you want to learn this Thu'um?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I wanted to know more about Markarth.
output: Then you're talking to the wrong man. You want that elf in the keep. Calcelmo. The only thing I'll tell you about Markarth is stay out of our business. We have enough around here without some outsider causing trouble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I didn't come here to debate philosophy with you.
output: Hahaha! You have much to learn of the dov, then. There is nothing else but philosophy to a dovah. It is no accident that we do battle with our Thu'um, our Voices. There is no distinction between debate and combat to a dragon. Tinvaak los grah. For us it is one and the same.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Excuse me?
output: Markarth. Is it bloody enough for you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to learn the Dragonrend Shout.
output: You have not answered my question. Why do you need to learn this Thu'um?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You grew up in a stronghold?
output: That's right. An Orc stronghold. Kept to ourselves. Lived as our ancestors would have wanted. Wasn't enough for me, though. I left. Didn't want to end up as the third wife of some lowly chieftain.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you mean by "blood and silver"?
output: It's right there in the name of the most powerful family in Markarth. The Silver-Bloods. They have a whole mine filled with prisoners to dig up silver ore, gets smelted by workers they pay, and they own half the city. I work for them. The inn is named after them. When the guards make an arrest, they check with them first.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was wondering where I could get a drink.
output: That's about the only harmless thing you can do in this city. Silver-Blood Inn is the place to go. And once you've had your fill of mead, do us all a favor and go home. Markarth has enough trouble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: More blood is always better.
output: Then you've found your home, friend. Blood and silver are what flows through Markarth. Welcome.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You live here in Markarth?
output: No. I live in a nice house in Solitude where the air isn't filled with smoke from the silver smelters and golden-haired girls shine my shield. Been here ever since I left the Bards College. Turns out a few muscles earn more gold than a damn lute. The Silver-Bloods pay me, let me crack a few skulls, and keep the guards off my back. That's all I need.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Bloody enough.
output: Then turn around and go back where you came. City doesn't need you, doesn't want you. Blood and silver are what flows through Markarth. That's the way it is. That's the way it'll stay.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where'd you learn to smith?
output: Grew up in a stronghold. Every Orc girl tended the forge at some point. But a girl has to grow up, and life in the stronghold asked for a lot in return, so I joined the Legion. Mastered my trade there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for work, if you have any.
output: I don't. Go bother Kleppr at the Silver-Blood Inn, he handles the newcomers. And by Ysmir, if you find work, just do what you're told. There's enough trouble in Markarth already.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've got better things to do.
output: Milk drinker.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've got better things to do.
output: Pit bait.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for work.
output: Jarl is who you want to talk to. Always coin to be made killing off some Forsworn in the hills. As long as you don't mind going axe-to-axe with a bunch of Daedra-worshipping savages who practice the dark arts.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're on. (Brawl - 100 gold)
output: Just fists. No weapons, no magic... no crying. Let's go!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're on. (Brawl - 100 gold)
output: Why don't you come back when you actually have a hundred gold?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you threatening me?
output: If I was threatening you, believe me, you'd know it. You outsiders never learn. If the Forsworn don't get you, the guards will throw you in Cidhna Mine to work your fingers off. Think that's water in the river? Blood and silver are what flows through Markarth, friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did you know some Alik'r warriors are looking for a Redguard woman?
output: The who? I'm sorry, I have no idea what you're talking about.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, I'm not.
output: Time is of the essence here, please hurry back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What if Mercer's there?
output: Then we show them Gallus's journal and hope for the best. Remember, we have proof and all he's got is his word.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready. Let's go.
output: Keep your eyes open. I'm not sure what to expect when we enter the cistern.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Arch-Mage Aren is dead?
output: I can hardly believe it. But there's no time. Whatever happened here has affected Winterhold as well. I need you to get out there and make sure everything's all right. I'll do what I can here. Go now, go!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's Ancano. He's done something with the Eye!
output: By the Nine... Is he responsible for this? The Arch-Mage, dead? There's more. Something's happened to Winterhold. It must be whatever Ancano did. You need to get out there and make sure it's safe. Quickly now, quickly! I'll find Mirabelle and see if we can't put a stop to this!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can you be sure Thorald is still alive?
output: He's my son. I just... I feel it in my heart. You'd understand if you had children.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do you think the Battle-Borns are involved?
output: It's hardly a secret that they have ties to the Empire, and hate anyone who speaks out against it. Thorald did worse. He took action against the Empire, and the Battle-Borns knew it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is Wuuthrad?
output: Wuuthrad was the blade held by Ysgramor when he came back from Atmora. An axe of great vengeance. Each fragment is precious.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No doubt you welcomed the Stormcloaks with open arms.
output: With open arms, with cheers and song, with joy in my heart and tears in my eyes! Praise be to Talos, this is a glorious day for Whiterun and for all Skyrim! Our liberators have come at last!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you glad the Stormcloaks are in charge?
output: I'm sure my brother Vignar is, since they made him Jarl after throwing Balgruuf out. Comes the end of the day, Imperials and Stormcloaks ain't much different. Both sides want to tell you how you should live your life. Guess I'd rather hear it from a real Nord than some Emperor down south.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have the Stormcloaks treated you roughly?
output: Of course they have! I've made no secret of my loyalty to the Empire. I'm no coward. Twice I've been robbed, and good luck getting any kind of justice from Vignar now that he's the Jarl. He probably told the Stormcloaks to do it. Lately, they've been threatening to send my whole family into exile if we're caught collaborating with the Empire. They think we're spies! Needless to say, these rebels and I have no love for each other.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you pleased to see the Stormcloaks in charge?
output: Pleased enough, I suppose. At least they appreciate the ways and traditions of the Nord people. Can't say I ever much liked the idea of the Empire telling us what to do an' how to do it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do you think Ulfric killed the High King?
output: No doubt he thought it was the only way to make his point. And also because he knew he could.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Whose side are you on?
output: If it's the war you're referring to, I'm on the side of Whiterun. No doubt General Tullius and his friends in the Empire will tell you that I owe them my loyalty, and perhaps I do. Ulfric Stormcloak would say that I owe my allegiance to the Nord people as they fight for Skyrim's independence. Perhaps this is also true. The day might come when I am forced to draw my sword for one side or the other. But that day has not come yet.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where are your children?
output: If the gods are merciful, they've found a safe place to hide in the city. I hope Vignar doesn't find them. He'll ask a king's ransom, I'm sure.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Karliah was behind Goldenglow and Honningbrew.
output: Trying to make Mercer look bad in front of Maven, eh? Clever lass. Was there anything else?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Plans for what?
output: Before Mercer took over, Gallus started collecting every bit of material he could on locations the Guild could heist. Museums, keeps, estates... you name it. By the time Mercer took over the Guild we must have had a few dozen.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Mercer killed Gallus, not Karliah.
output: Aye. I feared that was the case. From that last entry in Gallus's diary, it looks like he was getting close to exposing Mercer to the Guild. Anything else?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Gallus, Karliah and Mercer were Nightingales.
output: What? Nightingales? But, I always assumed they were just a tale... a way to keep the young footpads in line. Was there anything else she told you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How could he have opened the vault door alone?
output: I don't have a clue. That door is impenetrable. Without two keys, it's impossible to open. I have a key, Delvin has a key, and Mercer has a key. That's it. There are no other copies.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How could Mercer have gotten into the Vault?
output: All I can tell you for now is that he's abused his authority as a Nightingale.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's it? After all the trust I've given you?
output: Be patient and your time will come. As a Nightingale, I took an oath and was sworn to secrecy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready to take the Oath.
output: Changed your mind? You ready to pledge your blood and honor for Skyrim's freedom?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why are the Alik'r after you?
output: I don't know for sure. I spoke out against the Aldmeri Dominion publicly; I suspect that's why these men were hired to hunt me down.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why haven't you gone to the guards for help?
output: You think I'd be in hiding if this was something I trusted town guards to handle? These men are ruthless. Cunning, deceitful... they'll pay off whoever they can. I can't trust anyone here in Whiterun. Guards and Jarls can be bought. And the Alik'r are close; I'm running out of time, so I'm choosing to trust you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Speaking of which...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why were you being executed?
output: Seriously, you don't know? That was Ulfric Stormcloak himself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you capture Ulfric?
output: I was assigned to Ulfric's guard. We were on our way to Darkwater Crossing, in the south of Eastmarch. The Imperials were waiting for us. As pretty an ambush as I ever saw. We were outnumbered five to one, at least. Ulfric ordered us to stop fighting. Didn't want us all to die for nothing, I guess. I thought they were taking us south to Cyrodiil. Parade us in front of the Emperor. But then we stopped in Helgen, and you know the rest.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Stormcloaks?
output: Surely even down in Cyrodiil people have heard news of the war in Skyrim? Ulfric is our rightful High King. He's leading the fight to drive the Empire out of Skyrim, once and for all. The Nords are tired of spending our blood fighting the Empire's wars, and paying for the Empire's decadence with our taxes.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe you'll see one yourself soon. Helgen isn't that far from here.
output: Don't even say such things! I hope that dragon stays away from Riverwood. We don't need that kind of trouble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Was that dragon on your side?
output: What? Oh, hardly! I don't think even Ulfric could pull a dragon out of his pocket. Lucky for us it attacked when it did, eh? I wasn't looking forward to getting a shave from the Imperial headsman.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't pay much attention to current events.
output: Oh, right, they said you were captured crossing the border. Still, I'm surprised you haven't heard of Ulfric. He's our leader - the leader of the Stormcloaks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Much bigger than that. As big as the inn.
output: Well I'll be! That'd be a sight to see. Not that I actually want to see one, understand. I hope that dragon stays far away from here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you think about the war?
output: The Empire may have been good for Skyrim once upon a time, but those days are long past. I'm glad Ralof is helping drive them out of here. If I was a bit younger, I might have joined the fight myself. Banning the worship of Talos was the last straw. Thalmor everywhere, dragging people off for honoring our own gods!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you think about the war?
output: I've got enough to worry about, taking care of my family. I don't concern myself with such matters.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Oh, right. Ulfric Stormcloak...
output: Right. The leader of our fight against the Empire. I forget that most people don't know what he looks like, except for those Imperial wanted posters.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I really don't want to talk about it.
output: Sure, sure. It's just, you know, not every day I meet someone who's laid eyes on a dragon.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have we reached Japhet's Folly?
output: Hard to say. The weather's taken a bit of a turn, here. Haldyn's been known to obscure his hideaways with magic.  If we take care of him, the way should be clear to properly assault the island.

input: He's a traitor of some kind?

They claim to be fighting for Skyrim's freedom, but the war is really all about Ulfric wanting to be High King of Skyrim.

input: Why is the worship of Talos banned?
output: It's from that treaty that ended the Great War, remember, when the Emperor was forced by the Thalmor to outlaw Talos worship. We didn't pay much attention to it when I was a boy - everyone still had their little shrine to Talos. But then Ulfric and his "Sons of Skyrim" started agitating about it, and sure enough the Emperor had to crack down. Dragging people off in the middle of the night... one of the main causes of this war, if you ask me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't pay much attention to current events.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you think about the war?

Nords have always supported the Empire, and the Empire has always been good for Skyrim. But was it worth tearing Skyrim apart, and maybe destroying the Empire? No, Ulfric will have a lot to answer for in the end.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

input: What's the mission?

I'll meet you there as soon as I'm finished up here.

input: Reporting in.
output: What's the Legion doing here? Damn Imperial spies... Well, should be fun for us, at least. They don't seem to know we're here yet. Ready to spill some Imperial blood for Skyrim?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How am I supposed to get rid of them?
output: They're mercenaries, only in it for the money. They're led by a man named Kematu. Get rid of him, and the rest will scatter. I don't dare show my face, lest they recognize me, so you'll have to find out where they are.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you looking for?
output: We're looking for information about a woman -- a foreigner in these lands. She's a Redguard, like us. We believe she may be hiding in Whiterun, but we're checking everywhere to be sure.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for work.
output: Aela's laid claim to your services, and I've learned the hard way not to upset her. Best you stick to her for now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for work.
output: Aela said you were hers, and I wasn't supposed to interfere. She scares me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for work.
output: And there is more work to be done, but I fear that Kodlak's gotten wind of our recent efforts. He's asked to see you.  My advice? Always be honest with the old man, but don't tell him anything he doesn't need to know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You said you had a task for me?
output: Have you heard the story of how we came to be werewolves?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Am I to do this alone?
output: You shall have no Shield-Brother this time. But the spirit of Ysgramor goes with you, to restore the honor of his legacy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We've killed your beast spirit.
output: And so slain the beast inside of me. I thank you for this gift. The other Harbingers remain trapped by Hircine, though.  Perhaps from Sovngarde, the heroes of old can join me in their rescue. The Harrowing of the Hunting Grounds. It would be a battle of such triumph. And perhaps some day, you'll join us in that battle. But for today, return to Jorrvaskr. Triumph in your victory. And lead the Companions to further glory.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there a way to cure yourself?
output: That's what I've spent my twilight years trying to find out. And now I've found the answer. The witches' magic ensnared us, and only their magic can release us.  They won't give it willingly, but we can extract their foul powers by force.  I want you to seek them out. Go to their coven in  the wilderness. Strike them down as a true warrior of the wild.  And bring me their heads. The seat of their abilities. From there, we may begin to undo centuries of impurity.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And they became werewolves?
output: They did not believe the change would be permanent. The witches offered payment, like anyone else. But we had been deceived.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Vilkas said it was a curse laid upon the ancient Companions.
output: The boy has a nugget of truth, but the reality is more complicated than that. It always is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened here?
output: One of the fiercest battles I've ever seen.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You were telling me about the witches.
output: Ah yes, their trickery.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So what is the truth, then?
output: The Companions are nearly five thousand years old. This matter of beastblood has only troubled us for a few hundred. One of my predecessors was a good, but short-sighted man. He made a bargain with the witches of Glenmoril Coven.  If the Companions would hunt in the name of their lord, Hircine, we would be granted great power.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Was anyone else hurt?
output: No, but they made off with all our fragments of Wuuthrad. But you and I are going to reclaim them. We will bring the battle to their chief camp. There will be none left living to tell their stories. Only songs of Jorrvaskr will be sung. We will avenge Kodlak. And they will know terror before the end.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The witches should be hunted down for their trickery.
output: We'll get to that. It's not so simple as just killing them, though.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't wish to remove this blessing.
output: This is not about your desires, lad.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: But aren't you more powerful now?
output: The witches didn't lie, of course. But it's more than our bodies.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I return them with honor. (Give fragments)
output: Don't get too flowery on me, lad.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Kodlak, is that you?
output: Of course. My fellow Harbingers and I have been warming ourselves here. Trying to evade Hircine.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do we get inside?
output: Return Wuuthrad to Ysgramor. It should open the way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It shall be done.
output: Good. Now move quickly. And don't leave any of them alive.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Skjor said it was a blessing from Hircine.
output: Aye, that sounds like him.  As in all matters of faith, though, the reality is more complicated than one believer would tell you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I work for the honor of the Companions.
output: Lass, I know what you've been up to.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was doing Kodlak's bidding.
output: I hope it was important, because it means you weren't here to defend him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Which of the Eight Divines do you serve?
output: This temple is dedicated to Mara, and the light of love she shines on us all. I'm only a humble acolyte, though. If you wish to avail yourself of Mara's blessing, you should speak with Dinya Balu or Maramal.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened to capturing Mercer alive?
output: From the moment you were struck with my poisoned arrow at Snow Veil Sanctum, my path changed its course. Perhaps I couldn't bring Mercer back alive, but together, we were able to clear my name and to put Gallus's memory to rest. I'd always intended Mercer's fate to ultimately be decided by the Guild, and it seems they've spoken.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So the Key unlocks any door?
output: All of us possess untapped abilities; the potential to wield great power, securely sealed within our minds. Well, yes. But the Key isn't only restricted to physical barriers. Once you realize the Key can access these traits, the potential becomes limitless.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: First time I ever set out to return something...
output: Very true. In our line of work, it's quite rare we set out to return a stolen item to its rightful owner.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He's done more?
output: Mercer was able to unlock the Guild's vault without two keys because of what he stole from the Twilight Sepulcher... the Skeleton Key. By doing this, he's compromised our ties to Nocturnal and in essence, caused our luck to run dry.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you make your own jewelry?
output: I do. Sadly, I'm one of the few traditional Saxhleel Jewelers that remains in Tamriel; it's becoming a lost art. Only trouble is gathering materials has become hazardous. The roads to the mines and to the other cities are thick with bandits... and worse. Would you be interested in gathering some materials for me? I'd certainly be happy to compensate you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Good luck with that.
output: The job pays well, so I hope I can make arrangements soon. We could really use the gold.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have your flawless sapphires.
output: Good, these will make wonderful settings for my rings.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did you need anything else?
output: No, I think I have enough here to get started. Here, let me give you this. It's the least I can do for all your trouble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could get it for you.
output: You would? Oh, that would be wonderful. Speak to Filnjar in Shor's Stone. He's got some sort of ore sample he wants us to identify and was willing to pay us well for it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Saxhleel?
output: Forgive me. It's a term I haven't used in some time. While most in Tamriel call my kind Argonian, we prefer the term Saxhleel.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Saxhleel?
output: Forgive me. It's a term I haven't used in some time. While most in Tamriel would call us Argonian, we prefer the term Saxhleel.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've brought the ore sample from Filnjar.
output: Thank you. I'll be sure to get Elgrim to examine this as soon as his... busy schedule allows. Here, I had him make you a few things for all that travel.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a chunk of gold ore for you.
output: Perfect. Melting this down will give me plenty of gold for those necklaces I started.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you jealous of her?
output: Oh! No, I didn't mean it that way. Elgrim can barely put his on his own shoes let alone have the energy to pursue a young girl. He's been gushing about how talented Ingun is at alchemy. He'd never say it to her face; that's not his way. I just think Elgrim's taken it upon himself to mentor the young thing so he focuses a lot of attention on her.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's so special about this ore?
output: Redbelly is supposed to be nothing but an iron mine. Been working it for years. Then right before the spiders had moved in, we found that chunk of ore. Never seen anything like it. I want to know what I'm dealing with before I start tearing it out of the ground.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you an alchemist as well?
output: I know how to mix a few basic potions, but I'm nowhere near as skilled as a master alchemist. I've picked up a few tricks by reading the tomes scattered all over the shop, but I don't have the knack to pull half of the formulas off.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a mammoth tusk for you.
output: The ivory from this tusk will be perfect for the inlay on my amulets.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does it bother you living underground?
output: When Elgrim said we were setting up shop down here, I told him he would catch his death. The dirt, the moisture... it's disgusting. Who wants to spend their life living like a skeever? But that old bellyacher just fed me some nonsense about light ruining his mixtures and being close to the water... agh.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm here for Elgrim's ore sample.
output: It's about time; I sent them a letter weeks ago. That Elgrim... he'd forget his own pants if his wife didn't help him dress. Here you go. Tell Hafjorg that she can chip off whatever she thinks is a fair trade for their time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You've got your hands full, eh?
output: I swear, if I wasn't around, Elgrim would forget to eat his meals. How we make any coin at all is beyond me. In fact, I need to arrange for someone to pick up an ore sample for me in Shor's Stone... goodness knows Elgrim won't lift a finger to do it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sure, I'll get them for you.
output: Thank you, marsh-friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sure, I'll get them for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do I open the door?
output: The whole of Whiterun is ripe with paranoia and tensions. The Jarl's court is right to fear the power I hold behind this door. The Jarl trusts few, and they will be his undoing. The dark child knows of what I speak. Let him guide your path.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry, I'm supposed to be meeting someone here.
output: I hope you're just playing dumb. I'm the one who left the note in Ustengrav.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: Yes. We're very old enemies. And if my suspicions are correct, they might have something to do with the dragons returning. But that isn't important right now. What is important is that you might be Dragonborn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was expecting someone... taller.
output: Good. The whole point of being in hiding is to appear to be someone you're not.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So I'm a bard?

What's more, Elisif has declared the Burning of King Olaf should become a weekly event. And finally, there's the matter of the Patronage that Elisif wanted me to give you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Festival is back on.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: I appreciate your help. Please, take this. Some gold I've saved up from working at the mill.

output: Camilla Valerius knows I'm the best man in Riverwood. That elf is kidding himself if he thinks she would choose him over me. I've seen him sneaking over to the Riverwood Trader to speak with her when I'm not around. He's wasting his time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes. Two people spending time together never blossoms into courtship.
output: Is that sarcasm? I've heard better wisecracks from Orgnar. Still, you have a point. Camilla letting Faendal visit her isn't a good thing for me. Here, let me give you a particularly venomous letter. Say it's from Faendal. That should get Camilla to stop inviting the elf over.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's your problem with Sven?
output: He's a bard, so he says. Occasionally he finds time to do his job here at the mill. Thinks his ballads and sonnets are going to convince Camilla Valerius to marry him. As if she would say "yes." An intelligent, beautiful woman like her wouldn't fall for that nonsense... I hope.
