instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do I get a black soul gem?
output: They are rare things, I have one I picked up during my research of the Oblivion realms but it is a precious item.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can you be so sure I'm a vampire?
output: I met several of your kind during my studies of life-extending magics. I even  considered becoming a vampire myself. In the end, vampirism would endanger my ward Agni which would defeat the intended purpose.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for a cure.
output: It requires a filled black soul gem. You will need to kill someone. When you have a gem and have filled it return to me and I will perform the ritual. I will bring life to your dead body, vampire.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Jarl has been appeased.
output: Very good. I hope this will allow us to maintain our reputation.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Nirya wanted me to steal your notes.
output: She what? Oh, I should've known she'd try it again! Thanks for warning me. I'll see to it this is taken care of.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You look like you could use some help.
output: Well, I suppose I could use a hand with something, yes. Faralda's working on something, and I want to know what it is. I want her notes. You think you could get them for me, without her knowing?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Isn't that stealing?
output: Yes, yes it is. You have a problem with that? Look, either you get the notes or I'll figure out another way to do it. Just come find me if you can get your hands on them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here are the notes you wanted.
output: Good, good. She didn't see you take them? Al right, this should be enough to figure out what she's up to. Then I can make sure it doesn't work. Good work. Here, take this, and keep quiet.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's in it for me?
output: I'll throw some money at you. Good enough? Just get the notes and bring them to me. If you can't do it, I'll find some other way to manage it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a filled black soul gem.
output: Very well. Meet me at the summoning circle in the marsh at dawn. We shall banish the creature you have become.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's get this over with.
output: Stand in the center of the circle.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want to purchase your black soul gem. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: I would not sell it to just anyone but I'll make an exception for you. The cost to replace the gem is quite high.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So, I'm no longer a vampire?
output: You are human again. Like the rest of us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The dragon is dead.
output: That may be true, but I ordered Irileth to bring back proof. You'd best report back to her at once.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd rather scout ahead.
output: Good enough. We'll meet up near the watchtower. Don't take any chances until we get there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are your orders?
output: That was the hairiest fight I've ever been in, and I've been in more than a few. I don't know about this Dragonborn business, but I'm sure glad you're with us. You better get back to Whiterun right away. Jarl Balgruuf will want to know what happened here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are your orders?
output: I'm taking command here for the moment. You head back to Whiterun and let the Jarl know what happened.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are your orders?
output: We'd better go make sure that bastard is really dead. Collect us a trophy or something to bring back to Ulfric.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are your orders?
output: Scatter and get behind cover! We need to hurt it, somehow! If you've got a bow or spells, now would be a good time to use them!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What evil do you mean?
output: We stand at the tomb of Hevnoraak, who has been dead for many generations. I fear, however, that his return may be at hand.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then I will help you. What must be done?
output: You would do this? Three vessels in the tomb below hold the power to vanquish Hevnoraak. Before anything else, we need those. Bring them to me - but be careful, mortal. They are guarded by Hevnoraak's minions. They will stop at nothing to see their master return.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There must be a way to stop this.
output: I have been holding him here. While he regains strength, however, I am fading.  By now I can barely contain his power, much less defeat him if he awakens. But with the help of a living champion I may be able to succeed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: This is pointless. I should just kill you and be done with it.
output: You think so? Let's see who the real woman is here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do these Greybeards want with me?
output: The Dragonborn is said to be uniquely gifted in the Voice - the ability to focus your vital essence into a Thu'um, or Shout. The Greybeards are masters of the Way of the Voice. If you really are Dragonborn, they can teach you how to use your gift.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I killed the dragon. I think I deserve a reward.
output: There's no question about that. It was a mighty deed. You've earned a place of honor among the heroes of Whiterun. But there must be more to it than that. Did something... strange... happen when the dragon died?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The watchtower was destroyed, but we killed the dragon.
output: I knew I could count on Irileth. But there must be more to it than that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: When the dragon died, I absorbed some kind of power from it.
output: So it's true. The Greybeards really were summoning you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Turns out I may be something called "Dragonborn."
output: Dragonborn? What do you know about the Dragonborn?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's just what the men called me.
output: Not just the men. The Greybeards seem to think the same thing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Greybeards?
output: Masters of the Way of the Voice. They live in seclusion high on the slopes of the Throat of the World.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Vilkas said you can still be cured.
output: Did he now? I can only hope. You still have the witches' heads? Excellent. Throw one of them into the fire. It will release their magic, for me at least.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Nothing I couldn't handle.
output: That's the spirit. I'll get all the details from Galmar when he gets back. Now then...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We lost a lot of good men. I hope it was worth it.
output: The blood of our fallen heroes will make Skyrim free, never doubt it. Also, never doubt me or Galmar. Now then...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Imperials were there ahead of us.
output: Damn it. What were they doing there? Imperial spies are everywhere. Never forget that...  I trust you gave them a thrashing? Now then...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So why are they hunting you?
output: We hurt them in the past, and they have long memories.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Thalmor?
output: Hmm. There's no simple answer to that. You want the long version or the short version?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So what's your plan? How do I infiltrate the Thalmor Embassy?
output: I can get you into one of those parties. Once you're inside the Embassy, you get away and find Elenwen's secret files. I have a contact inside the Embassy. He's not up for this kind of high-risk mission, but he can help you. His name's Malborn. Wood elf, plenty of reason to hate the Thalmor. You can trust him. I'll get word for him to meet you in Solitude, at the Winking Skeever -- you know it? While you're doing that, I'll work on getting you an invitation to Elenwen's little party. Meet me at the Solitude stables after you've arranged things with Malborn. Any questions? The Thalmor ambassador, Elenwen, regularly throws parties where the rich and connected cozy up to the Thalmor.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So, we need to find out what the Thalmor know about the dragons. Any ideas?
output: If we could get into the Thalmor Embassy... it's the center of their operations in Skyrim... Problem is, that place is locked up tighter than a miser's purse. They could teach me a few things about paranoia...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: I am called Boethiah. Many names have mortals given me. But I am not interested in names. I am interested only in deeds.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: My reasons are my own.
output: I abide only those whose will is aligned to my own. Those who oppose my desires perish in the most dreadful of ways. I have a purpose for which you might prove useful. But first I must test the deftness of your guile, and the strength of your purpose. Make a thrall. Lure him to my shrine. Prove your will is stronger. Convince him to embrace the Pillar of Sacrifice, and then slay him without mercy. Do this and I shall remember you and bestow an important task upon you. Do this not, and I shall forget you, and your soul will waste in obscurity.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here. Have a gold piece. (1 gold)
output: Oh, thank you! Divines bless your kind heart. Oh, thank you! Divines bless your kind heart. Oh, thank you! Divines bless your kind heart. Oh, thank you! Divines bless your kind heart. Oh, thank you! Divines bless your kind heart. Oh, thank you! Divines bless your kind heart.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: I am sworn to carry your burdens. I am sworn to carry your burdens. I am sworn to carry your burdens. I am sworn to carry your burdens. I am sworn to carry your burdens. I am sworn to carry your burdens.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And that's where I come in?
output: I need you to retrieve the poem. Yes. According to Giraud, our histories keeper, the portion of the Edda dealing with King Olaf might still exist in Dead Man's Respite.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: My reasons are my own.
output: Indeed. But I abide only those whose will is aligned to my own. Those who oppose my desires perish in the most dreadful of ways.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: A god? Assuredly not! When was the last time you saw evidence of Aedra in the world? No, we Daedra are far more powerful than any god. And among my brethren, I am the most feared.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not afraid of you.
output: Is that so? You should be. Though a heart without fear is something I can use... Perhaps you are the one I seek. We shall soon find out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about the Forsworn?
output: Only that they break an old woman's heart. So many friends, so many kin, all lost trying to rebuild a past that was over long ago.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was looking for you, actually.
output: I told you I'm not hiring any more guards. Why do you people always bother me when I'm trying to finish my research?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't have time. Sorry.
output: Fair enough.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You said something about Talos.
output: That's a true Nord hero. A legend. So great that the Divines themselves lifted his soul into the heavens and made him a god.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Would some coin help? (<BribeCost> gold)
output: Well, the Priesthood of Arkay always accepts generous donations.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Would some coin help? (<BribeCost> gold)
output: That's not going to work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you a wizard? I wanted to buy some spells.
output: Magic. That's what they always want. Never history. Never the secrets of the lost races. No, just little spells and enchantments.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll bring one if I find it.
output: Thanks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't know what you're talking about.
output: There's a war on and you don't know what I'm talking about? The Empire is destroying everything Skyrim stands for. Jarl Igmund can refuse to see me all he wants. The Silver-Blood family will be heard.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Excavation site?
output: Nchuand-Zel? The ruins underneath Markarth? The wealth of artifacts that I've based two human lifetimes of research on?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm no friend of the Imperials.
output: Finally, someone with decent sense. The Empire is destroying everything Skyrim stands for. Honor. Pride. Mighty Talos. Jarl Igmund can't ignore us for much longer. Not if the Silver-Blood family has a say.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could help if you tell me. (Persuade)
output: All right. I was going to suggest the Jarl hire someone to sort this mess out, anyway.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's wrong with your apprentice?
output: Tacitus? Boy's an Imperial. I keep showing him how to treat the iron, but he never gets it. In the Legion, the Imperial smiths used to read books when they couldn't set their hammers straight. Wisdom of the old, I guess. If you find a book called "The Last Scabbard of Akrash," could you bring it to me? Tacitus sure isn't learning by example.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's Arkay?
output: Arkay. One of the Eight Divines. God of the Cycle of Birth and Death. It is his shrine people pray to when they visit the Hall. That his divinity will watch over their ancestors on the way to the next life.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ulfric saved Markarth? How?
output: He used the Thu'um. Shouted those Forsworn from the walls. Then he led a band of Nord warriors in to take the city. Just like Talos himself at the Battle of Old Hroldan, reclaiming the Reach from those heathen natives.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's the book you wanted.
output: Books. Don't know why the Imperials like these so much. This should help the boy, though, Malacath willing. Here, let me show you how an Orc learns to smith.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the Hall of the Dead?
output: New to Skyrim? I was confused at first, too. The Nords call their mausoleums the Hall of the Dead. It's where people in the city are buried. Fathers. Forefathers. Mothers. Foremothers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I support the Empire. What of it?
output: What of it, he says. Your Empire is destroying everything Skyrim stands for. Honor. Pride. Mighty Talos.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I support the Empire. What of it?
output: What of it, she says. Your Empire is destroying everything Skyrim stands for. Honor. Pride. Mighty Talos.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's this about elves?
output: They started the Great War. Nearly destroyed the Imperial City. Then the Emperor took the coward's way out and surrendered. Now the Elves dictate everything we do, and they don't want us acknowledging a "mere human" like Talos as the god he is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's this about elves?
output: Your kind started the Great War. Nearly destroyed the Imperial City. Then the Emperor took the coward's way out and surrendered. Now you people dictate everything we do. Don't want us acknowledging a "mere human" like Talos as the god he is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't have time right now.
output: Very well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why should the Jarl listen to you?
output: We own Cidhna Mine. Best prison in Skyrim, and source of half the wealth in this city. We keep the Reach safe. We flood Markarth with wealth, but does the Jarl listen to us when we want a say? No.  He's busy forgetting that Ulfric Stormcloak saved this city from the Forsworn. Ulfric's a hero, not a damn criminal.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll come back later, then.
output: Arkay keep you and protect you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll make sure he gets it.
output: Thank you. He can be a bit difficult, but I'm sure he'll appreciate your help.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any burglary jobs?
output: Pretty simple. Break into a house, grab a specific item and get out before they realize what's going on. The catch is you can't kill anyone who lives there or you forfeit the payment. You ready for some good old-fashioned burglary?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any burglary jobs?
output: We're looking to recover an heirloom for a client. They claim ownership of it, and as long as they're paying we don't really care. You in?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any burglary jobs?
output: We've been trying to get this item for a while, but no one with the skills has come along to claim it. Can I count on you to get it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any burglary jobs?
output: Have a house with a good bit of valuables inside, but one particular item's caught my eye. You up for it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any burglary jobs?
output: Got a tip on a desirable item at this location. We want you to break in there and bring it to us. What do you think?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any burglary jobs?
output: Good, got a buyer in a rush for this item. If you hurry we can turn it around and make a quick profit. Can you get it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any burglary jobs?
output: Sure, sure. We're always looking to get our hands on items from all over Skyrim. How about this one?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any burglary jobs?
output: As long as you can keep things quiet and don't get yourself killed in the process, this place has exactly what we're looking for. You in?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any burglary jobs?
output: We've actually stolen this item before and somehow it ended up back in some other mark's house. Guess it's time to reclaim it, eh?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You caught me. I'll pay off my bounty. (<CrimeGold> gold)
output: Smart woman. Now come along with us. We'll take any stolen goods, and you'll be free to go. After you pay the fine, of course. Smart woman. Now come along with us. We'll take any stolen goods, and you'll be free to go. After you pay the fine, of course. Smart woman. Now come along with us. We'll take any stolen goods, and you'll be free to go. After you pay the fine, of course. Smart woman. Now come along with us. We'll take any stolen goods, and you'll be free to go. After you pay the fine, of course. Smart woman. Now come along with us. We'll take any stolen goods, and you'll be free to go. After you pay the fine, of course. Smart woman. Now come along with us. We'll take any stolen goods, and you'll be free to go. After you pay the fine, of course. Smart woman. Now come along with us. We'll take any stolen goods, and you'll be free to go. After you pay the fine, of course.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd rather die than go to prison!
output: Then suffer the Emperor's wrath. Then suffer the Emperor's wrath. Then suffer the Emperor's wrath. Then suffer the Emperor's wrath. Then suffer the Emperor's wrath. Then suffer the Emperor's wrath. Then suffer the Emperor's wrath.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd rather die than go to prison!
output: Then let me speed your passage to Sovngarde! Then let me speed your passage to Sovngarde! Then let me speed your passage to Sovngarde! Then let me speed your passage to Sovngarde!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd rather die than go to prison!
output: That can be arranged. That can be arranged. That can be arranged. That can be arranged. That can be arranged. That can be arranged. That can be arranged.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I cleared the mine of draugr.
output: You did? We were waiting for the Jarl to send an entire regiment to clear that mine. Now we can get back to work. Thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The mine isn't safe? Why?
output: We tunneled into an old Nordic crypt. The whole place is crawling with draugr. We're not mining up any ore with those undead around, so I wouldn't go down there if I were you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any shill jobs?
output: When a client needs us to eliminate another, we don't operate like the Dark Brotherhood. We find alternate means to get them out of the way. We send you to plant some phony evidence in the mark's house, and then tip off the town guard... the rest takes care of itself. Sound like you can handle it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any shill jobs?
output: Someone wants to see this mark suffer. They're paying a good bit of coin to have us plant the evidence in their house. You in?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any shill jobs?
output: This one should be easy. Get in, plant the goods and get out. Quiet and neat. Sound like your kind of job?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any shill jobs?
output: The mark must have ticked-off our client badly. He's impatient and keeps asking if the job's done. Can you get him off my back?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any shill jobs?
output: Got a good one here. Personal score to settle between myself and this mark. You up for it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any shill jobs?
output: Brynjolf finally got some dirt on the mark and the evidence to back it up. Think you can give him a hand?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any shill jobs?
output: This one angered someone pretty high up in the keep. Can I count on you to get this done for me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any shill jobs?
output: Got another personal score to settle and I'd consider it a favor if you'd take the job. Think you can help me out?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any shill jobs?
output: Sure, sure. Got one that should be pretty easy, as long as you keep your weapon sheathed. Can you handle it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any shill jobs?
output: Yeah. Someone ticked off Maven and she wants to teach them a lesson... our way. You in?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any numbers jobs?
output: Most of the establishments in Skyrim keep their transactions recorded within business ledgers. Your job would be to change the numbers in those books so the shortfalls from our other jobs look legit. Feel like doing a bit of writin'?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any numbers jobs?
output: This business is a regular target for the Guild. They keep pretty shoddy records, so the job should be a cinch. You in?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any numbers jobs?
output: We want to waylay a shipment on the way from this business without them even noticin' anything went missin'. Want the job?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any numbers jobs?
output: Yeah, sure. Got a business on tap that could use a little number rearrangin'. What do you say?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any numbers jobs?
output: Okay, got just the one for you. Ledger's just beggin' to be changed and the Guild could use the coin. How about it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any numbers jobs?
output: Have a client lookin' to have a rival's business ledger changed. Don't know the reason, and don't want to know. Count you in?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any numbers jobs?
output: Got a personal request from Brynjolf on this numbers job. He says we may hit 'em hard later, and wants to prep their books. Help us out?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any numbers jobs?
output: These marks keep their ledger all neat and tidy, but they're ripe for some change if you know what I mean. Take it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any numbers jobs?
output: All right. Got a simple one. Just get in, change the books and be back in time for last call. So how's about it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any fishing jobs?
output: There are all sorts of people wandering around carryin' their valuables on their person... just waitin' for someone like you to pick their pocket. So, you in for a little fishin'?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any fishing jobs?
output: Sure, I've got a mark for you. Stole something quite important from a friend of the Guild and we take care of our own. You in?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any fishing jobs?
output: One of our marks seems to have an item of value we want to add to our vault. Get it for us and you'll receive the usual pay. Sound good?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any fishing jobs?
output: Got ourselves a freelancer thinks he can muscle in on our territory. How about you teach him some manners, eh?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any fishing jobs?
output: Maven wants this mark's most prized possession. The bloody fool carries it on his person all the time. So, think you can handle it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any fishing jobs?
output: Brynjolf want's this mark's head on a pike, but we'll settle for what the bastard's carryin' instead. Can I count on you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any fishing jobs?
output: Got a mark taxed with carryin' a heavy item. Care to lighten' the load?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any fishing jobs?
output: This brilliant soul decided to pick a fight with a fellow Guild mate. Time for them to pay the piper. Will you help out?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any fishing jobs?
output: I've got a mark who just got an item from a relative outside of Skyrim. They probably should have been quieter about it. You in?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What should we do?
output: Gods above! Look at that!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So you want me to put out the Lighthouse fire?
output: What an interesting idea. I think if someone were to do something like that, there would definitely be a certain amount of loot to be shared... Yes, if someone were to put out the Lighthouse fire and then meet me on the docks afterwards... I could certainly direct them to that loot.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do you wish to die?
output: My time has come. I am old. Too old to become chief. It would be wrong for me to take wives at this age. So I will die. Malacath has given me a vision of a glorious death. I am to wait here until it finds me. As you can see, it has not yet arrived.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yeah, he went that way.
output: Great! Thanks! Bastard stole from me. I'll catch him though!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I presume this <Alias=Loot> belongs to you?
output: Yes! How'd you get this? Never mind, here. It's not much, but its something.  I'm going to track down that thief and murder him!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, I am sure. I will give you a good death.
output: Hmm. We shall see.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Perhaps I could give you the death you seek?
output: Perhaps...  Are you sure about this?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, didn't see anyone. (Lie)
output: Well, if you do, grab him and yell. Bastard stole from me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You don't look that old to me. Certainly you're still a strong, capable warrior.
output: Indeed. One should find his death while he can still call himself a proper man. We Orc men are not like these Nords and Imperials who carry on until they are grey and feeble and their hair falls out. To cling to something past its usefulness is unseemly, how much more so when that thing is you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: A good death?
output: Yes. Were I to simply lay down and die, it would not please Malacath.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm going to put it on Olaf's Effigy.
output: What?! This is exactly why... don't they understand it's hard enough to fight a war without these juvenile attempts to undermine authority?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Festival is back on.
output: I'll tell everyone we're ready but we'll start the festival at dusk. Come talk to me after dark, we'll get the festival started when you do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need your coat.
output: My coat? What do you need my coat for?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's all in good fun, Tullius.
output: If you say so. If this were anyone but you I would lock them up. Take it. Take the coat, have your fun. I'll see you at the festival.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I haven't found the mask yet.
output: Well then, what are you waiting for? Get in there and earn your pay.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've found the journal of Skorm Snow-Strider.
output: And what? You couldn't read it yourself? Fine, give it here a moment.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So how do I open the door?
output: I told you, I know everything about this castle. For some reason that door is special. Only two people can open it, Balgruuf and Farengar, the court wizard. How you get it from them is up to you. Nobody would notice if Farengar went missing, I promise you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could look into it for you.
output: I don't even care any more. You want to check it out? Fine. I'll sell you the thing for fifty gold, and then it's your problem.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll take that claw for 50 gold.
output: Fine, here you go. You get killed on account of this thing, it's not my fault. Got it? But, I suppose, if it does actually turn out to be worth something, let me know, will you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll take that claw for 50 gold.
output: Oh, I'd gladly sell it to you if you had the money. But you don't, do you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You said something about a bad deal?
output: Yeah, it was stupid of me. I shouldn't have believed the story and just refused the trade. But I didn't, and now I'm stuck with this worthless junk.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What was the story?
output: Some line about this claw thing and Yngol Barrow. He said it was worth more than its weight in gold if I took it back there. What was I thinking? Even if it were true, I'm not setting foot in some ancient tomb, filled with who knows what. Something about placing it back in Yngol's chamber, I don't know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you get much business way up here?
output: So I'll sell whatever I can. If it's worth putting a price on, you can bet I'll do it. Very funny. I'm sure you've noticed that Winterhold isn't exactly overflowing with people.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Never mind. I think she wants a more cultured man.
output: If that's what she wants, then that's what she'll get.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there anyone who knows what she likes?
output: There is one... Yngvar. He's quite popular with the ladies. Thankfully Faleen is not quite his type, but they've been friends for some time, and he may have some ideas. Please, ask him what she likes. It's my only chance.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I mean that you should be bold.
output: Wait... you mean I should just... tell her? Tell her how I feel?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want you and your men to leave.
output: Helping out Ainethach, huh? Give me a reason not to plunge a dagger in your chest.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think you should sell the mine.
output: No. This is my land. You expect me to just hand it over to those Silver-Blood thugs?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Silver-Bloods?
output: You haven't heard of the Silver-Blood family? They're the most important people in the Reach. They practically own the city of Markarth. And we're here on their coin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why have you shut down the mine?
output: Forsworn attacked a while back. Jarl had no men to spare, so the Silver-Bloods generously offered to send us to clean things up. We just want that old native to hand over his land in payment for our services. Then we'll leave, and everyone can get back to work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Those sellswords won't be a problem now.
output: That won't be the last we hear from the Silver-Bloods, but at least we can get back to work. Thank you. You've done a good thing for me and my workers. Here. This is for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Silver-Bloods?
output: A family of thieves. Running their corrupt empire from Markarth. The Silver-Blood family own half the Reach, and they won't stop until they own all of it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Trouble with the mine?
output: Robbery is what it is. The Silver-Bloods are trying to muscle in on my land. Forsworn attack the mines, and suddenly all these sellswords show up to "help." They won't let anyone work until I sell it off.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who else is in the family?
output: Well, there's Ingun Black-Briar, Maven's daughter. Strange girl. She likes to spend time down in Elgrim's Elixirs working on her alchemy. Then you have Hemming, Maven's son; spoiled brat and heir to her empire. He follows her word like a loyal dog follows its master. And finally, Sibbi; the worst of all of them. He's in Riften Jail for murder.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about the Black-Briar family.
output: Maven Black-Briar, the matriarch of the family, represents everything that's wrong with this city. She's bribed countless officials, has friends back in the Imperial City and freely associates with the Thieves Guild. I've tried everything I can to protect Riften's citizens from her family, but to no avail.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're not from the Reach?
output: No. I'm a Breton from High Rock, and I refuse to be mistaken for a filthy native.  I don't care if we share the same ancestors, these people are savages. Half of them are Forsworn barbarians, and have you seen what they eat? What have I done for the gods to take me so far from my beloved Daggerfall?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Thalmor?
output: We're the ruling body of the Aldmeri Dominion. Saviors of Mer. Victors of the Great War. The Empire exists because we allow it to exist, and I'm here to make sure the Jarl of Markarth remembers that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you mean "saviors of Mer"?
output: The Thalmor saved all of Elven-kind during the Oblivion Crisis. We've been watching over our lands for 200 years. We re-founded the Aldmeri Dominion, an alliance between us and our Bosmer cousins. You might know them from their common name. Wood elves. We intend to prove the superiority of Mer over Man, one century at a time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Not right now.
output: Hmph. Fine.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No. Sorry.
output: Very well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm interested. What is it?
output: Ogmund the skald. He's old, respected, and I know for a fact that he worships Talos in his home. But the Jarl has been hesitant to call for his arrest. I want you to break in to his home and find evidence.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Deal.
output: Good hunting.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found this amulet in Ogmund's house.
output: Ah, there we have it. This will be all I need to have Ogmund taken care of.  I would like to personally thank you on behalf of myself and the Thalmor for your assistance. Here, for your work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm thinking of buying some armor. Any recommendations?
output: Depends on what you need. A light armor is good for travel. Less to carry. A heavy armor weighs you down, but no true warrior goes without it. If you want some heavy armor, I might have a deal we could work out. I need a Daedra's Heart. Jarl wants me to cool his new sword in blood. You get me a heart, I get you some armor. Interested?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why are you after Talos worshippers?
output: It's a religious matter. The Thalmor do not recognize Talos as a god. He was only a man, and does not deserve to a place in our pantheon. The Empire has agreed to accept our beliefs, and its citizens have a responsibility to cease their heretical worship. You're awfully inquisitive, aren't you? I like that. Perhaps you'd care to solve a little problem I'm having?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're married to Thonar? What's he like?
output: He's the real head of this family. He may not be the eldest, but all the work that keeps us respected is handled by my Thonar.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What kind of weapons do you forge?
output: Anything. Served in the Legion with my sister, Ghorza, for over 10 years. We've seen every piece you can imagine. Have you met her? She runs the forge near the smelter. Just don't bother talking to her apprentice. Boy has no talent.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're not from Markarth, I take it?
output: As if this craggy, wretch of a city could give birth to a superiorly bred Mer such as myself. No, I'm not from Markarth. I was sent here to lead the Thalmor's interests in this corner of Skyrim. It's my mission to root out all Talos worship in this city.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have your daedra's heart.
output: Good. I'd prefer using water to cool my metal, but it's what the Jarl wants. Here. Some of my best armor. Wear it well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll go see Bryling for you.
output: You're doing me quite a favor. I won't forget it. I'm sure she'll be angry. Brace yourself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can't you reason with her?
output: Can't do that and keep an eye on things here at the same time. But... You could take word to her in Solitude, let her know it'll be coming soon. I'd make it worth your while. No one would notice a few missing ingots out of the next shipment.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there any way I can help?
output: You could take word to her that there'll be a shipment soon. Buy us some time and keep her off our backs. In exchange, I'm willing to let a few ingots go missing. Maybe more than a few.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Everything is fine. The shipment will be here soon.
output: That's good news. I was starting to fear something had happened. You have my thanks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you get many offers?
output: Well, no. But that's not the point. Bryling owns the mine, and she's not selling. We make her some decent coin running this place. Keeps her living well in Solitude. At least, when we can get shipments to her. We're late on the last one. I expect her to start breathin' fire any moment now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Pactur asked me to deliver a message.
output: Is everything all right? I've not heard from Sorli or Pactur in some time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I wasn't asking.
output: I'm just protecting Bryling's investment. She's the owner, even though we're the ones here doing all the work. She's already come down hard on us for missing shipments. Likely to do it again, since we're late.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you own the mine?
output: No, and before you ask, it's not for sale.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe some other time.
output: Won't be 'some other time' at this rate.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there a story behind that burned down house?
output: Hroggar's house fire? Aye. He lost his wife and daughter in the blaze.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does this finally mean peace?
output: The fiercest of the remaining rebels will continue to harass us, but by in large, the people here desire peace. What I'm not so sure about is the peace we've made with the Thalmor. But we'll keep that between the two of us, alright?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does this finally mean peace?
output: There are those who still call themselves Stormcloaks, who continue to fight us, and bring misery to the people... but they are few in number. And they should enjoy it while they can... I suspect all of Tamriel will again be called to arms in the not too distant future. The ordinary citizen will be happy to get back to life as normal, to have their families return home.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does this finally mean peace?
output: Because getting rid of the Empire was only half the problem.  There will be peace for a time, during which we must rebuild Skyrim into the land it once was. Strong. Self-reliant. The center of mankind. For it will be Skyrim that shall lead Tamriel in those dark days, when the fate of the world is finally determined. Soon, the elves will again seek to rule the world. We must ready ourselves to fight them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

It's who we are, it's in our blood. It'll be Skyrim that leads the charge. Mark my words. And that time around, mankind will either succeed once and for all or die trying. It's only a matter of time before their pointy ears start itching to rule the world again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there anything further I can do...?
output: That said, Stormcloak true believers are still operating out of hidden military camps in the hills. If you encounter any on you travels, kill them. There's not much more I could ask of you. The gods, however, I suspect, may have plans for you elsewhere.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there anything further I can do...?
output: The Legion's work is far from finished, but you are free to roam. I suspect you'll be of greater good to Skyrim out there, in the world. If while you're out there, you stumble into any Stormcloak military camps, I expect you to destroy them. I've reports they are hiding in the hills.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there anything further I can do...?

That said, some of the Legion's staunchest men have organized themselves, and are operating out of hidden military camps in the wilderness. True sons and daughters of Skyrim reign in every city, we've crippled the Imperial Legion, and cut off its head by killing General Tullius himself. If you come across any Imperials in your travels, I expect you'll know what to do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's next for you?
output: No, I suspect Skyrim to be my home for many years. Can't say I'll ever get used to the damn cold, or understand these Nords... but, I've come to respect them. The harshness of Skyrim has a way of carving a man down to his true self.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's next for you?
output: The General's put me in charge of assisting the new governments. I may understand things here in Skyrim better than the General, but I'm a soldier at heart, not a politician. But I'll do my best. This is the land of my birth, the land that shaped me. I'm proud to have any part in making it strong again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

The new Jarls need help building armies, and enforcing their right to rule. The Empire may try to reclaim Skyrim, and I need everyone ready for that. Though the biggest threat, of course, is the elves.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

The Empire might send over a few Legionnaires to make sure we're serious, and of course, we'll be taking the fight to the elves soon enough. We'll need trained, disciplined and creative warriors ready for all that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What brings you to this party?
output: You must be new around here. Bad manners to ask such a direct question, at one of Elenwen's little soirees. But I have nothing to hide. I'm in from the south, on business. And if you want to do business in Tamriel these days, well, you'd better get used to cozying up to the Thalmor. Like it or not.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't worry, I just want to play a joke on someone. (Persuade)
output: Well. Anything to relieve the boredom. As long as it doesn't get back to me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You look thirsty.
output: Ah, the nectar of the gods! If there's ever anything I can do for you, just name it!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You look thirsty.
output: Indeed. Being a drunken boor is thirsty work. And I can't seem to find my way back to the bar...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: If the parties bore you, why attend them?
output: The East Empire Company has interests all across Tamriel, inside and outside the Empire's borders. We try not to get involved in politics. However, as the head of the company it's my job to make sure we maintain good relationships with prospective partners and investors.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've decided to help you end the nightmares.
output: Mara be praised! Nightcaller Temple is only a short walk from Dawnstar. Come, we must hurry.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry, I can't.
output: I understand. If you should change your mind, I'll be here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then leave. This isn't your problem.
output: Turn my back on these people when their lives could be at stake? I should say not. Those dreams are not just visions, they're a footprint left by the Daedric Lord Vaermina as she drains these people of their memories!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't be ridiculous. Dreams are harmless.
output: In any other circumstance, I'd agree with you. However, these aren't normal dreams. The Daedric Lord Vaermina's voracious hunger for memories is responsible for these visions. The nightmares are an echo of her presence as she feeds.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does she do with the memories?
output: Who can say? Perhaps she collects them for display like works of art in a nonsensical art gallery. Whatever the case may be, her intentions are far from benevolent.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, we haven't.
output: Then allow me to introduce myself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, we haven't.
output: I am Savos Aren, Arch-Mage of the College of Winterhold. I am quite content to see nearly any aspect of magic explored and investigated here. But I do not and will not approve of any research or experiments that cause purposeful harm to your fellow members of the College. Are we clear?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can't you do it for me?
output: No. No I can't. I have enough to keep me busy. View it as a chance to hone your craft.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Thanks for nothing.
output: My pleasure.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Dangerous research must be a problem here.
output: Not often, no. Some risks must be taken, to be sure. I am simply trying to avoid untimely deaths. We also must make an effort to avoid worsening what Skyrim thinks of us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need something enchanted.
output: I'm sure you can figure it out on your own. If you can't, perhaps Urag has a book you can read.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like training in Alchemy.
output: I can teach you, but I won't be held responsible for what you do with the knowledge.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, sir.
output: "Sir"? How quaint.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need something enchanted.
output: Well, there's an Imbuer here in the Great Hall.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need something enchanted.
output: Well, there's an Imbuer in the Great Hall.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Reporting for duty.
output: I'm in the middle of something. But don't go far. I'll need you soon. I'm in the middle of something. But don't go far. I'll need you soon.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Reporting for duty.
output: I've got my hands full with something. Don't go far. I'll need you soon. I've got my hands full with something. Don't go far. I'll need you soon. I've got my hands full with something. Don't go far. I'll need you soon.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for work.
output: Yes. I have something a little different planned this time. But it's not for everyone to hear. Meet me in the Underforge tonight. We will speak more.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Anything you can tell me about High Hrothgar?
output: The Greybeards are a solitary lot. I don't think they've ever ventured outside their monastery. We get the occasional pilgrim passing through here on their way to the summit, but almost all of them have returned disappointed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Anything you can tell me about High Hrothgar?
output: I've been to the monastery many times, but I've never even laid eyes on one of the Greybeards. Not that I'd care to. Being masters of the Thu'um, they could kill you by uttering a single word. Well, not that they would. They seem peaceful, but I wouldn't want to provoke them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Anything you can tell me about High Hrothgar?
output: Other than that, they seem like a quiet lot. Don't really know too much about them. Klimmek brings food supplies up to them once every few weeks when the weather permits it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Anything you can tell me about High Hrothgar?
output: It's frightening living below their monastery. Sometimes I swear I can hear strange noises rolling down from up there. It sounds like thunder, but there's never any rain. What do you make of that?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Anything you can tell me about High Hrothgar?
output: The Greybeards stay away from me, and I stay away from them. Suits me just fine.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Anything you can tell me about High Hrothgar?
output: Always thought it was odd that there's a layer of thick clouds covering the peak of the mountain above the monastery. Not sure what's up there, but I bet the Greybeards know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Anything you can tell me about High Hrothgar?
output: They call the path to the monastery the 7,000 Steps. Can you imagine? I'm not certain if I could even make it to the top without collapsing from exhaustion.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Anything you can tell me about High Hrothgar?
output: The Greybeards are a strange bunch. I heard they live their entire life without uttering a single word; can you even imagine?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Anything you can tell me about High Hrothgar?
output: I've always fancied a journey up the 7,000 Steps to the monastery. Anything to break the boredom of living in this town. I envy you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was sent by Louis Letrush.
output: Ah, and let me guess. He wants his horse. Well, that's going to be a bit of a problem. You see, I don't really outright "own" Frost...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why is Sibbi in jail?
output: No idea, but whatever he did it must have angered Maven. No guard would lock up a Black-Briar without the old lady's permission.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That sounds acceptable.
output: Then I think we're done talking.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You don't own the horse you already sold to Letrush?
output: That is correct. You see, Frost belongs to the Black-Briar estate. Technically everything in the estate is owned by my mother, Maven. My plan was to take the horse from our lodge and deliver it to Letrush at the stables. Obviously, that didn't exactly work out as I'd planned... Still, I don't want to cross Letrush. Tell you what. Steal the horse and deliver it, and you can have the second half of the payment.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you aware there's a plot to steal Frost?
output: I'm aware of who stole Frost. And why.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I promise. Just a joke I want to play on someone. (Persuade)
output: Hmm. Very well. I'm putting my reputation on the line for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Never mind.
output: Don't presume upon our friendship. My first loyalty is to the Thalmor, as you well know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What brings you to this party?
output: To maintain relationships. By the way, I don't know who you are, but unless you want me to blow your cover, I'd advise that you avoid me for the rest of the party.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need your help with something.
output: I'm listening.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need your help with something.
output: What is it, my friend?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need you to cause a scene. Get everyone's attention for a few minutes.
output: That's it? Sure. Shouldn't be too hard. I usually end up making a fool out of myself without even trying.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need you to cause a scene. Get everyone's attention for a few minutes.
output: This is very irregular. I trust that whatever you're doing doesn't compromise my position in any way?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What brings you to this party?
output: There are those in the Empire who would wish to evade their obligations to help root out the Talos heresy. I am here to remind the ruling classes of Skyrim that their loyalty to the Emperor requires cooperation with the Thalmor. Fortunately, those most opposed to the Emperor's wise policy have now branded themselves traitors as well as heretics.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I can handle this on my own.
output: Are you quite sure? I don't want to get in the way, but...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I thought you wanted to get out of there.
output: Well yes, I did. And thank you so much for helping me. But... I rather thought that if I were to help, I might... Well, I might be allowed to return to the College. I'm not sure where else I'd go.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: All right, you're safe now.
output: Wait, what? I thought I was going to help you!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can you make me Blood-Kin?
output: Trust like that is not freely given. Trust like that is not freely given.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are all the Orc strongholds guarded?
output: The most well known stronghold is Dushnikh Yal. Here, I'll mark it down for you. The most well known stronghold is Dushnikh Yal. Here, I'll mark it down for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Hjalti? Who are you talking about?
output: You promised me, Hjalti. You promised that when we sacked Hroldan, you would make me your sworn brother. And I've waited. Even after the enemies' arrows dug into my chest and their hammers crushed my bones. I've waited. Give me your sword, Hjalti. That we may become brothers as you promised.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DB08FestusIdentityTopic1
output: Don't be so petulant! In my, um, investigations, I came upon this. It's a copy of the Gourmet's cookbook. Ah, but not just any copy. It's signed you see! Seems to be a message from the Gourmet to one Anton Virane. I've tracked Virane to the keep in Markarth. It would seem he's the cook.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How's the meadery working out?
output: It's tough, with just the two of us. We could use a pair of hands and a strong back. There'd be a little coin in it for you. There's hardly ever time to make the occasional delivery to the taverns of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How's the meadery working out?
output: Indeed I do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a case of Frost River Mead for you.
output: Ah, good. I've been waiting on that. Here's the gold for it. Thanks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a case of Frost River Mead for you.
output: Ah, good. I've been waiting on that. Ah, good. I've been waiting on that. Here's the gold for it. Thanks. Here's the gold for it. Thanks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I can certainly help.
output: That'd be great. There's a case of our soon-to-be famous mead that needs to get to Winterhold. Get it there, and you can keep the delivery fee.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've brought the fragment.
output: I'll speak with Aela about how you handled yourself. Come back later.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've brought the fragment.
output: I'll speak with Farkas about how you handled yourself. Come back later.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds good, I'll follow you.
output: If you like. But we need to find a way to unlock that trap door.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The ghost is looking for his sword.
output: A sword? I remember a legend that Tiber Septim had attacked one of the enemy camps before he came to Old Hroldan. It could be there. I'll mark it down on your map.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I heard screaming.
output: There's a... ghost. Just wandering around my inn like it owned the place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I heard screaming.
output: Yes. I've heard stories that Old Hroldan was haunted, but no ones seen a ghost here since the Great War. He's from the battle, I just know it. He's one of Tiber Septim's soldiers... back from the dead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The ghost mentioned a "Hjalti."
output: Hjalti? I've never heard of anyone named Hjalti. Tiber Septim had many names. Maybe that's one of them?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have Hjalti's sword.
output: It's been an honor to serve you, brother. Remembers our lessons from the sword masters of Alcaire? Let me show you a few things you may have forgotten before we leave Hroldan.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Reporting in.
output: Speak with Ulfric, he's expecting word from Whiterun. Speak with Ulfric, he's expecting word from Whiterun.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I buy a horse?
output: Got one all saddled and ready to go. What are you willing to pay?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I buy a horse?
output: Not today. Sold my last one. Pretty sure I sold it to you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I buy a horse?
output: Yeah, I got one for sale.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I buy a horse?
output: You could if I had one. Sold my last available horse to someone that looked an awful lot like you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: On second thought, I'll walk.
output: Suit yourself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: On second thought, I'll walk.
output: Off with ya then. I've got work to do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's my offer... (<Global=Horsecost> gold)
output: You've got a deal. It's the one with the saddle.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's my offer... (<Global=Horsecost> gold)
output: Then come back when you've got that much.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's my offer... (<Global=Horsecost> gold)
output: That'll do. She's all saddled up for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's my offer... (<Global=Horsecost> gold)
output: When you get it, she's yours.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a delivery from <Alias.ShortName=QuestGiver>.
output: Oh dear. Darkwater Crossing needs medicines for its miners? I'll see about getting this order filled right away. Here, a few septims for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have your frost salts.
output: Well, well, you actually did what you said you were going to do. I'm impressed. Here, let me teach you a thing or two about Alteration magic. It's the least I can do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry to hear that.
output: He'll be fine, I just hate worrying about his worrying.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Someone giving you trouble?
output: He's been in Kynesgrove forever. Great storyteller. Keeps everyone's spirits up. Owes me a lot of coin for drinks. I keep telling him not to worry about it, but he's got the stubborn Nord blood. Damn fool doesn't have the coin to pay me back, so he just beats himself up over it, and then he gets thirsty, and it cycles all over again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry to hear that.
output: It's not any of your bother, so I don't see what you're apologizing for.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could find those frost salts for you.
output: If you want to go to the trouble, feel free. I suppose I could offer you a bit of free Alteration training when you get back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you do in Kynesgrove?
output: Nosy one, huh? I was a mage back in Morrowind. I lend my talents to the mines here, helping them keep the tunnels safe. By Azura, it gets hot in there. I use Frost Salts for a potion to keep the heat bearable, but I'm out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe we can come to an understanding. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: A true Nord would settle it himself, but at least this way Iddra gets her coin. Thank you. Tell her I'll be fine.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe we can come to an understanding. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: This isn't about me paying Iddra back, this is about me being able to pay her back with my own coin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll do it.
output: This brings back memories. Come back when you're done and maybe I'll be up to showing you a few tricks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want to talk to you about <Alias.ShortName=QuestGiver>.
output: I guess if you're telling me to stop worrying about it, maybe I should just let it go. Thank you, friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want to talk to you about <Alias.ShortName=QuestGiver>.
output: What do you think I am, a beggar? My family has always paid back every single coin we owed, going back to Tiber Septim's time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Forget it.
output: Fair enough.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's a shame.
output: We'll get by.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What if I talk to <Alias.ShortName=Target>?
output: If you could convince him that I don't care about his tab, it'd certainly make me feel better.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could deliver that for you.
output: Thank you. Take it to Quintus, in the White Phial.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Fine. Forget I asked.
output: It's better that way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to collect my earnings.
output: Here's your pay. It's never enough for what we do, but war gives us warriors its own kind of benefits, doesn't it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to collect my earnings.
output: Are you sure? It's rightfully yours, but this money could go to getting better weapons and armor, and making repairs to the settlements we control.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you all right?
output: Now the Thalmor will be hunting me for the rest of my life. I hope it was worth it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you all right?
output: I should have known this would end badly. I can't believe I let Delphine talk me into this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you all right?
output: Let's get out of here, for pity's sake!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you all right?
output: I saw guards dragging bodies over here. Might be a way out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you all right?
output: We've got to get out of here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you all right?
output: You saved my life. I won't forget it. Look me up if you're ever in Riften.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you all right?
output: You didn't have to help me, so... thanks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Not yet. These things can't be rushed.
output: Ha. Don't toy with me. I may just have to seize my opportunity with both hands, ha ha ha. But we'll play it your way for now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't worry. She's all yours.
output: Ha. We'll see. I do have my eye on her, but she seemed a bit cold when I spoke to her earlier. Maybe just playing hard to get, eh?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I saw you eyeing that serving girl.
output: Mmm, yes... Brelas, is that the one? I hope you're not thinking of cutting me out, are you? Haha. I'm warning you, when I get my heart set on something I'm not easily put off.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What brings you to this party?
output: You must be new to Skyrim, or you'd already know who I am. I have a stake in most anything of importance in Solitude. I feel that it's time to put aside the grievances of the past, and let peace and prosperity flourish between the Empire and the Aldmeri Dominion. I try to do my little part. Besides, just between you and me, it's making me pots of money, hahaha.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes. She said she can sneak you up to her quarters right now.
output: Haha. I knew it! No woman yet born has been able to resist my charms for long. Thank you, my friend. I owe you one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe I can talk to her for you. See if she's interested.
output: Really? Yes, maybe that would be just the thing. She seemed to be playing hard to get when I spoke to her earlier. Go on. See what she says. Now you've gone and gotten my hopes up again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That fellow over there asked me to talk to you...
output: Ugh. Erikur, right? He was talking to me earlier. I could tell what he was after. I hate working these parties. Some of the guests are nice, but there's always a few like Erikur. Please tell him to leave me alone. Politely. I'm sure you'll have better luck getting through to him than I would.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like a drink.
output: Here you go, sir. Colovian brandy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have no idea what you're talking about.
output: Look, it's all very simple. The Dwemer, they were uhh, masters of magic in a way we can't even begin to conceive of. Their greatest achievement, however, has also been their greatest, shall we say... Mystery.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want me to say to Enthir?
output: I don't know, I don't know! I've already agreed to pay him quite handsomely for the... well, the item in question. Just... Do whatever it takes to get him to stop lording this over me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can you tell me more about this project of yours?
output: Ah, yes. Umm, no. No, I don't think so. Not at this point. It's just that, well I'm not even really sure it's going to amount to anything just yet. All theoretical right now, you understand. But the implications are quite intriguing, I think. I simply need some experimental results to confirm my suspicions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How is your project coming along?
output: Terrible, just terrible. I vastly underestimated the heat transfer necessary, and have destroyed my only working model. I'm at a loss.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want me to do?
output: Well, yes. The designs for my Convector were based on real dwarven machines, so there may still be some in existence. I'd go looking myself, but uhh... Yes, there are calculations to double- and triple-check. Many calculations. Perhaps you could seek out these Convectors in Skyrim ruins? I can even teach you the spell to heat them. It's very particular, and very important.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Didn't you tell Enthir this was valuable?
output: Have you lost your mind? Think, please, just for a moment, about what he would do if he knew its true value. Do you really believe he would honor our agreement, or go running off to the highest bidder? Please, you must set this right. I'm begging you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this thing that's so important?
output: It... It's very valuable. Critical to my work, and one-of-a-kind. That's all I care to say for now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And that won't work?
output: Well, yes. I mean, no. That is, it might, but I'm not completely sure. I'm no tonal architect, I've only read their writings. Scraps, really. The soul gem by itself isn't enough, you see. It needs to be altered, purified. The dwarves had machines for this sort of thing. I attempted to build my own, based on designs and using parts you helped to provide. My very own Dwarven Convector. It worked, but not fully. And the uhh... The device was destroyed in the process.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's in this for me?
output: Well, I... Don't you see? Unlocking this mystery... The story alone is worth more riches than you can even imagine. And perhaps... well, I don't wish to speculate, but... What if we could contact the dwarves? What if they're still out there? Imagine!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What sort of "payment" do you expect this time?
output: Nothing, nothing at all! Arniel already overpaid for... whatever it is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is it Arniel wanted you to get?
output: I don't know. He never told me. He made most of the arrangements himself, he just needed it transported from Morrowind. That's what I agreed to help with. If I'd known it was so important to him, I'd have charged him more.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you involved in something dangerous?
output: What? No, no. Goodness, no! At least, I don't think so. No, it's just... It's just something I'd prefer to keep to myself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not running any more errands for you.
output: Did I ask you to? Did you hear me say that?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I understand you have something of Arniel's.
output: Oh dear. He's so afraid to talk to me he's sending you to do it? I should've expected as much. I'm afraid you've been a little mis-informed. I have something of mine, that I was going to sell to Arniel.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can you build another?
output: Hmm? No, no. No! I'm too close now. Can't take the time. Though... Perhaps there's another option. I, umm, I may require further assistance from you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you unraveled the mystery of the dwarves yet?
output: No, and at this rate, I never shall! Enthir is once again holding out on me. He refuses to deliver yet another item absolutely essential to my work! I am close, so close! You must force him to see reason!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've got the Soul Gem you were after.
output: Do you? Wonderful. I was afraid I'd have to give up, and when I'm so close... Thank you for this. I have a great deal of work ahead of me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did you account for the, uh, extra coefficient introduced by... umm...
output: Don't patronize me!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It left Morrowind, but never arrived here.
output: No, no no no. This can't be happening.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're holding out on Arniel again.
output: Oh, by the Divines, you too? I've already told him. I don't have it!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The courier never arrived with it.
output: He has some simple-minded courier delivering it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Teach me your spell, and I'll see what I can do.
output: Wonderful, just wonderful! I knew I could count on you! Now this spell is not for defending yourself, but it's just right for heating the Convector. At least three seconds' burn is necessary. Just place the soul gem inside, and heat the Convector. At least three seconds. You'll almost certainly need to find multiple Convectors. I suspect it may be due to the nature of the soul gem versus the crystals this was intended for. Destroys the equipment in the process. But, ahh... It's effective.
