instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I find this Augur?
output: I... I am unsure. He is somewhere within the College. Surely one of your colleagues must know his location. I am sorry I cannot provide you with further help, but this conversation requires a great deal of effort on my part.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So what exactly is the problem?
output: As you may have learned, this object... The Eye... is immensely powerful. This world is not ready for it. If it remains here, it will be misused. Indeed, many in the Order believe it has already... Rather, something will happen soon, something that cannot be avoided.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Aren't you just an advisor here?
output: Technically, that is true. But I still report to the Aldmeri Dominion, and I cannot ignore this situation. Don't worry, you can return to your petty squabbles and meaningless 'research' as soon as this matter is resolved.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want with me?
output: I merely wish to talk to you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did you do?
output: I've given us a chance to speak privately, but I'm afraid I can't do this for long. We must be brief. The situation here at your College is of dire importance, and attempts to contact you as we have previously have failed. I believe it is due to the very source of our concern. This object... The Eye of Magnus as your people have taken to calling it. The longer it remains here, the more dangerous the situation becomes. And so I have come here personally to tell you it must be dealt with. The energy coming from it has prevented us from reaching you with the visions you have already seen.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who is the Augur of Dunlain?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

Change Arn's entry in the book to anything you want and they'll be forced to let him go after he serves a few weeks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

If you get caught, I can't afford to be connected to you. Remember that before you do anything stupid.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So what's the job?
output: The job is two-fold. First, steal a letter that was sent from Solitude warning Whiterun's guard to be on the lookout for Arn. The second is to change Arn's name in the prison registry to his new identity.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: His dragon allies must know where this portal is...
output: Very true! Hmm. I wonder... do you know the Jarl's palace in Whiterun?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I thought there weren't any dragons until Alduin came back.
output: Oh, this was thousands of years ago, before the Akaviri crusaders cleansed Skyrim of dragons. Skyrim's mountains were still infested with dragons. One of the early Nord kings caught a dragon and kept it in Dragonsreach.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the Jarl's palace have to do with this?
output: Well, you see, the palace - Dragonsreach - was originally built to hold a captive dragon. Hence its name.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You mean Dragonsreach?
output: Yes, exactly! Most people don't know that it was originally built to hold a captive dragon - hence its name.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I defeated Alduin, but he escaped. I need to find him.
output: He must have returned to Sovngarde to feed on the souls of the dead. If you don't find him soon, he'll return, stronger than ever!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I know. That's why I need to find him.
output: Yes, yes. We must think. He must have some means of travelling to and from Sovngarde. But no tale tells where that might be.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So if I could lure a dragon into Dragonsreach...
output: You could trap him there, exactly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Deal. Where do I begin?
output: The only name I have is Niranye. Has a house right here in Windhelm. That's where you should begin looking.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Delvin Mallory said you had a job for me.
output: My daughter Fjotli... she was murdered a few months ago. Left her laying on the ground in a pool of her own blood. I assume they were after her valuables... she always wore far too much jewelry in public. When I told her it'd be the death of her, I never thought...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What exactly do you need me to do then?
output: Well, like I told Delvin, I think we can help each other. You recover what I'm looking for and take out a rival Guild in the process.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have Fjotli's Locket.
output: It pains me to see this locket... to be reminded of  Fjotli once more, but I'm glad it's back where it belongs. Tell Delvin that if he still desires to have my support for the Thieves Guild in Windhelm, he's got it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I assure you it wasn't anyone from the Guild.
output: No need to explain, I'm well aware of your Guild's methods. It took me weeks, but I finally tracked down the killer. A bloody Altmer at that. Can you imagine?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's something they took from Fjotli, I assume.
output: Exactly. One of the pieces stolen from her was a silver locket, a Cruel-Sea family heirloom. I want it back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened to him?
output: Let's just say I'm a firm believer in an eye for an eye and leave it at that. He fancied himself a thief in some sort of a new Guild forming around here. Gave me some valuable information before... well, you know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Thank you.
output: There's no need to thank me. What you did was for the people of Dawnstar. If anyone should be thanked, it should be you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How about some compensation?
output: Being a humble servant of Mara, I have little in the way of gold or coin, but perhaps I can offer you something better... companionship.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So we're done, then?
output: Yes. The Skull has been destroyed and Dawnstar is safe.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you going to be all right?
output: In time, I believe I will.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I came here looking for the Synod.
output: And just why would you be doing that? Oh, it doesn't matter now. Gavros is never coming back, and he was supposed to have the crystal. Without that, we're lost. It's all been for nothing. So congratulations, whoever you are, you've found the Synod. Just me, alone, surrounded by angry machines and angrier Falmer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's this about a crystal?
output: It didn't work the first time. I tried to tell Gavros, but he wouldn't listen. "No, it won't be too cold" he said. Well, I was right, wasn't I? Focused completely wrong by the time we got here! The cold had warped it! Gavros had to cart it all the way back to Cyrodiil. Left the rest of us here to fend off the damnable Falmer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: What are you doing here? What've you done with Gavros?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found the Synod in Mzulft. They're dead.
output: Really? Well, I do recall warning them it might not be the safest of locations. I hope this doesn't become a problem for us. Were you able to learn anything?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found notes about a crystal, and the Oculory in Mzulft.
output: Hmm. I can't say I've any idea what they were up to. Have you found this observatory? You might be able to learn something from it. Keep looking, but be careful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your friend Gavros is dead.
output: It was the Falmer, wasn't it? Curse them! They've ruined everything! If Gavros is gone, there's no hope. He was supposed to return with the crystal... Without that, all our efforts are wasted. And you. If you're here for treasure, or wisdom, or anything, I'm afraid you've wasted your time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: They were trying to perform some sort of experiment, I think.
output: I can't imagine what that might be, but if it's safe, you might see if they were successful. You could get some useful information about whatever they were up to. Sounds like it won't be of use to them now, anyway.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you doing here?
output: I am on official business of the Grand Council of the Synod. That's all you need to know. I might well ask the same of you, running around by yourself in this dangerous place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: You're the one Mazzaka described to me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So we're splitting the loot, then?
output: Ha! I'm afraid the loot's already been moved. You've been useful to the Blackbloods, though. You've earned a quick death.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I dealt with the rest of the bandits.
output: It's appreciated. The captains around here will have one less thing to worry about. Here's your reward.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: I'm Captain Aldis. I'm here to help you take down these bandits.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Looks like Deeja won't be bothering us again.
output: Good riddance.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Looks like Deeja won't be bothering us again.
output: I'll take care of it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Just you?
output: We're stretched thin in Solitude, and I don't expect these bandits to be much challenge. Are you ready?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's take them out.
output: With pleasure.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So, what did you think about the deed?
output: Aringoth sold Goldenglow? What's that idiot thinking? He has no idea the extent of Maven's fury when she's been cut out of a deal, but I'm certain he'll find out. If only this parchment had the buyer's name instead of this odd symbol. Any idea what that might be?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I just want the key to your safe.
output: I can't. If I do, I may as well cut my own throat.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why not level the entire estate?
output: I'll give you one good reason. Maven Black-Briar. Burn all the hives and she'd have to import honey for Black-Briar Meadery which would cut into her profits.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What makes you think I won't? (Persuade)
output: Fine. Take it! Once the new owner finds out I gave in, I'm as good as dead anyway.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No idea.
output: Blast. Well, I'll check my sources and speak to Mercer. But for now, you're off to speak to Maven Black-Briar. She asked for you by name.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: New owner? What are you talking about?
output: I've already said too much. I gave you what you came here for, now go. Leave me in peace.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What scared them off?
output: We were excavating this old tomb when we opened a chamber full of corpses. The team took one look, turned tail, and ran.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me more about this treasure.
output: Legend says this tomb holds a treasure that bestows great power on the one who discovers it. Beyond that, not much more is known.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Deal.
output: Excellent. With my brains and your brawn, that treasure will soon be mine... uh, ours.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Haven't they seen dead bodies before?
output: Well, probably not like these. The ones in there are all still walking around.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You seem troubled.
output: Of course I'm troubled. I'm on the verge of incredible wealth, but my cowardly work force ran at the first sign of danger.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No deal. This sounds too risky.
output: Bah! You're just as bad as the rest of them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe I could help you.
output: Say, that's not a bad idea. You look like you could handle yourself against these beasts.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where are we going?
output: The Silver Hand have taken over the old fort at Gallows Rock. They always make such easy prey.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where are we going?
output: Old fort. Abandoned for years. They're like jackals, making their home anywhere they can find.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then I'm off to Labyrinthian.
output: What? Are you... Are you sure? The staff is there? That can't be a coincidence.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you talking about?
output: The Arch-Mage.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I heard some shouting about the Forsworn. That was it.
output: The Forsworn? Strange. Well, I hope the Eight give you more peace in the future, for what it's worth.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Which makes Maven lose faith in us.
output: Exactly. For the Guild to survive, they need Maven's support. This Karliah must have spent a lot of time and resources planning this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How would that hurt the Guild?
output: Maven Black-Briar needs Goldenglow's honey for her mead. She's been using the Guild to keep the Estate under her thumb. If the owner cuts the Guild out of the picture, he's cutting Maven out of the picture... which she can't afford. If I was Maven, I'd blame the Guild for weakening and not being able to handle the place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You have the poison?
output: No, no. That's the beauty of the whole plan. We're going to get Sabjorn to give it to us. The meadery has quite a pest problem and the whole city knows about it. Pest poison and mead don't mix well, you know what I mean?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There's more to this than a debt, isn't there?
output: If this plan works, not only is my debt gone, but I'll be set up for life. Maven and I worked out a little deal. If Sabjorn ends up in jail, she's going to take over his meadery. And guess who gets to run the Black-Briar Meadery in Whiterun? You're looking at him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes. I've seen that symbol before.
output: Well, whoever this mysterious marking represents, they'll regret starting a war with me. You should bring this information to the Thieves Guild immediately. There's also the matter of your payment. I believe you'll find this more than adequate for your services.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Job's finished. Here's the information you requested.
output: Have you lost your mind? I thought it was clear I didn't want anyone killed. Now I have to spend a fortune to keep the whole thing quiet. Guess where that money comes from.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What about my pay?
output: You'll just have to wait until after the captain's finished. I suppose you can wait around if you must.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Clever.
output: Maven and I spent weeks planning this. All we need is someone like you to get in there and get it done. Now get going before Sabjorn grows a brain and hires someone else to do the dirty work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to get a look at Sabjorn's books.
output: So, Maven wants to hunt down Sabjorn's private partner, huh? You're welcome to take a look around Sabjorn's office. He keeps most of his papers stashed in his desk. Here, this should help.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Oh? Who would that be?
output: Silent means I don't tell and it's none of your business.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want no part of this.
output: Very well. But should the hunger call out to you, I'll be waiting outside Reachcliff Cave. Tell the people of Markarth that their dead are safe. My work is done here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where is this place?
output: It's inside Reachcliff Cave. But the dead have stirred from their slumber recently, and I was forced here. Meet me there. We will fight our way to Namira's embrace together.  Until then, tell the people of Markarth that their dead won't be disturbed, anymore. We have bigger plans ahead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Hall of the Dead is safe now.
output: Divines preserve you, you're a hero. We'll re-open the Hall right away. Here. Take my amulet as a reward.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait here. I'll take care of them.
output: Then I'll wait.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could use a hand.
output: I was hoping you would say that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is Wuuthrad?
output: Wuuthrad was the blade held by Ysgramor when he cut through the elven hordes that once swarmed this land. He made it safe for our kind.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does this have to do with me?
output: This is a simple errand, but the time is right for it to be your Trial. Carry yourself with honor, and you'll become a true Companion.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I would be honored to retrieve it.
output: There's a fine line between respect and boot-licking, new blood. But I like your spirit. We've decided this will be your Trial. Do well, and you'll be counted among the Companions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is Wuuthrad?
output: Wuuthrad is a relic of Ysgramor. Through that weapon, we trace our line straight to the first harbinger of makind in this land. What fragments we have are displayed in honor, but we always seek more.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Urag suggested I come see you.
output: Did he now? Does he have information about our wonderful discovery?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There's a book he thinks you should read.
output: Ah, yes. Well, I'll be sure and stop by the Arcanaeum later.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found a certain book, "Night of Tears"...
output: Is that the one about something buried beneath Saarthal? Something that men and mer fought over? I'll have to make a point of re-reading it. I don't recall the details.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you nervous about being here?
output: Why? Because it's old, and full of dead things? Clearly you've never spent any time in Morrowind.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're not happy about being here?
output: No. There's no chance anyone in authority approved this. Our ancestors should be allowed to rest in peace.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's so important about me being Dragonborn?
output: The Blades have always guarded and guided the Dragonborn. But we'd forgotten why. Now our purpose is clear. I'm all that's left of the Blades, and you're the Dragonborn. Together we're going to stop these dragons, if we have to put every last one of them back in the ground.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why does the Empire allow the Thalmor free reign?
output: Part of the cost of peace. Emperor Titus Mede saved his Empire at a very high price. A price that included the Blades. The Nords didn't like the peace treaty much either. Thirty years later, the Empire ends up with the Stormcloak rebellion on its hands. No doubt exactly as the Thalmor intended.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened to the Blades? Why are you on the run?
output: The Thalmor happened. They've been hunting down every Blade they can find for the past thirty years. Thanks to the White-Gold Concordat, they've been able to operate throughout the Empire with impunity.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So why are they hunting you?
output: When I was young, our leaders became obsessed with the Thalmor threat. They believed that if and when we found a Dragonborn, we would need to protect her against the Thalmor.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You want me to kill a dragon for you?
output: Something's happening to bring the dragons back to life. And I need you to help me stop it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You said the Thalmor are after you?
output: The Thalmor. We're very old enemies. And if my suspicions are correct, they might have something to do with the dragons returning. But that isn't important right now. What is important is that you might be Dragonborn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I just came here for the horn.
output: And now you have it. No harm done. I knew the Greybeards would send you for the horn if they thought you were Dragonborn. Taking it was the only way I could be sure this wasn't a Thalmor trap.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: They won't stop until you do. (Persuade)
output: You're right. They always get what they want, somehow. Fine. Tell Atar I'll sell.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: They won't stop until you do. (Persuade)
output: Someone has to stand up to them. I won't sell.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You'll listen to gold, I take it? (<BribeCost> gold)
output: That I will, stranger. This is more than the Silver-Bloods are paying us. We'll clear out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You'll listen to gold, I take it? (<BribeCost> gold)
output: Don't think I'm being paid already? Get lost.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Good luck with that.
output: Right.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could convince Ainethach to sell.
output: Do that and I'll make sure you get a cut.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's in charge here?
output: I'm not from here. I'm a sellsword. These are my men.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: This whole town wants you out. Leave. (Persuade)
output: Dealing with a mob wouldn't be good for my coin purse. Fine. We're leaving.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: This whole town wants you out. Leave. (Persuade)
output: Let's see them make us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you in charge here?
output: My family has owned Karthwasten for generations. Rare for anyone in the Reach that isn't a Nord. Not that it does me any good. Nords think I'm working for the Forsworn. Forsworn think I'm working for the Nords.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What if I convince them to leave?
output: You can try, but I'd keep your sword-arm ready if things get ugly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Forget it, then.
output: Let's do that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ainethach won't be a problem anymore.
output: Good work. Here's your cut. I guess this finishes up our contract with the Silver-Bloods, so we'll be heading out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: On second thought, I'll be leaving.
output: Milk drinker.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You do or you get hurt. (Intimidate)
output: Easy. I'll sell. Just don't hurt anyone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Look. I'll give you a fair price. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: That's more gold than they're offering. Fine. I'll sell.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Look. I'll give you a fair price. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: This isn't about the money.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think I'll just kill you. (Intimidate)
output: Whoa. Wait a second. I was just kidding. We'll leave. We'll leave!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think I'll just kill you. (Intimidate)
output: I thought today was going to be boring.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Would you play "Tale of the Tongues"?
output: Certainly! It's a fine tune and a good request! Certainly! It's a fine tune and a good request! Certainly! It's a fine tune and a good request! Certainly! It's a fine tune and a good request!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do you think we're here?
output: Because Tolfdir says so. He says there are things to learn here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do you think we're here?
output: Hopefully we can learn something from the experience. How the ancient Nords used magic, maybe even what happened to this place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do you think we're here?
output: Not really. Just that it's very, very old. It was one of the first cities of men in Tamriel, I think.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You seem excited to be here.
output: Oh, yes. J'zargo hopes to find things that will make him a more powerful mage here. Hopefully small things that fit inside pockets, and will not be noticed if they are missing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What has he done to displease you?
output: For a time he served his purpose, but that time has ended. He uses my gifts for his own amusement, and the only amusement I tolerate is my own.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I find him?
output: You will find him holed up at Knifepoint Ridge, where he plays king to bandits and highwaymen.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Say no more. He's as good as dead.
output: Slay him in the coldest of blood. Do not give him the dignity of defending himself. Once his corpse lays cold upon the ground, and all trace of his followers erased, retrieve my Ebony Mail. A gift fit only for my true champion. Kill every single member of his band. Do so as silently and invisibly as you can, for this is not about you. You are to be my instrument in this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Actually, I'm hoping to join them.
output: You disappoint me. I expected someone from outside Riften to be different, but I see corruption's reach holds little regard for boundaries. Enjoy the city. It will suit you well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Fascinating! Do go on...
output: Ah ha! So you're a student of theoretical applied harmonics! Putting aside Ralston's Constant of Universal Inversion for a moment, how would you approach the problem? Draw the harmonic energy into the reagent or allow it to generate its own field?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I try not to care.
output: That's a shame. Too many people in Riften share your view and look where its getting them. It's going to take more than just myself and Aerin to help this city... it has to want to help itself first.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I agree completely.
output: You know, I'm beginning to respect you. Other than Aerin, you seem to be the only other person I've met I might be able to trust. Since we share the same opinion of them, let me warn you that they're recruiting others to join their "guild" and you should be cautious.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did Aerin save your life?
output: It was Aerin who found me dying outside of a Dwemer ruin. If he hadn't brought me here and nursed me back to health, I would have died. When my strength returned and he told me about the problems plaguing Riften, I decided fate brought me here for a reason... so I stayed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've located Grimsever.
output: Astonishing. To think you actually were able to reach it and yet return to tell the tale. Rarely in my travels have I encountered those who possess skills equal to your own. I see I still have much to learn. If you'd permit me, I'd be honored to accompany you in your travels for a time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Swallow a soul gem?
output: Are you completely insane? Swallow a soul gem? That has to be the most brilliant and unexpected solution I've heard in a long time. It solves all of my problems and keeps the field stable! Now all I need... wait, what were we talking about?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Easy, it's nine.
output: Of course! Nine is the most basic of magical principles. Oh, how stupid of me. That completely takes care of all your basic problems, magicka burn, dimensional collapse and thermic drift! You've done it! Now, if I can only remember what we were originally talking about.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the word around town?
output: The Thieves Guild has been pushing hard to regain a foothold in this city. Rumor has it they're falling apart from the inside.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: Please be careful, I don't wish to be the reason for your death.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: Safe travels.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How about using calipers?
output: Calipers? That's utterly ridiculous. Maybe long ago, you could just find calipers in every household across Tamriel, but not anymore. Hold on, you've given me a brilliant idea. Just as calipers hold materials in place, a soul siphon can hold magic fields in place. Genius! And I'm sure you've completely worked out how to counteract complete dimensional collapse, right?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I would use the blue thing.
output: The blue thing? But even the simplest harmonic field is composed of entirely... Wait just a moment. The blue thing. Yes, yes, yes! I can see your point. Draw out the necessary energies using a Jarol Apparatus! But wait. What about soul reversal? You must be aware of the consequences when using the apparatus near an open magic field.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Um... I don't know. Seven?
output: Seven. Astonishing. I hadn't considered that. I mean, it would take months... years to work out the differentials. But what a revolutionary concept. Wait, wait. I can see a minor problem in your theory. Without a soul siphon, how would you prevent permanent magicka burn?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Quite a forge you've got here.
output: The Skyforge? Aye, my clan-fathers have worked it since the first Gray-Manes came to Whiterun. Skyforge Steel is all the Companions will use, for good reason.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you a Companion?
output: Why? Who says I have to be? Skyforge Steel is my art and honor. The Companions need the best, so they come to me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Clan Battle-Born.
output: Battle-Born is a name out of legend, sung in the songs of old and heard in deeds of valor for a hundred generations. "For Clan Battle-Born!" they cry in the mead halls. "First into the fray and last to quit their ale!" We've got honor. Wealth and titles, too. Aye, and buxom women to warm your bed on a cold Skyrim night. Now if that don't answer your question, then no words will.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What about Clan Gray-Mane?
output: Uncivilized, pelt-wearing axe-draggers. It's a wonder they don't still live in a cave like those ancestors they keep boasting about. It's true the Vignar Gray-Mane and his lot are one of Whiterun's oldest and, depending on who you ask, most respected clans. I don't dispute that. But it's one thing to take pride in your lineage, and another to cling blindly to the past. What they call honor and tradition, I call ignorance.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why the feud with Clan Gray-Mane?
output: Money, you laggard! What else? It always comes down to coin. The Gray-Manes have deep roots in Whiterun, but so do we. Difference is, we're rich, and Vignar hates it. Oh, and they hate it, too. All their big talk of pride and honor, and what have they got to show for it? Beggar's rags and stale bread. We've got the same pride, the same honor, and we've got wealth. No wonder they envy us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's happened?
output: Look, I know the others think I'm a bit daft for sayin' stuff like this, but I'm gonna give it to you straight. Somethin' out there is piss-drunk mad at us. I don't know who or what it is, but it's beyond just you and me. We've been cursed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I know what I'm doing.
output: Lyin' to my face isn't gonna win you any favors with me, I can promise you that. On the other hand, takin' some of these extra jobs off my hands, now that'll get you to the top of my list.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So, what can we do?
output: You can get out there and start making a name for us again... make them start fearing us like they did long ago. And, while you're at it, make a little bit of coin on the side. Not a bad deal, eh?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What sort of business?
output: I'm not going to sugar-coat it for you. We're in a bad way down here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll keep that in mind.
output: Then we understand each other... good. Now, it's time to get your feet wet and I don't want to waste a lot of time talking about anything but business.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Brynjolf pointed me your way.
output: Brynjolf, huh? Lemme guess. He plucked you off the street and dropped you into the thick of things without tellin' you which way is up. Am I right?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So how do I get my cut of the spoils?
output: Simple. Do as you're told and keep your blade clean. We can't turn a profit by killing. You should talk with Delvin Mallory and Vex. They know their way around this place and they'll be able to kick some extra jobs your way. Oh, and talk to Tonilia in the Flagon... she'll set you up with your new armor.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Back on its feet?
output: Look around you. The Flagon, the Guild... it's all fallin' apart. A few decades ago, this place was as busy as the Imperial City. Now, you're lucky if you don't trip over a skeever instead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any idea why?
output: Who knows. Old Delvin thinks it's some kind of a curse. I think he's crazy. If you want my opinion I say it's just plain old bad luck.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Back off. I know the drill.
output: Now you I like. I've been getting sick of the pushovers that usually walk in here. I think you and I are going to get along just fine. Now, it's time to get your feet wet and I don't want to waste a lot of time talking about anything but business.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Brynjolf said I should speak to you.
output: Before we begin, I want to make two things perfectly clear. One, I'm the best infiltrator this rathole of a Guild's got, so if you think you're here to replace me, you're dead wrong. And two, you follow my lead and do exactly as I say... no questions, no excuses.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I didn't make that much noise.
output: Please. You're in the presence of a born huntsman. I can hear the sweat sliding down your forehead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't you have trouble getting ripe goods here?
output: I have my ways, but it's not easy these days. The Blackblood Marauders have been plundering ships off the coast. A lot of people been hurt by their foolishness.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are your sales?
output: Oh, very brisk. When the snow sets in, even the hardiest Nord needs some spiced wine to warm the blood.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where do you catch the fish?
output: Down at the docks. There are a few good spots, if you can avoid the East Empire Company workers and those Red Wave thugs.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why is this place called the Winking Skeever?
output: Well, as it turns out, I had a pet skeever when I was a boy and he used to wink.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you get a lot of business like that?
output: Radiant Raiment has the finest attire in all of Skyrim. That is how we get business.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's wrong with my outfit?
output: Nothing at all. It's very... nice. If you want something with a little more style, however, you should see what we have available.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're pretty dedicated to the Empire, then?
output: Ah... To be honest, no. But High King Torygg supported them, and now her lady Elisif has thrown in with them. You could say I'm a King's man at heart. Hmph. I guess that's "Jarl's man" now. My loyalty lies with Solitude. So where Jarl Elisif leads, I follow.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: A curse? What can we do about it?
output: I'll tell you what we do. We spit in that curse's face and turn things around down here. Put things back the way they were. That's where you come in. I've got plenty of work available that could guide us down the road to recovery. All you need to do is ask and we can both come out of this smellin' like a rose.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I suppose I could use some advice.
output: See, that kind of attitude comes from someone who wants to get rich and stay alive long enough to enjoy it. We're goin' to get along nicely. So, if you've got the nerve, I've got plenty of extra jobs to help get the Guild back on its feet.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I guess that's as good a reason as any.
output: I thought so.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Hey, take it easy.
output: Easy, huh? So, should I just hand you purses of coin or are you going to work to earn your keep? Let me give you a small bit of advice. Nothing in this line of work is easy. If it was, every dreg in the Ratway would be robbing Riften blind. If something's being handed to you on a silver platter, then there's a catch... steal the platter instead. You get it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to know more about Winterhold's history.
output: I'm afraid there's not much to be said. Winterhold is hardly what it used to be. Most of the business we get is from folks here to visit the College, though even that's dried up some. You can talk to Birna if you need to buy anything. She doesn't have much, but could certainly use the coin. And then there's our little inn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Bards College? What's that?
output: It's a school that teaches music, poetry, that sort of thing. Most bards in Skyrim have been to the college at some point. If you're thinking of applying, talk to Viarmo in Solitude.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: A skald? Is that some kind of bard?
output: That's about the truth of it. Write tales about the sights I've seen. The battles I've fought. Earned quite a name for myself when I was younger. The Bards College still teaches some of my work to their students.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who is Beirand?
output: Beirand's my husband. He works the forge up at Castle Dour. I barely see him nowadays, what with him filling orders for the army.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You kept a skeever as a pet?
output: They were smaller back then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DCETAlertToNormal
output: Nothing... Nothing... Nothing... Nothing...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DCETAlertToNormal
output: The glimmer of life is gone... The glimmer of life is gone...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How goes the training?
output: Their aim could be steadier, but they're battle ready.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Nasty bit of business, Roggvir's execution.
output: Perhaps, but necessary. My cousin, Fura, is somewhere out there in Skyrim right now, fighting Ulfric Stormcloak and his damned insurrectionists. She wouldn't have to be there at all, if it weren't for Roggvir.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: But you're talking right now.
output: I shouldn't be. Mama says if I do, people are going to ask about uncle Roggvir. Maybe if I don't talk, they won't either.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You seem proud to be a bard.
output: And why wouldn't I be? We sing tales of kings, queens and their politics, 'tis true. But do you know who really makes history? The person who writes it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You play well.
output: Thank you. I'm still at the beginning of my lessons but Inge... Dean Six Fingers... says I'm quite good with the flute.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You were the one who executed that man...
output: Aye. I'm the headsman here in Solitude. It's my job.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Elisif seems to rely on you a great deal.
output: She still mourns greatly for her husband, High King Torygg. So she leaves many of the courtly details to me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How long have you tended the Hall of the Dead?
output: All my life. I practically grew up in the Hall. My father and mother were the priest and priestess of Arkay before me, you see. I believe I was put here to protect this place from the darkness that pervades Solitude.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're a long way from home, then.
output: Aye, but I'll be here in Solitude for longer still. Fihada's skill as a fletcher drew me to this place. I wanted to learn. And there is still much of Skyrim I wish to see. I hear there is a city, Wind-Helm, that is nearly white with... What do you call it? Ah yes! Snow. And far to the west lies a ruin. Volskygge. Inside, there is said to be a wall, black as night. And it speaks! In the ancient Dragon tongue! There are wonders in this place I never dreamed imaginable.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Were you really in the army?
output: What? You see a man fallen on hard times, and you think he's been like that forever? You understand? They left me for dead. I didn't leave them. I was there. I fought in the Great War. I was on the field at Anvil. And when I was struck down, they left me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes. I think your brother was a traitor.
output: Then you didn't know Roggvir, and you have no idea what it means to be a Nord of Skyrim! He did the honorable thing, even when he knew it would cost him everything. My brother was the best man in Solitude.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's your place in the court?
output: I'm a Thane. In the future, you may want to gain that information before talking with someone. Risk of looking like an idiot, and all that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So Erikur is your brother?
output: Yes. My older brother and the person you probably want to be speaking to right now. But really, since Torygg's death, Falk Firebeard wields the true power of the Jarl's court. My brother is nothing more than a pompous little fop.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So what's your job here, Melaran?
output: I make sure Erikur keeps breathing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like training in Alchemy.
output: I think I can teach you a thing or two.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like training in Alchemy.
output: I can certainly share a bit of what I know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The same symbol from Goldenglow was involved.
output: Someone's trying to take us down by driving a wedge between Maven and the Guild. Then this is beyond coincidence. First Aringoth and now Sabjorn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What about just going in through the brewery?
output: Sabjorn keeps that locked up tight. If you can get through that way, go right ahead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Okay, never mind.
output: Thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sure, I'll do it.
output: Excellent. Here, this is the key to the warehouse. See if you can drop in on this dealer of poison and convince him to close down his operation permanently.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sure, I'll do it.
output: Good. Here, take the key to the warehouse. Pay dear old Sarthis a visit and tell him Maven sends her regards, would you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And who says I won't? (Intimidate)
output: You can't threaten me any worse than they have!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've discovered a skooma dealer in Riften.
output: Yes, I'm afraid we're aware of Sarthis's presence in the warehouse. Unfortunately, we're certain he has informants within the city guard. Every time we've made a move to arrest him, he's escaped. However, if you'd take care of this discreetly, you might be able to surprise him without warning.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've discovered a skooma dealer in Riften.
output: Ah yes, Sarthis... a thorn in my side for the last few years. I've tried repeatedly to eradicate that meddler, but he has ears within the city guard. Gives us the slip every time we raid the warehouse. However, if you'd wish to eliminate that burden for me... well, let's just say it would go a long way with earning my favor.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here, does this help? (<BribeCost> gold)
output: It's got nothing to do with the coin... this is my life we're talking about.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who has a key to the warehouse?
output: I overheard Bolli say that only the Jarl carries the key to the warehouse. When I meet Sarthis there, he's usually waiting for me outside with his bodyguard.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will you do now?
output: If it wasn't for skooma, I'd already be on my way out of this horrible city. Although I suppose a little mead now and then would be harmless... All my gold... completely gone. Now I have to start over. I'll never use skooma again!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think you owe me one. (Persuade)
output: It's not worth dying over.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where do you get your skooma?
output: Look, I don't think I should say. I mean, they could kill me!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry, sounds dangerous.
output: Hm. Well, if you change your mind, come see me again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry, sounds dangerous.
output: Let me give you a word of advice. Think about your choices carefully from now on. You'll go much farther in Riften with me on your side.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Perhaps some other time.
output: I can't say I'm happy with your decision. If you change your mind, let me know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Perhaps some other time.
output: I'm very disappointed. I'd advise you to rethink that decision soon.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll make sure it's done.
output: Good. Report back to me when your task is complete.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll make sure it's done.
output: Good. Make sure not one of them escapes alive.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've discovered the source of the skooma.
output: Then there's no time to lose. It won't take long for Sarthis's associates to learn of his death. The source of the poison must be destroyed once and for all, otherwise another dealer will simply take his place. Do this task for me and you'll be well on your way to a title in Riften.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've discovered the source of the skooma.
output: Then I want you to head out there immediately and eliminate all of them. I can't afford to have another Sarthis blunder into Riften because they think we're too lazy to disrupt their pitiful operation. Do this task for me and you'll be well on your way to a title in Riften.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sarthis Idren has been taken care of.
output: It's nice to receive good news for a change. Did you recover anything else from the warehouse worth mentioning?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sarthis Idren has been taken care of.
output: Results speak volumes over words and you've just proved it. Did you happen to discover where the fetcher was getting his skooma from?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Never mind. My mistake.
output: I should say so. I'd be careful in the future before you confront someone without all of the facts!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Remember now? (<BribeCost> gold)
output: Come on, what are trying to do? Insult me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you take the horn from Ustengrav?
output: I knew the Greybeards would send you there if they thought you were Dragonborn. They're nothing if not predictable. When you showed up here, I knew you were the one the Greybeards sent, and not some Thalmor plant.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What makes you think dragons are coming back to life?
output: I know they are. I've visited their ancient burial mounds and found them empty. And I've figured out where the next one will come back to life. We're going to go there, and you're going to kill that dragon. If we succeed, I'll tell you anything you want to know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you going to do with this place?
output: Start changing it over to the Black-Briar Meadery West as soon as possible. That was Maven's part of the deal. She's put me in charge of keeping the mead flowing, so that's exactly what I'm going to do. If you're in the area and you ever need anything fenced, you just let me know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a question about the statue.
output: What is there to know? It's in the temple, you bring it out. You bring it to me, I pay you. Now get moving.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's dangerous out there. You should stay.
output: You're... probably right. Just hurry, please. Who knows what those things are doing to her.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We'll save her together.
output: Thank you, friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: This was the only way to get <Alias.Shortname=Jarl>'s help.
output: Yes, yes. Which is why I allowed this... violation of all our traditions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It will be fine.
output: But regrets are pointless. Here we are. Take your seat at the council table and let us see what wisdom we can find among these warriors of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: <Alias=ImperialMinorHoldCapital> seems like a fair trade.
output: In exchange for Riften, the jewel of Skyrim? Hardly. Whiterun seems like a better choice to me. From there we can threaten to undermine the whole Imperial position.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: <Alias=ImperialMinorHoldCapital> seems like a fair trade.
output: In exchange for Riften, the jewel of Skyrim? Hardly. How about the Reach? Gaining control of the silver mines would be invaluable.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't worry. I'll get them to agree to peace.
output: Peace? I doubt it. They may put their weapons down for a moment, but only to gather strength for the next bloodletting. They are not yet tired of war. Far from it. Do you know the ancient Nord word for war? "Season unending"... so it has proved.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're right. <Alias=ImperialMajorHoldCapital> is a fair trade for Riften.
output: I'm glad you agree. I was starting to wonder whose side you were on here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're right. <Alias=ImperialMajorHoldCapital> is a fair trade for Riften.
output: Well. Good! You favor the Empire less than I feared. Maybe we will be able to come to some agreement here after all.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You asked my opinion. I gave it to you.
output: I did ask. Although I'm beginning to wonder whose side you're really on. Still...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You asked my opinion. I gave it to you.
output: Fair enough. I thought you might be able to see past your Imperial loyalties in the interests of peace, but I guess not. Still...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I told you they'd come.
output: So, you've done it. The men of violence are gathered here, in these halls whose very stones are dedicated to peace.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How about <Alias=ImperialMajorHold>?
output: It has its advantages. I've never liked having the Empire perched on my doorstep. And Riften would be easy to hold...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How about <Alias=ImperialMajorHold>?
output: Yes. With Markarth in our hands, we'll be able to raid the Imperial supply lines out of Solitude...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How about <Alias=ImperialMajorHold>?
output: You're right. Tullius isn't in any position to ask for Riften.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ulfric holds only Windhelm. He's in no position to make demands.
output: Just what I was thinking.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm listening.
output: This council was your idea, eh? So tell us, what do you think Riften is worth?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, not yet.
output: Well, hurry up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: They're all dead.
output: Then we've no time to lose. Follow me!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there someway to open them?
output: There'd better be. I didn't come all this way to leave empty handed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Fine. I'll come quietly.
output: You'll never see the sun again, you hear me? No one escapes Cidhna Mine. You'll never see the sun again, you hear me? No one escapes Cidhna Mine. You'll never see the sun again, you hear me? No one escapes Cidhna Mine. No one. No one. No one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're not taking me alive!
output: You'll never leave Markarth! You'll never leave Markarth! You'll never leave Markarth!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can I help?
output: Come see me in Windhelm when this is all done. There's always work for those willing to fight for Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can I help?
output: Come see me in Solitude when this is all done. The Emperor can always use another good soldier.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ulfric should compensate you for <Alias=ImperialTownRaided>.
output: Well said! You may be fighting on the wrong side in this war.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ulfric should compensate you for <Alias=ImperialTownRaided>.
output: Well said.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I thought you needed to be taken down a notch.
output: You made your decision. Now live with it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ulfric doesn't need to give up any more territory.
output: What? Have you forgotten your oath to the Emperor?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ulfric doesn't need to give up any more territory.
output: As I expected, you favor your friends.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm sorry. I was trying to reach a fair agreement.
output: Very honorable, I'm sure, but you should not put your own honor above the freedom of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I accept your offer. I'd like to join the Imperial Legion.
output: Excellent! You aren't the first to have a change of heart, after seeing what Ulfric's reckless pride is doing to Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I accept your offer. I'd like to join the Stormcloaks.
output: Welcome, sister! I'm glad that your eyes have finally been opened to the Empire's true nature.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I did what I thought was right.
output: I'm sure that will be a great comfort to the families of your comrades who died to free the land you just gave back to the Empire.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I did what I thought was right.
output: You should think harder on your commitment to Skyrim's freedom next time you're deciding what's right.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I agree. Ulfric should turn over <Alias=SonsMinorHold2>.
output: I'm impressed at your even-handed treatment. Thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I agree. Ulfric should turn over <Alias=SonsMinorHold2>.
output: I knew I could count on you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You and Ulfric are both mistaken. I fight for Skyrim's freedom.
output: I'm sorry to hear that. I thought you'd finally seen through Ulfric's lies.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I agree. The Empire should turn over <Alias=ImperialMinorHold2>.
output: Spoken like a true daughter of Skyrim!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's to say what happened at <Alias=ImperialTownRaided>?
output: I expected better from you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's to say what happened at <Alias=ImperialTownRaided>?
output: I should have known better than to expect you to give us a fair hearing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Empire doesn't need to give up any more territory.
output: What? And you call yourself a daughter of Skyrim?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's to say what happened at <Alias=SonsTownRaided>?
output: Think carefully where your loyalties lie... sister.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: People are having bad dreams?
output: Not a single man or woman in Dawnstar has gotten a good night's rest in days. We keep having the same nightmare, over and over. If people aren't tired, they're angry, and if they aren't angry, they're afraid. It's made keeping order a mess. I hear Mara has sent one of her priests to the inn to try to calm people down, but I don't know how much words will do now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: People are having bad dreams?
output: That's right. Dawnstar. My Dawnstar is plagued with nightmares. I haven't slept properly in days. That priest of Mara who came here before you says the Divines will cure us. Well, until they do, I don't have any business to discuss with outsiders.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: People are having bad dreams?
output: You haven't heard? All of Dawnstar hasn't had a decent night's rest in days. People are having nightmares they swear are real. They go to bed, but they wake up more tired than yesterday. I've heard that a priest of Mara has come, saying that the Divines will lift this curse somehow, but that remains to be seen.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: People are having bad dreams?
output: Nightmares. I haven't met a single man or woman who doesn't admit to having them. A bad dream I can handle, but everyone having the same bad dream, every night? It's a curse, I say. I hear there's a priest of Mara visiting the inn. Maybe the Divines will cure us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: People are having bad dreams?
output: It's these nightmares. Me and every one of my workers can't catch a nod without having one. They're almost... real. They say a priest of Mara has arrived in town. We'll see if faith can cure this curse.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: People are having bad dreams?
output: Everyone else though.... They're horrible. Imagine dying over and over again in your dreams night after night. New in town? You're lucky. Dreams aren't affecting travelers. They say a priest of Mara is visiting the Windpeak Inn. Says the Divines will take care of everything. We'll see about that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: People are having bad dreams?
output: Everyone here is having nightmares. I have miners tripping over their own feet from lack of sleep. I heard there was a Priest of Mara who was supposed to be looking into it. We'll see if anything comes of that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've defeated the guardians.
output: Kyne's guardian troll awaits you. Complete this trial and you'll have proven yourself a true hunter.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've defeated the guardian spirits.
output: Then you finally know what it means to be a true hunter, in the Nord way. For this you have earned the Blessing of Kyne, and can count me as a friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm willing to pay. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: That's no small amount of coin, friend. I suppose I can come with you for a short venture. Lead on.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There would be treasure to share... (Persuade)
output: Treasure, you say? I suppose the Jarl won't mind if I'm gone for a little while. Lead on.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have need of a priest in my travels.
output: You are looking for Arkay's protection while you delve some dank tomb, I take it? My duties keep me busy in Markarth. I don't know if I can help you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're coming with me. Now. (Intimidate)
output: I think you need to calm down before I summon the guards.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's far beyond my level of skill.
output: Is it? This is disappointing. J'zargo hoped there might be one who could keep pace with his accomplishments.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is it you do here?
output: I am an advisor to the Arch-Mage. The Thalmor wish to promote relations with your College. I am at the Arch-Mage's disposal if he requires advice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Not yet, but I will.
output: Ah, this is good. But J'zargo will know them first. It is good to finally be around mages who may be able to keep up with J'zargo.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, I have.
output: You... you have? Already? Well, J'zargo is surprised. And pleased! There is real competition here. This is good.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did Falion leave the College?
output: He didn't like the Arch-Mage. Hated dealing with him, hated having to answer to him. I understand he settled down in Hjaalmarch, and his presence there caused something of a problem. Falion said he hated what this place was becoming. So he just left. Aren found a note on his desk, and that was it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are there many Conjurers outside the College?
output: Not within society, no. Many who practice within the school of Conjuration do so on their own, secretly. Falion is the only one I know who is public about what he does. He was once my teacher here, but left the College years ago.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does the Arch-Mage often ask for advice?
output: Perhaps not as often as he should. In time, I believe he will be more trusting.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You seem very sure of yourself.
output: There is much for J'zargo to be sure of. There is skill in magic, there is charm, and there is a strong will. J'zargo will be successful, of this there is no doubt.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to know more about the Thalmor.
output: Now that stability has been established between the Dominion and the Empire, we seek only to help Skyrim. To guide its people through this time of transition, to help lead them to a better future.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Not everything is a competition, you know.
output: Oh, but you are wrong. The only reason you could disagree is because you are losing so badly you cannot see it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It doesn't matter. You're safe.
output: Thank you. I don't know what's going on, but I think I owe you my life.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You were this close to being food.
output: Sweet Breath of Arkay, were these the cannibals that were plaguing the Hall of the Dead?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ulfric has a point. The Thalmor have no business here.
output: I'm glad we agree on this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, you're right. Elenwen should stay.
output: Maybe so, but bringing her here is a deliberate provocation. We need to show Tullius we won't be pushed around.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I agree. We can't let Ulfric push us around. Elenwen should stay.
output: Hmm. It feels like a mistake to me, but I'll bow to your judgment on this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let Ulfric have his way now. He'll have to give ground later.
output: We're off to a good start.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why name your store Grave Concoctions?
output: I know it's a bit strange. Not exactly a name to bring comfort to the sick and ailing who come to buy a poultice or salve. But what you must understand about Falkreath is that our town is defined, for better or wrose, by the large and ancient cemetery here. That's why the inn is called Dead Man's Drink, the farm is called Corpselight Farm, and so on. I suppose it's sort of a running joke.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are you a better Jarl than Siddgeir?
output: For one thing, I won't empty Falkreath's coffers to buy myself fine clothes an' expensive mead. For another, I won't get mixed up with criminals and other sorts who take advantage of the honest folk for profit. I might be old, but I haven't forgotten that a Jarl's first duty is to look after his people.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you side with the Stormcloaks?
output: You think some Emperor sitting on a gilded throne in Cyrodiil is going to know what's best for Skyrim?  The Imperial City's so far from here, it might as well be on one of the moons. And yet the Empire thinks it can tell us what to do an' how to live. I'm no man's fool. I know Ulfric Stormcloak's selfish and power-hungry, but he's the devil I know. Does that put it plain enough for you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're a Stormcloak?
output: I was once, but not any more. I was wounded in a skirmish up near Windhelm. This was years ago, mind you. Now, maybe I don't pick up a blade in Ulfric's name no more, but I still hold with his ideals. Skyrim is Nord land, and we ought to rule it. We don't need no help from the Empire on that count.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You mentioned a brother? Who is he?
output: His name's Bolund. He's the one who works the lumber mill down by the river. If you meet him, don't expect much in the way o' conversation. He ain't one for talking, especially with folk he don't know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How does a maid become a Steward?
output: Comes down to trust, I expect. After Dengeir gave up his seat to his nephew, he didn't trust anyone. Everywhere he looks, he sees assassins, spies an' plots against him. I'm the only one he confides in. So, when he was made Jarl again, he didn't wait a moment to name me his Steward. He said I was the only choice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds like loyalty is important to you.
output: I was Dengier's personal guard for years. I risked my hide more than once to protect him. Why would I do that? For money? Because I swore an oath? No, it was because he was a good man and a true friend. A true Nord places loyalty and honor above all else.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There aren't many Redguards in Skyrim. What brought you here?
output: Well, my family back in Hammerfell didn't approve of my interest in lethal poisons and death in general. So I left, and wandered north. When I found this town, with its huge cemetery, I felt right at home. I opened the shop and I've never looked back. This is where I belong.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You said you were the Jarl once?
output: Aye, not so long ago. Some'll tell you I stepped down on account of my old age. Truth is, I found out about all the Imperial spies crawling around Falkreath. A few well-placed bribes, and they bought themselves some friends.  Suddenly the nobles are calling for a new Jarl, and all the while their pockets are jingling with the sound of Imperial septims. They named me Thane, and they got my nephew Siddgeir in my place. A real friend to Cyrodiil, that one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, I put out the fire.
output: That was good work. Deeja's in the hold of the ship. Go down two levels.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Thank you, my Lady.
output: Wallow in your wretchedness, my newest champion.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's a lot of work for such a little thing...
output: Your mockery will be the end of you. And on that day, another servant will feast on your entrails and discover a ring clenched in her teeth. Be grateful for what time I give you until then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your family was concerned for you.
output: Of course. I should've known. Avulstein was behind this, wasn't he?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your family was concerned for you.
output: Of course. I should've known. This was all Avulstein's idea, wasn't it? Where is he?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I told him to wait in Whiterun.
output: A wise decision, but I fear he may not be safe there anymore. They'll go looking for me, and Whiterun will be the first place they search.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I told him to wait in Whiterun.
output: So he might still be in there? I don't dare go back in now. I'll just have to hope that in the confusion he can slip out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I told him to wait in Whiterun.
output: Avulstein... you stupid boy... What is my freedom worth, if the price is my brother's life?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about this incense.
output: Yes, the incense. Fetch for me a deathbell flower, one silver ingot, a flawless ruby, and some vampire dust. Then I will show you how.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Peryite.
output: He is the pus in the wound. Oh, proper ones curl their noses, but it's pus that drinks foul humors and restores the blood. I worship Peryite, yes, because sometimes the world can only be cleansed by disease.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: May I commune with Peryite?
output: Not everyone has the stomach required to entreat my Lord. But Kesh likes you, friend. There is a way Peryite may speak to us who will take Him in. If you wish to commune with Him, we'll need the incense.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There was an attack in the marketplace.
output: My guards told me. Poor Margret. And witnesses report that the attacker was shouting some nonsense about being a Forsworn. I want to make things clear. Markarth has its troubles, but there are no Forsworn in this city. They're only a threat in the hills and along the roads, where they live. Everywhere else, we are in control.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There was an attack in the marketplace.
output: It's unfortunate that we live in such violent times, but there you have it. Now I've been told that the attacker claimed to be a Forsworn. It's nonsense. More likely he was just sick in the head.  So don't concern yourself with it. Markarth is safe. You have my word.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: This should help translate Gallus's Journal.
output: I suppose it would be inappropriate of me to ask how you obtained this, so I simply won't. A rubbing, eh? Odd. I expected notes.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's quite the tale.
output: I undertstand. Now, let me take a good look at this. Over here, please.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could help you get the claw back.
output: You could? I've got some coin coming in from my last shipment. It's yours if you bring my claw back. If you're going after those thieves, you should head to Bleak Falls Barrow, northeast of town.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could help you get the claw back.
output: You could? I've got some coin coming in from my last shipment. It's yours if you bring my claw back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Which are the best Illusion spells?
output: Oh my, that's quite a difficult question. Never underestimate the ability to influence others. Whether they're friends or foes, they're almost all susceptible to Illusion spells. They can turn the tide of a battle in a moment's notice. There are also spells that help in avoiding conflict altogether. Invisibility is tricky to master, but exceptionally useful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn new spells?
output: Well, that depends on what you're looking for.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I... No, I can't see you. Not at all.
output: But you can hear me, obviously. Something still isn't quite right. At least I'm making progress.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Of course I can.
output: Confound it all. I was quite sure I was invisible, or at least transparent.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do Nords have a problem with the College?
output: Well, look at the evidence. Nords generally don't trust magic, so it's not off to a good start. Throw in the Oblivion Crisis, which was caused by magic-users, and the troubles now with the Aldmeri Dominion, who are elves and magic users. And finally take the fact that the College is the only thing left standing after most of Winterhold was destroyed. It's all fairly damning.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is it difficult being so far away from the rest of your family?
output: Not at all. I consider it a blessing. My family was convinced coming here was a death sentence, or worse. It took years of insisting that this is what I'm meant to do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why aren't there many Nords at the College?
