output: Magic is shunned by most. If it can't be swung over your head and used to crack skulls, most Nords want nothing to do with it. Magic is seen as something for elves, and weaker races.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you talking about?
output: Faralda. Don't act like she didn't say anything. I know her, I know what she's been up to.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there any advice you can give about Destruction spells?
output: Certainly. Destruction spells come in different forms, each useful for various purposes. Concentration spells can be cast immediately, though they're weaker. Good for a tight spot, and less costly if you miss. You'll also need to decide whether to devote yourself to a single type of spell. Focusing solely on flame spells will make them more powerful, but you may find yourself at a disadvantage against foes immune to fire.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why side with the Empire?
output: Mutual advantage! Any fool can see that. For centuries, we have benefited from the Empire's protection, and prosperous trade with the south. In exchange, the people of Cyrodiil sleep peacefully, knowing their northern border is guarded by the fiercest warriors in all Tamriel.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What school of magic are you studying?
output: Not at all. I consider it a blessing. My family was convinced coming here was a death sentence, or worse. It took years of insisting that this is what I'm meant to do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What school of magic are you studying?
output: Mages in Cyrodiil are all about politics. The Synod and the College of Whispers are too busy guarding secrets to bother to teach. Skyrim was not J'zargo's first choice, but Winterhold is removed from politics, dedicated to study. This is the place for J'zargo to become great.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What school of magic are you studying?
output: So far, if only because no one is telling me how great I ought to be. I just want to learn, I don't want to think about what's expected of me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about the city's districts.
output: Well, there are three of them. Arranged in three tiers, as you may have noticed. The Plains District is so named because it's the closest of the three to the plains that surround the city. The inn and marketplace are found there. Most of the city's residents live in the Wind District, which is the middle of the three. Dragonsreach occupies the highest, which we call the Cloud District. From here, the Jarl can see all that goes on within his city.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are things not going well for you?
output: We got the mill up and running before we found out that the big stand of trees on the hill was sacred. Now we can't cut them, and can't afford to buy another mill somewhere else.  So we scrounge whatever we can from around the tundra.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do you know so much about mead?
output: A lifetime of study, you might say. The best comes from Riften, but I haven't been there in years. Ever tried making your own? It's... not easy. Trust me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Darkwater Crossing?
output: Those falls... dangerous place. Derkeethus thought he could find some good fish in the pools.  Haven't heard from him in a long while.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Darkwater Crossing?
output: Not much to it, really. We fish, and keep to ourselves. Try to keep from upsetting the Empire or the Stormcloaks, and so far the war's left us alone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Kynesgrove?
output: A bunch of lazy rabble trying to make a living. Can't get better workers in because everyone's afraid of the tomb up above the mine. Dead dragons... it hasn't moved since Ysgramor and it's not going to start now. Superstitious milk drinkers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Kynesgrove?
output: So it seems the milk drinkers were right. That dragon was nearly the death of us. All we can do now is rebuild.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Has the war affected you?
output: I'm lucky enough that none of my friends have been killed. Of course we have soldiers coming through all the time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me more about your people.
output: We have lived in Skyrim since before the Nords came. Our way is simple, all work to make the tribe strong. Only the bravest are allowed to lead, and to marry. A great chief is able to attract many wives and raise bold children. Wise women like myself are mothers of chieftains. We guide the tribe and advice our kin on what is most pleasing to Malacath.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who is Malacath?
output: He is our creator and master. The Daedric Lord of the Sworn Oath and the Bloody Curse. Malacath teaches us to honor all words with action. To demand blood from your enemies and strength from your allies. He watches over all Orcs as his children. A truth those who leave the stronghold are quick to forget.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your weapons and armor are impressive.
output: It is said that an Orc first learns to wield a hammer in her mother's womb. It is said that an Orc first learns to wield a hammer in her mother's womb. By tradition, a mother always teaches her children how to smith. If a chief has a second wife, she is called the "Forge-wife" in honor of this. By tradition, a mother always teaches her children how to smith. If a chief has a second wife, she is called the "Forge-wife" in honor of this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do the Orcs govern themselves?
output: The Code of Malacath. It is both tradition and law in the strongholds. Break the code, and you must pay Blood Price. The code is not written anywhere. It is known and carried on by the Orcs, and all who live in the strongholds follow it. For an outlander, following it is simple. Do not steal or attack anyone in the stronghold, or be ready to pay in gold or blood.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about yourself?
output: Ah, well, I'm Redguard, as I'm sure you've noticed. Though not like you. Hmph. No, definitely not like you. I am a child of Hammerfell, born of the sands of the mighty Alik'r. In that great desert, blood is a shade of crimson I can scarce describe. My past is long and storied, and not altogether proud. But the Dark Brotherhood saved me from myself. And I have never looked back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Very well. What does Azura need?
output: You must go to a fortress, endangered by water, yet untouched by it. Inside, you will find an elven mage who can turn the brightest star as black as night. It is cryptic, I know, but Azura's signs are never wrong. I believe the fortress may refer to Winterhold. Ask if they know this elven enchanter.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: I am Sanguine, Daedric Prince of Debauchery! I know, I know, how could I lie to you? Well, how could I trust you until we've shared a few drinks? But it wasn't long before I realized you'd make a more interesting bearer of my not-quite-holy staff than this waste of flesh.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I lost Madesi's ring.
output: Lost it? Well, at least you showed signs of initiative by telling me. I guess I shouldn't be surprised with the way things are going around here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do?
output: Yamarz has demanded we stay inside the walls. We cannot leave. I must petition Malacath for relief. This curse must be lifted. But I cannot travel to Malacath's shrine. The ritual must be done here, and I do not have the materials I need. I beg of you, can you bring me Troll Fat and a Daedra Heart? I have no wish to depend on a stranger, but I have no choice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: Nords don't care much for magic. The College in Winterhold is about the only place it's not looked down on. Otherwise you could talk to the Jarl's pet wizard in Solitude.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: The College of Winterhold is the only place in Skyrim open-minded enough to teach magic. Although Ulfric's court wizard has been known to take on apprentices once in a while.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: Magic? Goodness, not here! Nothing dangerous like that! That's all kept to that College up in Winterhold. Better that than dealing with Ulfric's wizard like some do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: Magic is for the weak. Elves, I mean. They keep to that College in Winterhold. They know their place. Of course there is Farengar. He might be the Jarl's wizard, but at least he's a Nord.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: Pfft, I should've guessed as much. Your kind sticks to that College in Winterhold, as well they should. You'd never think to learn from a Nord like the Jarl's wizard.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: There's a College in Winterhold that teaches magic. It's very secretive, though, and you know how people hate secrets. The Jarl's court wizard was taught there. That one's full of secrets.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: Magic? That's dangerous. You want to learn that, go to that College in Winterhold. They teach that stuff there. Hey! I know. The Jarl's wizard could teach ya. He's lots closer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: I've got no interest in magic users. No use for their kind at all. They're way up north in Winterhold, and that's fine with me. I don't even like our Jarl havin' a  court wizard.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: Bit of advice, folks here don't care for magic or those that use it. If you're intent on it, check at the College up in Winterhold. Either that or go see the Jarl's court wizard.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: Looking to blow yourself up? I hear that's what magic does to you. There's a College in Winterhold that teaches magic, unless that blew up too. Be a lot safer just to have the Jarl's wizard teach you a thing or two.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: Magic is nothing but trouble. If you're set on it, there's that College in Winterhold or Ulfric's court wizard. But don't say I didn't warn you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: The people of Skyrim don't like magic much, so about the only place you're likely to find a teacher is the College of Winterhold.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: That'd be the College in Winterhold. I suppose you'll be headed there, then. Well, don't let me get in your way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: Seen enough magic in my day to know to stay away from it. I'd stay away from the Jarl's wizard in Dawnstar too.  If you wanna be a damn fool, go to the College in Winterhold instead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: You lookin' for Falion? Why don't you go bother those mages at their College in Winterhold and leave my brother alone?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: Any aspiring mage would do well to look for the College in Winterhold. Head there, and you'll get what you're after. Although our Jarl's humble wizard might be willing to help you too.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: Head north to Winterhold. There's a College there, they teach magic. Most Nords don't care for them. Else you could go see the Jarl's wizard. Might be able to help you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: Magic? You're on the wrong side of Skyrim. You want Winterhold... that College there. They teach it. Otherwise you can try the Jarl's wizard. I wouldn't, though.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: Winterhold. You want the College there. They teach quite a bit.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: Oh, I think you'll find that magic is rare in Skyrim. Winterhold, though... The College there has it in abundance. Look there if you wish to learn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: Not here. Definitely not here. You want to learn, join the College in Winterhold. They'll deal with it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: Magic is... frowned upon in Skyrim. Only the mages at the College of Winterhold teach it freely. If you wish to learn, join them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: A prospective student, are you? Well, I'm afraid I'm not much good at teaching. You should try your luck at the College of Winterhold.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I learn more about magic?
output: I have no time or patience for a student. Perhaps the College of Winterhold will grant you admission.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It was quite a trip. Where are we?
output: I thought you might not remember your first trip here. You had a big night. I think you've definitely earned the staff.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to know more about the College's history.
output: I've seen documents dating back to the late Second Era. Beyond that, it's hard to say. Events in the last several hundred years resulted in a significant loss of our history, I'm afraid.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why all the hatred for the Empire?
output: They mean to take our history and crush it all in the name of some damn treaty. The soil beneath our feet is steeped in the blood of our ancestors. We've fought for this land and... died for it. I lost my own daughter to the Imperial dogs, and by Talos I'll not lose anyone else!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened to your daughter?
output: Lilija joined the Stormcloaks many years ago, when the first of the skirmishes broke out across Skyrim. I was so proud of her. She served as a Battle Maiden, using her healing arts to help those that fell on the battlefield. Never even lifted a blade in her life. It didn't matter. The Imperial soldiers cut her down... killed her like a dog and left her body to rot in the mud. And that's why I won't rest easy until every single Imperial soldier joins her, and Ulfric sits upon the throne of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No thanks.
output: Suit yourself. If you change your mind, I'll be around.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: May I ask why you're in mourning?
output: It was my sister, Lilija. She served as a Battle Maiden with the Stormcloaks. We recently heard she'd been killed... I... I find it difficult to talk about. Perhaps you'd be better off speaking to my parents about it. Anyway, I'm glad my work at the Black-Briar Meadery keeps me busy. Helps me keep my mind off of things.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you work for the meadery?
output: Sure. How do you think I get my hands on the good stuff and offer it so cheap? You think old Maven is just giving it away to anyone? Good thing she makes so much money. Makes it easier for merchandise like this to fall through the cracks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about your parents.
output: My father was a Stormcloak soldier in his younger days. Now he just walks the streets spewing his hatred and propaganda. My mother is the Priestess of Talos. She tends to the shrine and teaches his ways. I'm just not so sure she's delivering the right message.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you selling?
output: Sorry, fresh out. Maybe next time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you selling?
output: Absolutely. Did you still want to buy one?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you selling?
output: Nothing but the best. Black-Briar Mead... fresh from the vat. Best of all, you don't have to pay the ridiculous prices Maven charges. So what do you say to that?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the word around town?
output: Riften's biggest exports used to be fishing and honey, until the Black-Briar family moved in. Now the meadery is the biggest game in town.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the word around town?
output: The city guard has been tearing Riften apart looking for the source of our skooma problem. I'd hate to be in their shoes if they get discovered.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the word around town?
output: Sibbi Black-Briar is furious that his ex-lover tried to murder him. He's leaving no stone unturned searching for her.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the word around town?
output: Mjoll the Lioness used to adventure across Skyrim before she settled down in Riften. I hear it all ended when she lost her enchanted blade.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the word around town?
output: Crime is at an all-time high in this city thanks to the Thieves Guild. Don't we have enough problems with the war going on?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the word around town?
output: If Maven Black-Briar keeps raising prices on mead, I'll have to resort to watering it down just to make ends meet.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the word around town?
output: If it's true that the dragons have returned, what will it mean for all of us? Is this how it all ends?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sure, I'll take one. (Pay 10 gold)
output: Here you go. Oh, and keep it quiet. This stuff isn't exactly easy to get a hold of at these prices, if you catch my drift.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No one has said anything about you.
output: Oh she will, mark my words. And don't you let her.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have no idea what you're talking about.
output: No? Well, then she hasn't gotten to you yet. But she will. And you don't you believe a word of it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about the Sleeping Tree?
output: How the tree came to grow there is a bit of a mystery... Some say that when Vvardenfell erupted, a piece was blown to the middle of Skyrim and from the crater grew the tree. I've also heard that it was a spore that fell from an island floating in the sky, but that just sounds like nonsense. All I know is that the sap makes you feel as healthy as a cave troll, but slow as a drunk horker. And that and it fetches good coin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The giant in <Alias=GiantCamp> is dead.
output: You've shown those monsters that they will no longer be tolerated in the Pale. Good work. Here, a reward from your Jarl.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where'd you learn to play?
output: My mother taught me. She was a Bard, from the college in Solitude. I hear they accept most people who apply, if you're ever interested.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't have time for that.
output: You don't have time? Fine.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was looking for a drink. Or some work.
output: Drowning your troubles in mead? A lot of folks are doing that these days. You'll want the Windpeak Inn. As for work, you could try to catch Skald in a good mood, but your best bet would be working in the mines. They're on opposite ends of town.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It will be done.
output: I'm counting on you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you been in Dawnstar long?
output: Seems Brina Merilis and the Legion came and now she's Jarl. That's a relief. I don't like the fighting, but Brina is the woman for the job.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did I see you arguing with someone?
output: Skald supports Ulfric's rebellion, and he doesn't like having a couple of old Legionnaires living in his town. He's a fool. A dragon has attacked Helgen. Dawnstar needs the Empire now more than ever.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I can't do that right now.
output: Disappointing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for work.
output: Giants are a common problem in the Pale. The Empire always demanded I leave them be, but the Empire isn't here now. Go and slay one of the beasts. It should let them know that Dawnstar is not to be trifled with.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It will be done.
output: Good.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any more work?
output: You've proven reliable. There's a group of bandits in my Hold that I... may have had a few discreet dealings with. The cut they were giving me was good at first, but now it's time to clean things up. Go and take care of it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've killed the leader of <Alias=BanditCamp>.
output: Teach them to stop paying me. Here. You deserve a reward for your service.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not interested.
output: It was supposed to be an honor, but very well. It was supposed to be an honor, but very well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could deliver that for you.
output: Thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So you're in charge of Anga's Mill?
output: That I am. My father left it to me after he died in that Great War against the Elves. I don't care what's going on in the world. Rebellion. Dragons awakening. The mill is enough trouble for me to worry about.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It would be an honor.
output: Good luck. Good luck.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's a shame.
output: Indeed it is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's in charge around here?
output: That would be Jarl Skald the Elder. He's over in the White Hall, probably talking about Ulfric like he's the second coming of Talos.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's in charge around here?
output: Jarl Brina Merilis is in charge, thanks to the Empire. Best hide any Talos amulets you have.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for work.
output: If you don't mind digging, I own the Quicksilver Mine. It's a better life than working in that damned Iron-Breaker Mine with all those milk drinkers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's too bad.
output: Then I don't have time for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a delivery from <Alias.ShortName=QuestGiver>.
output: Oh, thank you. The dogs were getting restless. Here, this is for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you do in Dawnstar?
output: I own Iron-Breaker Mine. We make twice as much coin as those horkers over in Quicksilver Mine, and don't let anyone tell you otherwise. I pay a good wage for any iron ore you dig up, if you're looking for work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for a job.
output: If you've got an axe, you can always make gold chopping wood. Just bring me everything you cut.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who runs Dawnstar?
output: That would be Skald the Elder. He's been running Dawnstar ever since he was a boy, and he never lost that brat's attitude. Turned on the Empire first chance he got. Now we're all part of this rebellion.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who runs Dawnstar?
output: Brina Merilis came in with the whole damn Legion and deposed Skald. Couldn't have happened to a better man.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: If it will help the cause...
output: Very good.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What mission?
output: The General has sent me to obtain a powerful weapon for the war effort. This was the last great bastion of the Dragon Cult, and their leader's mask was reported to be quite powerful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not anyone's champion. Find someone else.
output: There is no one else, but very well. I cannot force you to accept your destiny.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think I found the mage from your vision.
output: Good. All will be revealed in time. Keep playing your part, and Azura will reward you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have Azura's Star.
output: Stendarr's Mercy. You found it. Azura's Star. Maybe this is my chance to make things right. I can finish Malyn's work, the way we had meant to before his madness. It would mean cutting the Star off from Azura. Only black souls would be able to enter it once we finished.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for an elven mage who studies stars.
output: Who sent you? Was it the College? The Jarl? We agreed there would be no more questions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did the daedra drive Malyn insane?
output: Azura is no ordinary Daedra. She commands an entire realm inside of Oblivion. The more Malyn worked on the Star, the more she was able to damn him. It started slowly at first. Malyn would see things that weren't there. Then he would yell at students over words they hadn't said. Then one day I walked in and Malyn had... killed a student, and in a horrific moment of inspiration, he started using her soul for his work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here. Take it.
output: I will commune with Azura.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is it? What happened?
output: There was an... unfortunate incident a few years ago. An elven mage named Nelacar was exiled from the College over it. He's still in town, getting by plying spells to the people inside the Frozen Hearth. Disgraceful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there an elven mage here that studies stars?
output: The mages are up in the College. You can ask them, if they'll let you in. Then again, Nelacar might know. He's an old-timer from the College, but he has a room here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How does Azura's Star work?
output: I mentioned how the Star is a soul gem, only it never gets depleted? There's another rule the artifact follows. You can only store white souls in the Star, belonging to the lesser creatures. Azura's magic won't allow black souls to enter it. As a mortal, Malyn's soul was black, so part of his work was breaking past Azura's rules. He was close before... well, I already told you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then let's get to it.
output: I've been pouring over the plans you brought us, and I'm convinced the Eyes of the Falmer are in the dwarven ruins at Irkngthand. Karliah and I will meet you there. Prepare yourself, lad. This will be a fight to remember!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't know what to say.
output: Well, we have a bit of an errand to run before your coronation, so don't get sentimental on me now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Me? What about you?
output: I've been at this game a long time, my friend. A long time. I've stolen trinkets from nobles and framed priests for murder. I'm good at what I do, maybe even one of the best. But it's all I know. I've never been one to lead. Never desired it, never cared for it. Don't want it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I accept.
output: Then it's decided. When this entire sorry affair is over, we'll handle the details. Until then, we have quite the task ahead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I accept.
output: Then it's decided. When this is all over and Delvin's contacts assure me that we've regained our footing in Skyrim, we'll handle the details. Until then, we have quite the task ahead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's about time you asked.
output: Ha! Spoken like the leader of the Thieves Guild. Just don't lose yourself in the role. We have a bit of an errand to run before your coronation.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, it's not right.
output: Look. Everyone in the Guild admires what you've done. Maybe they won't come out and simply tell you, but I promise you it's true. And now they know Mercer never genuinely cared about the Guild. He lacked the loyalty you obviously possess. I can't think of anyone better.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why tell this to me?
output: As a result, we both feel that you'd make an excellent replacement for Mercer as leader of the Thieves Guild. Thanks to your efforts, the Guild's been restored to it's full strength and you've exposed the traitor in our midst. Karliah and I had a long discussion before you arrived here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why tell this to me?
output: As a result, we both feel that you have the potential of replacing Mercer as leader of the Thieves Guild. Thanks to your efforts, Mercer's treachery has been exposed. After we deal with him, all that remains is restoring the Guild to its full strength. Karliah and I had a long discussion before you arrived here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How is Dawnstar faring in the war?
output: The Stormcloaks are destined to win this fight. Talos is with us, and when you fight under a Divine's blessing, victory is assured. Dawnstar has a history of being the site of battles that have crippled the fate of the Empire. I hope this remains true.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is Dawnstar prepared for dragon attacks?
output: The only reason dragons are attacking is because Talos is angry with us for turning our backs on him. As soon as we drive the Empire out of Skyrim, the dragons will vanish. Mark my words.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Has the war been hard on Markarth?
output: It all started here. This rebellion. When the Empire lost the Reach during the Great War, we became desperate. We promised a group of Nord militia free worship in exchange for their help retaking the Hold. Then the Elves found out about it. We were forced to arrest all of them. Ulfric Stormcloak, their leader, used the whole thing as proof that the Empire had abandoned Skyrim. The rebels called it "The Markarth Incident." It was the founding day for the Stormcloaks, and where this war really started.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you work here all day?
output: Yes. Ever since mother died a few winters ago. I play songs and help with the drinks when I have the time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Instruction? Where do I sign up?
output: Well, you are lovely to look at, and there's so many things I could teach you, but I'm afraid the Temple isn't taking in new students.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you arrest the Nord militia?
output: The White-Gold Concordat. Our treaty with the Elves after the Great War forbids free worship of Talos. But that's what we promised Ulfric and his men. It seems foolish looking back, but at the time we were hoping the Elves wouldn't find out. So when they did find out, it was either we arrest Ulfric and the militia, or enter into yet another war with the Aldmeri Dominion. The choice was clear. And now, Ulfric threatens the thinly veiled peace we sacrificed so much for.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's your position on the war?
output: The Imperials were weak. They created this Forsworn problem, but now that we're in charge we'll solve it. Once the war is over, I'll petition Ulfric to send the militia and we'll cleanse the Reach of this menace. Then the Forsworn will be where they belong. In the mines, bringing us wealth.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Empire lost the Reach before? How?
output: When the Aldmeri Dominion invaded the Imperial City, the Legion all but turned a blind eye to the other provinces. Many of the disgruntled natives of the Reach used the opportunity to depose the Empire, and founded what they called an independent kingdom. It was little more than a chaotic uprising, but the Reach was removed from Imperial authority for two years before we reclaimed it. But the leaders of the uprising refused our offers of peace. They fled into the hills and became the Forsworn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're researching the Dwemer?
output: Yes. Their history and culture is all around us in Markarth. A race of stonecutters, artisans, and engineers. They invented machines and built elaborate underground cities where they researched powers to rival the gods themselves. And then, at a time we are still not sure when, they disappeared. The whole people, all at once. Leaving behind only their works.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is Markarth prepared to deal with dragons?
output: The stone structure the Dwarves have left makes us invincible. Let the dragons singe a few carpets. They'll never topple Markarth.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here. Have a gold piece. (1 gold)
output: Finally. Now get lost.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Dragons have returned to Skyrim.
output: Yes, I know. We have some advantages if they come here. The city is built into the mountainside, so it's hard to reach into even from the skies. And everything is made of stone. Even the beds. We'll have no trouble from dragon's fire here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How's the war going?
output: The Empire has stretched itself too far. This rebellion in Skyrim is one problem, but solving it won't fix everything. But that's the kind of talk an old warhorse shouldn't be making. Don't worry. I have my problems with the Empire, but I'm still a soldier first. We'll keep peace and order in Dawnstar.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Dare I ask where all this meat comes from?
output: Ah, now that is a good question. Where does Hogni get the finest, freshest meat from all over the Reach? The answer is simple. Orcs. There is a stronghold nearby whose hunters can butcher a deer in seconds. Now having an Orc for a wife would be something, yes. Strong and bulky. Too bad they don't let people go beyond the walls. Let me show you where they are. Maybe they welcome you. Maybe they put an arrow in your face. Who knows?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Empire created the Forsworn? How?
output: Through neglect. During the Great War, they let the unwashed natives retake the Reach and declare their own sovereignty. The Stormcloaks were forced to retake the Reach on our own, but that taste of independence emboldened them. And the Forsworn were born. In the end, we took back Markarth, but those damn Forsworn still stalk the hills and roads, looking for revenge.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is Dawnstar prepared for dragon attacks?
output: No. We're completely exposed. Bows and arrows are in short supply. Every building is made of thatch and wood. I've given standing orders to the guards to prepare water bucket runs to the harbor in case of a fire, but that's all we can do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you the court wizard?
output: If you could call it that. The Jarl can make all the demands in the world, I'm not setting one foot on the battlefield. I fought in the Great War. I cut enough young lives short, I'm not going to do it again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who is Dibella? This is her temple?
output: A heathen. Lovely. Oh, don't put on that angry look. I'm just teasing you. Dibella is the Divine of Beauty. She is a patron deity to artists and bards and those who seek life's simple pleasures. The temple offers her blessings to pilgrims and instruction in enjoying all life has to offer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have all the things needed to repair it.
output: Oh, the Hagraven feather and so on. You can throw all those out.  You see...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I submit. Take me to jail.
output: You'll never see the sun again. No one escapes Cidhna Mine. No one. You'll never see the sun again. No one escapes Cidhna Mine. No one. You'll never see the sun again. No one escapes Cidhna Mine. No one. You'll never see the sun again. No one escapes Cidhna Mine. No one. You'll never see the sun again. No one escapes Cidhna Mine. No one. You'll never see the sun again. No one escapes Cidhna Mine. No one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready to go.
output: Well aren't you in luck. He's the next piece of gutter scum on the docket. Between you and me, I hope you cleave his arrogant head open.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do I have to do?
output: We don't just let people rot in cells until they've served their time. Here, you fight. If you win, you go free.  If you lose, well, you'll know the freedom of Sovngarde if you're lucky.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Calm down. Just tell me what happened.
output: I'm sorry, I'm just... you're right. Let me explain.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Stand aside, woman. I'm here for Fjola!
output: Fjola?  How do you know that name?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Her husband sent me. Where is she?
output: Christer?  He's here?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I had to kill her. She attacked me.
output: What?  My Fjola would never...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There's no way you'll come peacefully?
output: None. Not back to him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: This is pointless. I should just kill you and be done with it.
output: Better men have tried. Let's finish this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What am I supposed to tell Christer?
output: I don't know. I never expected the old bag to follow me so far. Just get rid of him. But don't kill him. I don't hate the man. I just want him to go back to his farm and forget about me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait. You know him?
output: The fool's my husband. I'm Fjola - or I was, once. Don't you see? I left that old scab. Came home to Skyrim, and found this rabble of bandits.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll try getting him to leave.
output: Take my wedding band. Stuhn only knows why I've kept it this long. He'll recognize it. Tell him whatever you think will convince him to leave. The ring itself is worth a few bits. Keep it as thanks for cutting off the last vestige of an unwanted fate.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's quite a story.
output: And it won't end here. I'd die before I went back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found this ring, but no sign of her.
output: Her marriage band? Then there's hope - she was here! I have to move on if I want to find her. Please, take the coin I promised. Blessings of Stendarr on you!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: She's dead, but I found this.
output: That... I gave it to her on our wedding day. Help me, Divines... it's true isn't it?  I'm sorry. Keep the ring. I cannot bear the weight of them in my heart, and I must make the journey alone now. Thank you for... thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's going on?
output: It's my wife, Fjola!  I think she's being held in this tower.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He won't bother you again.
output: How did... no, forget it. I don't care to know. I'm free of the little man, and that's what matters.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Very well. I'll look for her.
output: Thank you! I don't have much, but I can give you some coin for the trouble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I haven't dealt with him yet.
output: Then stop wasting my time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're sure she's being held here?
output: Honestly? I have no idea. But I've looked all over and the kidnappings here started around when she disappeared. So I have to hope...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't like where this is going.
output: I could soul trap you. Place you inside the Star. Then bring you back once Malyn has been dealt with.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's to keep me from ending up like Malyn?
output: Malyn's soul is beyond hope because his body is dead. But I'll be keeping you just slightly alive on this end. But be careful. If you die inside the Star, your soul will be disrupted. There's nothing anyone can do for you if that happens.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You want to send my soul inside, don't you?
output: A special type of soul trap. Placing you inside the Star without fully killing you. Once Malyn has been dealt with, I'll bring you back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready to enter the Star.
output: Okay. Stand very still. This might sting.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So we need to deal with Malyn somehow.
output: Precisely. But it's not as simple as enchanting Malyn away. He's put up barriers. Souls are only allowed in, not out. If we were to... somehow... send a soul inside the Star. One that was ready to overpower Malyn from the inside....

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do I do once I'm inside?
output: Malyn's soul should be in the Star. Theoretically, purging him will be just like killing a ghost anywhere else. I'll have a magical tether to your soul while you're inside. Once you're done, it'll be as simple as pulling you back into your body.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: By right of glory. I lead the Companions of Jorrvaskr.
output: I welcome the chance to challenge the blade of Ysgramor's heir, honored shield-sister to Kodlak Whitemane, whom I've watched for in vain.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Won't that kill him?
output: He's already dead. Worse, the enchantment keeping him intact requires black souls. I don't know how many people he must have killed. If we don't do something, the enchantment will eventually fade, and the Star will slip back into Oblivion. Azura will have the last laugh.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does a Housecarl do?
output: I am charged with protecting the Jarl from any and all threats. Powerful men have many enemies. More so, in times of strife. So you can imagine the dangers. Oh yes, there have been attempts on the Jarl's life. More than one would-be assassin has met his end at the tip of my blade.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did a dark elf come to be Housecarl?
output: Balgruuf and I share a battle bond. We met as youths, and forged our friendship in the fires of war. When he became Jarl, I insisted on serving as his protector. He had no cause to argue. Gods, you are curious. Almost... dangerously so.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Talos?
output: Hello, my friend! If you seek knowledge about mighty Talos, you have most certainly come to the right person. In mortal life, Talos was a Nord possessed of unmatched tactical skill, limitless wisdom and the power to see into men's hearts. Talos mastered the power of the Voice, and with it he united the lands of men into a great Empire. In southern lands, he was known by the name Tiber Septim. Here in Skyrim, we honor him by his proper Nord name. So great was his reign in life, when he ascended to the heavens he was made lord of the Divines. If you want to know more, I'm sure you can find any number of tomes on the subject.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why is the keep called Dragonsreach?
output: That is an old tale, but well known to those of us who serve in the keep. Long ago, there lived a mighty hero of the Nords. Olaf One-Eye. Olaf did battle with a fearsome dragon named Numinex. The struggle between Olaf and the dragon culminated in a mighty duel atop Mount Anthor, with Olaf the victor. Olaf returned in triumph to Whiterun. By his decree, the city's keep was rebuilt as a prison for Numinex. And so, from that time until this, our great keep has been called "Dragonsreach."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will it take to end the war?
output: Ulfric Stormcloak's head on a pike. Do you think Ulfric really cares about Skyrim's independence, or the welfare or its people? I promise you, he doesn't. He's nothing more than a barbarian renegade, whose lust for power has cost the lives of countless innocents.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the city's history?
output: Ah, splendid! Our fine city has a proud history, and I'm happy to share what I know. The history of Whiterun begins with Jorrvaskr, the hall of the Companions. For a long time, it was the only building on the mountain. As time passed, a thriving community sprang up around Jorrvaskr, as was common with mead halls. Today, Whiterun is the jewel of Skyrim. I can say without boast that is the greatest city in all the holds.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are the duties of a court wizard?
output: I'll put it simply, so you'll understand. I advise the Jarl in matters of magic. If the hold is faced with any threats or mysteries of a magical nature, I am called upon to explain things and suggest a course of action. Hopefully that answer will satisfy you. Good day.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Aren't you worried you'll be arrested?
output: Let them come! I have no fear, for Talos is my ally and I am his prophet. His word is upon my lips, his voice in my throat.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can you protect Whiterun from the dragons?
output: With good planning and constant vigilance. Even now, my court wizard, Farengar, continues his research into ways we might drive back these terrors.  We must also have ample reserves of water to combat the fires that will surely spread after an attack. But our greatest weapon? Courage. For if we cannot kill the beast, we must at least have the tenacity to drive it back. Until brave heroes step forward to destroy these monsters, that is the best we can do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you owe allegiance to the Imperials?
output: If I said that was a tedious question, would you be smart enough to know what I meant? Probably not. As long as I'm left alone to pursue my research, I don't care who gives the orders. Now, I'm a busy man and your pointless questions are boring me terribly. Good day.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you encountered any dragons?
output: Sadly, no. My work affords me few opportunities for such an adventure. Perhaps some hero will bring one to Dragonsreach, like old Olaf One-Eye once did. What a fascinating conversation that would be!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why was Talos worship outlawed?
output: Because the so-called Emperor is a coward! That's right, I said coward! Oh yes! He agreed to banish the worship of Talos at the tip of an Aldmeri sword. They called it the "White-Gold Concordat." Well, I call it blasphemy! A true son of the Empire would never have turned his back on our greatest hero, not at any price. Well, let me tell you something, friend. Cyrodiil is a long way from here, and in Skyrim, we will never forsake mighty Talos!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What threats does the jarl face?
output: Take your pick. Dragons, Stormcloak assassins, ambitious and unscrupulous nobles... Sometimes I think his own children want him dead. And those are just the physical threats. Assaults on his sanity are another matter entirely. Every day, he deals with obsequious functionaries and incompetent bureaucrats. Sadly, I'm not allowed to eliminate them. Well, not yet, anyway.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You said your son is in Old Hroldan?
output: That's right. Old inn to the south. The oaf doesn't even bother to visit these days. What am I supposed to do if the dragons burn down the farm? You're a traveler, right? I have this letter for him. Let him know how much of a failure he is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Hand me the letter. I'll take it to him.
output: Good. You make sure the lug tips you when he gets it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't have time.
output: Typical. Well don't mind me, then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a letter from your father.
output: What's this? I guess some things never change. Thanks for bringing this to me. Here, for your trouble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Reporting in.
output: The Stormcloaks are here. In force. Get down to the front line. This is it. We must hold the city. Move it! The Stormcloaks are here. In force. Get down to the front line. This is it. We must hold the city. Move it! The Stormcloaks are here. In force. Get down to the front line. This is it. We must hold the city. Move it!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Reporting in.
output: The Imperials are here. All lined up pretty-like in their shiny armor. We'll put a few dents in those bastards before we give up the city. Move it!  The Imperials are here. All lined up pretty-like in their shiny armor. We'll put a few dents in those bastards before we give up the city. Move it!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sure, I'll take the book.
output: Great.  Here you go. Come back later and I'll have other things.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Runil was one of the Thalmor during the war...
output: I knew he was troubled but one of the Thalmor? I wish I could say I did not believe it. Thank you for telling me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Some of your friends feel you're troubled.
output: Burying the past is much harder than burying remains. I'm... I'm afraid of what you will think of me if I tell you about the things I've done.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What sort of items?
output: First off, let's keep this between us. I picked these up from the graves in town so don't go blabbing about it to Kust. You have to understand, Gentle Repose is a fallow festering place I should have left a long time ago. This is one of the few ways I make any money. Right now I've got a book that I think you might like.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Go on.
output: Although I have not practiced in a long time I was once a wizard. Even when I was young my magic was undeniably powerful. It was that power that brought me to the attention of the Thalmor. In the Summerset Isles it is a great honor to be chosen to serve the Thalmor.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Runil was one of the Thalmor during the war...
output: I knew he was troubled, but one of the Thalmor? I wish I could say I did not believe it. Thank you for telling me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Thalmor?
output: They are the governing council of the Aldmeri Dominion. They lead us to attack the Empire and forced the Empire to agree to stop worshiping Talos.  It was during the war with the Empire that I was at the height of my power. As a Thalmor battlemage I laid waste the enemy. Men, women, children, no one was spared my wrath. I destroyed whole villages.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: A book?
output: Yeah, if your interested then I'll give you the book for free. If you like it you can come back later and I'll have other stuff. I mean, it don't cost me anything to let you have one and the dead won't notice their stuff missing. heh.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your secret is safe with me.
output: Thank you. May Arkay bless you. I won't forget this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Lod has a book he stole from a grave.
output: I knew something was up. I'll make sure he doesn't disrespect this place anymore. Honesty is a rare thing to find these days. Thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And you're afraid your friends will find out?
output: I dream about those days still. Except I'm not me. I can see myself there and I try to stop what I know is going to happen but... Many of the Empire's troops were Nords at that point. Some of them could even have been from around here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready to enter the Star.
output: Have faith, mortal. I will be watching over you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: If it's fixed, then it's mine.
output: Go ahead. Take it. I'd sooner finally put this chapter of my life behind me. Congratulations. You've altered the fate of a Daedric artifact and lived.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do we do with it now?
output: Now? You could use it for what we meant it for. Using black souls for enchanting. The Black Star will never decay, but it can no longer hold the white souls of lesser creatures. You keep it. I'd sooner finally put this chapter of my life behind me. Congratulations. You've changed the fate of a Daedric artifact and lived.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Thank you, Lady Azura.
output: Farewell, mortal. Know that Azura will be guarding over the threads of your fate in the Twilight.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I dislike the daedra looking into my future.
output: Oblivion has been watching you since the day you were conceived, mortal. Do not think that your life has been served by your will alone. Go now. I have seen the threads of your fate in the Twilight, and you still have much to accomplish.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have a plan?
output: The front gate is locked so you'll need to use the mine entrance behind us.  Open the front gate and we'll try and give you some support.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds like more then just "bad blood."
output: You ask a lot of questions for a mercenary.  Just get in there and open the gate, we'll try and provide help once that's done.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm the best.
output: Good, the place is crawling with bandits.  We lost some good men trying to take it earlier.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I expect in return for my help?
output: My family is everything to me.  Clear the fort and on top of the posted reward you can have whatever items you'd like.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here, take it.
output: Thanks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to talk to him. I'm a friend. His life's in danger. (Persuade)
output: Maybe I'm just getting soft in my old age, but I actually believe you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to talk to him. I'm a friend. His life's in danger. (Persuade)
output: That's a touching story. Now get outta my face.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to talk to him. I'm a friend. His life's in danger. (Persuade)
output: A friend, huh? Well... then it's probably okay if I tell you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to talk to him. I'm a friend. His life's in danger. (Persuade)
output: I guess you don't hear too well. I never heard of this "friend" of yours.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you going to tell me, or am I going to have to beat it out of you?
output: There's no need for that. Not like he's a friend of mine or anything. Just calm down.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you going to tell me, or am I going to have to beat it out of you?
output: You've got a lot of nerve. But not a lot of common sense.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you going to tell me, or am I going to have to beat it out of you?
output: Easy there. I don't want that kind of trouble. Guy ain't worth it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you going to tell me, or am I going to have to beat it out of you?
output: Yeah. That's what it's going to take.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want?
output: Ah... so tender. Come here, you juicy morsel!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want?
output: Go away. Go away. Go away!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want?
output: It's hopeless. He told me. He's right, you know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want?
output: Their fires lit up the night. All across Lake Rumare, like stars come to earth. It was beautiful, really.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want?
output: They were golden, even when they were dead. But their blood was red. I knew it would be.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want?
output: You don't think there's any hope, do you? I don't. He's right.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want?
output: He explained it all to me. Before, when I still understood. I don't remember, but I still know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want?
output: He'll tell you. Just ask. You don't even need to ask. He'll tell you anyway.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want?
output: I finally understand what it all means. What it was all for. The killing. And the dying.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want?
output: I had a medal. It had someone's face on it. I threw it away, after. It didn't help.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe this will help your memory. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: Well... when you put it that way, I think I do know the old guy you're talking about.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe this will help your memory. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: Big talk for someone with a light purse.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe this will help your memory. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: You know what? I think I do know the guy you're talking about.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe this will help your memory. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: Maybe it would. If you had it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll see what I can do.
output: I don't expect you to be capable of even that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're the Jarl? I'm looking for work.
output: Winterhold has lost much of its history, and with that much of its power. I aim to change that. I've heard rumors of the resting place of the Helm of Winterhold, the very same helm that Jarl Hanse wore in the First Era. Hanse was in line to be High King of Skyrim, you know. Having that might get the ear of the other Holds and give me some authority.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's your problem?
output: Nothing. I'm busy, and I don't like being bothered unless I'm expecting something from you. Oh, don't give me that look. Fine. I supposed I can find some menial task to set your mind on. Hmm.... We have something of a vampire problem. Bodies have been found with blood drained. I know of a den nearby you can wipe out as a precaution.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I won't be able to do that right now.
output: Very well. Very well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It will be an honor.
output: Good. Honor to you. Good. Honor to you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you all right?
output: Me? Nothing. And I hope to keep it that way. The Jarl is convinced I have some connection with the College, so he goes easy on me. Maybe you'd like to help me keep up appearances? Old Nelacar has a mage's staff in his room in the Frozen Hearth. It'd be good to have that staff in case the Jarl starts wondering if I actually have a real connection to the College.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll have to do that some other time.
output: Fine, then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What if I talk to <Alias.ShortName=Target>?
output: Go right ahead. He just might be sober enough to listen to you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll get it for you.
output: Thanks. I'll be waiting for it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It would be an honor.
output: As you were, then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't have time for that now.
output: Then stop wasting my time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Forget it.
output: Daedra take you, then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Someone giving you trouble?
output: He owes this tavern enough coin to burn it down, build it back up, then burn it down again just for laughs. He's had some troubles in his life, but I can't have him drinking here without at least paying back some of the coin he owes.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll have to do that some other time.
output: Very well. Very well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want to talk to you about <Alias.ShortName=QuestGiver>.
output: Who are you to say what I should do? I'll pay her back when I'm ready.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It would be an honor.
output: Good luck to you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's your <Alias=QuestItem>.
output: This should come in handy. Here. Let me show you a few tricks I've learned about buttering up royalty.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It would be an honor.
output: Good luck to you. Good luck to you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry to hear that.
output: I'm sure we'll get our gold at some point. Not like he has anywhere to go.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have the Helm of Winterhold.
output: Can you believe that this hold used to contend for the throne of the High King? Now perhaps others will listen. Here, your reward as promised. You have Winterhold's thanks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's a shame.
output: Very well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I cleared out the vampires from <Alias=Dungeon>.
output: Filthy creatures, aren't they? Living in the darkness, like they do. So uncivilized. I prefer finery. Like this. Here, for your trouble. And I suppose I should show you a little about Illusion magic for free, shouldn't I?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe we can come to an understanding. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: I won't say no to that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe we can come to an understanding. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: I'm not about to take on debts from some milk drinker I don't know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't have time for that.
output: Then I have no work for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's too bad.
output: I suppose it is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's too bad.
output: Be glad you're not training under me with that mouth of yours.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a delivery from <Alias.ShortName=QuestGiver>.
output: Joric's sister? Poor child. Magic runs deep in that family's bloodline. It's not always a blessing. Thank you for this. Something for your trouble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're on. (Brawl - 100 gold)
output: Just your own two hands. Weapons and magic are out. Now let's see what you got!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're on. (Brawl - 100 gold)
output: Come back when you have the coin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Not interested.
output: I give, and I give.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll recover the helm.
output: Good. I'll have a sum of gold waiting for your return.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have the Fine-Cut Void Salts.
output: That's the first bit of good news I've had since I set sail a year ago. Here's your cut.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't bother asking. I'm not interested.
output: Your choice, friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened to the salts?
output: Sailors are what happened to them. They got drunk and ended up losing the merchandise in some cave. If you're not afraid of little exploring, I'll pay good gold to get those salts.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're the ship captain?
output: By inheritance, as my men are fond of saying. Can't blame them, my mother ran the Sea Squall as strictly as she ran the house. I've been trying to find new areas of business, trying to win the sailors' respect, but I keep having problems. Take the last trade we did. Some Fine-Cut Void Salts from the College of Winterhold. Plenty of coin if you know who to sell it to.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your old crew member has been taken care of.
output: Fine work. Here's your pay. Don't spend it all on mead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Not interested.
output: Coward.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: They're as good as dead.
output: That's the spirit.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're the ship captain?
output: The North Wind is my mistress, and I'm her master. I don't tolerate any disloyalty. You looking for work? Got a sailor who thought running a gang of thieves would be more money than hauling my cargo. You make an example of that gang, I'll give you a year's worth of pay.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have things changed much with the Empire in charge?
output: Well, not yet. The Empire hasn't been in charge for that long, and real change takes time. Still, having a just and honorable man like Brunwulf in charge can only be an improvement. Unlike Ulfric, Brunwulf has shown a great willingness to work with the other races and make us feel more at home here. For the first time in a long while, I truly believe that there are brighter days ahead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you glad to see Ulfric Stormcloak gone?
output: You have no idea. Did you know it was his decree that forbade the Argonians from living inside the city walls? I hope in his next life, he's reborn as an Argonian forced to live in a slum because of some bigoted Nord dictator. I'm joking, of course, but I'm a lot happier seeing the Empire running things in Windhelm.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is life better under Imperial rule?
output: Yes, markedly so. Ulfric and his Stormcloaks made no secret of their disdain for the Dark Elves. In fact, they didn't seem to care much for anyone who wasn't a Nord. The folk of the Empire have always had a more cosmopolitan view of the world, so I'm glad to see them in charge.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any plans to renovate the Gray Quarter?
output: I've taken the first steps toward doing so already. I met with several of the Dark Elves to discuss improvements in the Gray Quarter, but we have no real plans as of yet.  First we'll need to refill our coffers and stockpile stone and wood. The war took a heavy toll on Windhelm's resources. But I swore an oath to our Dunmer friends that, for as long as I sit on the throne of Windhelm, their needs will not be ignored.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Will you let the Argonians into the city?
output: I'd like to, but it's not as simple as that. Most of the folk in the city believe as Ulfric did, that outsiders should not be trusted. Until those people learn to accept the Argonians, they must remain outside, for their own safety.  Old habits don't die easily, and we Nords can be as stubborn as stone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are you settling into your new role?
output: Every day is a struggle, but a Nord doesn't back down from a fight when the cause is honorable. I just wish things were simpler. In my days as a soldier, I knew who the enemy was, and how to defeat him. Unfortunately, a sword can't repair damaged buildings, feed hungry people or undo years of prejudice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You must be devastated by Ulfric Stormcloak's death.
output: I don't care what the Imperials say -- when Ulfric Stormcloak died, one of Skyrim's greatest heroes was lost. Now at last, the Thalmor will get their way. The worship of Talos will finally be stamped out. Or so they think. Those true sons and daughters of Skyrim will never cease to worship mighty Talos. If we cannot do so in our temples, we will do so in our hearts. Oblivion take the Thalmor! I'll never give up Talos, not even if it means my life. Let them come and make me a martyr!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you miss Ulfric Stormcloak?
output: Aye, that I do. I ain't sayin' he was perfect, but he knew what it meant to be a Nord. The Empire's always taken us for granted. Nords died by the thousands in the Great War, and what did the Empire do? They outlawed the worship of Talos, Skyrim's most beloved son. There's thanks for you. I guess what I'm sayin' is, Ulfric stood up for us, an' for all Skyrim. So who's goin' to stand up for us now?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Will you stay in Windhelm now that Ulfric's gone?
output: I almost didn't. I wasn't sure I could stomach having some Imperial tell me how to live my life. I was ready to pack my things when Hermir came to me. She wanted to make sure I'd finish teaching her the smithing trade. That girl's determination won me over. I suppose it didn't hurt that she said she only wanted to learn from the best smith in Skyrim. I couldn't let her run off to that pretender Eorlund Gray-Mane, could I?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Has the change to Imperial rule disrupted business?
output: In some ways, yes, but there is often opportunity in chaos. When a new government takes charge, records can be lost, taxes can be forgotten and laws aren't always enforced. The new guards are often too busy learning their responsibilities to notice a few smuggled goods or minor robberies. Not that I'd ever get involved in any of those kinds of things, of course.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I pursue Alduin, the World-Eater.
output: A fateful errand.  No few have chafed to face the Worm since first he set his soul-snare here at Sovngarde's threshold. But Shor restrained our wrathful onslaught - perhaps, deep-counselled, your doom he foresaw.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I seek entrance to the Hall of Valor.
output: No shade are you, as usually here passes, but living, you dare the land of the dead. By what right do you request entry?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you work the forge all day?
output: Aye, that I do. I've got to, if I hope to be as good as Eorlund Gray-Mane some day. In fact, I just finished my best piece of work. It's a sword. I made it for the Jarl, Balgruuf the Greater. It's a surprise, and I don't even know if he'll accept it. But... Listen, could you take the sword to my father, Proventus Avenicci? He's the Jarl's steward. He'll know the right time to present it to him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is the College dangerous?
output: Goodness, no! They're simply scholars, they mean no one harm. I've had... several conversations with Arch-Mage Aren over the years. He's perfectly polite, if a bit guarded.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Great Collapse? What's that?
output: Just about eighty years ago, there was a terrible disaster. The cliffs overlooking the Sea of Ghosts collapsed, taking most of Winterhold with them. In the middle of it all, the College was practically untouched. Many of the survivors were suspicious. Some believed the mages were behind the whole thing, and others felt they could have at least prevented it. Arch-Mage Aren assures me that his people had nothing to do with it, and I believe him. But Winterhold never recovered.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did the Oblivion Crisis impact Winterhold?
output: You may have noticed the College, just to the north there. Very prestigious place. Mages from all over Tamriel traveled here to seek knowledge. After the Oblivion Crisis was over, many felt that magic users were to blame. Elves, to be specific. It created a great deal of tension. A good many dark elves were driven from the city, and people became... uncomfortable with the presence of the College.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Those bandits back there...
output: Brynjolf and I found them like that. Mercer's doing. We have to catch up to him before it's too late.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did you lose?
output: My Amulet of Arkay. It's the source of my divine powers and also a sacred badge of office. I misplaced it in the catacombs. I'd look for it, but I've been hearing noises down there. I fear the dead have become... restless. Without that amulet, I'm powerless to confront them. Would you be willing to search for it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you the only wizard in Whiterun?
output: I believe I am, yes. Technically speaking, of course. The city is also home to a priest, priestess, an alchemist, and I'm sure others who practice. Ah, that reminds me. Speaking of alchemists, I have some frost salts for Arcadia. She asked me to obtain them for one of her potions. Would you be so kind as to deliver the frost salts for me? I'm sure Arcadia will provide some form of recompense...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for work. Got any leads?
output: The Jarl has put out a bounty on some bandits. Here, take a look at this decree for details. The Jarl has put out a bounty on some bandits. Here, take a look at this decree for details. The Jarl has put out a bounty on some bandits. Here, take a look at this decree for details. The Jarl has put out a bounty on some bandits. Here, take a look at this decree for details.
