instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is this the tomb?
output: This is the resting place of Ysgramor. And his most trusted generals. You should be cautious.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I return them with honor. (Give fragments)
output: Don't get too flowery on me, lass.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did you need help with?
output: J'zargo has seen that Tolfdir likes you. You must be very skilled with magic, yes? J'zargo is working hard, but cannot do it alone. Can you help with this?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm just looking for the Ragged Flagon.
output: Brynjolf's been sending idiots like you down here for years looking for their hideout. Funny thing is his stupid Thieves Guild never counted on me and my partner blocking the way. Now, empty your pockets or I'll pick the gold off your corpse.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How about I kill you instead?
output: Suit yourself. Get 'em Hewnon!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How much to let me pass?
output: You aren't going to pass. You're going to give me everything you have. Whether you leave here in one piece is up to you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've killed dozens like you. (Persuade)
output: No need to get hasty. I... I was just testing you. You can go on ahead. Let 'em go, Hewnon. All clear.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've killed dozens like you. (Persuade)
output: I doubt that very much.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Exactly what kind of help do you need?
output: J'zargo has worked hard on learning new spells, trying new things. This will make J'zargo stand out as a mage. But J'zargo works so hard, there is no time to test these new spells. If you help with the testing, this will make learning easier. J'zargo will give you scrolls, you will use them and report the results. This is a good plan, no? You tell J'zargo when you are ready.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: All right, I'll help you. Give me the scrolls.
output: Ha! You can't resist, can you? Let's see... this one, I think. J'zargo has designed it to be an excellent flame cloak, with a twist. It is especially potent against the undead, and should burn them to a crisp in no time. J'zargo gives you plenty of these scrolls, so you try them and return when you can say whether they work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The last? What happened to the rest?
output: We were betrayed by one of our own kind. In fact, I'm to blame for what's happened here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait a moment... You're Gallus!
output: I haven't heard that name in a long time. How do you know of me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are you to blame?
output: I was blinded. Blinded by dark treachery masquerading as friendship. Perhaps if I had been more vigilant, then Mercer Frey wouldn't have lured me to my fate and stolen the Skeleton Key.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then I'll have to proceed alone.
output: I'm afraid so. I'm weakening, and I can feel myself slipping away. The years without restoration of my power have taken their toll. Whatever damage has been caused can only be corrected by following the Pilgrim's Path to the Ebonmere and replacing the Key.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can a spirit die?
output: The Sepulcher isn't merely a temple or a vault to house the Key. Within these walls is the Ebonmere... a conduit to Nocturnal's realm of Evergloam. When Mercer stole the Key, that conduit closed, severely limiting our ties to her.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's wrong with the other Nightingale Sentinels?
output: With the Ebonmere closed, and their sudden severance from the realm of Evergloam, I fear they've undergone a drastic change. They're shadows of their former selves. They no longer remember their true purpose or their original identities.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then take the Key and right all the wrongs.
output: Nothing would bring me more pride than to return the Key, but I'm afraid it's impossible. From the moment I arrived here, I've felt myself... well... dying.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why aren't you like them?
output: My spirit didn't manifest itself in the Sepulcher immediately, so fortunately I wasn't present when the Ebonmere was sealed. However, ever since that day, I've felt my power waning... slowly draining away.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd ask the same question of you.
output: The last of the Nightingale Sentinels, I'm afraid. I've defended the Sepulcher alone for what seems like an eternity.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I did this to honor the Guild.
output: You've done the Guild a great deed. And although they may not show it, I'm certain they appreciate your sacrifices. My only regret is that you had to undertake this task alone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I did this to get rich.
output: Were I able to provide it, I'd shower you in wealth for what you've done. My only regret is that you had to undertake this task alone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Luck is meaningless. What we do involves skill.
output: Yes, absolutely. Your skill is your own... don't let anyone ever tell you otherwise. But Nocturnal, she influences our luck; nearly imperceptible assistance we get when we ply our trade.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So with the Ebonmere closed, our luck's run dry.
output: Precisely. There are a few who still call Nocturnal "Lady Luck" and for good reason.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How's that changing the way things are?
output: Think about the Guild... about the state it was in when you began. Think about all the little things you might have heard. A pick breaking when it shouldn't have, the clouds in the nighttime sky clearing at the wrong moment... Our access to those bits of luck are what separates us from common bandits.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: MS10Hellos
output: Give those pirates what for!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: MS10Hellos
output: What're you looking at?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: A courier gave me this pamphlet...
output: And here you are. I hope you've found the museum to your liking.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's the pommel stone of Mehrunes' Razor.
output: Our master craftsman are nothing compared to the perfection of the Daedra. Look at how it shines. Here's your gold, as promised.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's talk about this job you want done.
output: A little history, first. After the Oblivion Crisis, a number of groups cropped up dedicated to wiping out the remnants of the Mythic Dawn. One of these groups found Mehrunes' Razor, the artifact of Dagon. They split it into three fragments and pledged to keep them apart forever. That was almost 150 years ago, and the pieces are still being kept by the descendants of that group. And they're right here, in Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The hilt of Mehrunes' Razor, as promised.
output: Did you try the grip? Isn't it eerie how it seems to mold itself into your hand? Here's your gold.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for pieces of Mehrunes' Razor.
output: Don't know what you're talking about, stranger.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You want me to get those fragments?
output: At least two of the owners, Ghunzul and Drascua, are dangerous marauders. And the third owner, Jorgen, I only know he lives in Morthal. Here are my notes about them. I'll gladly pay you for getting the pieces any way you can. No questions asked.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have the blade shards of Mehrunes' Razor.
output: Look at them. The legendary sharpness of a deadric weapon. Marvelous. And here's your payment for the shards.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready to go.
output: All right. Head to the pit when you think you're ready.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The beginning of what?
output: There are pockets brimming with coin and coffers overflowing with riches ripe for the picking. We may be Nightingales, but in our hearts we're still thieves and we're damn good at what we do. Why, perhaps the greatest crime spree Skyrim's ever known.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Pleased? She sounded indifferent.
output: I wouldn't take that to heart. It's her way. Think of her as a scolding mother continually pushing you harder to be successful; outwardly sounding angry but silently content. I assure you, had she been displeased with you, we wouldn't be having this conversation.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why can't I be all three?
output: This is Nocturnal's way of maintaining balance. If you ever feel the need to change your abilities, you can return to the Sepulcher and step onto a different circle. Be warned that once you've chosen, you can't reselect for at least a day.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's this about becoming an Agent of Nocturnal?
output: The circles at the base of the Ebonmere imbue you with powers befitting a Nightingale Agent. The crescent moon represents the Agent of Shadow, the half moon for the Agent of Subterfuge and the full moon for the Agent of Strife.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And you?
output: The Guild has welcomed me back with open arms. I feel like a void in my life has finally been filled. I only hope that this isn't an ending to things, but actually the beginning.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So what now?
output: Now, your life as a Nightingale begins. Should the need arise, you'll be summoned to the Sepulcher in order to defend it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Hello, Karliah.
output: Nocturnal seemed quite pleased with your efforts. I'm glad you were able to bring the Key back safely.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He helped me find the pieces. He deserves to live.
output: Only Dagon can declare if a pawn is worth keeping. I. Have. Spoken.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So what is this Mythic Dawn cult?
output: They were worshippers of Mehrunes Dagon, the Daedric Lord of Destruction and Change. The Mythic Dawn killed Uriel Septim VII and his heirs, triggering the events that lead to the Oblivion Crisis, when the Daedra invaded Tamriel. All that remains of the infamous cult, I've gathered in my museum.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It will be done, Lord Dagon.
output: Kill him. Take your rightful place as my champion, or I will crush you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there anything else?
output: I planned to kill Alain myself, you know. Nilsine, too. But lost my nerve. I even brewed a special poison, Lotus Extract. Maybe you could use it? Just coat your weapon with it. Then... you get the idea.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I will use the Razor as I see fit, Dagon.
output: Spare me your pitiful pride. You are but a tool of my ambitions, mortal. Never forget that. Place your hands on my altar one last time, and you will witness the power of Mehrunes Dagon for yourself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Thank you, Lord Dagon.
output: You have been a worthy tool. Fill the world with destruction in my name. Place your hands on my altar one last time, and you will witness the power of Mehrunes Dagon for yourself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let me find him first. Dragons are bad for business. (Persuade)
output: Aye, you've got a point there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let me find him first. Dragons are bad for business. (Persuade)
output: Passing on a golden opportunity is worse.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need your help to defeat Alduin.
output: Alduin escaped us long ago. Today we take our well-tempered revenge. Alduin escaped us long ago. Today we take our well-tempered revenge.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need your help to defeat Alduin.
output: For a hundred lifetimes my heart has burned for revenge on Alduin too long delayed. For a hundred lifetimes my heart has burned for revenge on Alduin too long delayed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: On second thought, I'll walk.
output: Don't blame me if your feet get sore.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: On second thought, I'll walk.
output: Then stop wastin' my time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: On second thought, I'll walk.
output: Didn't think you had the coin for it anyway.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: On second thought, I'll walk.
output: Then off with ya. I've got better things to do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: On second thought, I'll walk.
output: Should have known you'd be a cheap one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: On second thought, I'll walk.
output: Then what are you wasting my time for?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I buy a horse?
output: Suppose so. Got one all saddled if you've got the coin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I buy a horse?
output: If I had one. Sold my last one to you a bit ago.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I buy a horse?
output: Reckon you can. How much you willing to pay?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I buy a horse?
output: Nope. Sold my last one to some stranger.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I buy a horse?
output: It's for sale, if you've got the coin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I buy a horse?
output: Not right now. You bought my last one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I buy a horse?
output: That one with the saddle? How much are you offering?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I buy a horse?
output: Can't help you. They're all spoken for.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I buy a horse?
output: Don't mind if you do. What's your price?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I buy a horse?
output: If I had one you could. They're all spoken for.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I buy a horse?
output: I've got one all saddled up for you! What do you figure she's worth?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I buy a horse?
output: Not today. You should have come by earlier. Wait, didn't I sell me last one to you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's my offer... (<Global=Horsecost> gold)
output: Sounds fair. She's yours. Like I said, she's all saddled.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's my offer... (<Global=Horsecost> gold)
output: When you got that much, we'll talk.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's my offer... (<Global=Horsecost> gold)
output: Fair enough. You can have her. She's the one with the saddle.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's my offer... (<Global=Horsecost> gold)
output: Didn't think you had the coin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's my offer... (<Global=Horsecost> gold)
output: That's your best offer? I suppose so. She's the one with the saddle.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's my offer... (<Global=Horsecost> gold)
output: If you had it, you'd be riding and we wouldn't be talking.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's my offer... (<Global=Horsecost> gold)
output: That much? I mean, of course. If that's all you've got.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's my offer... (<Global=Horsecost> gold)
output: I'd sell her for that, but you ain't got it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's my offer... (<Global=Horsecost> gold)
output: Sold. She's all yours. She's already saddled up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's my offer... (<Global=Horsecost> gold)
output: That would work, except you ain't got.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's my offer... (<Global=Horsecost> gold)
output: Wish everyone haggled like you. She's all yours.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's my offer... (<Global=Horsecost> gold)
output: Too bad you don't have that much. Guess you'll have to walk.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your name carries weight in Riften.
output: Of course. Nothing gets done without my approval in this city. I have the Jarl's ear, and the guards in my pocket. Anyone makes trouble for me and I pay a visit to the Thieves Guild. Make me angry and I contact the Dark Brotherhood. You'd do well to remember that the next time you make such a stupid observation.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you become allied with the Thieves Guild?
output: The Black-Briar family has always been allied with the Guild. Our connections with the Empire and within Skyrim make for a perfect fit. I dare say the Guild owes its survival as much to my family as it does to its own people.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a price on my head in Riften.
output: I don't believe in getting my hands dirty. You have people that handle those sort of things... use them. And you think that I care? Interesting.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can you tell me about Mara's beliefs?
output: Mara's domain encompasses the emotions we strive the most to embrace; love, compassion and understanding.  It's difficult to appreciate her gifts in these dark times, but you should consider her light a beacon in the storm.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's wrong with Riften?
output: The question is, what isn't wrong with Riften. This city is corrupt. Rotten to the core. No one cares about anything except themselves and how much coin they can make off the misery of others.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this place?
output: The Bunkhouse is for the working man, not some sort of a luxury inn for tourists. This heap of matchsticks is what everyone calls Haelga's Bunkhouse. Can you stay here? No.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you the only one that works at the Bunkhouse?
output: Of course not. You expect me to take care of it by myself? My niece Svana helps me with the chores. She'd be more help if she kept her head out of the clouds. She's been with me ever since her parents were killed by bandits and she was dropped in my lap.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe you should speak to the authorities.
output: Authorities? Have you been listening to what I said? They're all dirty. Every one of them. The only way to get things done in this city is to keep your head down and pay off the right people.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DBSancMalloryRefitChoice1
output: Banners, huh? Trying to pretty up the place? All right, you got it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a message from General Tullius.
output: Oh, yes? I wonder what that old busybody wants now. Whatever it is, it will have to wait until after I've finished dealing with this dragon situation.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a message from General Tullius.
output: And I'm sure he told you it was urgent. Well, he's not the only Jarl in Skyrim with problems to deal with. Whatever it is, it will have to wait until after I've finished dealing with this dragon situation.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Delphine needs your help to stop the dragons. (Persuade)
output: So Delphine keeps up the fight, after all these years. You'd better come in and tell me how you found me and what you want.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Delphine needs your help to stop the dragons. (Persuade)
output: Delphine? How do you ... ? This is just a trick to get me to open the door, eh? I told you to go away!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you? What are you doing here?
output: Hey, haven't I seen you around the Flagon? I never expected to see another Guild brother down here. They grabbed me in the Ratway. The nerve of these bastards... they need to be taught a lesson.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you? What are you doing here?
output: They grabbed me in Riften. They seem to think I know something. They just kept asking me the same damn questions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Now where are the books?
output: The... the books? Oh, I see. I thought perhaps... Well, I thought you'd come for me. But yes, the books. The Caller will have them. She was most interested in one of the volumes. Although not interested enough to keep me from being locked up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you trade your weapons with any of the cities?
output: Occasionally. But an Orc blade is a very personal thing. Anger, regret, pride. All these things are put into our steel. When my daughter Lash chose to leave the stronghold, I forged a sword to channel all my shame and grief. Honor me with a task, outlander. Bring the sword to my daughter, if you see her. It'll be all she needs to know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your mother Gharol wants you to have this sword.
output: So that's it, then. "Don't come back." Thank you. Here. You honored my mother's task and should be rewarded. Now, I need to be alone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: "Upon my honor I do swear undying loyalty to the Emperor..."
output: "...and unwavering obedience to the officers of his great Empire."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: "...and unwavering obedience to the officers of his great Empire."
output: "May those above judge me, and those below take me, if I fail in my duty."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: "May those above judge me, and those below take me, if I fail in my duty."
output: "Long live the Emperor! Long live the Empire!"

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: "Long live the Emperor! Long live the Empire!"
output: Welcome to the Imperial Legion, soldier. Just remember, we take care of our own. Once you're in the Legion, you're in it for life. Now, if I'm not mistaken. Legate Rikke has a special assignment for you. Speak to Beirand, he's normally out by the forge. He'll get you outfitted.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you mean, "return"? You've been there?
output: I've already said too much. If anyone overhears what we're saying, it could start a panic. I would simply ask that you trust me and help me end Dawnstar's nightmares.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why is it dangerous if they're asleep?
output: I'm concerned that when this place is unsealed, the Miasma will dissipate and they'll awaken; both orcs and priests alike.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does the Miasma do?
output: The Miasma was created by the priests of Vaermina for their rituals. It's a gas that places the affected in a deep sleep. Because the rituals would last for months or even years, the Miasma was designed to slow down the aging process.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is the gas dangerous?
output: Sadly, yes. The longer an individual is exposed to the Miasma, the more the mind can become damaged. Those who've been under the effect of it for extended periods of time have been known to lose their minds entirely. In some cases, a few never awoke at all.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: "I do swear my blood and honor to the service of Ulfric Stormcloak..."
output: "...Jarl of Windhelm and true High King of Skyrim."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: "...Jarl of Windhelm and true High King of Skyrim."
output: "As Talos is my witness, may this oath bind me to death and beyond..."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: "As Talos is my witness, may this oath bind me to death and beyond..."
output: "...even to my lord as to my fellow brothers and sisters in arms."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: "All hail the Stormcloaks, the true sons and daughters of Skyrim!"
output: Now you're one of us. Which means you get to tag along on a little trip with me. Oh, and here. You're a Stormcloak now, you ought to look the part.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What else is there to be learned about Conjuration magic?
output: How quickly you've advanced. Most impressive. There are spells yet to be learned, powerful spells that can more closely and more permanently bind creatures to your will. But there are risks. There are always risks. You must summon and command an unbound Dremora.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You will do my bidding.

output: I am glad you believe that. At least it will continue to exist. Grik los lein. Even I cannot see past Time's ending to what comes next. Niid koraav zeim dinoksetiid. We must do the best we can with this world.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have something special for me, Delvin?
output: Contacts are springin' up all over and I've got young footpads beatin' down the door to join up. Well, I never thought I'd see the Guild this way ever again. The place is growin' into what it used to be when Gallus was runnin' the show. I got one last special request of you. Finish this one and all of Skyrim's ours for the takin'.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have something special for me, Delvin?
output: We've got half of Skyrim back under our wing and the coin's startin' to flow. I don't know what your made of, but I've never seen anyone tackle this many jobs without endin' up dead or in jail. Now, if you're ready, I got another special job for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have something special for me, Delvin?
output: Your makin' a name for yourself, that's for sure. But more important, you're makin' a name for the Guild. Keep it up. I've got another special request and they specifically asked for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have something special for me, Delvin?
output: Well, it appears your actions are startin' to make waves out there. People are talkin' about the Guild again. In fact, I just got a special job request in. I haven't gotten anythin' like it in years.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So, what's this special request?
output: Got word from Torsten Cruel-Sea in Windhelm that a rival Guild is tryin' to get itself started. Not only that but they're givin' us thieves a bad name by murderin' their marks. Get over there and see what you can do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So, what's this special request?
output: We actually got a request from one of the most powerful families in Whiterun, the Battle-Born's. Make your way up there and look for Olfrid. He says he's got a matter that requires a delicate touch, and I suggested you for the job. Don't make me the fool and let me down, all right?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So, what's this special request?
output: I want you to head out to Markarth and speak to Endon. He's a silversmith... has some kind of a shop there. His father was a good friend of the Guild back in the day, and we could really use his family's influence back on our side.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So, what's this special request?
output: I need you to make your way to Solitude and talk to Erikur. He's lookin' to run some kind of a shill job. Now, he's not exactly goin' to welcome you with open arms, but keep your cool. Do this job right and we've just made an important friend out there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready for some extra work.
output: Slow down, you have that special request in Windhelm to finish first. After that's done, I'll send you some more jobs.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready for some extra work.
output: Before I'm goin' to give you any more work, you need to finish that job in Solitude.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready for some extra work.
output: I want you to finish that job in Whiterun first. Then we'll talk about more work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've finished that special Markarth job.
output: I hear Endon's quite pleased to have his merchandise back. He's a powerful ally in Markarth. Should help the Guild regain a foothold in the west.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've finished that special Whiterun job.
output: Olfrid sent ahead his compliments. Looks like his friend Arn is soon to be released thanks to his brand new identity. More importanly, he's pledged the full support of the Battle-Born clan to the Thieves Guild.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've finished that special Solitude job.
output: Erikur assures me that Captain Volf will spend pretty much the rest of his life clapped in irons. Best of all, he's also pledged to open doors for us in Solitude and to get things rollin' again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've finished that special Windhelm job.
output: Torsten was gratified the death of his daughter was avenged and the heirloom was returned. At this very moment, he's layin' the groundwork for the Guild to reestablish itself in Windhelm. Burnin' that banner was a nice touch, too. Should send a clear message to the Summerset Shadows that we're a force to be reckoned with.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've finished that special Windhelm job.
output: Torsten was gratified the death of his daughter was avenged and the heirloom was returned. At this very moment, he's layin' the groundwork for the Guild to reestablish itself in Windhelm. I wished you could have sent more of a message to those Summerset Shadows upstarts, but hopefully they'll stay out of our business.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DB02Captive2Persuade
output: I'm a woman living in Skyrim with six children and no husband. I don't have the time or patience to be "nice." Do some people look down on me? Have I made some enemies? You're damn right.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DB02Captive1Persuade
output: Okay, well... I guess it's possible. I've been selling my sword arm for years now. Killed a lot of people. Could be someone wanted revenge. But... But you're not going to kill me. Right?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DB02Captive3Intimidate
output: Fool! Don't you get it? I live in the shadow of death every day. A knife in every doorway, a nocked arrow on every rooftop! If one of my enemies wouldn't pay to have me killed, I'd take it as a personal insult.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DB02Captive2Intimidate
output: I'm kneeling here with my hands bound and a sack over my head, and you have the gall to ask me that? What do you think, genius?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DB02Captive1Intimidate
output: Please! I don't know! I mean, I'm a soldier. I've killed people. When I was ordered to. Maybe there were some times... some times I got carried away? But war is war. Right? Nobody could blame me for that. Could they?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DB02Captive3Persuade
output: He he he he he he he. The real question is, "Would someone pay to have me killed... again." A day goes by without someone trying to gut me in the street, I get disappointed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How many of these are there?
output: I think there were twenty-four in all. Most people keep them as a curiosity. Some of the Guild members have tried to locate them over the years, but they haven't been successful... well, until now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is it worth anything?
output: Not like that it isn't. The stone was pried off of Barenziah's ceremonial crown by a thief in order to cover his tracks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Now is it worth something?
output: When I told you the set had to be complete, I left out a small detail... I honestly didn't think you'd ever get this far. If the stones were remounted on the crown, it would be of great benefit to the Thieves Guild.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've found the Crown of Barenziah.
output: I knew you had it in you. After all, finding the Stones was no easy feat. Well, I'm not one to welch on a deal, so here's your reward. I hope you put it to good use. I know I have.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You sure you won't buy it?
output: Look, I only buy things I can turn around quickly for a profit. And no one wants those stones unless they have the whole set. Tell you what, if you find the rest of them, talk to me again. Otherwise, keep it and maybe it'll bring you luck.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've found all the Stones of Barenziah.
output: Unbelievable! You must be the first person to set eyes on all twenty-four of them in... well, the last two eras.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is this unusual gem worth anything?
output: Been a while since I've seen one of those. What you've got there is a Stone of Barenziah.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does the crown still exist?
output: I have it on good authority that the crown is within Tolvald's Cave; dropped by a Dunmer caravan leaving Morrowind long ago. If you can bring it back, we could restore the paragon... and reap its benefits.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And now that Potema has returned?
output: For the moment, the Wolf Queen has retreated to a place filled with dead eager to serve her. She has gone to her old Catacombs. Summoned in spirit form is not raised from the dead. She'll need help before she can return to the living. A few days ago, one of her servants busted through a wall into the Temple of Divines. We'll need you to go into the Catacombs themselves.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have Potema's remains.
output: Excellent! These things do have a way of working out when people take action. I'll sanctify the remains.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I can do that.
output: I can provide you with some help with her minions.  Good. Being at the summoning created a connection to Potema, you are the one to do this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll talk to Styrr. We'll figure something out.
output: I wish you well friend. Be careful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You'd better, or I yell "skeever." (Intimidate)
output: Okay, okay. No need to make rash decisions. Here's half. You get the rest when the job's done.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You'd better, or I yell "skeever." (Intimidate)
output: Yell all you want. It's not going to change my mind.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I might be able to help.
output: Oh really? And I don't suppose you'd just do it out of the kindness of your heart, would you? I hope you're not expecting to get paid until the job's done.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's the only way I operate. (Persuade)
output: Oh, very well. Here's half. You get the rest when the job's done.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's the only way I operate. (Persuade)
output: Well that's not how I operate, so forget it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Just pay me when the job's done.
output: My only demand is that these vermin are permanently eliminated before my reputation is completely destroyed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You seem to know an awful lot about this place.
output: I suppose there's no point in concealing the truth any longer. My knowledge of this temple comes from personal experience. I was a priest of Vaermina.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found your crystal.
output: Ha! So you did. I was almost beginning to think Gavros had gone and gotten himself killed just to spite me. Well, with the Falmer skulking around I can't very well do this on my own. I guess you'll have to come with me. I'll explain on the way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm with the College of Winterhold.
output: You are, are you? Savos wouldn't even grant us an audience when we came to you, but now you come here expecting something from me? I don't much like this, I'll tell you. But you've saved my skin, so maybe I can overlook the past for now. Come on, I'll explain on the way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the crystal for?
output: It was a brilliant idea, really. Mostly mine, though Gavros took the credit. Secret, though. Official Synod business. Can't talk about it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I happen to have found a focusing Crystal. Is this what you were looking for?
output: You found... how in the world... That's it. That's it! I don't know who you are, but you may have just saved this little project... In fact, who are you, anyway?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I happen to have found a focusing Crystal. Is this what you were looking for?
output: I don't know what sort of help you expect from me, but if you can actually find the crystal I'd certainly be grateful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm afraid I don't have any gold to spare.
output: Fine. If you can't pay with coin, you'll pay with your life!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: <Global=WE17GoldAmount> gold? You can have it, if you can take it from me.
output: If you insist. Come on boys. This'll be fun.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here, take it. (Pay <Global=WE17GoldAmount> gold)
output: The, um, Emperor thanks you... Now shove off! Er, rather, have a nice day, citizen.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found the Torpor.
output: So... I've taken us this far, but you need to guide us the rest of the way. Drink. I'm relieved you discovered a bottle intact; this place looks as though it was ransacked by the orcs.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here? Now?
output: Dawnstar's fate rests in that tiny bottle. The longer we wait, the more damage Vaermina could be doing to those poor people. I understand your hesitation, but I promise you that it works.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How will I know what it looks like?
output: It should be in a small bottle, very similar to a potion. I'll begin searching up here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We can discuss it later. We need to proceed.
output: Indeed. My reverence for Vaermina's machinations should not take precedence over our mission. My apologies. The inner sanctum lies ahead. We must reach the Skull and put an end to Dawnstar's troubles. Lead on, my friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What am I looking for?
output: The tome bears the likeness of Vaermina on the cover. It should be here somewhere. We're looking for a book of alchemical recipes called "The Dreamstride."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I hear you attacked a little girl.
output: Believe me, it wasn't anything I ever intended to do. I just... lost control.  It's all on account of this blasted ring. I tried to tell them, but none of them believe me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I feel sick.
output: There, there. It will pass. Going too long without a proper meal can make the stomach weak. Feel free to stay and mingle with your new coven, if you have the strength.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Thank you, Eola. For everything.
output: It's an honor, champion. Feel free to stay and mingle with your new coven.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know the way out of here?
output: Yes, yes. We should proceed cautiously.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sold. Here you go. (Gain <Global=WIAddItem07PayB> gold)
output: I'm glad we could come to an agreement.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sure. Take a look.
output: Excellent. Very good. This is exactly what I need to complete a series of studies I'm doing on Dwemer craftsmanship and magical resonance. I simply must have this! I'll pay you double what it's worth.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Not good enough. I'll hold onto this. You'll need to find another one.
output: Oh... well... I can see you have no appreciation for scholarship.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Actually, I'm not sure I have it anymore.
output: Oh... what a terrible shame. Well, if you think you know where you left it and can retrieve it, I'll be here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Not good enough. I'll shake the extra coin out of you if I must. (Intimidate)
output: Hold on, there. I suppose, in the uh, interest of research... I can spare a few more coins. Double and a half its value. That's all I can muster.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Not good enough. I'll shake the extra coin out of you if I must. (Intimidate)
output: Ha! I'll see to it the Jarl hears of your abuse of a court scholar. Shame on you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm here about the <Alias=Item>.
output: You are? Very good.... may I see it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think you can do better than that. (Persuade)
output: Well... I suppose important research is worth every coin. All right. You have yourself a deal. How's double and a half its value in trade?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think you can do better than that. (Persuade)
output: Come now, where's your sense of propriety? Extorting an old man like this. With this the world could have a better understanding of the Dwemer!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds fair. Here you go. (Gain <Global=WIAddItem07PayA> gold)
output: Wonderful. You've just made an important contribution to the advancement of a Dwemer scholarship.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Folk are talking about murders.
output: Terrible shame, that. Seems we have a killer on the loose here in Windhelm. He's claimed three victims that I know of, though maybe there's more that haven't been found yet. All lovely young ladies, too. Let's hope the guards find that demon soon, and introduce him to the headsman's axe.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are the dark elves treated in Windhelm?
output: Well you see where we have to live. This forgotten alley. All the filth from the upper quarters flows downhill, like they say. Good luck getting one of the guards to help with anything. I tried to get Ulfric to even come down here to see the squalor, but the High Lord of His Mightiness couldn't find the time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's there to do in the city?
output: If you're looking to pass the time, you can give Calixto a few septims and gawk at whater oddity he's come across lately. If you're need of goods, there's a market. If it's a soft bed and a hot meal you're after, there's Candlehearth Hall.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There have been murders in Windhelm?
output: None of that matters to me. Until someone takes a Dunmer, I let Windhelm deal with its own problems.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why are there so many dark elves here?
output: Where else would we be? When the Red Mountain burned, you could scarcely breathe in Morrowind. So we came west.  Windhelm is the first city on that road, and here we are. If we had known the Nords would be so unwelcoming, we may have kept walking.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does Talos have to do with the war?
output: The Empire's elven puppetmasters never cared much for the idea of a human becoming a divine. So the worship of Talos is outlawed.  Skyrim doesn't take kindly to being told what to do. And to try and forget Talos, well... they may as well ordered us all to cut off our ears.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Talos.
output: Talos, who in life was known as Tiber Septim, united Tamriel and founded the Empire.  He was rewarded for his deeds by being joined with the Divines in eternal glory. The only mortal to do so. We worship him that we might follow in his path. We can't literally join him in the heavens, but we may do our best to know them here on Nirn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are the people of Windhelm devout?
output: Like anyone, a crisis will push them towards devotion. I've been seeing a lot of the Shatter-Shields, since they lost their daughter.  Hillevi Cruel-Sea comes in a lot, but I haven't seen her husband here in years.  Ulfric prays for strength. I speak to Captain Lonely-Gale, but he doesn't spend much time here. Too busy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the prominent citizens in Windhelm?
output: There's an author named Adonato staying at the inn. He's published a few works of historical fiction. The clans Shatter-Shield and Cruel-Sea see most of the gold that passes through the city. And obviously you have Ulfric, the Jarl and future High King.  Oh, and that busybody Viola Giordano. She's got her nose in everyone's business, which I guess is one way of being prominent.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What kind of captain are you?
output: Well, nothing. At least not any more. Folk just call me that because of what I used to do. I was a sailor for many a year. I made my coin as a trader and in time, I bought my own ship. When I retired here in Windhelm, most folk already knew me as Captain Lonely-Gale, and the name just stuck.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have the items you requested.
output: Ah, have you? Let Kesh have them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's what they owed us.
output: I suppose it's not a total loss then. Let me give you a piece of advice. If you want to make some serious coin in this business you need to listen to rules. Now, on to other things.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's what they owed us.
output: Well done. And it would seem I owe you something in return. Here you go, I think you'll find these quite useful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've helped your people as you asked.
output: Then by my right as Jarl, I name you Thane of the Reach. Congratulations. Then by my right as Jarl, I name you Thane of the Reach. Congratulations. I grant you a personal Housecarl to watch over your home and this weapon from my armory to serve as your badge of office. I grant you a personal Housecarl to watch over your home and this weapon from my armory to serve as your badge of office. I'll also notify my guards of your new title. I grant you a personal Housecarl to watch over your home and this weapon from my armory to serve as your badge of office. I'll also notify my guards of your new title. input: I'm the Jarl's Thane. I demand you let me go at once.
output: No one in the Jarl's court is above the charge of conspiring against the city. You're coming with us. No one in the Jarl's court is above the charge of conspiring against the city. You're coming with us. No one in the Jarl's court is above the charge of conspiring against the city. You're coming with us. input: I've helped your people as you asked.
output: Then by my right as Jarl, I name you Thane of Eastmarch. Congratulations. Then by my right as Jarl, I name you Thane of Eastmarch. Congratulations. I grant you a personal Housecarl to watch over your home and this weapon from my armory to serve as your badge of office. instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: (Remain silent)
output: Hmph. When most would speak, you listen. You think. You understand that the only thing that matters is you following my orders. To kill.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You told me to kill, and I killed.
output: Indeed. For you, my friend, seem to understand what's truly important. When I give an order to spill blood, you follow it. No questions. No remorse.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So who was it? Who had the contract?
output: Oh. No, no, no. Don't you understand? Guilt, innocence, right, wrong.... Irrelevant. What matters is I ordered you to kill someone, and you obeyed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think you're in luck.
output: I can't believe it. You have them already? Here, take this. This should cover your end of the work nicely.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think you're in luck.
output: It's a good start, but you need all four of the volumes or the set isn't complete. Why don't you head back out to Yngvild and find the rest?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not into books.
output: Yeah, but you're into gold. Let me know if you change your mind. I'm not going anywhere.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll get them for you.
output: Then we have a deal. In his later years, Andoril moved into some ice caves known as Yngvild. He prefered the solitude in which to perform his, um... experiments.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What kind of books are they?
output: I'm told they're the ravings of a madman... a wizard named Arondil and his peculiar cravings. It's said to be spread across four volumes and very hard to come by. My client is offering quite a reward for them, which I'd split with you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've recovered all of Arondil's Journals.
output: Good. I was hoping you hadn't forgotten about it. As promised, here's your payment for bringing them to me. Got it as part of a fair trade from my client.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Anything you need done around here?
output: Now that you mention it, there is. I have a buyer with, shall we say, a very odd taste in literature looking for some particular books.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can you be certain the journals exist?
output: Recently, a woman was found... naked and shivering along the road to Dawnstar. The only information the guard could get from her were tales of strange experiments and Arondil scribbling in his journals.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know anything about Arondil?
output: Only rumors. He used to have a home in Dawnstar until they burned it down. The people say he was doing unspeakable experiments on reanimation... rituals only a necromancer would perform. After he made for Yngvild, he was never heard from again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've helped your people.
output: Then by my right as Jarl, I name you Thane of Winterhold. I grant you this weapon from the armory to serve as your badge of office. I'll also notify the guards of your new title. Wouldn't want them to think you're part of the common rabble, now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't worry about me. I'll do it.
output: Divines watch over you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've helped your people.
output: Then by my right as Jarl, I name you Thane of Falkreath. Congratulations. Then by my right as Jarl, I name you Thane of Falkreath. Congratulations. I grant you this weapon from my armory to serve as your badge of office. I grant you this weapon from my armory to serve as your badge of office. I'll also notify my guards of your new title. instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any more work for me?
output: I do. A personal matter. My father died trying to negotiate with the Forsworn, back when that was possible. They took his shield to those Hagraven beasts they consort with. I need you to bring it home where it belongs. I warn you, it's dangerous work. No man of mine has ever faced a Hagraven and lived. I'll understand if you decline.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've helped your people.
output: Then by my right as Jarl, I name you Thane of Hjaalmarch. Congratulations. Then by my right as Jarl, I name you Thane of Hjaalmarch. Congratulations. output: No one in the Jarl's court is above the charge of conspiring against the city. You're coming with us. No one in the Jarl's court is above the charge of conspiring against the city. instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm just doing what I'm asked.
output: That attitude would get you far, if you were some stuffy merchant or a Jarl's footstool. Around here, you'll want to learn to live your own life. Remember, nobody rules anybody in the Companions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't want that job.
output: Fine, I'll get someone else to take care of it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I would kill him before he drew his sword.
output: Woah, ease up there. We're rough, but there's no need to kill a Shield-Brother over a dispute.  I like your fire, though. You'll make a fierce Companion. Let us hunt together sometime.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You dare question my skill?
output: Calm down there, whelp. Don't feel like you need to show off for our sake. Vilkas, here, will be the one testing your mettle.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is it true that the Companions are werewolves?
output: I see you've been allowed to know some secrets before your appointed time. No matter. Yes, it's true.  Not every Companion, though. Only members of the Circle all share the blood of the beast. Some take to it more than others.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I can handle myself.
output: That may be so. This is Vilkas. He will test your arm.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Didn't you just tell me not to be a servant?
output: This isn't a command. Just decency. Help out an old blacksmith. I've got to get back to my work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll take care of it.
output: Of course you will.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't care for boasting.
output: Ah, a man of action.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't care for boasting.
output: Ah, a woman who lets her actions speak for her. I knew there was something I liked about you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you a Companion?
output: My name is Eorlund Gray-Mane. I work the Skyforge. Best steel in all of Skyrim. All of Tamriel. Not actually a Companion myself, but none of them know how to work a forge properly, and I'm honored to serve them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd rather not do that.
output: This work isn't for everyone. Maybe you're more cut out for those snowberries up in Winterhold.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does Vilkas always send newcomers on errands?
output: Oh, don't worry too much about it. They were all whelps once. They just might not like to talk about it. And don't always just do what you're told. Nobody rules anybody in the Companions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I would like to join the Companions.
output: Would you now? Here, let me have a look at you. Hm. Yes, perhaps. A certain strength of spirit.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll need to be going.
output: I have a favor to ask.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How was that?
output: Not bad. Next time won't be so easy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have your shield.
output: Ah, good. I've been waiting for this. Good to see you made it up here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Someone has to be in charge, though.
output: Well, I'm not sure how they've managed it, but they have. No leaders since Ysgramor.  Kodlak is the Harbinger, and he's a sort of advisor for the whole group, but every man is his own. Every woman, her own.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm happy to lend a hand.
output: That's a good man.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm happy to lend a hand.
output: Well done.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Vilkas sent me with his sword.
output: I'm guessing you're the newcomer then?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So you're supposed to train me?
output: Not here. Out in the yard. Come on.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So you're supposed to train me?
output: The old man said to have a look at you, so let's do this. Just have a few swings at me so I can see your form. Don't worry, I can take it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have much to learn.
output: That's the spirit. Vilkas, here, will get started on that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: If there's nothing else, I really must ask you to leave.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What else is there to be learned about Destruction magic?
output: I daresay you've learned all I can teach you. But... That doesn't mean there isn't more out there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you mean?
output: Over the years I've heard things. Powerful magics lost to the ages, incredible spells that only the most skilled mages can master. This is the only thing I've ever found. I think it's better off in your hands.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did you have in mind?
output: It's easy to find things to sell. Things nobody will miss. Things from underground, or just left lying around in someone's house. I bet the two of us, we're very alike. So why not take the next step? We can help each other. My sister Deeja and I are treasure hunters. We like to collect things.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We were victorious!
output: By defeating Ulfric at Whiterun we have solidified the allegiance of the Jarl. Perhaps the Stormcloaks will soon lose heart for this little rebellion of theirs once and for all.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Having a good time?
output: Oh my, yes. I absolutely love weddings. I haven't found my special someone yet, but there's still hope. Vittoria is, well, getting up in years...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Having a good time?
output: Am I! Free food and wine, and nobody trying to throw me in the dungeon. I wish they did weddings here every day.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Having a good time?
output: Not really. It's just a bunch of elders standing around, looking important. I wish something exciting would happen.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Having a good time?
output: Oh. Why... why certainly. I keep telling myself I'm not losing a son, I'm gaining an Imperial. Daughter. An Imperial daughter...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Having a good time?
output: No, I'm not having a good time. My boy just married a gods-forsaken Imperial. Skyrim is full of eager Nord women, and he beds down with the enemy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Having a good time?
output: The best. Vittoria's a good woman. Any man should be so lucky. I know my father's not happy about me marrying an Imperial, but that's his problem.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Having a good time?
output: I most certainly am not. I've just lost my daughter to a Nord beast, and my nephew Titus is too busy playing Emperor to even show up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Having a good time?
output: I am, thank you. I do so enjoy singing at weddings. It's just one of the many duties we at the Bards College are called upon to perform.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Having a good time?
output: So far. I just hope things remain calm. Wine gets drunk, tempers flare. This may be a joyous celebration, but it's shadowed by a lot of animosity.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Having a good time?
output: Oh, yes. Presiding over the union of two lovers is one of my greatest responsibilities. It helps that Asgeir and Vittoria truly care for each other.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for work.
output: Skjor was looking for you before. Talk to him before doing anything else. Skjor was looking for you before. Talk to him before doing anything else.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You were at Namira's feast, weren't you?
output: Shh. You mustn't speak about such things away from the shrine. Only you and your dinner guests can know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You were at Namira's feast, weren't you?
output: Better if we don't talk about that. As far as anyone's concerned, we all had dinner at a nice inn along the road, and nothing strange happened.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You were at Namira's feast, weren't you?
output: Don't go talking about that. Only the dinner guests can know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait. I know you.
output: Ah, yes. The courier. I guess you know my secret ingredient for that spiced beef, now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait. I know you.
output: You buy a war dog from me? There's a reason why my hounds are so eager to bite into people.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait. I know you.
output: That's right. You're the sellsword. Thank you again. It's so nice to have help with my husband gone. Shame what happened to him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait. I know you.
output: One of my customers? Did you know I inherited the store from my late husband? Shame what happened to him. He had such good taste.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait. I know you.
output: "The bloodiest beef in the Reach!" Ha ha ha.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can you protect Whiterun from the dragons?
output: With good planning and constant vigilance. We must have ample reserves of water to combat the fires that will surely spread after an attack. But our greatest weapon? Courage. For if we cannot kill the beast, we must at least have the tenacity to drive it back. Until brave heroes step forward to destroy these monsters, that is the best we can do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who forges your arms and armor?
output: Since Adrianne's death, I've had to buy them from the Khajiit caravans. Tried making some myself, but I'm no good with the forge and anvil. Anyway, our wares are strong and the prices fair. What else matters?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's the best blacksmith in Skyrim?
output: Curse you for bringing up that bitter memory. Not long ago it was my husband Eorlund. There was no finer smith in the nine holds. Now he's dead and gone and the Skyforge of Jorrvaskr lies cold.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who should I talk to for work?
output: Try Olfina, the new innkeeper at the Bannered Mare. It's just up the road, near the market. You should check in at Dragonsreach, too. There's so much going on these days, the Jarl or his Steward might have need of help.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, I haven't.
output: Seems no one in this city has.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you need any help?
output: I was actually just about to head on inside. Be good to have someone watch my back. Follow me, and keep your eyes open. Daedra are powerful creatures and tricksters. Never know what you'll find.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are your orders?
output: Be careful. We need to find out what happened here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I would like to purchase a house in the city. (<Global=HPWindhelm> gold)
output: There is an empty home in the city, but there was some... unpleasantness recently. I'm afraid it's not available just yet. There is an empty home in the city, but there was some... unpleasantness recently. I'm afraid it's not available just yet. instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want with me?
output: I have watched you for some time, you know. The decisions you've made intrigue me, and I wonder if you are the proper agent for a task of mine.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's going on?
output: Breathe deep, mortal. I would have you hear me well, so let these vapors fill your lungs.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this? Have I been poisoned?
output: In a sense, but no more poisoned than a fool after too much wine.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have proof that Thorald lives.
output: Well, where is it? Forgive me, but I don't dare just trust your word, no matter who you are.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're going to make me a werewolf?
output: Oh, no. Only the Circle have the beastblood. Prove your honor to be a Companion. "Eyes on the prey, not the horizon."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're going to make me a werewolf?
output: No, only members of the Circle get this blessing. Right now we're just seeing if you're worth keeping around. No, only members of the Circle get this blessing. Right now we're just seeing if you're worth keeping around.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What was that?
output: It's a blessing given to some of us. We can be like wild beasts. Fearsome.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What was that?
output: Come on now, you're a sharp one. You must have heard of werewolves before. It's a blessing given to the most honored of the Companions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's in the tomb?
output: Vals Veran. My family has never really seen eye to eye with him and he has finally gone off the deep end. He's gone in to defile our family tomb by using our ancestors for his filthy dark elf necromancy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's go.
output: Great! I'll unlock the door and meet you inside, then you can lead the way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't have time right now.
output: Fine, but I've locked the door so don't think you're getting in there without me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do we find the entrance to Sky Haven Temple?
output: The Akaviri blood seal can only be opened with the right kind of blood. Your blood, Dragonborn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do we find the entrance to Sky Haven Temple?
output: The entrance must be past the Forsworn camp. Look for a canyon or cave entrance into the Karthspire.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do we find the entrance to Sky Haven Temple?
output: Ah, yes. The entrance seems to be near what's now known as the Karthspire. We'll have to see what we find when we arrive.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll meet you at Karthspire.
output: Very good. I'll trust you to get there in one piece. Don't be long.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll meet you at Karthspire.
output: Your call. Might be safer to travel separately - attract less attention that way. Don't worry, I'll get Esbern there in one piece. We'll wait for you near Karthspire. Good luck.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why would anyone accuse you of that?
output: The people of Morthal would much rather weave their own horrid tales about my life than simply ask me for the truth. If they choose to fear me in their ignorance, that is their choice. But it will not change what is true.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't like being told what to do.
output: No? Then how do you like the idea of having your legs broken? Mind your manners in this hall, friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why would I disrespect her?
output: It's no secret that Jarl Idgrod is... different. It's also no secret that there are rumors about her and her visions. I won't repeat them, and I won't allow them to be spread under this roof. Now, you go about your business.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We certainly do.
output: Then by all means, go about your business.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So then what do you do?
output: I keep to myself. I offer spells and scrolls to those who need them, and wisdom in Conjuration magic for those who wish to learn. Beyond that I seek only to be left alone to pursue my research.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can we find Alduin's Wall?
output: That's where we'll find Alduin's Wall. This is what I've been trying to explain. It's in Sky Haven Temple, an ancient Blades sanctuary, hidden deep in the crags of the Reach.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do we find the entrance to Sky Haven Temple?
output: We should be careful. There's no telling what traps and wards the ancient Blades may have set.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So you think Alduin's Wall will tell us how to defeat Alduin?
output: Yes, exactly. Well, I think so. It's certainly our best hope. The ancient Blades remembered much Akaviri dragonlore that has now been forgotten.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the best way to get there?
output: From Riverwood? The road south through Falkreath is the most direct route. Or you could catch the carriage from Whiterun to Markarth and then approach from the west. Either way, the Reach is wild country these days. The Forsworn are everywhere. Best be careful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's travel there together. Are you ready to go?
output: Always. Let's go see if we can find this Sky Haven Temple.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did you need?
output: We can meet you there, or all travel together, your call. I know the area of the Reach that Esbern's talking about. Near what's now known as Karthspire, in the Karth River canyon.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: (Hand over 200 gold)
output: Wise move. Now get out of here ya goat licker, before I decide the toll's gone up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't have the money.
output: That's a real shame. Gonna make it hard for you to pay a healer after we cave your skull in.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How about you let me through and I don't kill you? (Intimidate)
output: You know, now that I think of it, that sounds fair. Just shove off before the others notice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How about you let me through and I don't kill you? (Intimidate)
output: Ha! Tough talk for someone who's about to have their guts spilled.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How does 50 gold sound? (Persuade)
output: Eh, fine. I can tell you aren't worth the trouble. Just get out of here before I change my mind.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How does 50 gold sound? (Persuade)
output: How does a knife in the gut sound? It's 200 gold or your life.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: Come to see the hag with an offering of coin, then? So be it. I accept your investment.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
