output: You're Dragonborn. The rules don't apply to you. You can Shout the way dragons do... without training, through inborn instinct. They always hope to teach the Dragonborn to respect the Way of the Voice as they do. They never fully succeed. You'll have to make your own decision. It's a beautiful philosophy, but outside the seclusion of High Hrothgar, I was never able to hold to it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So you know how to Shout?
output: Yes. Although I rarely use my training. The Greybeards believe the Voice should be used only for worship of Kynareth. I have... fallen from their strict teaching, but I still don't feel it should be used lightly. Not all of Arngeir's lecturing was wasted, it seems.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Arngeir - is he one of the Greybeards?
output: Yes. The oldest and most powerful, although he may not seem so. I doubt he's forgiven me for leaving. And for... well, for what he'd consider blasphemy. Using Shouts for anything but worship of Kynareth.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You trained with the Greybeards?
output: Yes. They chose me when I was just a lad. It was a great honor, of course. I was to become a Greybeard myself. I spent almost ten years at High Hrothgar, learning the Way of the Voice. Then the Great War came... I couldn't stand missing it. I often think about High Hrothgar. It's very... disconnected from the troubles down here. But that's why I couldn't stay, and why I couldn't go back. I suppose the Greybeards care about Skyrim's troubles, in their way, but I needed to do something about it. I'm sure Arngeir would call it one of my failings.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Shouts?
output: I know more than most. I trained with the Greybeards at High Hrothgar when I was a boy. The Way of the Voice is an ancient, spiritual form of magic in which you project your vital essence into a "thu'um" or Shout. Most people would need to train for years before they could even attempt a single Shout. The Dragonborn is different - you have an inborn ability to Shout, the same way dragons are said to.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's it mean to be Dragonborn?
output: The old tales tell of Dragonborn heroes who slew dragons and took their power. It seems those tales are true. With the dragons returning, and now a Dragonborn appearing... maybe the Greybeards know what it all means. It means you have the Dragon Blood - you have an inborn ability to use your Voice the way dragons do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's it mean to be Dragonborn?
output: It means you can kill dragons and steal their power - even speak with a dragon's voice, they say. There hasn't been a Dragonborn seen in the land for centuries. Not since Talos himself walked the 7,000 Steps to High Hrothgar.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Greybeards?
output: Ulfric can tell you more than most anyone. He was studying to be a Greybeard himself, back before the Great War.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do you know so much about them?
output: I studied with them when I was young. They taught me how to Shout.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're an important family, I take it?
output: My dear vagrant, we're the only family worth knowing in Markarth. We own everything in this city, even the jail. And guess who owns the Silver-Blood Inn? Not that we named it that, the people just insisted.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What task?
output: I sent a blessing to Mundus, a wasting plague that infected a scattering of Breton villages.  One of my monks, the elf Orchendor, was sent to gather these Afflicted. He shepherded them into Bthardamz for me, but has since lost his way. I will not stand for betrayal. I want you to go to Bthardamz and kill Orchendor, in my name.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How will you protect yourselves against the dragons?
output: How can we? We're a community of farmers, not fighting men. If not for the war, we might have enough guards in the hold to protect the settlements. That the dragons should return now is most unfortunate.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your farms are thriving, even despite the harsh climate. What's your secret?
output: Secret? What makes you think there's a secret? There are no secrets here, my curious friend. Our prosperity is simply the result of hard work, good fortune and the blessings of the gods.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you come to make your home at Rorikstead?
output: Have you met Rorik? He owns these lands, and it's from him that our village gets its name. We have been friends for many years now. Rorik fought for the Empire in the Great War. He was gravely wounded, and so was brought before me. I was a healer then, you see. We were as close as kinsmen, and when Rorik returned home I came with him. I am happy to spend my twilight years here with my good friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Has the war taken a toll on your settlement and its people?
output: Not yet, anyway, though it certainly could. With most of the hold's fighting men committed to the war, there are fewer swords to keep the roads safe from brigands and wild beasts. And of course, as the war drags on and supplies run low, our ample fields and stores of food will make a tempting target for desperate men. The best we can hope for a swift end to the conflict. The longer the war goes on, the worse it will be for all for us, I'm afraid.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did you fight in the Great War?
output: Aye, that I did. I commanded a force of several dozen men, most of them levies from villages in this part of the hold. I damn near met my end in that war. An Aldmeri soldier ran me through with his blade and left me for dead. A healer named Jouane saved my life. He's been my closest friend ever since. I tell you, that man is a miracle worker.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is the town of Rorikstead named for you?
output: Yes, that's right.  Look around you. Most of the lands you see are mine. Most of this I purchased while my comrades were fighting in the south, helping the Empire against the Aldmeri Dominion. Back then, nothing would grow here and so the land was worthless. Now, thanks to hard work and the gods' blessings, our farms prosper.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where do you sell your surplus crops?
output: In Whiterun, mostly. Ennis handles the business arrangements, but I know that he has a few purchasers who give us a fair price. Ennis prides himself on his shrewd business schemes. For my part, I'm far happier working with cattle and crops than with people.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your farm is doing very well. You must be proud.
output: Do I detect a bit of jealousy in your tone? I would hardly blame you. What calling could be more noble than this?  I see in your eyes that you think I jest. I assure you, I don't. I am proud, and rightfully so, of the work we do here. Working the soil with your hands, seeing your seeds take root and grow, tending a herd... there is a joy in honest labor you won't find elsewhere.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't have 10,000 gold.
output: If there's one thing I hate more than a mean-spirited drunk, it's one who can't settle their debts.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not giving you anything. (Intimidate)
output: All right... All right... Fine. I thought we were friends, but you're a real jerk, you know that?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not giving you anything. (Intimidate)
output: Are you kidding me? I fought off all those bandits. I'm not afraid of you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe you should do your own work.
output: J'zargo sees what you are up to. Very well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Never mind.
output: Yes, that's probably for the best. I really shouldn't risk getting on Elenwen's bad side.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't worry, I just want to play a joke on someone. (Persuade)
output: I don't think so. Sorry. I would love to help you, but Elenwen can be very vindictive. I wouldn't want to get on her bad side.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need your help with something.
output: Oh? Something interesting, I hope?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need you to cause a scene. Get everyone's attention for a few minutes.
output: Nothing would please me more. I'll keep their eyes away while you do what you came here for.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need you to cause a scene. Get everyone's attention for a few minutes.
output: I don't even want to know, do I? But for you... all right. I'll do it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let me in or I'll kill you. (Intimidate)
output: Ha ha! That's funny. Ya' think you can take me on? Try it anytime. I've been itching for a fight.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He's in debt because of a quill?
output: The wizards called it the Quill of Gemination and demanded a tremendous amount of gold to have it made. If you can locate the quill and return it to me, something Vald was too stupid to do himself, I'll consider the debt satisfied.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did he do?
output: A few years back, I commissioned a unique quill from a good friend of mine in Winterhold. Vald was tasked with getting it here safely and it ended up at the bottom of Lake Honrich.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to erase Vald's debt.
output: Vald? Why would you want to help that idiot? He owes me a steep debt. In fact, he's lucky all I did was force him to work for Mercer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found the Quill of Gemination.
output: Really? I wrote that off a long time ago. Well, I suppose I need to fulfill my end of the bargain. Give this document to Vald. It frees him from the debt, but I never want to see him in Riften again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did it end up in Lake Honrich?
output: I had Vald meet the caravan from Winterhold on the western end of the lake so he could avoid the roads. The idiot got lost in the mist and ran his boat right over some rocks, sending it straight to the bottom. He's too stupid to remember where he was, and any attempt I've made to find it in the past has been unsuccessful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll watch it for you.
output: Wow, sure is nice of ya'. Here, hang on to the key and don't let anyone in!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any ideas where I can look?
output: Vald said his rowboat struck some rocks... I'd check under the water near one of the small islands in the lake. Perhaps you should start at the docks and work your way out towards Goldenglow Estate.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Mercer needs you in Markarth right away! (Persuade)
output: But I can't leave here! I'm supposed to watch his house. What do I do?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Mercer needs you in Markarth right away! (Persuade)
output: Oh come on, I ain't that dumb.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll take care of it.
output: Be careful, lass. This is the last place in Skyrim I'd ever want to send you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What if someone else got their hands on it?
output: Fortunately, the quill required an ink with a unique formula known only to myself. So if you're getting any ideas about selling it to someone else or keeping it, you'll find it would hold little value.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is the Quill of Gemination?
output: The quill was supposed to allow me to duplicate any writing I'm viewing in exacting detail. I'm sure you can understand how useful that would prove in a business situation, especially where signatures were involved.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I erased your debt. You're free.
output: I don't know how ya' talked Maven into letting me go, and I don't care. You did something for me, I'm gonna do something for ya'. Here, take the key to Mercer's house. Won't need it any more.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's in it for me?
output: Well, I... I simply thought you might wish to help out one of your fellow mages. If that's not enough, I suppose... I have this amulet you could take.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you need help with?
output: We're all trying to become better mages, right? Well, I need someone I can practice a few spells on. Nothing dangerous, really. Would you be willing to assist me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you need help with?
output: I still need someone to practice a few spells on. Interested?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't think so.
output: Oh. Well, if you change your mind, let me know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did you do?
output: I'm not really sure. I think it's just a minor miscalculation on my part. I'm sure it will wear off soon. When it does, you'll be perfectly fine, and then we can try again. In the meantime, I'll see about figuring out what went wrong.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me this isn't permanent.
output: It's not! It shouldn't be. You'll be back to normal in no time. And when you are, we can try this again and I'll be sure to get it right.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: If I didn't know better, I'd say you were trying to kill me.
output: Oh. J'zargo takes this to mean it did not go... well. This was not the intention, to be sure. It is true that J'zargo was slightly concerned there may have been... problems. But you were not placed in harm's way on purpose. Still, you are a good friend to J'zargo now, for taking this risk. J'zargo thanks you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Okay, I'll help.
output: Oh, good. I was afraid I'd have to go ask J'zargo. Now, you just stand there...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Okay, I'll help.
output: Oh, good. I was afraid I'd have to rely on Onmund. Now, you just stand there...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Okay, I'll help.
output: Thank you. I was afraid I'd have to figure out some way to do this on my own. Now, you just stand there...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It did not go well.
output: No? It is true, J'zargo suspected there might be problems. But this is most disappointing. It is good that you were willing to help J'zargo. This will not be forgotten, friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've tested your scrolls.
output: And? Were they magnificent?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can't you practice on yourself?
output: No, not that kind of spell. Believe me when I say I wouldn't be asking if it weren't necessary.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Were they supposed to explode? Because they exploded.
output: Ah. No, that was not supposed to happen. But... J'zargo is pleased to see that you are here, and not in pieces! You are a good friend to have done this. J'zargo will not forget it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You and your daughter were at the execution.
output: Svari, yes. It's been hard on her. The girl misses her uncle. I've tried to explain that Roggvir did something bad and that we all have to be accountable for our actions but... a child feels what she will.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why didn't Torygg ever declare independence?
output: Because the Dominion is a sleeping beast that Skyrim cannot slay alone. Because many Nords are part of the Imperial army even now. Because the food and resources we get from the Empire are important to our people. Because even if we can't openly worship him, Talos the god was once Tiber Septim the man, and this is his Empire. And Torygg wasn't ready to let it fall apart.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Has the war affected your college much?
output: Not much. But as a bard, I find the whole affair depressing. There are no heroes in this war. No winners to be had and no real conclusion.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the Burning of King Olaf?
output: It's a great big festival put on by the bards, every year. They burn an effigy of old King Olaf. It's quite a bit of fun. The bards give out spiced wine during the festival, so they put in a big order. And then, for weeks after, demand is so high, I can barely keep up. But with the death of High King Torygg, the Festival has been declared "in poor taste." So it looks like it won't happen this year.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are your sales?
output: They're... adequate. Honestly, I rely on the business brought in by the Burning of King Olaf, and that's not likely to happen this year.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is your spiced wine made from a secret recipe?
output: Oh, yes. A secret family recipe. The only good thing my father Octieve ever did. In fact, it's so good, no one else in Skyrim even tries to make any.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So the war started when Istlod died?
output: No. Even after Istlod died, the moot voted to make Torygg High King of Skyrim. But Ulfric was at that moot, continually talking about Skyrim's independence in terms just shy of treason. I don't think Ulfric knew how much Torygg respected him for that. If Ulfric had asked Torygg directly to stand up, to declare independence, Torygg might have done it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did it happen?
output: Ulfric showed up at the gates of Solitude requesting an audience. We thought he was here to ask Torygg to declare independence. By the time we realized Ulfric was here to challenge Torygg... it was already too late.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why was Torygg killed?
output: Someone he could defeat that represented the Empire, the White-Gold Concordat, the banning of Talos worship. Because Ulfric needed a symbol. Torygg's father Istlod had held Skyrim together for nearly twenty-five years. When he died, Torygg became that symbol.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Were you there when High King Torygg died?
output: I was, to my shame. The whole court was in attendance. I've seen much in my time, but that was a gruesome day.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I bet you get some interesting people through here.
output: That I do. I had a messenger from Dragon Bridge stop here on his way to the Blue Palace, not too long ago. He was very nervous, mentioned something about needing help.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I bet you get some interesting people through here.
output: At times. Jaree-Ra stopped by the other day. Told me to keep an eye out for him, see if any new people arrived in the city.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I bet you get some interesting people through here.
output: Everyone who's anyone. Viarmo bought an apple the other day, said he was looking for a new student.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I bet you get some interesting people through here.
output: Not lately. Business has been slow.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about dragons?
output: Not much, to be honest. Their return was a shock to us all. Giraud Gemane has some tomes about them in the library, if you're interested.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You look very young.
output: I like to think I've aged well. I'm certainly wiser than I once was. And I know when one should speak... and when one should hold their tongue.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why should I care?
output: Watch that tongue, new blood. Watch that tongue, new blood. Watch that tongue, new blood. Watch that tongue, new blood.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why were you waiting for me?
output: Come, follow me. Come, follow me. Come, follow me. Come, follow me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why was it too late?
output: By Nord custom, once the challenge was issued in court, Torygg had no choice but to accept. Had he not, Ulfric would have had cause to call a new moot and a new vote for High King. Torygg had some martial training, of course, but it mattered little that day. When Ulfric's lips parted, when he unleashed the power of the Thu'um... That Shout, that ancient and terrible tongue... ripped Torygg asunder.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So you and High King Torygg were close?
output: Very. I helped raise him. Oh, I could not have been more proud to see Torygg on the throne. He made a fine king. A fine king...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You won't be the one to look foolish, I promise. (Persuade)
output: Mmm, sorry. I really can't risk it. I'm sure you can find someone else with a little less dignity.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't worry, I just want to play a joke on someone. (Persuade)
output: Sorry, but you'll have to find someone else to help you with your prank.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Never mind.
output: Yes, this probably isn't really the place for your little jokes.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Never mind.
output: Thank you. I knew you'd understand.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Never mind.
output: I'll try to forget you ever asked.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You'd be doing me a big favor... (Persuade)
output: I'm sorry, but I really can't.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need you to cause a scene. Get everyone's attention for a few minutes.
output: Say no more. I was wondering what you were doing here... I'm glad to play my part.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need you to cause a scene. Get everyone's attention for a few minutes.
output: I trust you don't presume on our friendship? I am a Jarl, after all. I wouldn't want to appear foolish in front of these people.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need you to cause a scene. Get everyone's attention for a few minutes.
output: Hmm. I don't want to get involved in anything beneath my dignity as Jarl.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need you to cause a scene. Get everyone's attention for a few minutes.
output: Oh... perhaps not, then. I don't think the Jarl of Solitude should be participating in a childish prank.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need you to cause a scene. Get everyone's attention for a few minutes.
output: I don't know... I don't want to do anything that might offend Elenwen. There is a lot of money at stake, after all.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need your help with something.
output: Let's hear it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need your help with something.
output: Well... let's hear it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need your help with something.
output: My ears are always open to a friend's request.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need your help with something.
output: Say on, friend. What do you need?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need your help with something.
output: I'm always glad to help a friend if I can. What do you need?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've had enough for now.
output: Well I really would like to make sure I've corrected what happened last time. Please give me a chance to try again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So...
output: Well, it all worked out in the end, didn't it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: One more chance. That's it.
output: Good, good. It'll be worth it, I assure you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Okay, you can try again.
output: This will be worth it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is something wrong?
output: Yes, but it needs to be kept quiet. I may have entered into an... agreement with Enthir. He had something I needed, so I traded him something of mine. It was a mistake, and now I want back what I gave him. It's an amulet that belonged to my family, and I never should've given it to Enthir. But he won't deal with me. Talk to him; see what it'll take to get my amulet back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your spell finally wore off.
output: Exactly as I said it would.  Now, are you ready to try again? I am confident it will work this time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's been a pleasure.
output: Oh, no it hasn't. Let's be honest. I have a long way to go before I'm ready for the kind of advanced magic I've been attempting. But at least I know where to start now. Thank you, you've been a great help to me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's never speak of this again.
output: Agreed. And thank you for your help. You're a good friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You seem to dislike visitors in Riften.
output: Every day the threat of exile from Riften draws closer for myself and my family. Who knows how many spies the Empire has sent into our midst already. We're at war. This isn't the time for hospitality. Thank goodness mother is keeping a level head about everything. If my brother Saerlund had his way, we'd be flying Imperial colors by now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What sort of lies has Ulfric been spreading?
output: Ulfric only cares about one thing... Ulfric. He's ordained himself the future High King of Skyrim and steps on anyone that gets in his way. He's begun a rebellion against those that wish to eradicate the worship of Talos and uses it as his rallying cry. His cause may be true, but the man is a lie... all he holds in his heart his lust for the throne.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why would I ridicule you?
output: Because I did something not a soul in this bloodstained house of war has the backbone to do... dared to speak my mind. Now my mother's stripped me of my heritage and incarcerated me here like a common criminal and my brother has all but disowned me. Be wary what you say around here, friend. You'll find not all take kindly to "insurrection." I dared speak of the Empire and the lies that have been spread by Ulfric, the leader of the Stormcloaks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready. Let's get this started.
output: Good. Wait until I start the distraction and then show me what you're made of.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You and your brother don't see eye to eye?
output: He's a traitor, plain and simple. Had I been sitting on the throne, he'd be hanging from the gallows for his sympathies towards the Empire. Can you believe that fool had the audacity to speak of his love for the Empire in the plaza? He expects us to drop our defenses and greet them with open arms... to dialogue with them rather than defend our homeland by spilling their blood.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you always insult people when you meet them?
output: It's not an insult, just an observation. If I were walking around with a wound, I would want you to tell me to see a doctor. Your outfit is something of an open wound... where attire is concerned.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you always insult people when you meet them?
output: Not many people care, these days. The world is the worse for it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Aromatics? So you sell perfumes?
output: We mostly carry herbs and alchemical ingredients, that sort of thing. Before the war, our stock was mostly used for aromatic use in homes, yes. These days, we have more people like you coming in, looking for healing and the like.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you get a lot of business like that?
output: I suppose I would, but you're the only one who gets that greeting.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you get a lot of business like that?
output: It's never been an issue. People say you helped with the problems at Wolfskull Cave. I applaud anyone who assists the court.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you get a lot of business like that?
output: Oh, we do all right. Rumor is, you had a hand in the Blackblood Marauders' demise... I'm impressed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you get a lot of business like that?
output: Radiant Raiment has the finest attire in all of Skyrim. That is how we... Wait. You're that new bard, the one who saved the Festival. Aren't you? That was a good bit of work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can you train me in Alchemy?
output: No, no. Mostly, I'm just a simple herbalist. Lami over in Morthal should be able to help you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can you train me in Alchemy?
output: No, no. I'm just a simple herbalist. You'll want to see Arcadia, over in Whiterun.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You make armor for the Imperials?
output: It's almost all I have time for these days. The men training here in Solitude and the troops out in the field, they all need weapons and armor.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Bad day?
output: Only when you're around. The rest of these fools I could do without.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Bad day?
output: You'd think so, wouldn't you? I'm fine. Thank you for asking.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Bad day?
output: It is when my customers waste time chatting, and not buying.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you considered getting out there and fighting?
output: I think I would, if it weren't for my son. And my wife. Oh, Sayma would have my hide if I even suggested I might step foot on a battlefield. You think Stormcloaks and Legionnaires are dangerous? Ha!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's wrong with my outfit?
output: Nothing at all. It's very... nice. If you want something with a little more style, however, you should come by our shop. Radiant Raiment. We could fix you right up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's wrong with my outfit?
output: I do. So few people possess the taste and sophistication of a proper wardrobe these days. Be sure and investigate Radiant Raiment's fine selection of clothing. We have many items you'll fancy, I'm sure.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Were you at Roggvir's execution?
output: No. That was an ugly affair. High King Torygg's death has turned the whole town on its head. And between you and me? He wasn't even that good a king. All of those rambling speeches about the Empire this, and the Empire that...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I took care of the problem in <Alias=BruteTown>.
output: Kind of fun to push people around sometimes, isn't it. Good work, sister.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I took care of the problem in <Alias=BruteTown>.
output: You seem to have a knack for this kind of thing. I'll make sure people in charge know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I took care of the problem in <Alias=BruteTown>.
output: I figured you had it in you. Nicely done.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I can handle that.
output: Try not to get carried away.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I can handle that.
output: Get to it, then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've cleared the beast's lair.
output: Not bad, not bad. The intensity of the hunt is special, isn't it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've cleared the beast's lair.
output: Good to hear. Have your share of the pay.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is your lumber selling better since the war started?
output: Damn right it has. Demand's never been so high, at least not since I built the new mill.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does your family that own the lumber mill?
output: My husband owns it, barely. He'll lose it soon enough. He's behind on his loan payments, but he drinks all his money away just the same. Now we're deep in debt, penniless and about to lose our sole source of income.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does the presence of the guards here bother you?
output: No, I openly welcome the presence of armed strangers who have no reason to care about any of us. Of course it bothers me! I'm sure it's only a matter of time until they seize our mill in the name of their war effort. Next thing you know, there'll be more guards, and then we'll lose our homes as well. This is just the start of it, mark my words.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd rather not do that.
output: This isn't an order of cowards. I'll find someone more agreeable, I'm sure.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who is Orchendor?
output: Orchendor? Kesh knew him. He's an Overseer. Shepherd. Gathers the Afflicted, contains the festering wound. Orchendor and his Afflicted are meant to stand ready, awaiting Peryite's command to cover the world with his Blessing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where is Bthardamz?
output: Not far, not far. This one looks upon it on clear days. Look to the west, at the foot of the mountain. The Dwarven ruins there. Bthardamz.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What would I gain from this?
output: The pettiness of mortals. I had almost forgotten. I can grant you a powerful token for this task. An escutcheon of Dwemer make, capable of shielding you from both the spell and sword. Return when the elf lies dead and it will be yours.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why does Orchendor deserve to die?
output: An impertinent question. The elf must die. Either carry out my will or do not. You are not the only mortal agent I could choose.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've heard your request. Release me.
output: So you have, mortal. Go now. Kill Orchendor.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you all right?
output: I thought I was a goner just now. Thanks for the help, and if you need any supplies I have a few to sell.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do all the Thanes support Elisif?
output: I don't suppose it matters much anymore. As long as Ulfric wishes Elisif to remain Jarl, remain Jarl she will. And the Thanes will continue to follow her orders. As long as those orders came from Ulfric.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: But you're talking right now.
output: I shouldn't be. Everyone wants to ask me about mama and uncle Roggvir. Maybe if I don't talk, they won't either.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You play well.
output: Thank you. I'm still at the beginning of my lessons. Dean Six Fingers used to say I was quite good with the flute.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why were they executing him?
output: You really don't know? He opened the gate for Ulfric Stormcloak. Ulfric rides in, defeats the High King and Roggvir was the one that let him ride right back out. And now the Stormcloaks have claimed the entire city. I guess we have Roggvir to thank for that as well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who is Beirand?
output: My husband. He was the blacksmith up at Castle Dour.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you the court wizard?
output: Now that Sybille Stentor is out of the picture, I am indeed. And the court is, well... free of her... eccentricities. Moving into her quarters was an interesting process.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I took care of him and the Blackblood Marauders.
output: Good man.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So Erikur is your brother?
output: Yes. My older brother. He was a bit of a fop, really. And truth be told, since Torygg's death, he had no real power in court. But still... He didn't deserve to die.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't you have trouble getting ripe goods here?
output: It's been easier lately. The Blackblood Marauders haven't been seen since the Icerunner attack, so my shipments have been more regular.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So what's your job here, Melaran?
output: I provide my wisdom and insight to the court.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So what's your job here, Melaran?
output: It does indeed. You know, I hear you had something to do with Sybille Stentor's demise... That must have been a hard bit of business. I hear Stentor had been alive for a long, long time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you the High Queen of Skyrim?
output: No. Although it's true my husband Torygg was the High King and I am his widow, I am in no position to claim such a title. Ulfric Stormcloak is victorious, and the Jarls have fallen in line. It seems I will never take my rightful place as High Queen.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You make armor for the Imperials?
output: These days? Aye. Most of what I make is for folk like you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does General Tullius respect Elisif?
output: Because killing her would yield no political advantage. By leaving Elisif alive, Ulfric completes the separation of the Empire and Skyrim.  With Ulfric's troops here, Elisif will be forced to support his bid for High King. He secures the position and appears above reproach. What's more, Ulfric's refusal to execute his slain enemy's wife will be portrayed as the ultimate act of compassion. Hmph. It's genius, really.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will happen to Elisif if the Empire wins the war?
output: That's the real question, isn't it? No one can deny Elisif has a legitimate claim to become High Queen of Skyrim...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will happen to Elisif if the Empire wins the war?
output: Well... By rights, she had a legitimate claim as High Queen of Skyrim. But now Skyrim is at Ulfric's mercy. The moot will meet and choose Ulfric as High King. With his troops in most of the cities, they have little choice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Nasty bit of business, Roggvir's execution.
output: Perhaps, but necessary. As you know my cousin, Fura, died out there fighting for us. She wouldn't have had to, if it weren't for Roggvir.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Has the war affected your college much?
output: Not much. But as a bard, I find the whole affair depressing. There are no heroes in this war. Even with Ulfric here in Solitude, there are no winners to be had. No real conclusion.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the Psijic Order?
output: They were a group of mages with a history that pre-dates the Empire. Very powerful, very secretive. No one's seen them in well over a hundred years. They vanished, along with their sanctuary on the Isle of Artaeum. I have no idea what connection they'd have to this place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll help you pay off your debt.
output: You will?! Oh, thank you!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me the details.
output: I was able to work out a deal with the stables in Whiterun to sell me some of their tack and harnesses. I borrowed some gold from Sapphire to pay for the shipment, but it got robbed before it even arrived. Now Sapphire wants her money back, and if I don't pay her, I think she's going to kill me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What kind of trouble are you in?
output: I owe a great deal of money to someone and I think they cheated me. I don't know what to do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You work at the stables?
output: Yes. Hofgrir took me in when I arrived in Riften about a year ago. He's been teaching me everything he knows. Horses are my whole life. Back in Hammerfell, I helped my family raise horses at our farm. I hope to open my own stables one day, but I think it's going to take a lot longer than I expected.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry, I wish I could help you.
output: Not half as sorry as I am.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I promise. Just a joke I want to play on someone. (Persuade)
output: This is neither the time nor place for such things. I'm surprised you would ask it of me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll get the staff for you.
output: Finally, we have an agreement. I look forward to having it back soon. The sooner, the better, in fact.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You won't let Onmund out of his trade, but you want out of yours?
output: It's an entirely different situation. I don't expect you to comprehend the nuances of these matters. Regardless, I'm making you a very simple offer. You get me the staff, and I give you Onmund's precious amulet. Do we have a deal?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why is this amulet so important to you?
output: I told you, it's from my family. I don't... I know they always disapproved of what I wanted in life, to learn magic instead becoming a farmer, or a hunter. But no matter how poorly they may have treated me, they're still my family. I didn't consider that until after I'd made the trade.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You want your staff back.
output: Well, yes. I was completely unaware of the reputation of the other party in this trade. I don't want that coming back to haunt me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did you need from Enthir?
output: It doesn't matter. It's also none of your concern. Just talk to him; see if you can convince him to give my amulet back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's your point?
output: You're not very good at this, are you. Look, I traded a staff to someone and found out later that was a bad idea. So, I'd like the staff back. Understand now?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You were going to tell me a story.
output: Let's pretend for a moment that a certain individual was looking to acquire a particular staff. Let's also pretend that he traded some valuable items for said staff. And it was only later that it was realized that this individual might... misuse such a staff. The resulting disaster would reflect quite poorly on everyone involved. Are you following me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There must be something I can do to change your mind.
output: Look how persistent you are. It's charming, really. Onmund gave up the first time I said no. But not you...  All right. I'll tell you a little story.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there anything I should be aware of?
output: Actually, yes Arch-Mage. I believe there is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What if I were to pay you for the amulet?
output: No, no. You're not understanding this. Onmund made a deal. He made that choice, and now he has to live with it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's your amulet.
output: Ha! I didn't think he'd really give it back. Thank you, friend. It's good to know I can count on you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's your staff. Now I'd like the amulet, please.
output: Pleasure doing business with you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's in everyone's best interest if you return the amulet. (Persuade)
output: Oh, I suppose. But you keep this to yourself; I don't want it being known that I go back on my trades. Understand?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's in everyone's best interest if you return the amulet. (Persuade)
output: Yes, you see, the thing is... I'm not concerned with "everyone's best interest." I find I'm only concerned with my own.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm working on getting your amulet back.
output: Oh, good. I was really afraid I'd lose it forever.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I understand you have something of Onmund's. He wants it back.
output: Oh my. How precious. Onmund is too afraid to deal with me himself, and so he's sent you. I'll make this very simple for you. All my trades are final. Onmund knew this ahead of time, and went through with it anyway. So there's nothing more to be said.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I understand you have something of Onmund's. He wants it back.
output: I've already made it very clear that all of my trades are final.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about the Thieves Guild.
output: They live below the streets in the Ratway like dirty animals. And trust me, they're no better than the vermin that slink out of there for scraps. They make it difficult for decent people to earn a living. Of course, not many decent people live here in the first place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the Ratway?
output: It's Riften's name for the sewers beneath our feet. Absolutely disgusting! If you fancy keeping your purse filled with gold and your head on your shoulders, I'd stay out of those awful tunnels.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You have an odd name for a dark elf.
output: I may be dark elf by birth, but I was raised Argonian. Through reasons I'm still trying to discover, I ended up orphaned then taken in by a kindly Argonian family in Black Marsh.  I hope one day to find out what happened to me... how I ended up like that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Dragonborn? What do you mean?
output: In the very oldest tales, back from when there still were dragons in Skyrim, the Dragonborn would slay dragons and steal their power. That's what you did, isn't it? Absorbed that dragon's power?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So you're a healer?
output: Of a sort. I don't have formal training in the Restoration school, but... something just as good. Within these walls, I have all that I need to brew a potion for nearly any ailment. If I had a Septim for every case of Rockjoint or Witbane I've cured since I opened this shop, I'd be a rich woman indeed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who forges your arms and armor?
output: Adrianne. At her forge, just outside. Place is named after her. "Warmaiden's." It's a childhood nickname, given by her father. What I hear, she was playing with swords even back then. Anyway, our wares are strong and the prices fair. What else matters?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did you kill all this game yourself?
output: Oh, yes. Hunting is my great passion. That's why my brother and I opened a shop to sell hunting supplies. It's the Drunken Huntsman, down by the main gate. He tends the store, and I've got this stall.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why the name "Drunken Huntsman"?
output: Yes, I hear that question often. My brother Anoriath and I came up with it one night after consuming... rather too much mead. After our drinks, we went out for a moonlight hunt. We got separated, and in his drunken state my brother mistook me for a deer. He shot an arrow that pierced my... well, my rump. After such a memorable adventure, we knew we had the name for our shop.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the next target?
output: Good that you're so eager.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's get in there.
output: I'll be right behind you!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe some gold will help? (<BribeCost> gold)
output: Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought. Seems your purse is lighter than you thought.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Never mind.
output: Hmph. Hmph. Hmph. Hmph. Hmph. Hmph. Hmph. Hmph. Hmph. Hmph. Hmph. Hmph. Hmph. Hmph. Hmph. Hmph. Hmph. Hmph.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't have time for this... I can get rough with you if I have to.
output: Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary. Now, now! That won't be necessary.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think you may be right.
output: Yes. I think I am. You can Shout now. That can only mean one thing. You must be Dragonborn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think you may be right.
output: There's one way to find out. Try to Shout... According to the old legends, only the Dragonborn can Shout without training, the way the dragons do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't know what happened to me.
output: Well, you can Shout now. You couldn't before, right? That can only mean one thing. You must be Dragonborn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't know what happened to me.
output: There's one way to find out. Try to Shout... that would prove it. According to the old legends, only the Dragonborn can Shout without training, the way the dragons do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I find the items you want?
output: This one would try a shop. You might prefer the direct route, hm? Deathbell grow in the frozen tundra. You might nip into a mine for the ruby and silver. Vampire Dust is tricky. Vampires, you know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't relish being a Daedra's puppet.
output: And yet you have done my bidding. Why, I wonder?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: May I commune with Peryite again?
output: The vapors are waning, but not yet gone. Take a breath. Peryite will speak if He sees fit.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will become of the Afflicted?
output: Did you leave any alive? The Afflicted are mere vessels for my Blessing. It will spread to others through their touch and my own. Another Overseer will replace Orchendor, when the time comes. For now all is cleansed and ordered.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happens now?
output: Go, seek your fate. I will be watching, and perhaps we will meet again - afterwards.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Very well. Goodbye.
output: Embrace order and hard truth, mortal. Good bye.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: May I commune with Peryite?
output: Ah, no. Don't think you've got the stuff. Come back when you've seen a bit more in life, perhaps.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So what is the Poetic Edda?
output: I think Giraud here would give you the best explanation of both it and the history of King Olaf's Verse. You should speak to him about it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Viarmo said you could tell me about the Poetic Edda.
output: He's sending you after King Olaf's Verse then? That's good, we shouldn't leave it lying around now that I've figured out where it is. The Verse was Svaknir's contribution to the Poetic Edda, the living history of Skyrim. Each bard adds to the Edda in his or her time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So King Olaf's Verse is a lost part of the Edda?
output: And a very ancient one. At least, that's what we thought until I translated some ancient texts a year or so ago. We now believe King Olaf buried the truth with the bard. If I'm right Svaknir and King Olaf's Verse lie in Dead Men's Respite, along with the burial chamber of King Olaf himself. The verse criticized the reigning King Olaf. He was so incensed the bard was put to death and all the copies burned.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you saying you sent me out there to die?
output: Not at all. That was as much a test of your abilities as it was your resolve. I wasn't sure your heart was in it. But you've proven me wrong. And I respect that. Now, if were done being sentimental, it's time for you to take the Oath.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And you think Ulfric will let me just walk in there, no trouble?
output: True, he's a dangerous and blood thirsty man, but he's also a Nord that honors our traditions. True, he's a dangerous and blood thirsty man, but he's also a Nord that honors our traditions. Keep your wits about you and you won't be harmed. Keep your wits about you and you won't be harmed. And then get back here. Because if Ulfric isn't bluffing, I'll need every able body to defend Whiterun. And then get back here. Because if Ulfric isn't bluffing, I'll need every able body to defend Whiterun.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does every recruit have to do this?
output: Only the ones I'm not sure about. This will prove your abilities, but more importantly, it will prove your commitment.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you become the Jarl of Eastmarch?
output: My father, the great Bear of Eastmarch, died during my imprisonment after the Markarth Incident. When finally set free, I returned to Windhelm, and was greeted by a city in mourning, at one with my own grief and anger. The Throne of Ysgramor! The throne of my father...  I only hope I can prove worthy of the honor. I, his only son, forced to deliver his eulogy via a letter I had smuggled out of prison. Such is the love of Titus Mede for his subjects. Clamoring in angry voices, calling out for justice, for war, they sat me on the throne.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And what of his widow? Doesn't she claim the throne?
output: Indeed, Elisif has become Jarl of Solitude, historically and conveniently home of the High King, backed by Imperial interests. But the Moot has not yet met to name her High Queen. And they won't. Not as long as I have any say in it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you always lived in Skyrim?
output: I'm originally from Cyrodiil, sent here at the request of the Emperor himself. I'm often ordered to places with problems that need fixing. Now, while I'm certain this is all terribly interesting to you, I have important matters to attend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's not why I'm here.
output: I'm sorry to hear that. If you change your mind, speak with Galmar. What does bring you to me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you desire to be the High King?
output: For too long he's been hand-picked by the Emperor, and given emphatic nods by milk-drinking Jarls addicted to Imperial coin. It's time we had a real king. One of our own making. There hasn't been a true High King in Skyrim for generations.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the Imperial Legion doing in Skyrim?
output: The Legion's always been here. Without us to keep order, the provinces would fall into barbarism and lawlessness. Especially Skyrim. Take for example, Ulfric Stormcloak and his little "rebellion." But rest assured, his days are numbered.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, sir.
output: Good.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Some call you a murderer.
output: I challenged him in the traditional way, and he accepted. There were many witnesses. No "murder" was committed. But that was precisely the point! He was a puppet-king of the Empire , not a High King of Skyrim. His father before him perhaps, but not Torygg.  True, he didn't stand a chance against me. He was too privileged and too foolish, more interested in entertaining his queen than ruling his country.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Heavy.
output: They don't make finer steel anywhere else. If this doesn't keep you from dying, nothing will.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's not why I'm here.
output: I see. Then there's nothing further to discuss. If you change your mind, speak with the Legate.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you kill the High King?
output: I killed Torygg to prove our wretched condition. How is the High King supposed to be the defender of Skyrim, if he can't even defend himself?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Medium.
output: Alright. This here's enough to keep your insides from spilling out, except from the fiercest of blows, and shouldn't weigh you down too much.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Light.
output: Alright... here you go. Should keep you light on your feet, and hold up decent enough if you wind up trading blows with the enemy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You have a task for me?
output: One moment. But don't go far. I expect I'll need you. One moment. But don't go far. I expect I'll need you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You have a task for me?
output: I've made up my mind, even if my advisors are still squabbling. I'm sending you to Windhelm. I've made up my mind, even if my advisors are still squabbling. I'm sending you to Windhelm.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready to take the Oath.
output: Well, then. Repeat after me. "Upon my honor I do swear undying loyalty to the Emperor..."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What?
output: Light armor for scouting detail, heavy armor for full on combat, or something in between?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will it take to end the war?
output: Ulfric Stromcloak's head rolling away from his lifeless body.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will it take to end the war?
output: I hope Ulfric will come to his senses. But I fear he's in too far to stop now. Likely only Ulfric's death, or the overthrow of the Jarls supporting him will end this. Either way, much blood will be spilt.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will it take to end the war?
output: First we'll kick the Thalmor and their bloody Imperial puppets out of the country. Then we'll rebuild Skyrim into the land she once was. When we are done with that, we will take our army to the Dominion, and show those pointy-eared bastards not every man is fit to be their slave.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will it take to end the war?
output: We're fighting because we're done bleeding for an Empire that won't bleed for us. We're fighting because our own Jarls, once strong, wise men, have become fearful and blind to their people's suffering. We're fighting because Skyrim needs heroes, and there's no one else but us. Untold numbers of Nords died defending the Empire against the Dominion. And for what? Skyrim being sold to the Thalmor so the Emperor could keep his throne!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: General Tullius said you'd get me outfitted.
output: Yep. I have just one question for you. Light, medium, or heavy?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What brings a Breton to Skyrim?
output: Isn't it obvious? Why, the wonderful weather and hospitable people, of course! Not to mention my great fondness for dragons and petty political power struggles. Ah, but without a doubt, the most compelling feature of this frozen wasteland is the volley of inane questions leveled at me on a regular basis.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How's business?
output: Interesting, to say the least. What with all that's been going on. On the one hand, supplies are harder to come by, since fewer traders are traveling the roads these days. But on the other, the scarcity of supplies has led to some, well, "elevated" prices. All that matters is that I have what you need. And it's worth every septim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's in charge of Whiterun?
output: That'll be the Jarl, Balgruuf the Greater. He's an honorable enough man. Never done wrong by me or my kin. Things are tough for him now, I'd wager. What with the fighting, and the dragons. But Balgruuf's a tough old Nord. He can handle it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you worry about raising a family in these dangerous times?
output: Of course. Every night I pray that we don't get a visit from a dragon, or that two armies don't show up to fight over the bridge. You ask if I'm worried? I'm terrified, if you want to truth of it. But I have to stay strong for my wife and children.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You ever think of returning to Cyrodiil?
output: Why, because I'm a proud citizen of the Empire? Because the Stormcloaks only want Nords in Skyrim? The Stormcloaks can rot in Oblivion for all I care. I've lived in this city for twenty years. Twenty!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You mentioned mean folk passing through town?
output: Both the Imperials and Stormcloaks have sent riders this way, scouting the bridge and the lands nearby. They stayed at the inn, but didn't pay. They said soldiers don't need to pay because they're risking their lives to protect us. And that's not all. They took a heap of our lumber, and one tried to have his way with my daughter. They think they can do whatever they want.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who should I talk to for work?
output: Try Hulda, the innkeeper at the Bannered Mare. It's just up the road, near the market. You should check in at Dragonsreach, too. There's so much going on these days, the Jarl or his Steward might have need of help.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did you say you came here from Markarth?
output: I grew up an orphan on the streets of Markarth. I'd have died there, too, but for the kindness of an old warrior named Logrolf the Bent. Logrolf rescued me and gave me enough money to get out of the city. I followed the Karth river north, and came here. When I met Michel, I knew this was where I belonged. I suppose that's it, really.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's the best blacksmith in Skyrim?
output: I can tell you're new around here, askin' a question like that. My husband Eorlund tends the Skyforge up at Jorrvaskr, the Companions mead hall. There's no finer smith in the nine holds. You should ask him about his work. It's the only subject that'll get him talking. Well, that and maybe those stuck-up, dung-sniffing Battle-Borns.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You get a lot of attention from men?
output: You've got no idea. Half the men in Whiterun have proposed to me. Some were even single. They'll never understand. No amount of flowers or honeyed words are going to change my mind. Right now, all that matters is my daughter Mila. No man's going to get between me and my little girl.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How old is that stone bridge near the town?
output: Hard to say. It's ancient, that much we know for sure. It was here long before the town itself. I just hope the bridge survives the war. It's the only place you can cross the Karth river for a long way in either direction. Could be if one side wants to keep the other from coming across, they might try to knock it down.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds like you're having some trouble with your wife.
output: Her name's Olda. If you've met her, then you probably already know what I'm talking about. I swear that woman is the most spiteful shrew in all Skyrim. I think there's a chunk of ice where her heart ought to be.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why would you want to leave Skyrim?
output: Are you serious? The war is tearing the land apart, the dragons have returned seeking who knows what... Skyrim is going nowhere fast. If I were you, I'd pack up and get out of here before you end up in one of those burial cairns.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You treat all your customers like this?
output: Look, I've moved all over Skyrim selling these bits of junk and I'm barely scraping by. I'm not out to win friends and I could care less if you're happy about your purchase or not. I just need the coin. The sooner I get out of Skyrim the better.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are the rumors of corruption you mentioned?
output: There are those that believe the Jarl does nothing for this city... that it's corrupt and run by the Black-Briar family. I can assure you that this is entirely false. We are fully in control of everything.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about the Black-Briar family.
output: Maven Black-Briar is the owner of the largest and most profitable business in all Skyrim, the Black-Briar Meadery. We're pleased to have her in Riften. She brings stability, opportunities for employment and strategic value to our city.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's go.
output: Before we depart, Brynjolf has some business to discuss. I suggest you listen to him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Whiterun?
output: Well, I know the Companions make their home here. Their mead hall, Jorrvaskr, is the oldest building in the city. Oh, and there's a nasty feud between two families called the Gray-Manes and Battle-Borns. You'll want to be careful there. The rest you can find out by asking the townsfolk. I'd start with the barkeep at the Bannered Mare, or the castle steward.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Erik the Slayer, huh? Sounds fearsome.
output: Father says I should pick a name that describes what I really am,  but nobody's going to hire Erik Greenthumb or Erik Hoe-pusher. No, I need a name that will put some fear in the hearts of my enemies. When I have some enemies, that is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: On second thought, let's talk about this another time.
output: Another time, or not at all. It's really none of your business, after all.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How old are your horses?
output: None of 'em's older than nine, and the youngest is six. Now, the horse I got for sale is seven years old, but in fine health. She's got a lot of spirit, that one. We've taken to calling her Queen Alfsigr, or just Allie for short. I expect you can name her anything you like once she's yours.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Find the money, or you'll have me to deal with. (Intimidate)
output: Go ahead, hit me as often as you want. It's not going to change anything, other than to make me and the town guard angry.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your days of exploiting your son are over.
output: Exploiting? What's that supposed to mean? Erik works the farm because he's a good lad! I'm not forcing him to stay here. I know that he wants a life of adventure, but I've told him before that I can't afford to buy him armor.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You'd prefer your son to grow bitter and resent you? (Persuade)
output: Perhaps you should let a father decide what is best for his own son.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about Riften.
output: You can get a room at the Bee and Barb, but mind your coin purse -- it's no secret the Thieves' Guild makes its home here. Oh, and if you meet Maven Black-Briar, stay on her good side. This is her city, and nobody else's.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Solitude?
output: Solitude's been the capital of Skyrim as long as I can remember. Most of the High Kings of Skyrim were Jarls of Solitude first. Ah, let's see, what else... The Bards College is here, and the main office of the East Empire Company. If you need it, you can get a room for a fair price at the Winking Skeever, just inside the main gate.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here, use this to buy some armor. (<bribecost> gold)
output: I appreciate the gesture, but I'd rather not be in debt to a stranger.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Windhelm?
output: It's an old city, I can tell you that. The Palace of the Kings is ancient. It's not the friendliest place for outsiders. The Dark Elves were all forced to live in a slum called the Gray Quarter. The Argonians can't even live inside the walls. They're all stuck out on the docks. Still, Candlehearth Hall's got decent food and cheap bunks. You could do worse.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm sorry, I don't even remember how I got here. (Persuade)
output: You were ranting but most of it was slurred. You said something about Rorikstead. Well, you were deep in your cups when you got here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't care about the ring! Tell me what else I said! (Intimidate)
output: All right, all right. You're mean when you're sober. You said you the ceremony was going to be in Morvunskar. You said your friend Sam was going to be your best man.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't care about the ring! Tell me what else I said! (Intimidate)
output: You think you can bully me. I grew up with five brothers. Go... get...my...ring.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me everything and you won't end up like your goat. (Intimidate)
output: Okay, okay. Most of what you said didn't make sense but you left a note. The only bit that I could read said "after repaying Ysolda in Whiterun." That's all I know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me everything and you won't end up like your goat. (Intimidate)
output: Do what you have to do, I'm not giving up on Gleda.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me how I got here and I'll pay for the damages. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: Well, we can always use contributions. You were ranting when you got here  but most of it was slurred. You did say something about Rorikstead . Maybe you should take a look there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me how I got here and I'll pay for the damages. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: Oh you must be nobility of some sort. Running around partying and paying others to clean it up. I don't think so. Clean up your own mess.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I just need to get to the wedding. Please. (Persuade)
output: You must have had a wild night if you can't remember that. But I suppose everyone gets the jitters before their wedding. And I did say you could take a bit of time paying me back. You said the ceremony was going to be at Morvunskar. Don't forget you still owe me!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I just need to get to the wedding. Please. (Persuade)
output: I'm sure your bride-to-be will tell you when you where the ceremony will be. If she still wants to marry you when you tell her you can't afford the ring.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Help me retrace my steps and I'll pay you for the goat. (1000 gold)
output: Fine, but I'll still be missing my Gleda. Doubt I'll ever have a prize winning goat again. Most of what you said was gibberish but you left a note. The only bit I could read was "after repaying Ysolda in Whiterun."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Help me retrace my steps and I'll pay you for the goat. (1000 gold)
output: There's not enough money in the world to replace Gleda.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to find Sam and the staff, in order to get Gleda back. (Persuade)
output: I suppose that makes sense. You didn't mention a Sam and nothing you said about the staff made sense. You left a note but it was mostly gibberish, the only bit I could make out was "after repaying Ysolda in Whiterun."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to find Sam and the staff, in order to get Gleda back. (Persuade)
output: You didn't seem to need either to sell Gleda to the Giant in the first place. I think you'll figure it out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Seriously, let me pay you for the ring. (2000 gold)
output: Decided to go through with it then? I knew you couldn't have forgotten about your fiance. You spoke of her so glowingly. I don't know much about Morvunskar but it sounded like a lovely place for the ceremony. Congratulations.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Seriously, let me pay you for the ring. (2000 gold)
output: I think I would prefer my ring back. I put a lot of time into making it and you just gave is away as a joke.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're going to assault Northwatch Keep?
output: I'll do anything if it means saving my brother. You'll join us, won't you? Thorald can't be left to those... monsters.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do I have to beat it out of you? (Brawl)
output: It would be my pleasure.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Not just yet.
output: Let me know. We shouldn't stay here all day. My men want their mead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How's business?
output: Not well I'm afraid. That Brynjolf... he keeps draining the people's pockets with his ridiculous miracle cures. A few months ago it was troll fat salve and now he's got something new. Not that there's anything that can be done about it. He's in good with the Thieves Guild.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You run the Black-Briar Meadery?
output: Maven Black-Briar wants me to keep the mead flowing and that's what I aim to do despite all these lazy good-for-nothings that work for us. Ever since I took over as the foreman the production of our mead has never been more profitable. And if the meadery is profitable, I get rich. Get the picture?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I take it you protect the Jarl?
output: Indeed. There have been multiple attempts on the Jarl's life. We're not certain if it's the Dark Brotherhood or simply Imperial sympathizers. We've also had run-ins with spies attempting to probe our security for weaknesses. I work with the city guard to make certain they fail. At the end of the day, I'm the last line of defense for the Jarl. I will not allow her to fall.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's your stance on the war?
