instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let me know if you find anything else.
output: I wouldn't hold out too much hope.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Calixto Corrium was the real killer.
output: Ysmir's beard! The man was always a bit odd, but I wouldn't have expected...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did you have anything to do with this?
output: I'm too busy tending to the dead to spend my time making more of them. And I wouldn't very well tell you about the cuts if I had made them, now would I?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready to take the oath.
output: I believe the Legate gave you an order. I expect you to follow it. Dismissed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Were they a part of the Thieves Guild?
output: Indirectly. The Trinity is usually selected from the ranks of the Guild although its existence is a closely-guarded secret.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about the Nightingales.
output: Gallus, Mercer Frey and I were once members of what's known as the Nightingale Trinity. The Trinity disbanded twenty-five years ago when Mercer Frey betrayed us by slaying Gallus and dumping his body in the ruins of Snow Veil Sanctum.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is their purpose?
output: The Nightingales protect the temple of Nocturnal, a place known as the Twilight Sepulcher.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, sir!
output: We have it on good authority that Ulfric has raised enough men to attack the city of Whiterun. The Jarl, however, refuses the Legion's support. This missive should convince him. Be aware soldier, these documents contain sensitive intelligence for the Jarl's eyes only.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the Jagged Crown?
output: A legendary crown, dating back to King Harald's time, or before. A powerful relic of a golden age, long since passed. Whatever the truth, if Ulfric get's his hands on it, it would be a powerful symbol around which to rally support for his cause. Legend has it that the crown is made from the bones and teeth of ancient dragons, and is said to increase the power of the wearer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do we know the crown is in Korvanjund?
output: Well, to be frank, we don't. Its location was lost with King Borgas, when the Great Hunt killed him while off on his Alessian campaigns. I know Galmar. We fought in many wars together. He's not a sentimental man taken to fancy. If he believes the crown is there... he's likely found it. But my agents report that Galmar is pretty damned convinced Korvanjund is the tomb of King Borgas. Supposedly, his body was brought back to Skyrim and secretly buried with the crown. Knowledge of that location was lost, in the Wars of Succession.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You made a deal with the Forsworn?
output: When their uprising was crushed, I had Madanach brought to me. He was a wild animal, but a useful one. I offered him a stay from execution if he used his influence to deal with any annoyances that came up. Competitors, agents, idiots. So I've let him run his little Forsworn rebellion from inside Cidhna Mine. Now he's out of control.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want the truth, or else. (Intimidate)
output: Or else what? You'll kill me? I already had to face that today.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Nothing. Looking around.
output: Well then, look. Look all you want. And when you're done looking, maybe we can get some work done.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No one tells me what to do.
output: We'll see. We'll see. We'll see.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: If you must know, I'm the maid. And the master of the house is old and needs his rest. So if you don't have any business. Leave.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not trying to cause trouble.
output: You're finding it. That's bad enough. You're finding it. That's bad enough. You're finding it. That's bad enough.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need the key to Weylin's room.
output: Sorry, but you don't exactly belong here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Forsworn have a king?
output: Madanach. The King in Rags. While we were off fighting the Elves in the Great War, Madanach was busy ruling over the Reach. Until Ulfric came and put them down.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did you send that guard to threaten me?
output: What did you expect? That no one was going to notice you butting into business that wasn't yours? The guards know who holds the purse strings in this city, and I don't like snoops. Markarth is my city. You have no right looking into my business. Now get out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't listen to threats.
output: You'll listen to this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You deserved this.
output: Shut up. Only the gods can judge me. You want to know what the Forsworn really are?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Just looking around.
output: This is a private home, and the master of the house is a very old man. He's not to be disturbed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you doing in Markarth?
output: Just visiting. I had some business here. That's all.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Cidhna Mine?
output: My prison. The source of half the silver in Skyrim. The most secure prison in Tamriel. No one escapes. I thought keeping Madanach down there would keep him under control.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want to know about the Silver-Bloods.
output: It's an old family. Very well-respected throughout the Reach. The Silver-Bloods run nearly all the lands in this Hold, as well as the local inn. And of course, they own Cidhna Mine, the finest prison and source of silver in Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What kind of patrons do you have?
output: For one, the landowners of the Reach. It goes without saying that they rely heavily on us for our silver and support. All the miners, farmers, and laborers in the Reach get their daily wages through us. Nepos the Nose handles that part of our business. He has a way with the workers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about the Forsworn?
output: Every other day, seems one of the laborers runs off in the hills saying he'll join the Forsworn. You don't like the Nords? Fine. But pledging your whole life to killing them? That's just dumb.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: By Ysmir, are you thick, or just too new to know better? The Companions are the oldest, most honored band of warriors in Skyrim. Whiterun was built around their hall, Jorrvaskr. Don't reckon they can use you. But stranger things have happened.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're not going to win this war on the battlefield.
output: True. A pause to consolidate our gains would be useful. And the Empire can afford to look magnanimous in victory.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're not going to win this war on the battlefield.
output: Ulfric's insurrection has reached its high tide. Soon enough the rebel Jarls will realize what it means to oppose the Empire. But, as you say, these negotiations may offer a chance for his supporters to gracefully return to the Imperial fold.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're not going to win this war on the battlefield.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Politics be damned. Alduin has returned! (Persuade)
output: Alduin? The World-Eater of song and legend? If that's true... well, it changes the situation doesn't it? Even Tullius may be forced to talk sense in the face of such a threat.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will you do now?
output: I believe I'll stay here and bask in Eldergleam's warmth a bit longer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there any way to revive the tree?
output: I've thought about that... Trees like this never really die. They only slumber. I think if we had some of the sap from the parent tree, we could wake up its child. But even if you could get to the Eldergleam, you couldn't tap it. Not with any normal metal.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why haven't the pilgrims been coming?
output: A big dead tree isn't very inspiring if you're coming to worship the divine of wind and rains. Kynareth gives life, and we need a living tree to be her symbol.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's not really my problem.
output: You're right. It's mine.  I may not live to see this little one grow into a new Gildergreen, but I can be remembered as the woman who planted it. I thank you. And may Kynareth's soft rains fall before you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me more about Eldergleam.
output: The sap is precious. It can restore barren fields or bring life to rocks. I can use it to repair the Gildergreen, so we can worship properly again. It's an old tree. Very old. They say it was a seedling when the first men were arriving from Atmora, thousands of years ago.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll get Nettlebane for you.
output: Your spirit is strong. Kynareth's winds will guide your path. It's held in a Hagraven nest called Orphan Rock.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What kind of weapon would work?
output: Eldergleam is older than metal, from a time before men or elves. To even affect it, you have to tap into the old magic.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What kind of weapon would work?
output: You'll have to deal with the Hagravens. I've heard about a weapon they've made for sacrificing Spriggans.  It's called "Nettlebane." The hags terrify me, or I would have gone after it myself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about this temple.
output: The Gildergreen, yes. It's a bit of an eyesore at the moment. More of a problem for the pilgrims than for me, but not many of them around anymore.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about this temple.
output: This is the Temple of Kynareth. The Gildergreen, outside, was planted as a seedling in the early years of Whiterun. Disciples of Kynareth could sense something holy in it, and traveled far to hear the winds of the goddess in its branches. Of course, not as many pilgrims these days.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about this temple.
output: This is the Gildergreen. It was planted as a seedling in the early years of Whiterun. Disciples of Kynareth could sense something holy in it, and traveled far to hear the winds of the goddess in its branches. They built the temple. Of course, not as many pilgrims these days.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where is the tree?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Thanks for your help.
output: It was my pleasure, friend. In a way, I envy you getting to carry such a direct sign of Kynareth's graces.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How long have you been in Skyrim?
output: Not long, in truth. I came to Skyrim after I found myself unwelcome in both Elsweyr and Cyrodiil. I seem to have an unfortunate talent for getting myself involved in misunderstandings with the law. Ri'saad was able to look past that, and it was he who helped to set me up with a trade caravan. Now I work for him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you had trouble with the locals?
output: Mostly it is the Nords. They do not like outsiders in their land, and so we are forbidden to enter the cities. When they look upon us, they see only pickpockets and skooma dealers. It is most unfair, but we do our best to ignore them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why sell your goods in Skyrim?
output: An astute question, for we are far from home and this is a cold, hard land. The wise trader finds the best opportunities, even if he must travel far to find them. Skyrim is a ripe opportunity indeed. The dragons and the war have scared many other traders away, but for those with courage, there is much profit to be made.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm curious about your homeland.
output: The Khajiit hail from a distant land called Elsweyr, bordered on the north by Cyrodiil and the south by the glistening blue waters of the sea. There are cities so ancient, the sands have swallowed them whole. But now I will say no more, for I miss my home greatly. Elsweyr is an arid land of deserts and rocky canyons, where the sun shines warmly, always.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Has the war made your travels difficult?
output: Quite the opposite, in fact. The soldiers are some of our best customers, for we offer supplies and wares they cannot obtain by other means. It was Ri'saad's idea to come here now, while the land is in turmoil. Where others saw only danger, he saw opportunity.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who owns the trading caravans?
output: It is Ri'saad who owns the three trading caravans that travel the roads of Skyrim. Long ago, I was an orphan on the streets of Corinthe. I stowed away aboard a trade ship that brought me here. It was Ri'saad who found me. He provided the funds to start this caravan, and put me in charge of it. I owe him more than I could ever hope to repay.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you work for Risaad?
output: He hired the others and paid for my goods. I am allowed to run the caravan, but I pay Ri'saad a percentage of my profits. I say this without bitterness, for it was Ri'saad who saved me from a life of servitude aboard a trading ship. I am grateful to have the life that I do now. It is a far cry from my days as an orphan on the streets of Corinthe.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So why are they hunting you?
output: When I was young, our leaders became obsessed with the Thalmor threat. They believed that if and when we found a Dragonborn, we would need to protect him against the Thalmor.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can I help?
output: I'm not sure if you've noticed, but there are several Khajiit Caravans that travel across the realm. They're shrewd traders and don't mind getting their hands dirty. I've bartered with their leader, Ri'saad, on more than one occasion.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: Ah, Moon Sugar. I could smell it on you. I'm pleased with this offer, and accept. Take my word to the leaders of your guild and tell them we look forward to a prosperous and profitable future. If you happen upon any of our caravans in your travels, we'd also be more than willing to pay you a fair sum for any of your stolen goods.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sure, what do you need?
output: Well, as you know, the Guild's growing and things are looking up around here. The only thing we're lacking is a reliable way to transport our merchandise across Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I bring an offer from the Thieves Guild.
output: Yes, I've heard the Guild is rising back to power. An alliance would be most beneficial to both parties. I'll consider the offer, but I'll have to discuss it with the other caravans.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me more about these caravans.
output: Ri'saad is the head of a small syndicate of independent merchant families. Each caravan is obliged to pay dues, but in return a small portion of the profits are shared between them and the leader parcels out the routes. If we could make contact with them, they could provide an excellent way to inconspicuously transport goods for us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's Moon Sugar?
output: It's an illegal substance highly favored by the Khajiit. Very difficult to come by. If Moon Sugar is refined properly, it can be used to make skooma, another substance that will knock you over after a single draught.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why does the town have such a large cemetery?
output: The cemetery is ancient. It's been here longer than the town. I'm no scholar, but I know that a lot of battles have been fought here over the course of history. After each battle, more dead were buried, and the graveyard got bigger. I've heard it's now the biggest graveyard in Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is this place always so gloomy?
output: Yes, and I couldn't tell you why. My wife and I think there's some dark magic at work. Or perhaps Arkay's influence is strong here, and he likes to keep it this way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you tend this graveyard alone?
output: Oh, merciful Arkay, no! I am too old and frail, and this graveyard is too large. Kust is my assistant. He helps me tend the headstones and keep our cemetery clean, as befits a place of rest.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you need someone to check out Wolfskull Cave?
output: Oh, I thought that matter was handled. I think Falk is taking care of that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who is Styrr?
output: He's Solitude's priest of Arkay. He's the one who figured out Potema was still around. He'll help as much as he can.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why me?
output: I'm not really sure. Styrr thinks you have some sort of link to Potema. I trust his judgment on this. As a priest of Arkay he's had to deal with necromancy before. Nothing as dangerous as Potema though.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Aren't you worried about Wolfskull Cave?
output: I've done my part, Dragon Bridge will have extra guards. Falk Firebeard will find a way to take care of the cave.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you worried about what that petitioner said about Wolfskull Cave?
output: Not really. Varnius Junius is a fool. I'm sure nothing will come of it. I suppose if you're truly interested you could talk to Falk. He's the better-safe-than-sorry type.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: When do I get out?
output: You'll pay off your debt to the Reach. Just work and you'll earn your freedom.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry to hear that.
output: We are used to the cycle of gain and loss. It is no trouble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could get your amulet back.
output: You are kind to offer. We believe the bandits are a part of a group headquartered here. Be careful. I miss my amulet, but a life cannot be replaced as easily.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Bandits giving you trouble?
output: A few days ago, we were ambushed. A nuisance, really, but many of the marauders had quick fingers. One of them stole my Moon Amulet, given to me by my mother when I was just a cub. It is my only memory of home in this cold land.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: What's this? Some kind of code? "Need as much iron ore as you can dig up...." He's not spying, but it's clear the Empire is making Lod smith up more swords and armor for them. Good work. Take this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you all right?
output: Not against me. Against all of Falkreath. Those Imperial bastards are spying on every one of us. Last night I saw Lod the blacksmith writing a letter. Probably sending word to Solitude and General Tullius. Are you loyal to Skyrim? Break into Lod's house and get that letter.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have your amulet.
output: There it is. Ah.... Home.... If you ever need the skills of a Khajiit warrior by your side, I would be honored to travel with you. Until then, here. This is for you, in thanks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll get it for you.
output: Good.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've found this expedition journal.
output: Oh really? Hmm... this looks like someone from Staubin's little group. A brave scholar, but not very wise.... If you find Staubin, it would be good to see any notes he may have collected. I doubt you'll find him alive, though.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I recovered your flute.
output: That's it! Wonderful! I knew I could count on you. I don't have any money to give you. but I can show you a few tricks I learned playing for the Winterhold wizards.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's neck is that?
output: Larina. That fool student of mine stole my flute and sold it to some necromancer. I just got a ransom note for it. That flute has been handed down for seventeen generations! Well don't just stand there. Go get my flute!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have Rjorn's Drum.
output: At last! I have searched for this drum for 20 years. The college treasury is a bit thin right now. But I can show you some tricks I learned from my days with the army.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've found Finn's Lute.
output: What? You did? Oh sweet Divines! You did! There is no way I can pay you what this Lute is worth. But I can teach you a few tricks I've learned over the years.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's Rjorn and why do you want his Drum?
output: You're joking, right? Rjorn? Only the most famous battle drummer of the second age. Well, famous among bards at least. That drum has been in half a dozen famous battles. It's a priceless artifact. Rjorn was always looking for new stories to tell. It seems he was writing a lay about Halldir when he vanished. That was the missing clue.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did they find?
output: Rjorn's drum! Nobody knows where he died, and therefore where his drum might be. Halldir was the missing link. Rjorn entered Halldir's Cairn in secret, and presumably died there. Now all I need to do is find someone to get it. Wait. You. You could do it. I need you to get me that drum.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's so important about Finn's Lute?
output: Finn was the bard who invented the eight course lute that is commonplace today. Until he found a way to string the extra courses, bards only had six course lutes. The lute they stole is Finn's original eight course lute. I doubt they even realize its true value.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: BardsCollegeDrumHello
output: They found it! They actually found it!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why would a necromancer want your flute?
output: Apparently Larina told him some story about the flute being able to make the dead dance. It's just a flute. A really old and valuable flute, but just a flute.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why are you sad?
output: Hmm? Oh, sorry. My mind wanders sometimes. I was just thinking about Finn's Lute. Over a year ago, thieves broke into the college and made off with a lot of valuable things. Mostly gold and silver. But they also stole Finn's Lute. We just learned where the bandits fled to, and I very much want that lute back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let Ulfric have his way now. He'll have to give ground later.
output: Well said.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, you're right. Elenwen should stay.
output: Maybe so, but bringing her here is a deliberate provocation. Tullius needs to know I won't be pushed around.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ulfric has a point. The Thalmor have no business here.
output: Maybe so, but I can't be making concessions before negotiations even start. It makes the Empire look weak.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me more about the barrow.
output: There ain't much more to tell... they're haunted and you should stay away. Look, I've seen one of the spirits with my very own eyes. When it glared at me, I swear it burned right through my soul.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry, I can't help you.
output: Don't blame you one bit.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You told Narfi she's coming back?
output: I just said that to make the poor guy feel better. I'm pretty sure she's dead. Reyda would gather ingredients from the small island in the river east of here. Then one day, she just vanished. I tried to look for her, but she never turned up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You having a bear problem?
output: Are you kidding? Those damn things will drive me right out of business! Tell you what. Bring me ten of their pelts from anywhere in Skyrim I'll gladly pay you for thinning out the herd.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is this her necklace? (Give necklace)
output: Reyda! You saw Reyda? Did you tell her Narfi cries? Did you tell her Narfi never said goodbye like mother and father?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found Reyda's necklace.
output: Reyda! You saw Reyda? Did you tell her Narfi cries? Did you tell her Narfi never said goodbye like mother and father?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could investigate for you.
output: If you think there's anything you can do, be my guest.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the story with Narfi?
output: He's harmless. He's been in a state ever since his sister Reyda disappeared over a year ago. He just keeps to himself in what's left of his folk's farmhouse across the river.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's wrong with you?
output: With father I said goodbye... with mother I said goodbye. Reyda leaves and Narfi can't say goodbye. Makes Narfi very, very sad. Narfi needs Reyda to say goodbye.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found this in Shroud Hearth Barrow. (Give journal)
output: Let me see that! ...I can't believe this... It was all just a fabrication of this Wyndelius character? I can't believe we were so stupid.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do the spirits haunt your town as well?
output: Fortunately, they seem to be sticking to the barrow. I think they're guarding it. Certainly isn't helping my business any; who'd want to rent a room anywhere near a haunted barrow?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How could bears run you out of business?
output: Have you ever seen what a bear does to the trees? They jump up on their hind legs and scratch them to bits... marking their territory or something. It's getting to the point where I have to scour Skyrim for untouched trees at the right size. Costs me too much time and money.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: She said she'll be home soon.
output: You've made Narfi so happy! Narfi now waits for his sister until she comes home. At least Narfi has Reyda's Necklace... reminds Narfi of his sister. Thank you for giving this to Narfi.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Anything dangerous on that small island to the east?
output: I've seen some sort of a cave entrance over there. Folks call it "Geirmund's Hall," but I don't know why. Probably best if you avoid it for now... it didn't seem to do Reyda any good.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Actually, you need to take a look at this. (Give journal)
output: Let me see that! ...I can't believe this... It was all just a fabrication of this Wyndelius character? I can't believe we were so stupid.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I brought ten bear pelts, just like you asked.
output: Nice to finally meet someone who can follow simple instructions. Here's your reward, as promised. Now if you'll excuse me, I have to get back to work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you okay?
output: Reyda was here, then gone. Went to gather plants and never came home... nope, nope. Everyone looked and no one could find her. Wilhelm said she'll be back... told Narfi not to worry... Reyda will come back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry Narfi, she's dead.
output: Oh no! No, no, no. Narfi never got to say goodbye! Now Narfi's all alone. At least Narfi has Reyda's Necklace... reminds Narfi of his sister. Thank you for giving this to Narfi.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Has anyone ever explored the barrow?
output: About a year or two ago, some fella named Wyndelius came through; said he was some kind of a treasure hunter. I warned him not to go in there, just like I warned you. The very next night we heard screams from the barrow, and that was it. We never saw him again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who is Malacath?
output: You do not know of Malacath? He is the keeper of oaths, the master of curses.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who is Malacath?
output: You are an Orc, but do not know of Malacath, our master and yours?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Deal with your own curses.
output: We have been on our own for some time now. I fear we will not survive.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It seems like I shouldn't be here.
output: No, don't go! You may not be one of our tribe, but you are an Orc nonetheless!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How long has this been going on?
output: Weeks? Longer? It feels like an age has gone by. I haven't slept in so long.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm just here to help.
output: Oh, of course! Because Malacath would take pity on us if only a useless outsider would lend a hand.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Okay, if you don't want it, I'll find someone who does.
output: Wait. Are you... Are you serious? You have an Elder Scroll? You?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I am serious. It's yours if you want it.
output: You... Really? An Elder Scroll?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Would you be interested in an Elder Scroll?
output: Very funny. Did Enthir put you up to this?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You asked my opinion. I gave it to you.
output: Fair enough. You claim to be neutral, but it seems that you actually favor the Empire. Still...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You will be stopped.
output: Oh? True, I may meet my end in a dark alley with a dagger in my back. But the people have seen the truth, and they will not back down.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You've killed the High King. Why make war on your own people?
output: I have shown the people that when our Jarls drink the Empire's milk, it makes us weak.  I must now show them the path that will lead us back to our strength. There is no progress without sacrifice. No wheat without threshing the chaff. The Empire and the Jarls who back them must be swept away. The people demand it. I demand it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ulfric means war.
output: You've returned with my axe. I knew that would be his response. You've returned with my axe. I knew that would be his response. As soon as you left I sent word to General Tullius, who's been kind enough to lend us some of his troops and Legate Cipius here. As soon as you left I sent word to General Tullius, who's been kind enough to lend us some of his troops and Legate Cipius here. Let Ulfric try to make it past our combined forces. Let Ulfric try to make it past our combined forces. I'll turn you back over to your Legion. Legate Cipius will have use for you. Gods be with us all. I'll turn you back over to your Legion. Legate Cipius will have use for you. Gods be with us all.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've brought a message from the Jarl of Whiterun.
output: Is that so? I've been wondering when he'd come around.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: An axe?
output: How long have you been in Skyrim? Yes. Give the man my axe.  How long have you been in Skyrim? Yes. Give the man my axe.  If he returns it to you it means we have business to settle. If he keeps it, then we are at peace. If he returns it to you it means we have business to settle. If he keeps it, then we are at peace.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We'll be seeing you soon.
output: Sooner than you think.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You have a task for me?
output: Deliver this axe to Ulfric Stormcloak. Deliver this axe to Ulfric Stormcloak.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was given strict instructions. For the Jarl's eyes only.
output: Don't be daft. Proventus is my eyes.  Don't be daft. Proventus is my eyes.  Just give me the letter. I presume once I have it, I can do as I please with it? Good. Just give me the letter. I presume once I have it, I can do as I please with it? Good.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Should I say anything to him?
output: Men who understand one another need not waste words. Men who understand one another need not waste words. There are but a few simple truths behind one warrior giving another his axe.  There are but a few simple truths behind one warrior giving another his axe.  Ulfric will know my meaning. Ulfric will know my meaning.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Understood.
output: Good. Good. Good... Good...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: (Hand him the axe)
output: Oh. What's this? Ahhh... You're quite brave to carry such a message. It's a pity you've chosen the wrong side... You can return this axe to the man who sent it. And tell him he should prepare to entertain... visitors. I expect a great deal of excitement in the city of Whiterun in the near future...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have an important message for you.
output: No doubt requesting to garrison his men in my castle. How many times must I deny him? No doubt requesting to garrison his men in my castle. How many times must I deny him? Well? Out with it. Well? Out with it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have an important message for you.
output: We can talk about that once this dragon is dealt with. We can talk about that once this dragon is dealt with.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have an important message for you.
output: Ah yes. I've studied those documents... Very interesting... Ah yes. I've studied those documents... Very interesting...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ulfric plans to attack Whiterun. The General wants to lend Legion troops.
output: Until that dragon's dealt with, I don't care what Tullius wants. Until that dragon's dealt with, I don't care what Tullius wants. For now, give the papers to my Steward. For now, give the papers to my Steward.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ulfric plans to attack Whiterun. The General wants to lend Legion troops.
output: I see... Give the papers to my Steward. I see... Give the papers to my Steward.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There are advantages to gaining <Alias=ImperialMinorHoldCapital>. (Persuade)
output: Not enough to outweigh the loss of Riften. The whole south of Eastmarch would be open to Imperial attack.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There are advantages to gaining <Alias=SonsMinorHoldCapital>. (Persuade)
output: Not enough to outweigh the loss of Markarth. With the Reach in enemy hands, our whole position in Solitude would be threatened.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: NightgateHadringBusinessBranchTopic
output: Nah, not so much. The odd traveler on the road. But mostly just old Fultheim, come to drink away a lifetime of bad memories, I'd wager. Course there's the Orc. Long-term tenant, that one. For what he pays, I could afford to shut this place down.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could do it for you.
output: Really? That would be kind of you. Here, take this bag of supplies. At the top of the steps you'll see the offering chest. Just leave the bag inside and you're done.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And in return?
output: Well, it's kind of an understanding between us. I mean, it just wouldn't feel right to charge them for a bit of preserved food. Trouble is, my legs aren't what they used to be and climbing the 7,000 Steps takes its toll.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What types of deliveries do you make to High Hrothgar?
output: Mostly food supplies like dried fish and salted meats; you know, things that keep fresh for a long time. The Greybeards tend not to get out much, if you catch my meaning.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Anything I should watch out for during the climb?
output: Well, there's the occasional wolf pack or stray, but that's all I've ever had to deal with. Shouldn't be a problem for the likes of you. Other than that, watch your footing. In these wintry conditions, the stairs can be treacherous.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I delivered the supplies to High Hrothgar.
output: Quite a climb, wasn't it? Anyway, much appreciated. Here, take this for your troubles.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry, I can't help you with that.
output: Maybe I'll hold off and go another day. Get some rest first.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's it like being a werewolf?
output: How did you... you reach beyond your station, new blood. Let's wait and see how we judge your Trial before speaking further.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's it like being a werewolf?
output: You shouldn't even know about that. Remember you're not a full Companion yet, whelp. Know your place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's it like being a werewolf?
output: What did I tell you? Keep quiet about that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's it like being a werewolf?
output: I think there are some things that... oh, wait. Are you trying to trick me? You are not a full-blood yet. We can't talk about that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's it like being a werewolf?
output: We should not be talking about that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's it like being a werewolf?
output: I don't know what you're talking about. But if I were you, I'd hold my tongue.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's it like being a werewolf?
output: I don't know who you've been talking to, but they were clearly mistaken.  Especially for a new whelp, you should choose your words more carefully.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's it like being a werewolf?
output: For me, a heavy burden.  The beastblood has given me prowess, but my soul is now forfeit to Hircine upon my death. I keep searching for some hope of Sovngarde, but to no avail.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's it like being a werewolf?
output: A sensitive question. You may want to be careful broaching that subject with some. The old man and I have our differences when it comes to this. It's a blessing, given by Hircine.  To worry about the hereafter means losing sight of the now. What do I care about Sovngarde? Give me the power to tear my foes as a beast of the wild, and I will savor it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's it like being a werewolf?
output: I was raised in the woods. Hunting every animal I could see, with my father. I know them all as well as I know my own mind. And when I feel myself filling with the blood of the wolf... it's like I'm bringing all the strength of all the beasts inside me. But my mind and soul remain my own. I become more than either human or beast.  It's like being born. Every time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's it like being a werewolf?
output: I've enjoyed the boons that come with beastblood. Just like every member of the Circle. Kodlak is right, though. We've given a piece of our souls for this power. I know my mythic histories. Bargains like that lead to ruin. This is a curse that was laid upon us. That much is clear.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's it like being a werewolf?
output: I like being stronger when I become the wolf. But Kodlak says it is bad for the soul, and I trust him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where do you stand on the war?
output: Politics are something best avoided. I prefer more personal confrontations, myself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where do you stand on the war?
output: None of our business. There's no honor to be had in the squabbling of jarls.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where do you stand on the war?
output: Kodlak says not to worry about it. I worry that a bunch of snowberries are out there earning glory while we stay out of it. But I'll follow the old man's lead. As ever.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where do you stand on the war?
output: Too confusing for me. Empire, Nords, Talos. Who cares? Just tell me who needs bludgeoning.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where do you stand on the war?
output: There are always good reasons to fight. I just wish this war had them. Who cares who worships what dead god? Give me something to make me draw my sword.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you join the Companions?
output: I learned the ways of the blade in the Great War. Nearly lost my life outside the Imperial City.  I came home to Skyrim when it was all over. But I wasn't much good at anything other than fighting. Wandered around as a blade for hire. Was a damned good one, too. The money was good, and the women were good, and the drinks were good. But I was losing myself. My heart.  I was lucky the Companions found me. Now there's a reason to be fighting. The honor of my brothers and sisters is worth more than coin. Of course, the money is still good. And the drinks!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you join the Companions?
output: My mother was a Companion. And her mother. And all the women in my family, back to Hrotti Blackblade.  I stayed with my father in the woods until I was old enough for my Trial. We hunted everything there was to hunt. Good training.  Ma didn't live long enough to see me join, but I fight to honor her and all my Shield-Sisters through time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you join the Companions?
output: Vilkas and I have been here since we were little whelps. Our father, Jergen, raised us here.  Even Vignar couldn't remember Companions younger than us!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you join the Companions?
output: To hear Farkas tell it, our father raised us here as happy pups, running around biting knees. I love my brother, but his brains are not his strong suit.  We were brought here by Jergen. Whether he was our father or not, I don't care. He left to fight in the Great War and never came back. So he's not my problem anymore. We've been here as long as either of us can remember, though. So try to show some respect.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you join the Companions?
output: Like most of our band, I found this family after losing my own. I traveled the length and breadth of this land, learning all I could of the sword and the axe. I was just a boy, but I had the fire of a man in my heart. Eventually, my body caught up to my spirit. My predecessor, Askar, found me in Hammerfell. I was serving as bodyguard for some weak-necked lord out there. He brought me back here, and I realized... that I was actually coming home. I work to bring honor to this family, and to the family that I lost. For my mother, my father, and my grandfather. For all my Shield-Siblings.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you join the Companions?
output: Fortune and glory, friend. Fortune and glory.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you join the Companions?
output: So I wouldn't have to answer stupid questions from idiots.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you join the Companions?
output: Are you kidding? I've wanted to be with them since I was a little girl. Haven't you heard the stories of Kodlak and Skjor fighting off the hundred-and-one Orc berserkers? Skjor says it was more like forty, but he's just being modest. Where else would I want to be but here? Learning from them, fighting at their sides.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you join the Companions?
output: A man of my station has many debts. I'm not much use at labor or learning, but I can throw a punch with the best of 'em. The Companions let me fight for gold, and so I fight.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you join the Companions?
output: When you get to be my age, you don't remember why you did much of anything.  Only that it happened.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you join the Companions?
output: Oh, I'm not a Companion, myself. I just help Vignar. He took me in when I was having a tough time, and... well, I owe him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Companions?
output: Ask any fool around here, and get a different answer. Mercenaries. Warriors of honor. Brothers and sisters of the blade. Drunken rabble. Take your pick. I've been here longer than most of them. Even I don't know sometimes. I just hope they don't kill each other.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Companions?
output: The Companions are my family. We fight so that other people don't have to.  We bring honor and glory to ourselves and each other.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Companions?
output: You'll hear some of the brighter faces around here talk about honor and glory. I've got nothing against it, but for me, the promise of coin is what feeds my blade. Wherever someone in Skyrim doesn't feel up to defending their own honor, we'll take up their burden.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Companions?
output: Your question carries more weight than you may know, newcomer. The sort of thing some of us spend our lives pondering. The difference between a noble band of warriors and a ragged bunch of assassins is as thin as a blade's edge. I try to hold us to the right path.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Companions?
output: Why would you even come to Jorrvaskr without knowing what we stand for? This is not play-acting, here. We are the true spirit of Skyrim. Honor is in our blood, death in our hearts. If you seek either, you've found the right place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Companions?
output: Are you looking to join? I wouldn't get your hopes up. The short answer is: we fight. The long answer is... eh, forget it. You're not worth my time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Companions?
output: Only the most famous warrior band in all of Skyrim. Have you been living with the horkers? When we arrive, blood is spilled and our blades sing to the glories of Ysgramor.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Companions?
output: We're the best damned fighters in Skyrim. At least, some of us are.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Companions?
output: They used to be something. Nowadays they just squabble amongst themselves. Take my advice and keep away. You look too smart to get caught up with this bunch.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Companions?
output: To hear Vignar tell it, they're a bunch of layabouts and useless whiners who used to know how to fight. But he thinks everything used to be better. I, for one, would trust any Companion with my life.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Companions?
output: A good bunch of men and women, who make too much a mess, if you ask me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does it mean to be a Companion?
output: It means living such that your Shield-Siblings would proudly say they fought at your side. Glory in battle, honor in life.  Deal with problems head on. Leave whispers and sneaking to the gutter rats who can't fight for themselves.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does it mean to be a Companion?
output: I wish more of our ranks asked such questions.  I've started seeing the Companions as a kind of family. I've battled next to every man and woman here, and the bonds of sweat are stronger than those of blood. I would trust anyone here with my life, which is more than I'd say for the milk drinkers who raised me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does it mean to be a Companion?
output: It means resting your haunches in Whiterun more than I'd care to, for one. But when it's time to draw blood, there's no one in Skyrim I'd rather have at my back. It means waking up every day knowing that you could die, and having to earn your life by clawing for every breath. I don't know how those cozy lords manage to drag themselves out of bed every day. Why bother if you're not living?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does it mean to be a Companion?
output: I've never been a smart one. But the Companions welcome anyone with the heart of a warrior. When we step into battle, we fight for our own name, and the name of the Companions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does it mean to be a Companion?
output: There's been a group called the Companions for over 4000 years. It's been many different things in that time. A conquering army. Ruthless mercenaries. A band of drunken louts. And the esteemed company you see before you.  But there's always been a kind of honor to it. We don't deal in politics or underhanded sneaking.  We try to uphold the legacy of Ysgramor. To bear his good name such that it never be forgotten, and always be spoken with reverence.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does it mean to be a Companion?
output: It means signing on for the Nord ideas of how to live your life. Honor, battle, glory, all that. "Even an elf can be born with the heart of a Nord," Skjor said when I joined. I think he meant it as a compliment.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does it mean to be a Companion?
output: Just because you've been accepted here so quickly, don't think I'm going to help you rise any faster. Fight well, don't be a lout, and you'll be fine. You don't need my help.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does it mean to be a Companion?
output: So much. This group... this family... this band... this is the best thing I've ever been a part of. The oldest fighting group in Skyrim, and nothing but glory from Ysgramor's day to our own. To be counted in that line is a bit of immortality. Even if I never see Sovngarde, I'll have that much.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does it mean to be a Companion?
output: It means when I have troubles, I always have someone on my side. We have Shield-Siblings to keep our backs as dangerous as our fronts. I think.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does it mean to be a Companion?
output: My advice? Don't overthink it. Fight well and the rest takes care of itself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's in charge around here?
output: Soon enough, it'll be me. In the meanwhile, the Circle handles our daily routine, and Kodlak advises them as Harbinger.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's in charge around here?
output: You don't just waddle in here and get to speak to the boss. Who do you think you are? If you want to embarrass yourself, I won't stop you. Kodlak is the Harbinger. He's the closest thing you'll find to a leader around here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's in charge around here?
output: The Circle are the ones who parcel out the jobs. That's Aela, Skjor, and the brothers, Farkas and Vilkas.  Kodlak advises them, but he doesn't really give orders.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's in charge around here?
output: In charge of what? I'm in charge of me, and you're in charge of you. If you're looking to join up, Kodlak's the one to be talking to.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do what now?
output: These spells are difficult, even for one as skilled as I. To even begin to inscribe them, I need something very special. A sigil stone from an Oblivion gate. I do not have one in my possession. Nor do you, I'm sure. So we require a Daedra to retrieve one for us. You will summon a Dremora, and order it to bring a sigil stone to you. I will then inscribe the spells for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I summoned you. I control you now.
output: You control nothing, mortal!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: Because I have no wish to be harmed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: If only that were true.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Great. How do I do that?
output: I will teach you the spell to summon the Dremora, but know that it will only work in a place properly prepared for the event. Once you have summoned the Dremora, you will order it to deliver to you a sigil stone from an Oblivion gate. Once I have the sigil stone, I shall inscribe the spells that you seek.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you in for?
output: A Nord nobleman I served was stabbed in the night. Wasn't me, but I knew I'd be blamed. So I ran. Joined the Forsworn. Started killing. Got caught. Now I'm here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: Because life was better under the old ways. No Nords and their laws.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need a shiv.
output: Ah, you want protection? I can get you what you need. Maybe you can do something for me, first? Duach has a bottle of Skooma. Finest distilled Moon Sugar. I'm shaking just thinking about it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

Anyone caught with Balmora Blue looks forward to rotting in jail for a very long time.

output: The Dragonborn is said to be uniquely gifted in the Voice - the ability to focus your vital essence into a Thu'um, or Shout. If you really are Dragonborn, they can teach you how to use your gift.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: Ulfric coveted the High King's throne. He thought he deserved it more than Torygg. Now it would seem Ulfric has his wish. And there truly is no justice in the world.

He told me once that he wanted me to grow up and be a sailor, 'cause that's where our family name comes from. But I don't want to be a sailor or a farmer. I want to be a warrior! The strongest one ever!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

Ulfric fought for that dream with more courage and honor than any Nord who ever lived. But now he's gone, and the dream is gone with him. But I'll be ready when a new leader takes up the cause. As sure as ice is cold and stone is hard, I'll be ready.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

It shapes worlds, creates and destroys life... It deserves proper respect and study. The College is a place where we can focus on that, without the pressures of the world weighing down on us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me more about the Great Collapse.
output: The Sea of Ghosts practically came alive. No one was expecting it. Monstrous waves battered the shore for weeks on end. Winterhold was ancient and weathered, but it couldn't withstand the sea's fury. Entire districts of the city were lost overnight. The waves receded in time, but the damage was irreversible. Most residents of Winterhold abandoned what was left of the city. The College survived, and so here we remain.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

It wasn't long before we lost what we depend on to survive... respect. By doin' these extra jobs and puttin' some fear into the people, we can take back the cities and start bein' taken seriously once again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

We had the best of everything down here... the Ratway was a damn palace. The only way this place will ever return to its glory days is if we can finish these extra jobs and start the gold flowing again.

I don't think she'd lead us down a suicidal path. Besides, I'd rather die with some of Mercer's blood on my blade than spend the rest of my life regretting that I ran the other way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

He took it right up to Enthir at the College of Winterhold. Didn't take long for Enthir to find a book in the college's library that told of Irkngthand and a great statue with gemmed eyes within.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: Wasn't by choice, I can tell you that. Options were in short supply. Ranmir and I grew up here, and nearly any money I make, he drinks away. Without the coin to pack up and leave, I decided to take to trading.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why set up shop here?
output: Wasn't by choice, I can tell you that. Options were in short supply. Ranmir and I grew up here, and his drinking soaked up whatever coin we had. So I opened a shop to try and get by. Now, though... Have to admit, I'm attached to the place. Suppose that makes me crazy, doesn't it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is it you do here in town?
output: Oh, well. You know. A bit of this, a bit of that. They haven't made me a guard, even though I've been asking. So I'll take odd jobs, anything that comes along for now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the story with the Pilgrim's Path?
output: Even though Nocturnal doesn't desire worship in the traditional sense, the Twilight Sepulcher propagated a small group of priests. Of course, they'd never come into direct contact with Nocturnal but they insisted they had her favor. As part of their "duties," the priests created all sorts of baseless rituals and ceremonies all on Nocturnal's behalf.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't understand why you won't come with me.
output: I've been a Nightingale for a very long time. I sold my allegiance to Nocturnal in exchange for many profitable years of thieving. Falling in love with Gallus was wrong. It was a distraction that allowed the Sepulcher to be desecrated and it likely cost him his life. Until the Key is returned, I will never set foot inside that place again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't understand why you won't come with me.
output: Right now, the Guild needs someone to maintain order. Everyone is awaiting the news of Mercer's demise; it couldn't be a more precarious time. I also need to reassure Maven that it's business as usual without Mercer... and that a new Guild Master will soon be taking over.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about the conduit inside the Sepulcher.
output: The conduit to Nocturnal's realm, the realm of Evergloam, has been in Skyrim... well, longer than recorded history. The Twilight Sepulcher was constructed around it by man and mer in order to shield it from those who would exploit its power. It's through this conduit that we're given Nocturnal's greatest gift, our luck. What she gains in return is a complete mystery.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: This didn't interfere with the Nightingales?
output: These priests weren't threat to the Skeleton Key or the conduit to Nocturnal's realm, so they were tolerated. One of their ceremonies involved the Pilgrim's Path, a so called "test of worthiness." If a pilgrim was able to complete the path, it was said that they would become one with the shadows. What that means is anyone's guess.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's so important about me being Dragonborn?
output: Haven't you been paying attention to anything I've said? Only you can finally defeat Alduin and avert the end of the world! If we can just find out what Shout the ancient Nords used, you may have a chance. Or not. There's no guarantee with prophecy. Merely hope.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where has Alduin gone?
output: Haven't you been listening to me? All the old tales agree that he has some means to travel to Sovngarde itself. There he devours the souls of the heroic dead to feed his power. You must find his portal to Sovngarde before he returns, stronger than ever.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where has Alduin gone?
output: The old tales say that he can travel into Sovngarde to devour the souls of the dead. You must find out how he does this, before he regains his strength and returns.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you assemble this collection?
output: My sister and I inherited a modest sum of money. We decided to travel and seek out whatever adventures we could find. As we journeyed across Tamriel, we encountered tales of exotic and wondrous artifacts. We decided to collect as many as we could. My sister passed away some years ago, so I settled down here and opened the House of Curiosities. I think she would be happy to know that our collection has brought smiles to faces both young and old.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have the Stormcloaks caused you any trouble?
output: No more than I was already getting. Four of the guards have already decided they're in love with me. Two of the guards got into a fight over me at the tavern. At least Balgruuf's men bathed regularly. These Stormcloaks always smell of ale and sweat, and their breath reeks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How's life under Stormcloak rule?
output: Well, the Stormcloak guards drink a lot more than the Imperials did, so I've been making more money lately. On the other hand, they're a violent bunch. Every night a fight breaks out and I end up with a smashed chair or a broken table. So, not much has changed, really.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The siege must have been hard on the city's merchants.
output: Oh no, not at all. I simply locked the doors, hid beneath my counter and prayed to the Divines that my life would be spared and my shop wouldn't burn to the ground. But other than that, everything was business as usual. Now, do you have any other painfully obvious things to say?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have things changed much with the Stormcloaks in charge?
output: Well, not a great deal, no. But I do less business than I used to. The Stormcloaks don't like buying from anyone that isn't a Nord. If I wasn't married to Ulfberth, I'd be out of business.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You guard the caravan?
output: Yes, I was hired to protect the others as we walk the roads of Skyrim. It is a thankless task and I would rather be back home in Elsweyr, but I have little choice. Ahkari freed me from a prison in Cyrodiil, and now I must repay my debt to him. A word of advice, my friend --  do not mix gambling and drink. Taken together, they will empty your pockets of every septim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Another time, maybe.
output: Very well. If you change your mind, you can usually find me here. In the meantime, feel free to look around.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What dangers does the caravan face?
output: Skyrim is filled with all manner of dangerous beasts. Wolves, trolls, mammoths and giants would all like to make a meal of us. But the dragons are the most fearsome. Lucky for us, they don't seem to hunt along the roads.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll take the tour. (2 gold)
output: Splendid! If you'll just follow me, I'll tell you tales and show you wonders such as you've never seen.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You mentioned a tour?
output: Indeed I did! For a few septims, I'll tell you about some of the most interesting curiosities in my collection.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And what about something for me, right now? (Persuade)
output: I don't think so. How do I know you won't continue to extort me? A wagon full of gold isn't good enough for you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And what about something for me, right now? (Persuade)
output: I don't think so. How do I know you won't continue to extort me? A wagon loaded with silver isn't good enough for you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's time for us to part ways.
output: I understand. We must all follow our own paths. If you wish to find me again, I'll be in Nightcaller Temple.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's time for us to part ways.
output: Farewell, then. If you need my services again, just come and look for me in the usual place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Follow me.
output: Good. We should keep moving.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need you to do something.
output: Name it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need you to do something.
output: All right. What is it? All right. What is it? All right. What is it? All right. What is it? All right. What is it? All right. What is it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: Running out of room, eh? I'll be glad to help.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: Do I get to keep it? Just kidding.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait here.
output: I'll stay here. You try not to get into too much trouble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait here.
output: All right. Don't take too long.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Young. I've always been known to get into trouble.
output: Then you know the hard looks as judgment gets set upon you. The sneers of people who never had to face sentence.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't need, or want, your help.
output: So many say that, at first, until they realize the truth. If you change your mind, speak to Braig. Tell him I sent you. I want you to know how widespread the injustice of Markarth is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Madanach asked me to hear your story.
output: My story, huh? Everyone in Cidhna Mine has a tale. Let's hear yours first. When was the first time you felt chains around your wrists?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You have a lot to answer for.
output: Do I? And what about you? What right did you have to meddle in my affairs? Kill my people? Was it worth it? Your truth?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I had questions about the Forsworn.
output: This was our land. We were here first. Then the Nords came and put chains on us. Forbid us from worshipping our gods. Some of us refused to bow. We knew the old ways would lead us back to having a kingdom of our own. That is who we are. The Forsworn. Criminals in our own lands. And we will cut a bloody hole into the Reach until we are free.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: None of your business.
output: Fine. Don't tell me. But I know that look in your eyes. Someone who's faced death at the hands of the law.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want to know about Thonar.
output: I had Markarth. My men and I drove the Nords out. We had won, or so we thought. Retribution was swift. I was captured, quickly tried, and sentenced to death. But my execution never came. Thonar Silver-Blood stopped it. He wanted the Forsworn at his call, that I would point their rage at his enemies and spare his allies. And I have. Humiliating at first, but I knew he would let his guard down eventually. That he would come to trust I was under control.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It was in Helgen. I was being sent to the executioner.
output: So you know what it's like to have your life in someone else's hands. Why should they get to decide? Isn't judgment for the gods?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Understand? How?
output: There's a man named Braig inside these mines. Besides me, he's been here the longest. Tell him I sent you. Ask him why he's here. I want you to know how widespread the injustice of Markarth is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's start with revenge!
output: Then come for me, "son of Skyrim." Come for me!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's start with revenge!
output: Then come for me, "daughter of Skyrim." Come for me!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's start with revenge!
output: Very well. Come for me, then. Come and let's end this!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any supplies I could take?
output: Of course. Take what you need. But what's this all about? What are you two doing here?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've never quite understood exactly what the Justiciars do.
output: The Thalmor Justiciars are so often misunderstood. Our primary goal is to preserve the peace between the Empire and the Aldmeri Dominion. The worship of the false god Talos contributed to the unfortunate friction that led to the Great War. Following the Great War, the White-Gold Concordat set out the terms for peaceful coexistence between the two powers. The Empire and the Dominion agreed that the worship of Talos was a relic of the past, and must be eliminated in the interests of peace. But I'm sure you didn't come here for a lecture on high politics.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does your position as Thalmor Ambassador involve?
output: One of my main duties is to foster a better understanding between the Aldmeri Dominion and the people of Skyrim. I also oversee the activities of the Thalmor Justiciars throughout Skyrim, although this has been unfortunately disrupted by the war.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, I have.
output: You will release me - ro laan - if in return I promise to take you to Skuldafn and stop helping Alduin?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's your position on the civil war?
output: As long as the Empire continues to uphold its treaty obligations, my government does not concern itself with the internal politics of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It doesn't matter.
output: Oh, fine. Keep your secrets. I see how it is. Oh, fine. Keep your secrets. I see how it is. Oh, fine. Keep your secrets. I see how it is. That wagon recently had a little accident. input: There's an enemy wagon loaded with coin and weapons. We need to capture it.
output: Really? It just so happens we've been tracking a wagon! For about a day now. Really? It just so happens we've been tracking a wagon! For about a day now. Really? instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait here.
output: Will do. Will do. Will do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Follow me.
output: Lead the way. Lead the way. Lead the way.
