instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I talked to Braig.
output: Imagine hearing a story like that, over and over. Each time a different family Each time a different injustice. Your meddling above ground reminded me of how removed I've been from the struggle. My men and I should be in the hills, fighting.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You'll help me escape then?
output: Yes, but I need a show of loyalty from you. I don't need a shiv in the back while we break out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Spare me from your speeches.
output: You know, I'm almost beginning to like you, but you haven't earned your place out of here yet.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm sorry to hear what happened to you.
output: My daughter is the one who needs your pity. I'm just a poor Forsworn whose only regret is not killing more Nords before I was locked up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Madanach says hello.
output: What? No. No don't kill me. Please!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Grisvar is dead.
output: You've finally become one of us. Come with me. I think it's time I announced my plans to you and your new brothers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You think your story justifies the murders the Forsworn have committed?
output: I'm not Madanach. I was never a leader of the Forsworn. The only anger I can justify is my own. But every family in the Reach has a story like mine. There are no innocent onlookers in this struggle. Just the guilty, and the dead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found this note on Ulag's body.
output: Did you? So Ulag didn't make it passed those giants then? More's the pity. If you found any of the sap, I'd be willing to pay you the same cut I offered him. Better price than you are likely to find otherwise.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have some Sleeping Tree Sap to sell.
output: Ah, of course! How much have you got?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was at Helgen.
output: Ahhh. Yes...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I can handle anything you throw at me.
output: That's what I like to hear. So long as you can back up those words with steel.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's why I'm here. I want to join.
output: All right. But before I can put you to use, I need to know how much you can take. I have a little test for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not sure about this.
output: When you kill that Ice Wraith, then we'll talk about you becoming a Stormcloak.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm going alone?
output: Not so sure of yourself after all?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm going alone?
output: At the end of the day, every warrior is alone. Before you can stand next to your shield brother, you need to be able to stand on your own.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I believe we've already met.
output: Is that so...? Ah yes, you were with us at Helgen.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's at Serpentstone Island?
output: It's where men have tested their mettle for ages. There's a strange rock formation, built by the ancients. Something about that place attracts the Ice Wraiths. You kill an Ice Wraith out there, and I'll have all the proof I need about you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm off to kill that Ice Wraith. I'll be back soon.
output: We'll see about that, won't we?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I helped Ralof escape. He said he'd vouch for me.
output: Ralof's alive? I hope that's true. He's a damn good man. But he hasn't returned yet, so I'll need to wait for his account. For now, speak with Galmar.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was set free. I could've gone anywhere. I came here to fight the Empire.
output: A fair point... Well, you've come to the right place, then. Speak with Galmar.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So, you only take Nords?
output: You mistake me. I'm not saying no - just wondering about your intentions. We're not looking for sellswords. The Stormcloaks need dedicated men and women who're devoted to the cause and willing to die for it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want to fight the Empire. I'll bleed for the chance to do so.
output: Can't fault anyone for that! As long as you hate the Empire as much as I do, that I can work with.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What kind of test?
output: The kind men use to measure themselves.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's expected of me here?
output: There are no expectations. This College is a place to study and practice magic freely. Hopefully any discoveries made in your pursuits will be shared with the members of the College first. That way we all benefit.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: They're a part of the darkness around us?
output: Absolutely. When we say "walk with the shadows," we are asking those Nightingales who have passed on to protect us. It's believed that they are literally what guides our uncanny luck... by placing their hands in ours. That's why the Ebonmere needed to be reopened. Without it, there's no way Nocturnal was able to allow them through.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How will I know if I'm needed here?
output: If this place is in danger ever again, the shadows will call. Should the need arise, a portal connects the Sepulcher and Nightingale Hall. Use it whenever you wish.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where did Gallus go?
output: Gallus's Oath has been paid. His actions have satisfied the terms. Now his spirit becomes one with the Evergloam... the realm of perpetual twilight and the cradle of shadow.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So, he's gone?
output: No, not gone... he's become one with the shadows. This is the greatest honor a Nightingale can possibly achieve. In death, he's become a part of that which we use to live.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where will you be from now on?
output: I've decided to make my home at Nightingale Hall. Since it's your home as well, I hope to see you and Brynjolf there. Of course, I may visit some of Skyrim's cities to "acquire" things from time to time. Can't afford to get rusty, now can we?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry to hear that.
output: We will endure. We always have.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Follow me.
output: J'zargo is ready for more adventure.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Follow me.
output: Of course. Let's go.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait here.
output: As you wish. Just don't forget about me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait here.
output: Here? Right here? Very well, J'zargo shall wait.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: If it will help you, then certainly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: J'zargo only has so much room to carry things.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's time for us to part ways.
output: You'll be all right on your own? Then I'll see you back at the College.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's time for us to part ways.
output: Really? J'zargo was having such fun. Ah, well. Back to the College then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's time for us to part ways.
output: Such a shame. I thought we were getting along so well. I'll head back to Riften if you should have second thoughts.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to think it over.
output: Don't take too long figuring it out. Might mistake your hesitation for Imperial sympathies. Come back when you're committed to the cause, or go join the Legion. They're taking anyone with a pulse these days.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You anticipate danger?
output: Aye. The Great Hunt killed old King Borgas. Gods only know with what profane arts those elves cursed his remains. Curses notwithstanding, the tombs of kings are always full of traps to ward off grave robbers, are they not? But nothing a band of Stormcloaks can't handle, I assure you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not sure about this.
output: When you kill that Ice Wraith, then we'll talk about you becoming a Stormcloak. Here. Take this. You'll need it. Use it on the island. Don't lose it. That's all the help you're getting. Try not to die.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready to take the Oath.
output: That's the spirit. By swearing this oath you become one of us. A hero of the people. A true son of Skyrim. A Stormcloak. Repeat after me. "I do swear my blood and honor to the service of Ulfric Stormcloak..."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready to take the Oath.
output: That's the spirit. By swearing this oath you become one of us. A heroine of the people. A true daughter of Skyrim. A Stormcloak. Repeat after me. "I do swear my blood and honor to the service of Ulfric Stormcloak..."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: "...even to my lord as to my fellow brothers and sisters in arms."
output: "All hail the Stormcloaks, the true sons and daughters of Skyrim!"

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do you know the crown is in Korvanjund?
output: It's true, the location of the crown was lost with King Borgas. After the Great Hunt killed him, while he was off on his damned Alessian campaigns. instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about the Gray-Manes.
output: We've got an old saying -- the Gray-Manes have lived in Whiterun since the first snows fell in Skyrim.  Well, maybe that's not entirely true, but our clan's got a long an' proud history in this hold. We respect the old ways, the Nord ways, an' a Gray-Mane has worked the Skyforge since before the time of my grandfather's father.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There's still the threat of a dragon attack.
output: And we've done as much as we can to prepare for that. But remember, Whiterun is home to the Companions. Any dragon that comes here will get more than he's bargained for, I think.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Will you restore the worship of Talos?
output: Aye, with a certainty. It was Talos that helped us win back the city. I'm as sure of that as the sun rising in the morning. Might even build a new temple and put Heimskr in charge of it. Hah! I bet he'd like that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are your top priorities as the new Jarl?
output: Well, first an' foremost there's repairs to make an' wounds to heal. Folks are depending on us getting the city back in working order. Once things settle down, I'll be lookin' to recruit more guards for the city, then shore up our stores of food an' water. The Empire might try an take the city back, or worse, we'll get a visit from a dragon. We've got to be ready for both.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You must have your hands full with the change in government.
output: Well, it could be worse. The former steward, Proventus, kept very detailed records. But yes, it's been a lot of work. Vignar doesn't want the change to disrupt the lives of his people. They've got enough to deal with already.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your clans used to be friends?
output: Aye, we used to be fast friends, though it was long ago. We were two of the city's oldest an' most-respected clans, an' we could trace our histories all the way back to Ysgramor's companions. But then Olfrid got rich an' decided he an his kin were too good for us simple, backwards Nord folk. When the troubles began, he took the Empire's side. We haven't spoken much since then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What about your rivals, the Battle-Borns?
output: Aye, they're an old clan like ours, but they cast their lot with the Empire when the uprising began. Olfrid Battle-Born made his money from farming, an' got himself some new friends among the Empire's nobles. Now he's in the Emperor's pocket like the rest of 'em, with no regard for honor an' tradition.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You've had trouble with thieves?
output: Are you kidding me? We're all alone out here except for a few guards who couldn't give a damn about us. We make easy pickings for thieves looking to steal everything we worked so hard for. Not only did I they take my bow, but they took all of our coin as well. Nothing's sacred to these people.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have 20 of those. (Give jazbay grapes)
output: My goodness, how did you ever come by all of these? No matter, I appreciate your generosity.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do you know the thieves were from Riften?
output: I bumped into them when I was coming back to my farm after buying supplies. I know those lowlifes took it with them back to the Ratway. They left an unmistakable stench behind. It was a family heirloom. I can't even put a price on how much that thing means to me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm sure. The Blades need new members.
output: Very well. She seems like a fighter to me. I'll give her the oath.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've brought you 20 jazbay grapes.
output: Fantastic. I was concerned I had asked for too many, but I'm glad to see you proved me wrong.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds terrible. Good luck with that.
output: I don't need luck, I need rest.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll try and find him.
output: Good. If you see him, tell him Grosta said he can go straight to Oblivion... he's not welcome here any more.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No need. It's right here.
output: That's it! That's my bow!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You seem quite exhausted.
output: Is it that obvious? Sigh. I've got my hands full here. Between the farm chores, cultivating my supply of nirnroot and keeping a tight rein on my sister Aduri, there's little time for rest.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry, I try and avoid thieves.
output: Fine. I'll wait until someone else with a little more courage comes along.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could help you if you like.
output: Really? That would be a pleasant change. One of the ingredients I need to cultivate nirnroot are jazbay grapes... the acidic content of the juice is perfect for the soil. I need twenty of them for my current crop.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did Leifnarr go to Broken Helm Hollow?
output: Well, he said that a few men have been going by to some of the local farms promising a good price from all the local mills and farms. Leifnarr said they'd pay double what you can usually get at the markets. The catch was, he had to head out there with our wood. So not only is Leifnarr gone, but a good bit of our supplies as well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll see what I can do.
output: Thanks. It would be nice to have it back... means a lot to me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Follow me.
output: Certainly, I'm ready.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't like to interfere in family affairs.
output: Doesn't matter. I'm sure he's long gone by now anyway.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is running a mill difficult?
output: With just myself and one child, it's damn near impossible. With Leifnarr gone, it's really put me in a terrible bind. I'm having trouble making ends meet. At this rate, we won't last more than a few more seasons at best. Then I'll just have to sell the old place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Actually, I discovered Leifnarr's body.
output: No, it can't be... oh my... and all this time, I was thinking he'd been unfaithful to me. I feel so stupid.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've brought a message from the Jarl of Whiterun.
output: Then I was wrong about him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You have a task for me?
output: You can return this axe to our friend. The esteemed Jarl of Windhelm has my answer. Make sure he gets it. You can return this axe to our friend. The esteemed Jarl of Windhelm has my answer. Make sure he gets it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Many will die by my hand.
output: Then I commit them to whatever gods they still believe in.  Talos be with you!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Orders, sir?
output: Make haste to our camp in Whiterun. I want you on the front lines.  I have a feeling about you. Your place is on that battlefield. I need you there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have an important message for you.
output: Did he now? The man is persistent, I'll give him that. Did he now? The man is persistent, I'll give him that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have an important message for you.
output: Ah yes. Ah yes. I suppose it's time I gave him an answer... I suppose it's time I gave him an answer...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, sir!
output: Fight well, or die well. Talos be with you!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ulfric plans to attack Whiterun. The General wants to lend Legion troops.
output: But until that dragon's dealt with, Ulfric's just going to have to wait. But until that dragon's dealt with, Ulfric's just going to have to wait. For now, I'll hold onto this axe. But it's a tenuous peace at best. For now, I'll hold onto this axe. But it's a tenuous peace at best.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ulfric plans to attack Whiterun. The General wants to lend Legion troops.
output: I suppose it's time I give him an answer... I suppose it's time I give him an answer...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a message for you from Brynjolf.
output: I'll already told that buffoon I'm not paying you people a single coin!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're not well? What's wrong?
output: I had a bad fall in the mine when I was bringing some food to the men. I was pretty bad off for a while, but a priest of Mara was passing through on his way to Dawnstar and healed me to the best of his abilities. I'm still pretty sore and can't really walk too far without having to rest for a while.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, I'm not really headed that way.
output: Yes, indeed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sure, I'll deliver it.
output: You would? Well then, I would insist on rewarding you for your time. Here, take my satchel and give it to my father, Verner. He'll likely have something for you to bring back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's wrong with the mine?
output: It's full of spiders, that's what's wrong with it! Almost killed Grogmar and me when they showed up. I'm worried that they'll come out of the mine looking for food soon... then we're in even bigger trouble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a package for you from Sylgja.
output: It's a shame our daughter couldn't make the journey herself, but at least she still thinks of us. If you wouldn't mind bringing this back to her for us, I'd appreciate it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's been sending you to Darkwater Crossing?
output: My parents live there. I usually make the journey to bring them gifts and to just say hello, but I haven't been well lately. I've written some letters and placed them in a satchel. Perhaps you wouldn't mind delivering it to them on my behalf?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The town guards can't help you?
output: They're as useless as a fifth wheel on a wagon. Gave me some sort of a line about "keeping an eye out for enemy soldiers." What's the point in protecting this place if the mine's completely useless? Idiots.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've already cleared Redbelly Mine.
output: Wait... you mean you killed every last one of them? I can't believe it!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm going to pass on that.
output: I never asked you to help in the first place. Why would I? Everyone in Skyrim only helps themselves.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm back from Darkwater Crossing.
output: Ah, yes... seems he sent back my satchel stuffed with letters. I look forward  to reading them. I appreciate the delivery, here... I want you to have this. I insist.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll clear them out for you.
output: Tell you what. Keep to your word, and I'll line your pockets with as much as I can scrape up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about the mine.
output: Redbelly Mine gets its name from the red mist filling the place. You get used to it after a while... kind of smells like the hot springs out in the tundra. No idea what's causing it though.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about the mine.
output: Mining iron takes a lot of strength and special reinforced tools. I must have broken five or six pickaxes in the last few months alone. But now that I've got Rocksplinter here, I can cut through stone like a hot knife through butter.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about the mine.
output: I might be a woman, but I can crack rock with the best of them. Be careful in there, you can take a nasty spill.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about the mine.
output: Damn place is filled with this reddish mist. Can't see more than ten feet in front of your face. But when you can sniff out a vein of iron like me, it isn't too much trouble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have Kodlak's fragment.
output: Thank you. Your Shield-Siblings have withdrawn to the Underforge. I think they're waiting for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I guess I'll have to.
output: I appreciate it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Would this loosen your tongue? (<bribecost> gold)
output: Ah, I think that'll do just the trick.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Would this loosen your tongue? (<bribecost> gold)
output: You'll need a little more coin than what you're floatin' around with.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It would be my pleasure.
output: Thank you. I'll be here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've inscribed the lexicon.
output: Give it, quickly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have inscribed the lexicon.
output: Oh, but the Dwemer had more than even Septimus expected. This will take time to decryptify. Be on your way, and Septimus will find  you if he has further need.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do I do with this cube?
output: To glimpse the world inside an Elder Scroll can damage the eyes. Or the mind, as it has to Septimus. The Dwemer found a loophole, as they always do. To focus the knowledge away and inside without harm. Place the lexicon into their contraption and focus the knowings into it. When it brims with glow, bring it back and Septimus can read once more.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do I do with this sphere?
output: The deepest doors of Dwemer listen for singing. It plays the attitude of notes proper for opening. Can you not hear it? Too low for hearings?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want?
output: You see this masterwork of the Dwemer. Deep inside their greatest knowings. Septimus is clever among men, but he is but an idiot child compared to the dullest of the Dwemer.  Lucky then they left behind their own way of reading the Elder Scrolls. In the depths of Blackreach one yet lies. Have you heard of Blackreach? "Cast upon where Dwemer cities slept, the yearning spire hidden learnings kept."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't make me hurt you. Just tell me where it is.
output: Oh, a brutish one. Septimus has no fear of you. But as one block raises another, perhaps ourselves could help us each.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can you help me get the Elder Scroll or not?
output: One block lifts the other. Septimus will give what you want, but you must bring him something in return.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: MS12SharedInfo
output: Now, how would you like me to align the Phial's properties?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: MS12SharedInfo
output: I'm not as skilled as Curalmil, so I'm afraid it will only ever refill with one type of liquid.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: MS12SharedInfo
output: It's just one of those things that happens. The lungs just... give up. Even elves get old.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: MS12SharedInfo
output: What's it matter to you? Not like you could do anything about it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found it in Blackreach.
output: Blackreach... why does that sound so familiar? Of course! It's where my mentor, Sinderion said he was going to do his field research. It's been... years I think, but perhaps you could still find him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did Sinderion teach you how to grow nirnroot?
output: Yes. He was an absolute genius when it came to the nirnroot. Sinderion made it his life's work, developing all sorts of interesting concoctions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you familiar with this Crimson Nirnroot?
output: Crimson Nirnroot? I'd heard such a strain existed, but never imagined I'd see any in my lifetime. Where did you find this?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you an alchemist?
output: I used to be. There isn't much time for that in my life anymore I'm afraid. I actually owned a shop in Vivec City long ago, but I had to leave all that behind when the Red Mountain erupted. Perhaps someday I'll reopen a shop here in Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've found Sinderion's remains.
output: I knew this day would eventually come. At least poor Sinderion died doing what he loved, his field research. I told the old fool he should take it easy, but he was too stubborn. Perhaps someday I'll continue where he left off, it's the least I can do considering how much he did for me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then he left for Blackreach I suppose.
output: One day he simply ran out to me in the field, excited that he'd made some sort of a breakthrough and he was going to head out on another trip. He never returned. From the journal you discovered, I'm sure you know the rest.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did he end up in Skyrim?
output: Well, after I fled Morrowind during the eruption, I made my way here... my family had purchased this farm and its all we had left. Years later, Sinderion simply showed up at our doorstep asking to stay for a while... said he was going to do field research. He stayed with us for decades... became an uncle of sorts to Aduri.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here you are.
output: Thank you. You've done alchemy a great service by helping to complete Sinderion's work. I'd like to give you this tome...it's one of Sinderion's greatest works. I believe you've more than earned it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you and Sinderion meet?
output: When I was very young, I was sent to Skingrad in Cyrodiil to study with him. He was a strange Altmer... paid more attention to his research than his own well-being. He lived in the basement of an inn for goodness sakes!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've brought this Crimson Nirnroot for you.
output: You've gathered quite a few of them I see. I'll search through Sinderion's notes and find some more information about the Crimson Nirnroot and its properties.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I just want to know how to defeat Alduin.
output: Ah. Of course. Not everyone has an appreciation for the artistic wonders of the world.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: She needed help with some wolves?
output: Well, there were eight of them and she'd already killed three by the time I joined the fight. Together, we made short work of them and the last one limped away licking its wounds.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you end up in Skyrim?
output: Well, after a while my father caught on to what I was doing. He confronted me one night and gave me a choice. Either leave Valenwood, or he'd have me thrown into jail. Gave me a day to say my goodbyes to everyone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why didn't you stay with the Tong?
output: I didn't have a choice. When the Red Mountain erupted in Morrowind, the Tong fled... spread to the nine winds. We made a pact that one day, we might reunite... but I believe that day is long in coming.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: With skills like yours? Why not?
output: I didn't mean to imply I was earning an honest living either. With my lock picking aptitude, I was a natural at jailbreaking... made a great deal of gold doing it too.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So how did someone like you join the Guild?
output: It's kind of an amusing tale. I was making my way down the road from Ivarstead towards Riften, and I saw Vex fighting off a couple of wolves.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Like being a thief.
output: I hooked up with a guild in Valenwood... I think they called themselves the Silver Crescents. Spent quite a few years doing jobs for them. Made a lot of coin, but I didn't care. I didn't really need it... I was running with them because it fit, made me feel alive.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You'd never had to do that before?
output: No, we usually let them go. I refused to do it, and Garthek ordered the clan to kill me as well. Luckily, I had made some friends with the clan who immediately sided with me. We tore each other to pieces. After it was over, those of us that remained simply went our separate ways.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you become so good at picking locks?
output: Pull up a chair, my friend... this is quite a tale. When I started out in this business, I wasn't really interested in the Guild or being a thief.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll keep an eye out for anything.
output: I appreciate that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why would you leave all that behind?
output: Because it was dull. Every day was the same boring routine; working at the winery, social visits with friends, parties with no one I cared about. I just wanted a little excitement. Something dangerous.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What changed?
output: We raided a caravan one spring... I think it was a few wagons with some farmers moving to a new village. They didn't put up much of a fight. All that was left were the women and the children. Then the leader of our clan... Garthek... he ordered us to kill the rest.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Was it anything like the Dark Brotherhood?
output: No. In fact, the Tong were quite the bitter rivals with the Dark Brotherhood. Where they operate within the shadows, we operated on the side of justice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You still never told me your real name.
output: Maybe one day, just not today.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you end up at the Guild?
output: I used to live in Valenwood working at my father's winery... we made the finest wine to ever cross your lips I promise you. We were doing well, plenty of coin, a huge mansion and I was even betrothed to a lovely young woman.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Morang Tong?
output: We were an assassins guild that was sanctioned by the Empire to provide public as well as private executions. We did this in the name of Mephala, whom I used to quite fervently worship.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you escape?
output: Over time, I managed to gain their confidence. Then one night I grabbed a knife, waited until they fell asleep and cut their throats. I never returned to that pig farm you know. There's nothing for me there. So that's my sad story. What do you think?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So who gave you the name?
output: Actually, the fisherman who found me, the man I call my father gave it to me. Thought it was fitting I suppose. I never changed it, because it never felt right to do so.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why were they laughing?
output: Well, I had forgotten we had our horses tied up just outside of Windhelm... Vex rode hers back and arrived hours before I did. So, that's how I earned the name. Now keep it to yourself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: But not for you?
output: Don't get me wrong. The first few years with that clan were some of the best years of my life. All the food I could eat, all the wine I could drink and all the women I could bed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You don't have to continue.
output: It's fine... I had to tell someone I suppose. Carrying around a weight like that... it hurts after a while. Cuts you inside like a dagger to the heart.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's an incredible distance to run.
output: Vex was waiting for me at the Flagon when I came in... drenched in sweat. Everyone just took a look at me and laughed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So you were part of a bandit clan?
output: I joined up with them maybe ten years ago. Small clan... maybe twenty men. We'd raid villages, rob caravans... but it was always about the killing for them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So, where do you hail from?
output: Morrowind of course. Any Dunmer worth their weight in ash would tell you the same. I used to be a member of the Morang Tong.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds horrible.
output: Oh, wait... it gets much better. How about the fact that our farm was attacked by bandits, and that they killed my entire family who didn't even brandish a weapon against them. Here's the best part. They took me as a prize, and violated me for a fortnight. Tossed me from bandit to bandit like... like...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe you aren't meant to know.
output: Perhaps. They could be nonsense... inane scribbles done by someone in idle boredom. But if not... if they actually mean something, they might tell me where I'm from... what ship was I on. Everything.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did either of you get caught?
output: Are you kidding me? Vex lost them in seconds... once she steps into the shadows, she vanishes. Me? I ran... and I ran... straight through the gates of Windhelm and all the way back to Riften.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you join the Guild and not the Brotherhood?
output: I don't know. I think I realized that out in the world, my skills would bring me more wealth as a thief rather than an assassin. Killing someone in a jail is much easier than what the Dark Brotherhood deals with. I guess I wanted to play it safe. I already knew Delvin, I asked if I could join up, and that was that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That was big of you to accept.
output: Something told me I wouldn't regret it. I had heard the Guild was back on its feet again and most of Skyrim under its belt. I'll tell you, I wouldn't want to cross blades with Vex again, but I certainly wouldn't mind a bit of a scuffle...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Something had to make you this angry.
output: Look, you want to know about me? All right, I'll tell you. I'll tell you about the time I was a young girl, barely out of her teens... living on a pig farm in the middle of nowhere. Didn't have a coin to spend between our entire family. Ate the same slop we fed our livestock.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know what they mean?
output: No one does. I've even taken the damn thing to the College of Winterhold. I must have spent every last coin I've made with the Guild trying to find out what it means.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds normal to me.
output: Well it was, up until the point where we set foot outside. The house was surrounded by town guard... the client had ratted us out. Vex just tells me to run, so I did. Half of them went after me, the other half went after her.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think I see what you're getting at.
output: The last jailbreak I attempted failed. I was imprisoned in High Rock for three years before they let me go. After that I promised myself I'd never do it again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: A stalemate?
output: Indeed. After a few minutes, she looked me dead in the eye and asked me if I wanted to join the Guild. Just like that, no apologies.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So, will you tell me your real name?
output: Look, I don't really know you. I don't even really know anyone here. Why do you care anyway? It's not like we're family. This is a business.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you get your unusual name?
output: My father told me he found me as a young boy in the wreckage of a ship that sank off of the coast near Solitude. All he found in my pocket was a tiny smooth stone inscribed with some sort of strange runes.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So how did you earn your name?
output: It was on a job a few years back... it was supposed to be a simple burglary on a house in Windhelm. I was working with Vex and we got inside with no trouble. We found the loot, and made our way out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Well, your secret is safe with me.
output: I should hope so. The Dark Brotherhood is also known to place contracts on those who associate with the Morang Tong as well. So, unless you wish a visit from one of their own, I'd suggest you follow your own advice and keep your mouth shut.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you stop doing it?
output: Well, as a jailbreaker, you work alone. No Guild to back you up. I'd do jobs for the Thieves Guild and the Dark Brotherhood, but if things didn't go as planned, I was on my own.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is that when she asked you to join?
output: Actually, that's when she politely asked me to hand over my coin purse. Can you imagine? We scuffled for a while, broke each other's weapons, and finally fell to the ground exhausted.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That must have been difficult.
output: I ended up in Skyrim thanks to a contact I'd made when I was with the Crescents... good old Delvin. He introduced me to Gallus, and that was it. I've been here ever since. And you know what? Despite what I left behind, I don't regret it one bit.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And Garthek?
output: I left his head on a pike at the wreckage of the caravan. Never knew what became of the rest of the clan that survived. I suppose they moved on just like I did.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Perhaps you should have joined the Dark Brotherhood.
output: Have you taken leave of your senses? If the Dark Brotherhood discovered I had been a Morang Tong, they would come after me with a vengeance. Better to stay out of sight and ply my trade with the Thieves Guild than risk a contract on my head.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Jailbreaking? What's that?
output: It's where a client pays you to get arrested, and you get thrown into a prison for the express purpose of breaking out. Usually it's to free someone the client cares about... and sometimes to... well, to kill someone on their behalf. Either way, the trick was in the escape, and that's where my strengths came in handy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a message from Brynjolf.
output: What does he want now? I already explained to him that you can't get blood from a stone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a message from Brynjolf.
output: Wha... what? Oh, it's one of you people. So, Brynjolf doesn't even bother to show up himself anymore, eh? What's this message?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So the guard at the North Gate was your man?
output: Aye, that he was. And you sniffed him out because he broke one of the cardinal rules of our business... he got greedy. He was told to run the scam on merchants, but he smelled the gold on you and his judgment went out the window.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: This is obviously a shakedown, but I'll pay. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: It's been a pleasure doing business with you. Let me open the gate and you can head into the city.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Forget it. I'll come back.
output: Don't want in, huh? Fine. Have a good walk to the next city.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the tax for?
output: For the privilege of entering the city. What does it matter?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: This is obviously a shakedown. (Persuade)
output: All right, keep your voice down... you want everyone to hear you? I'll let you in, just let me unlock the gate. All right, keep your voice down... you want everyone to hear you? I'll let you in, just let me unlock the gate.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you mean?
output: Look how you sniffed out my little scheme at the North Gate. You knew it was a shakedown and you called him on it. That's what I'm talking about.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Just passing through.
output: Stay clear of that College, if you know what's good for you. Nothing but foul deeds behind those walls.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does it matter?
output: It does. The College has caused enough problems; don't need you or anyone else adding to them. If you're not here for the College, then you've little other reason to be in Winterhold at all.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm here for the College.
output: Should've known. Not that it matters anymore. No one bothers coming to Winterhold for any other reason.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's wrong with the College?
output: Look around you. Winterhold is in this state because of those damned mages. They sit up there in their tower, doing gods-know-what, and who watches over them? The guards don't even dare go up there unless they've no choice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's wrong with the College?
output: I do, and if you count yourself among their numbers then you've blood on your hands as well. There's nothing left of Winterhold. Nothing! Everyone knows it's the College's fault that the sea swallowed our city. Still they deny it, but we all know the truth.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe some gold will help? (<BribeCost> gold)
output: Well, if you insist... Well, if you insist... Well, if you insist... Well, if you insist... Well, if you insist... Well, if you insist... Well, if you insist... Well, if you insist... Well, if you insist... Well, if you insist...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Find any dragons to hunt?
output: I have. One of the old Akaviri records names a dragon living nearby. Shall we send the Blades to help you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not ready yet.
output: Let me know when you are, then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The dragon of <Alias=DragonLair> is dead.
output: It's good to see the Blades fighting alongside the Dragonborn once again. To think we're treading in the footsteps of thousands of years past. While you're out hunting, keep a sharp eye open for any dragon scales and bones you might find. I'd be interested in looking at them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell them to meet me there.
output: Good luck, Dragonborn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm sure. The Blades need new members.
output: Very well. He seems like a fighter to me. I'll give him the oath.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Delphine mentioned you're studying dragon lairs.
output: I am. The Blades of the 2nd Era hunted down many dragons in their day, and they have records of where the beasts lived. Only you can truly defeat these monsters, Dragonborn, but you do not have to do so alone. The Blades can help you. Just ask whenever you're ready to take on a dragon. We will send the Blades to help you fulfill your destiny.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Delphine mentioned you're studying dragon lairs.
output: It's quiet for now, Dragonborn. Perhaps later we'll find where one of those serpents is hiding.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I brought someone to induct into the Blades.
output: You want this one to become a Blade? You're sure?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes sir.
output: For the Emperor!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes sir.
output: Gods be with you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes sir.
output: Go with the gods.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes sir.
output: For Skyrim!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any advice for fighting dragons?
output: You're in luck. There is a blessing the Blades used on the eve of battle. It's supposed to prepare the mind for slaying dragons. I doubt the blessing's effects last for very long, so ask whenever you're heading out, and I'll perform the proper rites.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's a dragon scale and a bone.
output: Have you ever heard of the expression, "the scale of the Argonian that bit you?" No, I guess not. Well, the principle applies here. It's a potion, made from those dragon parts. Give it a try.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The dragon of <Alias=DragonLair> is dead.
output: Good. The dragon's soul should be making you stronger. Come back another time, and we'll track down another one for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need that dragon slaying blessing.
output: "May the scales of the dragonkind splinter at the touch of your arrows and crack under the weight of your sword." That's all there is to it, Dragonborn. Good luck.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll get it for you.
output: Thank you, friend. Don't worry. I'll have that shiv ready for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: CWSharedInfoStack
output: My father was a Legionnaire, and his before him. I guess I never considered doing anything else. My father was a Legionnaire, and his before him. I guess I never considered doing anything else. My father was a Legionnaire, and his before him. I guess I never considered doing anything else. My father was a Legionnaire, and his before him. I guess I never considered doing anything else. My father was a Legionnaire, and his before him. I guess I never considered doing anything else.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: CWSharedInfoStack
output: My cousin disappeared one night. Some say the Thalmor grabbed him. It wasn't long before I found myself under Ulfric's banner. My cousin disappeared one night. Some say the Thalmor grabbed him. It wasn't long before I found myself under Ulfric's banner.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: CWSharedInfoStack
output: I don't want some snotty elf telling me what gods I can and can't worship.  I don't want some snotty elf telling me what gods I can and can't worship.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: CWSharedInfoStack
output: I'm a true Nord. Simple as that. I'm a true Nord. Simple as that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's next?
output: Get over to our camp in Hjaalmarch. We need to strengthen our defensive position. I trust you've come to see the error handing the hold over to the rebels?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's next?
output: Make your way to our camp in Falkreath. We're going to take it back. And don't think I've forgotten that you were the one that gave it to Ulfric in the first place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's next?
output: Hurry over to our military camp tucked away in the Reach. Ulfric's been enjoying those silver mines for far too long. And, soldier. You better help win me back Markarth, or die trying. It was your brilliant strategy to give it over to the rebels in the first place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's next?
output: Get over to our camp in the Pale. It's time we bring them back into the fold. And don't think for a moment I've forgotten it was you that lost us the hold in the first place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's next?
output: Get up to Winterhold. We're going to take it back. I know you thought we weren't losing much when you gave it to the enemy. But I'm wasting troops guarding the border that belong on the front lines.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's next?
output: Make your way to our hidden camp in the Rift. I can't continue to push forward when I'm worried about Eastmarch's southern border. I hold you responsible for this situation. So, you better win me back Riften, or die trying.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you worship Talos?
output: No but my husband Torygg would want a proper burial and this is the way Nords are buried in Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe later.
output: Come back to me if you change your mind.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm sorry, I can't right now.
output: That's all right. Return to me if you change your mind though.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I can do that.
output: Wonderful. Just speak to various bards outside of the college, get there parts of the Poetic Edda and return them here to me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I would be honored to help.
output: Thank you. It would mean a lot to me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is the Edda complete now that you have King Olaf's Verse?
output: The Poetic Edda is never truly complete. As a living history of Skyrim we Bards continually add parts to it. In fact, If you collected parts of the Edda from any Bard you encountered in your travels I would be willing to pay you for them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do for you, Jarl?
output: Falk told me what you did for us at Wolfskull cave. He says you're someone we can trust. As you may know Talos worship is outlawed in the Empire. When we buried my husband I made offerings to all the gods... except Talos. I would like you to take an item of his, a warhorn handed down from his father, and place it at a Shrine of Talos.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do for you, Jarl?
output: Yes, when we buried my husband I wasn't able to make an offering to Talos. I was hoping you would to take something of his, a warhorn handed down from his father, and place it at a Shrine of Talos.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've collected some of the Edda for you.
output: Wonderful. Soon we'll have the latest section of the Edda complete. Keep up the good work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've collected some of the Edda for you.
output: That's it! You've collected every last verse. I can't thank you enough. This deserves a special bonus.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Giving away your spiced wine, eh?
output: Just one bottle per customer. Except for the man who saved the festival. Here's a couple bottles for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've placed the horn at the shrine.
output: Falk said I could count on you. You have more than earned the right to purchase property and take the next step to becoming a Thane. Speak to Falk when you have the funds. And thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did you say free meat pies?
output: I said "a free meat pie". As in one. Here's yours.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So what's the story behind the Rueful Axe.
output: One of Clavicus's little jests. A wizard named Sebastian Lort had a daughter who worshiped Hircine. When the daughter became a werewolf it drove Sebastian over the edge. He couldn't stand to see his little girl take on such a bestial form. The wizard wished for the ability to end his daughter's curse. Clavicus gave him an axe.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's get this over with.
output: As you desire.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found King Olaf's Verse.
output: Ah wonderful, I knew it would be. This is a significant find. I'll let Viarmo take possession but I will be looking forward to adding this to our library. Good work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found King Olaf's Verse.
output: I knew it was at the Dead Man's Respite.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think I want to keep the axe.
output: The axe isn't the only item dear old Clavicus has. Give him the Rueful Axe and once we're reunited the Masque of Clavicus Vile will be yours.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you located any Words of Power?
output: We have felt the whisper of a Word. Give me your map, and I will show you where its echo can be found.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to learn more about the Voice.
output: You have learned so much already, Dragonborn. Growing your gift too quickly would be dangerous. But there are many Words of Power in Skyrim, carved in the Dragon tongue. Even from here, we can feel the Thu'um resonate from them. Finding these lost Words would be a sufficient test, to temper your abilities with experience. Ask when you are ready to search.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to learn more about the Voice.
output: There is only silence right now. Perhaps later we will hear one of the lost Words.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Olaf sacked it in dragon form! (Persuade)
output: No, that's pushing it too far. Very exciting but highly unlikely, I can't possibly write that in.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know "The Age of Oppression"?
output: Only true Imperials request that one. Only true Imperials request that one. Only true Imperials request that one. Only true Imperials request that one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have a verse for the Poetic Edda?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Olaf was Numinex. A dragon in human form! (Persuade)
output: I find that highly unlikely... I think it would be irresponsible to write that in to the verse.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready to take the oath.
output: Deliver your report to Legate Rikke.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're with the College?
output: No. Gods no, not for years. I left Winterhold for some time, and returned to stay here at the inn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're with the College?
output: I still have research that keeps me busy, and being here in Winterhold ensures I have access to former colleagues.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've defeated the guardians.
output: Maybe you're not so soft, after all. Now you're ready for a real challenge. I'll anoint you with the symbol of the Bear, the Sabrecat and the Mammoth. Tread carefully, these are mighty beasts.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've defeated the guardians.
output: The guardian spirits of Bear, Mammoth and Sabre Cat await you. Return when they are defeated.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've defeated the guardian spirits.
output: You do Kyne proud. Only one challenge remains. Go and defeat the troll champion.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're the Master of the Greybeards. Do others come here to train?
output: I have taught the Way of the Voice for centuries and the Thu'um since long before that. But no, Dovahkiin. Others do not come here to train anymore. Saraan. You are the first in over a hundred years. I meditate on the Rotmulaag - the Words of Power. I counsel in their use. It is enough for me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Feim.
output: "Fade" in your tongue. Mortals have greater affinity for this Word than the dov. Everything mortal fades away in time, but the spirit remains. Ponder the meaning of spirit. Unslaad zii. Where mortal flesh may wither and die, the spirit endures. That is "Feim." Let that meaning fill you. Su'um ahrk morah. You will find that your spirit will give you more strength.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yol.
output: In your tongue, the Word simply means "Fire." It is change given form. Power at its most primal. That is the true meaning of "Yol." Suleyk. Power. You have it, as do all dov. But power is inert without action and choice. Think of this as the fire builds in your su'um, in your breath. Su'um ahrk morah. What will you burn? What will you spare?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Fus.
output: It is called "Force" in your tongue. But as you push the world, so does the world push back. Think of the way force may be applied effortlessly. Imagine but a whisper pushing aside all in its path. That is "Fus." Let its meaning fill you. Su'um ahrk morah. You will push the world harder than it pushes back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You meditate on the Words? How?
output: Knowing a Word of Power is to take its meaning into yourself.  Contemplate the meaning of a Rotmulaag. You will become closer to that Word, as it fills your inner self. Will I teach you, Dovahkiin? What Word calls you to deeper understanding? There are three to master: Fus, Feim, and Yol.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I wish to meditate on a Word of Power.
output: Which calls to you, Dovahkiin? Fus, Feim, or Yol?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why were you searching in Skyrim?
output: I learned that a matron who had served for House Telvanni had escaped Morrowind during the Accession War. Records showed her buying passage aboard a sailing vessel named "The Pride of Tel Vos," but that's where the trail ran cold. I spent years looking for what became of the ship, but I ended up empty-handed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any idea where I can find some ice wraiths?
output: Well, I'd be careful if I were you. I hear the Nords hunt them for some kind of initiation rite and not all of them end up victorious. The last traveler that traded me some said he found them at a place called Ancient's Ascent. Careful though, rumor has it a dragon makes its home there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Not really interested.
output: Oh! Well if you change your mind, come back and see me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do you keep this food so fresh?
output: I picked up a trick from a butcher in Elinhir, a small town over the border in Hammerfell. He showed me a way to grind up ice wraith teeth and use it as a preservative. Keeps everything cold and fresh, but only for a limited time. I'm always looking to replenish my supply, so if you ever come across five of them, I'd be more than happy to take them off your hands.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: Anything you can find would be of great help. Good luck.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: I really appreciate what you've done for me. I'll never forget it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: Keep your eyes to the road.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: Thanks again for the ice wraith teeth.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: Be careful looking for those teeth... those little bastards are dangerous.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: Keep your belly full and your shoulders strong.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: Come back when you're ready to spend more gold... goodness knows I could use it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: Safe travels, landstrider.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Goodbye.
output: Good journey, marsh-friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any clues about your past?
output: Just one. I know when I was found by my Argonian father, I was wrapped in a blanket bearing the symbol of House Telvanni. It was one of the great houses in Morrowind long ago. Whether that means I was one of them or not, I'm uncertain. If you come across anything in your travels that might provide me with the answers I'm looking for, I'd be grateful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Okay, I'll find some.
output: Thanks, I was actually worried I'd run out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll keep an eye open.
output: Thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does it mean to be a Companion?
output: To me, it means not having to answer foolish questions a second time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Just checking on our take. How are we doing?
output: It's as if the merchandise and coin are simply falling from the sky. Vex and Delvin are having to turn clients away at this point, it's almost impossible to keep up. Don't forget to check your tribute chest once in a while. As Guild Master you're getting a significant cut of the spoils.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How's the Guild doing?
output: Take a good look around you! Have you ever see the Guild in such a prosperous state? With Mercer Frey gone and our influence present in all of Skyrim's cities, the Guild's accumulating wealth faster than we can spend it. I couldn't be more proud to be a part of the Thieves Guild, or its new Guild Master.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How's the Guild doing?
output: Take a good look around you! Have you ever see the Guild in such a prosperous state? With Mercer Frey gone and our influence spreading across Skyrim, the Guild's earned a new level of respect it hasn't seen in decades. I couldn't be more proud to be a part of the Thieves Guild, or its new Guild Master.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: About the secrecy of the Nightingales...
output: I think by now, most within the Guild are well aware of what transpired between Mercer Frey and ourselves. The notion that the Nightingales are a fictive group has long since passed. If you wish to wear your Nightingale Armor within the Guild, I'm certain that no one would give it a second thought.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How have things been now that Mercer's gone?
output: I'm feeling a sense of inner peace... something I haven't felt in a very long time. Instead of being clouded with thoughts of revenge and retribution, I feel only serenity and fulfillment. Of course, I've been also dabbling in my old pastimes as well. Take a look around, and feel free to share the fruits of my labor.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I haven't met her, but I could try to get more information.
output: Oh that's very sweet of you. Anything you can find out from Captain Aldis would be welcome news.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, sorry. I haven't been to Whiterun before.
output: Ah well, it was a long shot.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: If you were dead, I could keep the horse... (Intimidate)
output: Now wait a minute... No need to do anything drastic. Look, Keep the horse, all right? Then we all walk away happy...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: If you were dead, I could keep the horse... (Intimidate)
output: Well ain't that the truth of it. All right, then. Let's see what you've got!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Actually, yes.
output: Wonderful. I hadn't really hoped to run in to someone who had been there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm sorry, I've never met her before.
output: Ah, well I guess it was unlikely. I'm sorry to waste your time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm going to Maven unless I leave here with Frost. (Persuade)
output: You're playing a dangerous game, my friend. Fine, you win. Take the horse and leave.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm going to Maven unless I leave here with Frost. (Persuade)
output: And telling her what? That you stole her horse? I don't think so.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: Of course. That's your choice. I just wanted to let you know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Thanks for the warning.
output: You're welcome.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there a problem?
output: No, no. Well, I don't think so.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does it matter what I say to him?
output: Between the two of us, there are rumors about him. That this "advisor" position he has is a sham, an excuse. That what he's really doing is spying for the Thalmor, trying to feed them information. Whether it's true, I can't say. But it never hurts to be a little suspicious, does it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, we did. I just informed the Arch-Mage.
output: I am well aware. Tolfdir is still in Saarthal, is he? I shall be expecting a full report from him when he returns.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Ancano?
output: I know I don't like the way he looks at me. I can't tell if he expects me to blow myself up, or to try and murder him. But he clearly doesn't trust any of us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Ancano?
output: I know he's from the Thalmor, and that he claims to be here simply as an advisor. I also know that no one really believes that. I've been trying to avoid him, honestly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe...
output: I know full well that you have. Please do not insult my intelligence. Tolfdir is still there now, is he? I shall expect a full report when he returns.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There's a rumor that you're spying for the Thalmor.
output: What? Preposterous, and just the sort of thing I would expect from mages who have nothing better to do with their time. I have made it quite clear that my only role here is as an advisor to the Arch-Mage. I would suggest that you not further spread this rumor.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Ancano?
output: Don't trust that one. He's up to something. Most here are up to something, of course, but in his case, it's not good. I haven't figured it out yet, but I will. He is rather handsome though, isn't he?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why does this matter to you?
output: Something was discovered in Saarthal that was significant enough that Tolfdir sent a new member of the College, alone, to deliver word. That sounds precisely like the sort of thing that should matter to everyone. Especially me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Ancano?
output: He's asked far, far too many questions about my research. I think the Thalmor are trying to steal my work! I haven't told him anything, of course. What I'm doing is far too important. Can't breathe a word of it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do you know anything about this?
output: It is my job to know these things. My role as advisor to the Arch-Mage is aided by knowing everything that transpires here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: At Helgen, they said you shouted the King to death?
output: Not entirely true, though not entirely false either. Any Nord can learn the Way of the Voice by studying with the Greybeards, given enough ambition and dedication. My shouting Torygg to the ground proved he had neither. However, it was my sword piercing his heart that killed him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm on it.
output: You should wait until night fall before trying to sneak in. Talos preserve you. You should wait until night fall before trying to sneak in. Talos preserve you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm out of missives, but I need some more.
output: Certainly! Glad to see you have the task well at hand.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: This was all I could find.
output: I see. It probably doesn't even matter now, what with the mess that's been made in here. I'll add this to the rest of the items. I don't think there's anything further I need from you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're in luck. I happen to already have the mold.
output: You've more than proven that the Thieves Guild is back on its feet in our city and earned every bit of your reward. Tell Delvin that he can count on me to provide the influence around here with the right people when he needs it. If you're ever looking to sell any illegally obtained merchandise, I'd also provide my services as a fence. It's the least I can do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's going on here?
output: I don't care what Beem says. It's high time we get in there and find our fortune. I don't care what Beem says. It's high time we get in there and find our fortune.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I failed to bring down Sinding.
output: Not a failure, my servant.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I defy you and your vile tasks.
output: So you may think.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You never mentioned that lunatic living in the tunnels.
output: I thought it would be better to leave some of the details out of our previous discussion. Didn't want to risk you walking away from the job. Besides, you've done Maven a favor getting rid of him and saved me from wasting coin hiring someone else to do it later.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any chance I could talk you into overlooking this? (Persuade)
output: You're not sweet-talking your way out of this. Not after what you did. You're headed to Cidhna Mine, and that's that. You're not sweet-talking your way out of this. Not after what you did. input: I'm with the Guild. Is this enough to clear my bounty? (<Global=GuildCost> gold)
output: I don't care who you're with. After what you did, you're lucky I'm not cutting you down where you stand! I don't care who you're with.
