instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No Thanks
output: Each has their own way. Each has their own way. Each has their own way. Each has their own way. Each has their own way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you talking about?
output: The finest skooma, the sweetest moon sugar. At a fair price, of course.  The finest skooma, the sweetest moon sugar. At a fair price, of course.  The finest skooma, the sweetest moon sugar. At a fair price, of course.  The finest skooma, the sweetest moon sugar. At a fair price, of course.  The finest skooma, the sweetest moon sugar. At a fair price, of course.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You didn't escape.
output: Are you ready to see the world as only a dovah can?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What have you got for sale?
output: Assorted books, scrolls... I'm sure you'll find something useful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What have you got for sale?
output: I have a few things laying around that weren't worth adding to the collection. You may look through them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What have you got for sale?
output: Please make sure your hands are clean before touching anything, all right?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't want to help you.
output: Suit yourself. But those who listen at doors always wonder what is beyond them.  Eventually your curiosity will drive you back to me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not so easily molded.
output: You may think so. But in the end, you mortals will always flit like fire with the winds of your desires and conveniences. And those winds issue from my whispers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you to expect anything?
output: I forgive your not knowing my name. Few can hear my whispers anymore. I am Mephala, the Lady of Whispers. I tug at the web of connections between mortals. Love, hatred, loyalty, betrayal.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What could the boy not do?
output: The boy is good at sussing out secrets, but the corruptibility of children is ultimately too limited for my purposes. You, though, I expect will prove far more malleable.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where did the Dawnguard come from?
output: Vampires need to be dealt with. Hunted, rooted out, destroyed. Once there was a group dedicated to a similar cause. They called themselves the Dawnguard. That was a long time ago, but the idea was, and is, a good one. That's why I'm bringing it back. This latest attack proves it's the right time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Calm down. Who's Arvak?
output: Arvak. My horse. We came to this horrible place together. We were attacked by monsters, so I told him to run.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can I help him?
output: Arvak! Arvak, where are you? Arvak, please come back! Come back!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where do I begin?
output: The first lay at the end of Darkfall Passage, a cavern that represents the absence of enlightenment. The only way to get to my brother is by following in the Initiates' footsteps and traveling from wayshrine to wayshrine just as they did.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Good, they should be able to help us.
output: I'm afraid in their current form, they still believe the Chantry to be an active center of worship. They won't respond to you in any way other than believing that you're an Initiate and you're undertaking the journey to the Inner Sanctum.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the spectral Prelates you mentioned?
output: They're ghosts of the snow elf priests that tended the wayshrines before being slaughtered by the Betrayed. Through the grace of Auri-El, they were restored to their spectral form to enable them to continue their duties.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wayshrine?
output: Yes, let me show you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes.
output: Then behold Auri-El's gift, my child. May it speed your journey to the Inner Sanctum.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What exactly did the Betrayed do?
output: They swept into the Chantry without warning and began killing everyone without pause.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I imagine you know why we're here.
output: I can help you get it, but first I must have your assistance. Of course. You're here for Auriel's Bow. Why else would you be here?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm back from <Alias=Dungeon> with the <Alias=Item>.
output: We've been so terribly fortunate. I can't wait to see what's in these drawings.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm back from <Alias=Dungeon> with the <Alias=Item>.
output: I think even Gunmar's been impressed with what we've managed to do with the Dwemer drawings. Let's see what we can do with these ones!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: Sorine needs help with her project to improve our crossbows. And if that doesn't interest you... Sorine needs help with her project to improve our crossbows. And if that doesn't interest you... Sorine needs help with her project to improve our crossbows. And if that doesn't interest you... Sorine needs help with her project to improve our crossbows. And if that doesn't interest you...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: I want to add some punch to our crossbow capabilities, I've done all I can on my own. I need a little inspiration. I've always been fascinated with Dwemer artifacts. I take them apart, poke around in their guts, and try to figure things out - with mixed results. But as luck would have it, I've tracked down the location of some actual Dwemer diagram drawings! So, if you'd be a dear and collect those plans for me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: Ready for more? I certainly am. Be a dear and fetch me another set of Dwemer diagrams?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: It's amazing what I'm able to learn from studying these Dwemer plans. Want to head out there and collect some more?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: I'm starting to think you like this as much as I do! Here's the location of the next set of Dwemer diagrams. Thanks!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: Alright! One more set of dwemer plans to go. Think I'll be sad when we're done collecting these. Who knows though, maybe more plans will turn up in the future. But I can't wait to see these drawings. Go on, get out of here!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: I've located more dwemer plans. Be a dear and collect these diagrams for me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why?
output: Because that means there's still hope that they might one day shed their hatred and learn to believe in Auri-El once again. It's been a long time since I felt that way and it's been long overdue. My thanks, to both of you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He was a vampire. He controlled them.
output: A vampire? I see. That would explain much. Deep inside, it brings me joy that the Betrayed weren't to blame for what happened here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you mean... "lost himself"?
output: He just became absorbed... obsessed. It was kind of sick, actually. The prophecy said that vampires would no longer need to fear the sun. For someone who fancied himself as vampire royalty, that's pretty seductive.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You took a big risk coming here.
output: I did. But something about you makes me think I can trust you. I hope I'm not wrong.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: This better not be all the things you just can't be bothered with.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: Anything good?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: If you think it'll help.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: All right, let's see what you have.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: Why don't you keep your things, and I'll keep mine.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: I think I'll hang on to my things, thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: Hands to yourself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: Not going to happen.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Forget me, who are you?
output: My name is Serana. Were you... sent to wake me? Who sent you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can you teach me how to make a crossbow?
output: A basic one? Of course. That is, assuming you know anything about steel smithing. It's pretty simple. Talk to Gunmar if you need materials.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can you tell me more about the old Dawnguard?
output: Only what I've heard. Back in the Second Era, the Jarl of Riften had a son. Adventurous type, too much for his own good it seems. Wound up turning into a vampire. The Jarl, unable to kill his own son, spent a fortune building this keep and hiring men to guard it. Their job was to keep the Jarl's son contained within. They took it seriously, and served honorably. They were eventually forced to put him down. The Jarl banished them from the hold, but they stuck to their cause. Fought vampires wherever they found them. I aim to continue that mission.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Will I be able to keep these rings?
output: Of course, I wouldn't be telling you where to find it if I desired it for myself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Understood.
output: Best of luck to you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there anything I can do to help?
output: I've located the last known resting place of a set of ancient Amulets of Night Power. They should be among our kind, not laying about unguarded for mortals to find.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there anything I can do to help?
output: I've located one of the lost ancient Amulets of Night Power. It should be among our kind, not laying about unguarded for mortals to find.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do these amulets do?
output: The amulets increase the effectiveness of your vampiric powers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do these rings do?
output: They increase the abilities of your vampiric powers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Understood.
output: Good luck.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: I've discovered the whereabouts of a set of ancient Rings of Blood Magic. They belong among our kind, not gathering mold in some vagabond's treasure pile.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: I've discovered the whereabouts of one of the ancient Rings of Blood Magic. It belongs among our kind, not gathering mold in some vagabond's treasure pile.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Will I be able to keep these amulets?
output: Of course. I wouldn't be telling you where to find it if I desired it for myself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm <Alias=Player>. Who are you?
output: I am Harkon, lord of this court. By now, my daughter will have told you what we are.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I will accept your gift and become a vampire.
output: Be still!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And if I refuse your gift?
output: Then you will be prey, like all mortals. I will spare your life this once, but you will be banished from this hall.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't want to become a vampire. I refuse your gift.
output: So be it!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're vampires.
output: Not just vampires. We are among the oldest and most powerful vampires in Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you saying that I need to become a vampire?
output: Not your first choice, I'd guess.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Hiding with the Dawnguard?
output: They'd be even less welcoming to her than they've been to me. It would have been a bloodbath. Any other ideas? And since the Dawnguard are still around, that must not have happened.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So there's no way in, then.
output: Vampires aren't counted among the living. I could probably go through there without a problem. There might be, but I don't think you're going to like it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It was. What happened?
output: Now that I think about it... I should have expected that. Sorry. It's hard to describe. The Soul Cairn is... well, hungry, for lack of a better word. It's trying to take your life essence as payment.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds like she was being cautious.
output: Maybe. What I can't figure out is why she said it that way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That hurt.
output: Are you alright? That looked painful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You said you didn't know where she went.
output: The last time I saw her, she said that she'd go somewhere safe... somewhere that my father would never search. Other than that, she wouldn't tell me anything. But the way she said it... "someplace he would never search." It was cryptic, yet she called attention to it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't see another way. I'll become a vampire.
output: You'd become the very thing you've sworn to destroy. I don't know how the Dawnguard will react. Are you sure? I'm willing to turn you, but you need to think it through.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you trust Harkon at all?
output: It's not a question of trust... he's just obsessed with the prophecy.  And from what I could tell, a thousand extra years of obsession haven't made him any better. We should have found him a hobby.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Those are my only options?
output: I'm sorry. I wish I knew a better way, something that would be easier for you.  Just know that... whatever path you choose, I won't think any less of you. Sometimes things just have to be done. I know that better than anybody.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What exactly are we looking for?
output: My mother was meticulous about her research. If we can find her notes, there might be some hints in there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why didn't you say something earlier?
output: Didn't want that lot getting wind of it. Especially my father.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There has to be another way.
output: We could just "pay the toll" another way. It wants a soul, so we give it a soul. Yours. Maybe.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ideas?
output: Let's take a look around. There has to be something here that tells us where she's gone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you trying to get my attention?
output: Do you have a moment to talk?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Isran asked me to find you.
output: If Isran is really asking for me, it must be serious. I'll help. Where do you need me to go?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know anything about the old Dawnguard?
output: I've only heard stories. Not sure if any of them are true. Like that they were supposed to guard some vampire here, but wound up all becoming vampires themselves when they saw how powerful he was. And then preyed on the Rift until finally someone put them down. I guess it doesn't matter now. At least Isran is trying to do something noble with the name.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know anything about the old Dawnguard?
output: Oh, I've read a few things. Heard a few more things. Arkay's told me a bit as well. The story they'd like you to believe is that they were such a noble bunch, doing the honorable thing and saving lives. Only I hear that's not quite how it happened. Secret organization, you see. No one to blame when homes are broken into, things stolen. Heard they'd go on midnight raids, pillaging and looting, and then stash the spoils somewhere, guarded by their sigil. Arkay tells me the Sun Fire spell can break open those caches, but I've never found one. I think he might be lying to me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will you do now?
output: Well, I think it's time I got back to my work as an alchemist. The Soul Cairn will offer a unique opportunity to continue my studies, and I intend to complete my research. In the meantime, if there are any potions you might need, feel free to help yourself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can you give me Bloodcursed Arrows?
output: I'm sorry, I don't feel comfortable giving them to you. I understand what you did for Serana and for me, but the prophecy never sat well for me, and I don't want to be a part of it. I'm sorry.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where'd you say this vampire was hiding?
output: That letter's the last I've heard of her and mentions where she is. Now please, leave me alone. That letter's the last I've heard of her and mentions where she is. Now please, leave me alone. That letter's the last I've heard of her and mentions where she is. Now please, leave me alone. That letter's the last I've heard of her and mentions where she is. Now please, leave me alone. That letter's the last I've heard of her and mentions where she is. Now please, leave me alone. That letter's the last I've heard of her and mentions where she is. Now please, leave me alone. That letter's the last I've heard of her and mentions where she is. Now please, leave me alone. That letter's the last I've heard of her and mentions where she is. Now please, leave me alone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not going to take your blood right now.
output: Oh. All right, then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I use your blood, then?
output: If you were anybody else, I'd probably be taking some blood from you for asking that. You wouldn't like it. But I can see this having its uses. Do you have any elven arrows on you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I use your blood, then?
output: Sure... do you have any arrows, though? They would have to be of elven quality, I'd guess.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Vyrthur was saying something about vampire blood and the bow...
output: It sounds like... that's the last bit of the prophecy. The blood of a Daughter of Coldharbour can corrupt the bow.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to treat some arrows with your blood.
output: I think you'll need to find some arrows, first. Only elven ones will work for this, remember?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to treat some arrows with your blood.
output: Let's just get this over with.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to treat some arrows with your blood.
output: Just... try to make it quick.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're a Daughter of Coldharbour.
output: So I am. I guess we could use my blood. Do you have any arrows? Elven arrows. I'm not going to just bleed on any old thing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're a Daughter of Coldharbour.
output: That I am. So I'm guessing you want to just use my blood, then?  Let's just get this over with. Do you have any elven arrows?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let me know if you need anything.
output: We've got enough to worry about right now. You stay focused, and I'll worry about me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Will it be hard for you if we have to kill him?
output: If? I've been assuming that's where all this is going.  I've been trying to make my peace with it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why would it matter more to me?
output: Don't tell me you're that naive.  Really? Oh, wow. All right, well, what do you think my father's going to do once we bring the bow to him?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We should keep moving.
output: Right behind you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Look what it did to your family.

input: I'll have to think about it.
output: Indeed. It is no small thing to submit yourself to the flesh sculptor's knife.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you sure you know what you're doing?
output: I have not always been a ragged beggar. I learned my art from the masters of the art of flesh sculpture. I studied with the Faculty of Chirurgeons in Cloudrest. I walked with the Hollow-Faced Men of Nohotogrha for three years. I count the nobility of both the Empire and the Dominion among my clients. And yet, I have fallen so low that I must justify myself to a wanderer in the sewers of this backwater of the world.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, I'd like you to change my appearance. (<Global=DLC1SurgeryCost> gold)
output: Hmm. Very well. Just tell me what you desire - beauty or hideous deformity, nothing is beyond my skill.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, I'd like you to change my appearance. (<Global=DLC1SurgeryCost> gold)
output: Despite my present low estate, I am no beggar. Begone until you have the coin to warrant my skills.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How will vampires gain power over the sun?
output: I don't know yet. The Moth Priest died before finishing the transcription, but he did name the Elder Scrolls that contained the prophecy. The scroll you found with Serana is one of those scrolls of prophecy. Now that it is back within my grasp, we can read the scroll and learn more.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You can find us at Fort Dawnguard, near Stendarr's Beacon.
output: Very well. I'll hurry on my way there before more of those vampires turn up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We're called the Dawnguard, and we need you to read an Elder Scroll.
output: You have an Elder Scroll? Remarkable! If my knowledge of history serves me, I recall that the Dawnguard was an ancient order of vampire hunters. I will be happy to assist you with your Elder Scroll. Just tell me where I need to go.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you prepared to read the Elder Scroll?
output: Oh, most certainly! Let's find out what secrets the scroll can tell.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you alright?
output: I'm quite alright, thanks to you. Dexion Evicus is my name. I'm a Moth Priest of the White Gold Tower. These vampires claimed they had some purpose in store for me, but they wouldn't say what. Probably hoping to ransom me, the fools.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have my companions made you feel welcome?
output: It's not exactly the hospitality I'm used to, but your man Isran has seen to my needs well enough. And might I add, this is a remarkable fortress. I have colleagues back home that would love to study this place in detail.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Glad you made it here safely, Dexion.
output: Ah, my rescuer! It's good to see you again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does he have the Scroll? Is everything ready?
output: For the reading? Yeah. Just let the old man know when you're ready.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm back from <Alias=Dungeon> with the <Alias=Item>.
output: You're back and alive to boot! Fantastic.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: I've got more leads on additional Dwemer plans. Those last ones helped me immensely. If you could collect this one for me, it's sure to result in extraordinary success!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's why I'm here for the Elder Scroll.
output: You think I'd have the audacity to place my own daughter in that tomb for the protection of her Elder Scroll alone? The scrolls are merely a means to an end. The key to the Tyranny of the Sun is Serana herself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is the Chantry of Auri-El?
output: This is, or was, the epicenter of our religion. Most of the snow elf people worshipped Auri-El. The Chantry was constructed near the beginning of the First Era to provide a retreat for those that wished to become enlightened.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why weren't the snow elves here affected?
output: The Chantry is quite isolated, so it took some time for word of the dwarves' offer to reach us here. By the time the compact had been completed, it was too late for us to even attempt to intervene.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you do?
output: So are you here as a client? Shall I remake your face?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You must be the face sculptor I've heard about.
output: Yes. I once practiced my art in the salons and manors of Tamriel's great and good. Now, the scum of Skyrim are my only clients. But no matter. The greatest artists are never recognized in their own time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you talking about?
output: I assumed you were here to see me about your face. To have it sculpted into something more... artful than Nature has bestowed upon you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want?
output: Hmm, I suppose I can work with your face. After all, the sculptor cannot always choose the finest clay.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're welcome.
output: You risked everything to get Auri-El's Bow, and in turn, you've restored the Chantry. I can't think of a more deserving champion to carry it than you. If you wish to learn more about the bow, or obtain Sunhallowed Arrows for it, I'd be more than happy to help. You've but to ask.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who were your people?
output: We were once a wealthy and prosperous society that occupied a portion of Skyrim. Unfortunately, we were constantly at war with the Nords who claimed the land as their ancestral home.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Betrayed weren't to blame.
output: What? What are you talking about?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I would never allow that to happen.
output: And how exactly do you plan on stopping him?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you saying Harkon means to kill her?
output: If Harkon obtained Auriel's Bow and Serana's blood was used to taint the weapon, the Tyranny of the Sun would be complete. In his eyes, she'd be dying for the good of all vampires.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will happen to you now?
output: Even with Vyrthur gone and the Inner Sanctum destroyed, my duty as a Knight-Paladin of Auri-El remains. I've been sworn to protect this vale and everything it represents until I die.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We have to do something.
output: Well of course we do. I'm old, not stupid. We're just going to need some help.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So you're just going to give up?
output: When did I say that? We just need... we need help.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: She'll help us?
output: Might need a little convincing, but she should.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I find the people we need?
output: Right to the point, aren't you. I like that. Not like those fools in the order. We should keep it small. Too many people, and we'll draw unwanted attention to ourselves. I think we'll want Sorine Jurard. Breton girl, whip-smart and good with tinkering. Fascination with the Dwemer. Weapons in particular. Last I knew, she was out in the Reach, convinced she was about to find the biggest dwarven ruins yet.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We'll return soon.
output: One more word of warning. There's a dragon that calls itself Durnehviir roaming the Cairn. Be wary of him. The Ideal Masters have charged him with overseeing the Keepers, and will undoubtedly intervene if you're perceived as a threat.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do we need to do?
output: At their bases, the barrier's energy is being drawn from unfortunate souls that have been exiled here. Destroy the Keepers that are tending them, and it should bring the barrier down. You need to locate the tallest of the rocky spires that surround these ruins.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is your decision?
output: Your intentions are still somewhat unclear to me. But for Serana's sake, I'll assist you in any way that I can.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Off the northern coast of Skyrim, due west of Solitude.
output: I'll set out at once, then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I command you to travel to Castle Volkihar.
output: Certainly. Where can I find this castle?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: Arkay has some grave news, friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've rescued <Alias=Prisoner> from <Alias=Dungeon>.
output: I know! Arkay told me of your success!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've destroyed the vampire in the Jarl of <Alias=Capital>'s court.
output: Good. Maybe now they'll afford the vampire threat a tad bit more respect, eh?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: The Jarl's in danger. A vampire plays as a visiting "advisor" to the court. Destroy it before it's able to complete its foul business. But be warned. The Jarl's guards are unaware of the threat, and will treat violence against this "advisor" as a crime. Convince the Jarl of the threat and he'll let you destroy the creature. If not, then do your best not to get caught. Quickly now! The longer you delay, the more danger the Jarl is in.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You are in danger. A vampire has infiltrated your court.
output: That's quite a bold claim. I'd need proof before I could possibly accept it. That's quite a bold claim. I'd need proof before I could possibly accept it. That's quite a bold claim. I'd need proof before I could possibly accept it. That's quite a bold claim. I'd need proof before I could possibly accept it. That's quite a bold claim. I'd need proof before I could possibly accept it. That's quite a bold claim. I'd need proof before I could possibly accept it. That's quite a bold claim. I'd need proof before I could possibly accept it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You are in danger. A vampire has infiltrated your court.
output: Well... I trust you'll take care of this unwanted visitor. My guards will not interfere with you carrying out my justice. Well... I trust you'll take care of this unwanted visitor. My guards will not interfere with you carrying out my justice. Well... I trust you'll take care of this unwanted visitor. My guards will not interfere with you carrying out my justice. Well... I trust you'll take care of this unwanted visitor. My guards will not interfere with you carrying out my justice. Well... I trust you'll take care of this unwanted visitor. My guards will not interfere with you carrying out my justice. Well... I trust you'll take care of this unwanted visitor. My guards will not interfere with you carrying out my justice. Well... I trust you'll take care of this unwanted visitor. My guards will not interfere with you carrying out my justice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you able to give us the scroll now?
output: Yes. Please, follow me. Keep watch for Durnehviir. With the prison's barrier down, he's almost certain to investigate.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And if Harkon failed?
output: The only way I'd even consider returning to Tamriel was if Harkon were not only to fail, but to be destroyed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You said "even if I could." Why?
output: Like Serana, I am a Daughter of Coldharbour, an vampire offspring of Molag Bal. My presence in Tamriel would simply double the risk that Harkon could complete the prophecy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why don't you come back with us?
output: Even if I could, it would only serve to hinder your efforts. Harkon would likely sense my return to Tamriel. The last thing you need right now is a trail for him to follow.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You hate him that much?
output: You must understand that he's no longer the man I married all that time ago. He's obsessed... insane. Everyone around him fears him as they would a rabid dog. For all of this to end, he must die.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We're not sure, but Isran is concerned.
output: In case you haven't noticed, Isran is always concerned about something. That's what got us working together in the first place. Still, if he sent you to find me, it may actually be pretty bad.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: They have an Elder Scroll.
output: I... Well, that's actually something I never would've anticipated. Interesting. I'm not sure what they would do with one, but in this case Isran is probably correct in thinking it isn't good.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Vampires threaten all of Skyrim. We need your help.
output: Vampires? Really? Oh, and I suppose now he remembers that I proposed no less than three different scenarios that involved vampires overrunning the population. Well, what are they up to?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We're not sure, but they have an Elder Scroll.
output: By the Eight... All right, look. I'll consider it, but I can't just leave this bear to prey on more innocent people. Once it's dealt with, then perhaps I'll see what Isran expects of me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You had a falling out?
output: Yes, that was my point. I felt it was rather clear. Look, what is it you want from me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We're up against vampires.
output: Vampires? That... well, that might change things. Tell me more about what's going on.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Isran asked me to find you.
output: Isran? Wants me? No, you must be mistaken. He made it exceedingly clear the last time we spoke that he had no interest in my help. I find it hard to believe he's changed his mind. He said some very hurtful things to me before I left. Anyway, I'm quite happy in my current pursuits. So if you'll excuse me...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Isran needs your help.
output: Isran? Needing someone else's help? Never thought I'd hear that. I'm afraid he's a few years too late. I've moved on. I have more important business to attend to. Besides, he can handle anything alone! He assured me so himself. What could he possibly need my help with?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We're meeting at Fort Dawnguard.
output: Ah. Been working more on his secret hideout, has he? It'll be interesting to see how much progress he's made. I'll finish up here and head in that direction soon as I can. See you there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know where these other scrolls are?
output: My traitor wife stole one of them away and then disappeared. As for the other, the last that I heard, it was lost in the bowels of a Dwemer ruin. It seems our work is not yet done. But I have waited this long, and we are so very close now. I can wait a bit longer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have made the Moth Priest my thrall.
output: Yes, I see that. I trust his capture was not too difficult a task?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then you may begin your reading.
output: Of course, master.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You must read an Elder Scroll.
output: Ah, yes, the Elder Scroll! I admit, I'm looking forward to this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a new task for you, thrall.
output: Of course. What is it that you need me to do?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Isran's at Fort Dawnguard.
output: He's been working on that place for years now. Never lets anyone in. His own little fortress. Well, I guess I'll get to see what he's been up to all this time. I'll meet you there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you know?
output: If Isran is anything, he's stubborn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, he said to meet him at Fort Dawnguard.
output: Of course he did.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Serana believes in me, why won't you?
output: Serana?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Please, we need your help.
output: Look, I've just gotten myself out of quite a mess here, in case you haven't noticed, and while I appreciate your help, I... What's that? No, that's not what I...  Yes, but... Are you sure? Really? Fine. Arkay says it's a good idea for me to go. I don't agree, but he's not the sort of fellow you can just ignore. I'll see you at Fort Dawnguard, then. Don't worry, Arkay will show me the way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Isran needs your help.
output: Isran? My help? Is this... some kind of a joke? Did Arkay put you up to this? Isran's done nothing but mock me. He's never given me the respect I deserve.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You can meet me at Fort Dawnguard.
output: I suppose I could... what, praytell, is there?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Because we're going to need her help.
output: Why, because of that story about the prophecy? About some vampire trying to put the sun out? Do you actually believe any of that?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, you're right. We just have to convince the others you're on our side.
output: Well, let's move then. I'm nothing if not persuasive.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who can?
output: Well, the Moth Priests are the only ones I've heard of who can do it. They spend years preparing before they start reading, though. Not that it helps us anyway, because they're all half a continent away in Cyrodiil.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What sort of prophecy?
output: It's pointless and vague, like all prophecies. The part he latched onto said that vampires would no longer need to fear the sun. That's what he's after. He wants to control the sun, have vampires control the world.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What about it?
output: It all comes back to my father. I'm guessing you figured this part out already, but my father's not exactly a good person. Even by vampire standards. He wasn't always like that, though. There was... a turn. He stumbled onto this obscure prophecy and just kind of lost himself in it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you doing here?
output: I'd rather not be here either, but I needed to talk to you. It's important, so please just listen before your friend, here, loses his patience. It's... well, it's about me. And the Elder Scroll that was buried with me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Understood.
output: When you offer the embrace, do so away from prying eyes. Our new sibling will then likely require rest while his blood undergoes the change. Return to me when your part is done.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Understood.
output: When you offer the embrace, do so away from prying eyes. Our new sibling will then likely require rest while her blood undergoes the change. Return to me when your part is done.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: I've found a new candidate, ripe for Harkon's Gift. I'm sending you to welcome this soul into our family.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He simply said "It is time."
output: Well, well. He wants the Chalice, then. You've heard of the Bloodstone Chalice?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you tried getting into the Inner Sanctum?
output: Leaving the wayshrines unguarded would be violating my sacred duty as a Knight-Paladin of Auriel. And an assault on the Betrayed guarding the Inner Sanctum would only end with my death.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you know?
output: For the thousands of years I've served as the Chantry's sentinel, there hasn't been a single visitor here for any other reason. They request Auriel's Bow, and I request their assistance. It's been repeated so many times, I can't imagine it any other way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll be off then.
output: This may be the last time we're able to converse. If you have any questions before you leave, I suggest you ask them. Otherwise, all I can do now is grant you my hopes for a safe journey.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You don't even know if he's alive.
output: He's alive. I've seen him. But something's wrong. He never looks as though he's in pain or under duress. He just... stands there and watches, as though waiting.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So I need to fill this at each wayshrine?
output: Once you've located a wayshrine, there will be a spectral Prelate tending to it. They will allow you to draw the waters from the shrine's basin as if you've been enlightened.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Didn't you fight back?
output: The Chantry was a place of peaceful worship. I led a small group of paladins, but we were no match for the Betrayed's sheer numbers. They slaughtered everyone and stormed the Inner Sanctum where I believe they corrupted Vyrthur.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Snow elves? You're a Falmer?
output: I prefer snow elf. The name "Falmer" usually holds a negative meaning to most travelers. Those twisted creatures you call Falmer, I call the Betrayed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: These caves must be massive.
output: Caves? Oh, no. The Chantry encompasses far more than a few caves, as you'll soon discover. But before I send you on your way, you'll need the Initiate's Ewer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do I have a choice?
output: Absolutely. You could turn around and travel back from wherever you started empty handed, or you could assist me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How many more wayshrines are there?
output: There are five in total, spread far apart across the Chantry.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What type of assistance do you need?
output: I need you to kill Arch-Curate Vyrthur... my brother.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: This cave is a temple to Auriel?
output: Auriel, Auri-El, Alkosh, Akatosh... so many different names for the sovereign of the snow elves.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Kill your brother, why?
output: The kinship between us is gone. I don't understand what he's become, but he's no longer the brother I once knew. It was the Betrayed... they did something to him, I just don't know why Auri-El would allow this to happen.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: I am Knight-Paladin Gelebor. Welcome to the Great Chantry of Auri-El.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this bloodspring?
output: An ancient font, full of power. As much as it looks like blood, sadly it is not. Can you imagine if it were? We'd never need to hunt again. Still, its liquid is powerful, full of magic. Others have noticed, though they have never fully realized its potential.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How long were you in there?
output: Good question. Hard to say.  I... I can't really tell.  I feel like it was a long time. Who is Skyrim's High King?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's impressive.
output: It's something all right.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I wasn't told where to take you.
output: Your lack of planning fills me with confidence.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why didn't you tell me it was so huge?
output: I didn't want you to think I was one of those... you know, the women who just sit in their castle all day? I don't know. Coming from a place like this, well... it's not really me. I hope you can believe that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't think he knew much of anything.
output: Figures I'd be woken by a couple of know-nothings. So where are we off to, now?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Someone you don't want to see?
output: My father and I don't really get along. Ugh, saying it out loud makes it sound so... common. "Little girl who doesn't get along with her father." Read that story a hundred times.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No. We expected some kind of artifact.
output: And instead you found me. So what's your next step, now that I'm here?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why wouldn't you be safe there?
output: Let's just say that my mother and father had a bit of a falling out. Don't worry, I'm not in any danger or anything like that. It'll just be more unpleasant to run into my father.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Nobody. I just walked in here.
output: You're lucky to be alive, then. I'm guessing you don't have a plan for where to go next, then?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's not really your business.
output: I see. Where are you taking me, then? Is that much my business?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about your home.
output: It's on an island near Solitude. Hopefully we can find a boat to take us there. It's my family home. Not the most welcoming place, but depending on who's around, I'll be safe there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about your home.
output: This is it. Home sweet... castle.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: A man named Isran.
output: I... don't know who that is. Did he... mention my father at all?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why were you locked away?
output: I'd... rather not get into that with you. If that's all right.  I'm sorry, it's not that... it's just that I don't know who I can trust just yet. Let's get to my home, and I'll have a better sense of where we all stand.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was sent to retrieve something from this cave.
output: That something... was probably me.  My name is Serana. Who sent you here?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's on your mind?
output: That Moth Priest, Dexion. He said we needed two other Elder Scrolls. I think I know where we can start looking.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can't it wait?
output: Well, you could waste a lot of time trying to figure out our next move, or you could let me help. Your choice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why didn't you say something earlier?
output: Half the people in your little crew would just as soon kill me as talk to me.  I got a warmer welcome from my father, and that's saying something. That doesn't exactly make me want to open up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: In Castle Volkihar?
output: Wait... that almost makes sense! All of the ingredients for our potions came from there. She used to say that my father couldn't stand the place. Too... peaceful. There's a courtyard in the castle. I used to help her tend a garden there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sealed away like you were?
output: I don't think so. She said she wanted to stay awake in case the situation was resolved. Anything else? It had to be one of us, and, well, she's so much more powerful than I am. It just made sense for her to be out here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So where is this Elder Scroll?
output: We need to find my mother, Valerica.  She'll definitely know where it is, and if we're lucky, she actually has it herself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Isn't that pretty risky, staying around the castle?
output: Oh, absolutely. But my mother's not a coward.  That is... I don't think we'll actually trip over her there. But it's worth a look.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do we need?
output: A handful of soul gem shards, some finely-ground bone meal, a good bit of purified void salts... Oh... damn it...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: If she made it there, we'll find her.
output: That circle in the center of the room is definitely some type of portal. If I'm reading this right, there's a formula here that should give us safe passage into the Soul Cairn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did she care where used souls went?
output: The Soul Cairn is home to very powerful beings. Necromancers send them souls, and receive powers of their own in return. My mother spent a lot of time trying to contact them directly, to travel to the Soul Cairn itself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's this "Soul Cairn" that she mentions?
output: I only know what she told me. She had a theory about soul gems. That the souls inside of them don't just vanish when they're used... they end up in the Soul Cairn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've found your mother's notes.
output: You did? Let me see them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You share her blood.
output: Hmmm. Not bad. We'd better hope that's good enough. Mistakes with these kinds of portals can be... gruesome. Anyway, enough of that. Let's get started.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You've been imprisoned here for all this time?
output: Time has very little meaning to me. Consequently, it has little meaning to the Ideal Masters as well. I suppose you could call this the ultimate waiting game, each watching the other to see which will give in.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll need your help.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Tyranny of the Sun requires Serana's blood?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: They tricked you.
output: The Ideal Masters unleashed their Keepers and sent them to destroy me. Fortunately, I was able to hold them at bay and retreat into these ruins.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How does Serana fit in?
output: Like myself, Serana was a human once. We were devout followers of Lord Molag Bal. We call such confluences the "Daughters of Coldharbour." Tradition dictates the females be offered to Molag Bal on his summoning day. Few survive the ordeal. Those that do emerge as a pure-blooded vampire.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you mean?
output: When I fled Castle Volkihar, I fled with two Elder Scrolls. The second scroll declares that "The Blood of Coldharbour's Daughter will blind the eye of the Dragon." The scroll I presume you found with Serana speaks of Auriel and his arcane weapon, Auriel's Bow.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What was the bargain?
output: I requested refuge in the Soul Cairn, and in exchange, I would provide the Ideal Masters the souls that they craved. If I had foreseen the value they placed on my own soul, I would never have come here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm just here for the Elder Scroll.
output: Glorious. Serana claims you're her guardian, yet your first instinct appears to be greed. I see that my daughter is still as naive as ever.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you become imprisoned here?
output: When I entered the Soul Cairn, I had intended to strike a bargain with the Ideal Masters, the custodians of this place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've saved her from your foolish plan.
output: I find your choice of words quite interesting considering that Serana is in far more danger now than she was following my "foolish plan."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And Serana's opinion in this?
output: You care nothing for Serana or our plight. You're here because we're abominations in your mind. Evil creatures that need to be destroyed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And Serana's opinion in this?
output: You care nothing for Serana or our plight. You see the Tyranny of the Sun as your chance at deification, and like Harkon you won't hesitate to destroy anything that stands in your path.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Perhaps her death is destined.
output: No! I will not allow that happen. The Elder Scrolls only tell of events that might be, not events that will be.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I wish to regain the gift of beast blood.
output: Do you, now? Hircine doesn't usually bestow his favor on the fickle. But you've proven your worth. I'm willing to try.  Are you ready now?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need more time to prepare myself.
output: Go. Reconsider your plight.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I am.
output: Hold still, then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do they resemble?
output: Well, some necromancers believe they are the crystalline structures dotting the Soul Cairn. I believe there's more to it than that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why haven't you pursued the prophecy?
output: Harkon's vision is a world plunged in eternal darkness where the vampire can flourish and never again fear the "tyranny of the sun." What he fails to realize is how much attention would be called to our kind if the prophecy came to fruition.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Serana underwent this ritual willingly?
output: It was expected of her, just as it was expected of me. Being selected as an offering to Molag Bal is an honor. She wouldn't have dared turn her back on that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Ideal Masters?
output: I know very little about them. They're mystic entities that lord over the Soul Cairn, controlling every aspect from its fabric to its appearance.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What sort of attention?
output: If eternal night fell, there are many who wouldn't stand for it. They would raise armies in attempts to return things to normal. The order of the day would be our destruction until every last vampire was hunted down and eliminated.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Coldharbour?
output: It's what some call the domain of Molag Bal. His place in Oblivion.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So you prefer living in the shadows.
output: I do. It's how the vampire has survived for millennia, and the only way we can continue to survive in the future.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do the Masters provide in return?
output: The ability to summon powerful undead guardians as one would conjure an atronach or daedra. However, the majority of necromancers that are foolish enough to enter into a bargain with the Ideal Masters wind up here... as harvested souls.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How so?
output: I think they transcend what we perceive as a physical form. Perhaps they were once corporeal beings, but they've obviously reached a point where they no longer require a tangible presence.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why would they require sustenance?
output: The Ideal Masters's weakness is their insatiable hunger for pure souls. It's the reason for the Soul Cairn's existence, and the only leverage a necromancer has when bargaining with them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And the crystals?
output: Conduits through which the Ideal Masters speak to their underlings and feed on their victims.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You heard the Scroll reading. Now do you believe Serana?
output: I heard a lot of vague nonsense. You could interpret that a hundred different ways. Only thing that stood out for me was Auriel's Bow. That's a powerful weapon, and I sure as Oblivion don't want the vampires to get hold of it. The Moth Priest can stay here for now. As for the vampire, I still don't trust it, so keep it on a leash.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any insights about your Elder Scroll reading?
output: I wish I could say that I did, but without the other two Scrolls, the picture will remain incomplete. I admit, I feel a bit frustrated that I can't be more helpful. Still, our enemy is likely just as much in the dark as we are, and that's something. Now it's a race to claim the remaining Scrolls and discover what part Auriel's Bow has to play in this prophecy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I guess we'll have to keep looking for that Moth Priest, then.
output: I guess so.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You want us to help you?
output: That was the plan, yes. Assuming the rest of them can trust a vampire. Come on, I'll need you to help convince them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's all this have to do with the Dawnguard?
output: I'm sorry, I had heard there were vampire hunters here. I thought they might want to know about a vampire plot to enslave the rest of the world. Was I wrong?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Will I be able to safely revisit the Soul Cairn?
output: As you've been traveling in the Soul Cairn, your body has become attuned to it. Let's just say a tiny part of you rubbed off on it, and in its place, a bit of the Soul Cairn filled the void. You should find no difficulty using the portal any longer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, the place was crawling with vampires.
output: Good. I assume you took care of that little infestation. Did you figure out what they were looking for in there?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: That would fit with the rest of it... I don't like it, but you did right to play along. We need to find out what this is all about.

output: Damn fool. I told him not to go. The Vigilants always had more bravery than sense. Did you at least find out what the vampires were looking for in there?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What exactly are you planning to do to these vampires?
output: First thing is to get this fort back into shape. Right now, a vampire could practically walk right in the front door. But I have something for you to do, since you're asking.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: I need someone out in the field, taking the fight to the damn vampires, while we're getting the fort back into shape...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: I suppose you're lucky you're not dead. Or worse, one of them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There were too many of them, and only one of me.
output: So they have everything they wanted, and we're left with nothing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm lucky I made it out alive.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What must I know about being a vampire?
output: As a vampire, you will gain new powers, but also a weakness to sunlight. With each passing day that you do not feed, that weakness will become more deadly, but your powers will also become stronger. Feed upon those who are sleeping, and your vulnerability to sunlight will diminish along with your powers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready to carry out this task.
output: Good. Go and speak to Garan Marethi. Tell him it is time. He will understand.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me again about being a Vampire Lord.
output: When you first transform into a Vampire Lord, you will hover in the air. While you do, you will command the powers of Blood and Night.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need training for Two-Handed weapons.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need training for Two-Handed weapons.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you call me "Qahnaarin?"
output: My claws have rended the flesh of innumerable foes, but I have never once been felled on the field of battle. I therefore honor-name you "Qahnaarin," or Vanquisher in your tongue.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I thought you were dead.
output: Cursed, not dead. Doomed to exist in this form for eternity. Trapped between laas and dinok, between life and death.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's stopping you?
output: I fear that my time here has taken its toll upon me. I share a bond with this dreaded place. If I ventured far from the Soul Cairn, my strength would begin to wane until I was no more.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Didn't you try to kill me?
output: The hostility was necessary. I was bound to an oath.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why are we speaking?
output: I believe in civility among seasoned warriors, and I find your ear worthy of my words.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We may never return.
output: After what I've put Serana through, I would understand if she never wished to see me again. I leave that decision in your hands.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What kind of a favor?
output: For countless years I've roamed the Soul Cairn, in unintended service to the Ideal Masters. Before this, I roamed the skies above Tamriel. I desire to return there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We could use your help in Tamriel.
output: As much as it pains me to send you and Serana back alone, I can't take the risk.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't trust things that try to kill me.
output: If my desire to end your life was still my purpose, we would not be speaking.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We'll return for you when we can.
output: I appreciate your concern for me, but Serana is all that I care about. You must keep her safe at all costs.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're staying here?
output: I have no choice. As I told you before, I'm a Daughter of Coldharbour. If I return to Tamriel, that increases Harkon's likelihood of bringing the Tyranny of the Sun to fruition.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want from me?
output: The tone of your voice is understandable. Perhaps I can alleviate your suspicions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Just call your name in Tamriel? That's it?
output: Trivial in your mind, perhaps. For me, it would mean a great deal. I don't require an answer, Qahnaarin. Simply speak my name to the heavens when you feel the time is right.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found you equally worthy.
output: Your words do me great honor.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How could I help?
output: I will place my name with you and grant you the right to call my name from Tamriel. Do me this simple honor and I will fight at your side as your Grah-Zeymahzin, your Ally, and teach you my Thu'um.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have more pressing matters at the moment.
output: Forgive me, Qahnaarin. We will continue this when time releases you from its relentless grasp.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Isran asked me to find you.
output: I understand that, but I really can't leave here without at least one usable piece of dwarven equipment. A single gyro would be enough, I think. Believe me, this is useful stuff.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you doing?
output: I am sure Nazir's cooking is great and all, but my appetites are a little more... discerning.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You were hunting?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you doing?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's not your concern.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's your father?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you a...
output: Vampire, yes.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who were you expecting?
output: I was expecting someone... like me, at least.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who were you expecting?
output: I was expecting someone from my family. I don't recognize you. Are you one of my father's little acolytes?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where do you need to go?
output: My family used to live on an island to the west of Solitude. I would guess they still do. By the way... my name is Serana. Good to meet you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you mean, "like you"?
output: A... can't you tell just from looking at me? A vampire.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why were you locked away like this?
output: That's... complicated. And I'm not totally sure if I can trust you.  But if you want to know the whole story, help me get back to my family's home.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Dawnguard would want me to kill you.
output: Don't think that'll keep them from turning on you eventually. They'll figure out what you are.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Dawnguard would want me to kill you.
output: Not fond of vampires, are they? Well, look. Kill me, you've killed one vampire. But if people are after me, there's something bigger going on. I can help you find out what that is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do I get a reward for finding your daughter?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happens now?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't really care what you are.
output: Perhaps you should. I count some of the oldest and most powerful vampires in Skyrim among the members of my court.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You first.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Forget I said anything.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to find someone named Florentius.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You sure? They might prove useful.
output: We're going to a place I've never been... and we're goind to see my mother. After all these years. I just don't feel comfortable sharing that moment with a total stranger, I'm sorry.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Come with me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's go to the castle's secret entrance.
output: Well, I don't take just anyone into the secret parts of the place I grew up. Get rid of this interloper and you and I can be on our way. I'll wait for you at the dock.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's go to the castle's secret entrance.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry, I'm not interested.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
