instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want to buy back the Elder Scroll I sold you.
output: Finally came to your senses, eh? Realized what you gave up? Can't say I'm surprised.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want to buy back the Elder Scroll I sold you.
output: Back, huh? Well, price is still 4,000 coins.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Make it 3,000 and you have a deal. (Persuade)
output: All right, I suppose I could do that. Here you are.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Make it 3,000 and you have a deal. (Persuade)
output: No, sorry. It's 4,000 coins or no deal.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm the Arch-Mage. It's 2,000 coins.
output: Oh, very well. I don't know how you expect me to keep this place in order when I can't make a profit.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Forget it, I'll come back.
output: Hey, if you don't like it, you could always shop for your Elder Scrolls elsewhere.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for an Elder Scroll.
output: And what do you plan to do with it? Do you even know what you're asking about?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's go to the castle's secret entrance.
output: It's around the side of the castle. Let's move.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think we should part ways.
output: All right. I'll meet you at Darkfall Cave.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think we should part ways.
output: All right. I'll meet you at the glade.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think we should part ways.
output: Oh. All right then. You know where to find me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Elder Scrolls have served me well, Dexion.
output: Of course they did. I never doubted for a moment. If I may ask, what will you do with them now?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm going to hold on to them for now.
output: Ah, yes. I see. Well, if you do change your mind, please let me know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd be happy for you to have them. Here.
output: Thank you! You're too kind.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: 6000 gold, and they're yours.
output: Oh my, that's... Well, that's not exactly what I had in mind. Still, if it means their safe-keeping, I suppose it is worth it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you still want the Elder Scrolls?
output: I'd very much like to have those scrolls. Someday I may be able to return them to their rightful place in the Imperial City. How would you feel about turning them over to me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you still want the Elder Scrolls?
output: Yes, certainly. Are you willing to let me have them?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did you have something in mind?
output: I did, in fact. Quite perceptive of you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: They're indestructible, so they'd make good armor.
output: Oh dear. No, I'm afraid that's not going to work at all. I have an alternative for you, if you'd be interested.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I hadn't really thought about it.
output: No? Well, I've given it a bit of thought.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: They're bound to bring me fortune and glory.
output: Ah, yes. Hmm. I'm afraid they don't quite work that way. Might I offer an alternative?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Very well. (Give Auriel's Bow)
output: Pitiful. Simply pitiful. I expected more from the defiant fool that beguiled my daughter. No matter. Serana will sacrifice her blood for the sake of the prophecy, and I will feast upon yours in Molag Bal's honor!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Stop wasting my time, Garan.
output: My apologies. I shall not trouble you with it again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't care. Do as you like.
output: Then I think I shall see to the repairs. Thank you for your time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: See to it at once.
output: It would be my pleasure.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Something on your mind, Garan?
output: Now that the Castle is yours, I was wondering. Would you be interested in having the passage to the Courtyard restored? Harkon clearly never cared much for it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think we should part ways.
output: I'll stick around this place if you need me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think we should part ways.
output: I'll be at Castle Volkihar if you need me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think we should part ways.
output: I'll be around here if you need me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think we should part ways.
output: All right. I'll meet you back at the castle.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do you call me "Qahnaarin?"
output: In my language, the Qahnaarin is the Vanquisher, the one who has bested a fellow dovah in battle.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is that why you're free now?
output: Free? No. I have been here too long, Qahnaarin. The Soul Cairn has become a part of what I am. I can never fully call Tamriel my home again, or I would surely perish. I only hope that you will allow me the precious moments of time there through your call.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you end up in the Soul Cairn?
output: There was a time when I called Tamriel my home, but those days have long since passed. The dovah roamed the skies, vying for their small slices of territory that resulted in immense and ultimately fatal battles.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: They didn't tell you she was immortal.
output: I discovered too late that the Ideal Masters favor deception over honor and had no intention of releasing me from my binding. They had control of my mind, but fortunately they couldn't possess my soul.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Were you a part of all that?
output: I was. But unlike some of my brethren, I sought solutions outside the norm in order to maintain my superiority. I began to explore what the dovah call "Alok-Dilon," the ancient forbidden art that you call necromancy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So you sought the Soul Cairn for answers.
output: The Ideal Masters assured me that my powers would be unmatched, that I could raise legions of the undead. In return, I was to serve them as a Keeper until the death of the one who calls herself Valerica.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Fellow dovah? I am not a dragon.
output: Even in the Soul Cairn, the defeat of the World Eater has reached my ears, Dovahkiin. You may not be dovah, but the defeat of Alduin earns you the right of title.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Fellow dovah? I am not a dragon.
output: You are the Dovahkiin, the Dragonborn. You may not be one of us in body, but you have earned the right to bear this title.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Fellow dovah? I am not a dragon.
output: Forgive me, my instinct was to grant you this title. I am uncertain why. Perhaps one day it will become clear to both of us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's so special about the moondial?
output: Well, as far as I'm aware it's the only one in existence. The previous owners of the castle had a sundial in the courtyard, and obviously that didn't appeal to my mother. She persuaded an elven artisan to make some improvements. You can see the plates that show the phases of the moons, Masser and Secunda.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So what exactly am I doing to it?
output: Hard to say. Maybe if we found the missing crests, we could figure it out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does it work?
output: That's the thing... what's the point of a moondial? I always wondered why she didn't just have the whole thing ripped out. But she loved it. I don't know. I guess it's like having a piece of art, if you're into that sort of thing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Dawnguard were protecting him, and they nearly killed me.
output: We both know that a band of fools with crossbows is no match for a scion of the ancient blood. I admit, I do not entirely understand your sense of humor.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Dawnguard were there. They fought well, but not well enough.
output: They are determined and well-armed, but foolish if they think they can defy us. We will deal with them in time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Dawnguard tried to stop me, but they posed no threat.
output: I wish I could have been there to hear the sounds of their screams.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: When do you plan to start trusting me?
output: Do not presume to tell me who I can and cannot trust. I possess the wisdom of a dozen lifetimes, and I will make my own judgements. Now be silent, and hear what I have to say.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I suspected as much.
output: Good. Strong instincts and a cunning mind will serve you as well as blade, spell or claw.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why else would she risk her life to come here?
output: Who knows, maybe it has a death wish. Maybe it's just insane. I don't really care.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Set your hatred aside and try to see the larger picture, Isran.
output: Set my hatred aside? Not a chance. It's what keeps me strong.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You don't trust her, fine. Trust me. I believe her.
output: You'd better know what you're doing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're the one who matters to me.
output: I thought you said you were happy together. I'm not going to be the one to destroy a marriage. I'm sorry.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're the one who matters to me.
output: If you're not happy with things... that's not my business.  I'm not going to blamed for whatever happens.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're the one who matters to me.
output: You're sweet to say that, but you need to sort things out on your own. It's not something I'm going to get involved with.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No. I was just curious.
output: You're sweet. And... I'm not stupid. I can see what you're getting at. But... that's just not something I'm going to be able to do. Ever. Given how I've lived... what I've done... I can't ask the gods for a blessing like that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No. I was just curious.
output: All right. If you say so.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was hoping you might want to talk about it.
output: Don't you already have someone at home waiting for you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was hoping you might want to talk about it.
output: Look, you're great. Really. But I just don't think that's for us. Especially not me. I mean... with my history, I still kind of get a chill just walking by a temple. Can't imagine going in one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was hoping you might want to talk about it.
output: Look, I care about you. A lot. And I'll come with you wherever you want to go. But... with everything in my past, I don't think I could bring myself to go into a temple and ask for that kind of blessing. It's just... it's not for me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're right. I shouldn't have brought it up.
output: Let's just pretend you didn't, all right?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you ever thought about marriage?
output: I think we've talked about that enough. Come on, now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you ever thought about marriage?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this place?
output: Heh... wait, you're serious? This is the Redwater Den, purveyors of the best Skooma outside of Balmora.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You talk about being lonely a lot.
output: Do you ever feel lonely?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll explain later. Right now, we need your help and time is short.
output: Well, you saved me from those vampires. I suppose the least that I can do is hear you out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I know why they needed you, because we need you for the same purpose.
output: You do? Alright then, enough mysteries.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is so special about your Skooma?
output: The secret is our mystic Redwater Spring. The magic in the waters opens the mind to experience Skooma in a way like never before.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How about a sample? (Persuade)

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your soul was trapped.
output: My what? Wait. That means...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where were you captured?
output: I had just moved from my ancestral home in Morrowind to the continent of Cyrodiil. I settled in the city of Kvatch to write my memoirs and to find some peace and quiet.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Prison? You mean the Soul Cairn?
output: Soul what? What in the name of Vivec are you talking about? All I remember is that damn dremora and his minions bursting into my home and sending me to their prison.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Were you successful?
output: Indeed I was. I hunted down and killed every last one of them. Took years. The people of Morrowind were so grateful to have the roads safer again, they took to calling me "Saint Jiub" and then the other names followed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Rival assassin?
output: Exactly. He got to my target first and called the guard to cover his tracks. By the time I got there, the place was on alert. Walked right into a trap, and didn't even realize it until I was captured.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't have time for this.
output: And you think I do? Humph.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't have time for this.
output: Oh, this is simply getting infuriating!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What ended up happening?
output: Well, I don't know. Everything seemed fine until that dremora attacked me. I only heard later about the gates from the other souls. I can only assume the gates have been closed by now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How is your work going so far?
output: Terrible, simply terrible. I was in the midst of writing the second volume and they just threw me into this prison. It's unfair!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why was Dagon able to do this?
output: All I heard is that without a Septim sitting on the throne of the Empire, the Dragonfires in a place called the Temple of the One were no longer lit. This meant that we were vulnerable to the forces of Oblivion.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Nope, never heard of you.
output: I can't say that I'm surprised by your answer. Until I get my second volume published, no one will ever know of my achievements.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Winged Menace?
output: Yes. I'm speaking of the Cliff Racer of course. Wretched things. They used to criss-cross the skies over Morrowind like vermin. Nasty flying creatures with a habit of sneaking up on the unwary.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here's all of the pages.
output: Finally! I never thought I'd see these again. These pages meant the world to me. Thank you!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why would a dremora attack you?
output: Well, that's a ridiculous question. Everyone traveling through here has said that the Oblivion Gates have been opening all over Tamriel.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What was your campaign against them?
output: After I was freed from prison, I decided to turn my life around. Give something back to the people of Morrowind. It became quickly apparent that the best way I could help would be by wiping out the cliff racers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: A dremora captured you?
output: Well, I assume so. It cast a spell at me from some kind of strange black crystal. Next thing I knew, I arrived here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you earn your nicknames?
output: Ah, yes. Saint Jiub, Jiub the Eradicator, Jiub the Magnificent... I've earned a lot of those titles thanks to my campaign against the Winged Menace.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's just start at the beginning...
output: Very well. I suppose a moment or two of my time couldn't hurt. I am Jiub. Some call me Saint Jiub. Others call me Jiub the Eradicator. Perhaps you've heard of me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're dead.
output: No... all these wasted months, or has it been years? I don't even remember how much time has passed. Now my work will never see the light of day. My name will be forgotten.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You must be crazy.
output: Hmph. I tell you what's crazy. How about sitting in your home, minding your own business and then suddenly getting attacked by a dremora and his cronies.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What exactly are you doing?
output: How does anyone expect me to write my opus with all of these rude interruptions?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Now, what were you saying?
output: Oh, I see. You've decided to cease pursuing your busy schedule and wish to talk now. How kind.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe a shorter title is in order?
output: Maybe you should leave the writing to an expert and stop making foolish suggestions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll be off then.
output: Oh, wait a moment. Here, I want you to have these before you go. A pristine copy of my first volume. Only one in print, actually. And take this as well. Seeing as Saint Jiub has ascended to pure spiritual form, I won't need it any longer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who threw you in here?
output: That damn dremora and his minions. They didn't even give me a chance to explain who I was.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You said you were in prison?
output: That was a dark time in my life. I did a lot of things I ended up regretting. Maybe that's why I worked so hard to redeem myself once I was freed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Could I help?
output: Perhaps. Do you have a way out of here?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're talking about a book?
output: A book? I'd hardly call a twenty-six volume epic simply a "book." Surely you've heard of "The Rise and Fall of Saint Jiub the Eradicator: Hero of Morrowind and Savior of the Dunmer."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did you do?
output: I murdered others for money. And before you think I belonged to some romantic or secretive guild, think again. I was simply an addict who needed money for skooma. The stuff wasn't cheap, and murder always seemed to be in demand.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I do, but you can't leave that way.
output: Maybe I can't leave, but my writings can. In order to write the second volume of my opus, I need the notes from my first volume. Otherwise I need to do all of this from memory.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How'd you get caught?
output: I finally bit off more than I could chew. I was paid to assassinate some high-ranking official from House Redoran. What I didn't know is someone had hired the Morag Tong to kill him as well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That was... a bit before my time.
output: Has it been that long? Oh my. Well, it started with the followers of Mehrunes Dagon having Emperor Uriel Septim VII assassinated. Without a Septim on the throne of the Empire, Dagon was able to leave Oblivion through the gates and attack.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So now what?
output: Now, volume two begins! What else?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How many pages did you lose?
output: When I was tossed in here I felt myself falling... and I dropped the pages I had been holding. There were ten of them in all. Find them for me, please, I beg you!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So what ended up happening to you?
output: They tried me for murder, threw me on a prison ship and sent me to the jail in Vivec City. Gave me a lot of time to think, that's for sure.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Opus? What do you mean?
output: "What do I mean," indeed! If I hadn't lost all of the pages, I wouldn't be in this predicament and we wouldn't be having this conversation.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Hello
output: Keep quiet! We're hunting vampires spotted in the area. Keep quiet! We're hunting vampires spotted in the area.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Actually, now that you mention it...(Attack)
output: Hunters! Take his heart!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Hello
output: Keep an eye out and let us know if you see any vampires.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, I haven't seen any.
output: Well, if you do just let us know. We'll be in this area until we find them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Hello
output: We're looking for some Vampires that have been reported in the area. Seen any?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Hello
output: Fellow hunter, we're looking for some Vampires that have been reported in the area. Have you seen any?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How so?
output: This is the most peace and quiet I've had in a lifetime. There's no one around to disturb me and distract me from my writing. Present company excepted of course.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't suppose there's a way to free you.
output: Considering the state I'm in, I'd say that option vanished a long time ago. Besides this isn't so bad when you think about it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is that where you were attacked?
output: Indeed! One moment I was writing diligently, and the next, my door bursts open. I took it upon myself to join the cause and fight the dremora, thinking this would simply be another feather in my cap. It was a cadre of dremora. The city was under attack.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will you do now?
output: Now that the first volume's complete, there's no much left to do but begin work on the second. There are plenty of other adventures I've had over the years, but you'll just have to read my next work to find out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Didn't work out that way I assume.
output: The reason I'm standing in front of you as only a whisper of my former self should tell you that. I never knew what became of Kvatch. I wonder if they were triumphant without me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why would your wife betray you?
output: You test my patience with these questions. That is a personal matter, and one I will not discuss.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: When you greeted Serana, it sounded like you hadn't seen her in a long time.
output: Serana and her mother disappeared long ago. I commanded every vampire in the court to look for them, but after centuries of searching without success, I lost hope. In my heart, I know that it was my wife, Valerica, who took my beloved daughter away from me. If I ever see her again, she will pay most dearly for that betrayal.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I heard you mention Serana's mother. What happened to her?
output: Her name was Valerica. She has been gone for so long now, I can only assume she has left this world, one way or another. I will say only that we did not part on good terms.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And if I want to remain a werewolf?
output: I will banish you from this castle. I will spare your life this once, but after that, you are prey.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm a werewolf. What will happen if I accept your gift?
output: Yes, I can smell it on you. The power of my blood will purge that filth and make you whole again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm already a vampire. What more can you offer me?
output: You contracted a disease, perhaps, but you are no true vampire. Accept my gift and I promise that you will learn the difference. Refuse me, and I will banish you from this castle. I will spare your life this once, but after that, you are prey.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to find someone named Florentius.
output: Florentius? Really? I assumed Isran would want nothing to do with him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I find him?
output: Well, that's the thing. We don't know where he is. Haven't seen him in years. I think he had regular contact with the Vigilants, and I know Isran kept track of them... So maybe you could ask Isran if he knows anything? Just keep in mind that he... well, he might not like the idea.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you do here?
output: Whatever is required! I am happy to do whatever is asked of me. I only wish to be useful. Often I take on tasks that Garan or Feran find distasteful, or... beneath them. If I can remain useful, those above me will see fit to keep me here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who is Florentius?
output: He's a priest of Arkay. Well, he was. It's... it's complicated. He's a little eccentric, but we can trust him and we could definitely use his skills.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're worried about what we're up against?
output: Yes. These vampires are a new threat, and a truly deadly one. Gunmar and I agree that we're going to need Florentius to help. Gunmar and I have a lot of work to do here, so we were hoping that maybe you could track him down.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: If I leave the Soul Cairn, can I safely return?
output: As you've been traveling in the Soul Cairn, your body has become attuned to it. Let's just say a tiny part of you rubbed off on it, and in its place, a bit of the Soul Cairn filled the void. You should find no difficulty using the portal any longer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It is done. <Alias=Spouse> has been welcomed into the family.
output: Excellent. I trust he'll find his situation more accommodating, now that he is a member of the family.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Understood.
output: Return to me when your part is done. And may you enjoy your second nuptials.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: I've been performing a little research on the Blood Chalice.  I believe we can prolong its salutary effects if we infuse it with potent vampiric blood.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: The potency of the Blood Chalice is beginning to wane. We must infuse it with more power if we are to keep it's fullest effects.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: I've located additional petrified remains of an elder vampire. Bring them to me, and I'll extend the effects granted by the Blood Chalice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm just here for the Elder Scroll.
output: I see. You're simply here to stop the Tyranny of the Sun, despite the cost to Serana. Nothing else matters.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've been keeping her safe.
output: Coming from one who murders vampires as a trade, I find it hard to believe your intentions are noble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why can't Orthjolf be trusted?
output: He claims to serve loyally, but he really covets the throne. He sees himself in charge someday. His ambition will justify any actions. Put your faith in him, and you will regret it, I promise you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do you serve Lord Harkon?
output: Simple. He says 'kill', I kill. Sometimes he doesn't even have to say it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you doing here?
output: I'm on my way to Markarth to confer with my colleague, Calcelmo. I've no time to stop and chat.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, I don't think so.
output: Then I'll take it from your corpse! Kill him!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, I don't think so.
output: Then I'll take it from your corpse! Kill her!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: Taron Dreth, the world's foremost expert in Dwemer metallurgy. Not that you would know anything about that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I made it.
output: What? You... you found the Forge? The Aetherium Forge?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: Taron Dreth. The world's foremost expert on Dwemer forging techniques. Now answer my question!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You don't trust Vingalmo?
output: No, and if you're smart you won't either. I know he's one of your kind and all, but he's only looking out for himself. You'll think you're best of friends, until you find his fangs in your neck.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You don't trust Vingalmo?
output: Of course not. He's an elf, isn't he? He'll cozy up to you, use his honeyed words to get you to lower your guard, then use you and throw you away when he's done with you. You watch yourself around him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where do the thralls come from?
output: All over Skyrim. It's my job to collect them. I try and keep something for everyone. For every taste, I mean. Sometimes you get one who comes willingly, but most have to be convinced to join us here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You were in the Companions?
output: Aye, I was. Didn't progress very far. Never did care for their attitude, acting like they're better than everyone else. But none of that matters now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can't we inform the Jarl's men of the threat?
output: Alas, the vampire can cloud the minds of those he preys upon. It won't be easy to convince anyone he's other than he appears. The law will require proof that we can't present. And Jarls disapprove of bloodshed they haven't called for themselves. Best not to damage our reputation. Let your actions be as discrete as possible.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is the vampire doing?
output: Vampires enjoy stalking their prey. Passing among us undetected emboldens them. Makes them feel powerful, untouchable. But we'll put a swift end to that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Understood.
output: The light be with you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can I avoid trouble with the law?
output: You must be clever. Find a way not to be caught or accused of murder. You'll figure something out. We must be vigilant and self sufficient if we are to defeat these monsters.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes.
output: Then behold Auri-El's gift, my child. May it light your path as you seek tranquility within the Inner Sanctum.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes.
output: Auri-El bless you, child. For you are a step closer to the Inner Sanctum and everlasting wisdom.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes.
output: Then go forth, child. May the enrichment of Auri-El strengthen your resolve as you undertake your journey to the Inner Sanctum.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes.
output: May the blessings of Auri-El protect you as you climb the road to the Inner Sanctum and final enlightenment.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: She doesn't seem too fond of him.
output: The moment we gave ourselves to Molag Bal, things got really icy between them. They were both drunk with power, and pulling in different directions. Then he found that prophecy, and... that was it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why would a necromancer want to deal with them?
output: Look around you. There are some extremely powerful undead here. Even a necromancer as seasoned as my mother would be willing to spend years trying to gain access to them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you sure Valerica has the Elder Scroll?
output: No, but there's no way she would have left it in Tamriel. She wanted to get it as far away from my father as possible. I can't imagine a better place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why not hide it in the Soul Cairn and then return?
output: Probably to avoid whatever my father would do to her if he could get his hands on her.  Or maybe her plan was to come back, but she was stuck here. We won't know until we find her.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you think we'll meet the Ideal Masters?
output: I don't think anyone's ever met the Ideal Masters. I'm not even sure anyone knows what they look like. They could be underground, flying above us... They might be the ground. I have no idea.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are you feeling after talking to your mother?
output: Relieved... I think. All those things had been building for a while. You have no idea how long I wanted to say that to her.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any soul gem?
output: Well, I think it's specifically the black ones. I don't know if the Soul Cairn takes just any leftovers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does anything live here?
output: Look at this place. Do you think anything would want to live here? The only things that can survive here are the Ideal Masters, the undead and the souls themselves. Well, if you want to call that "living."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know anything about this place?
output: Just what my mother told me. I've also studied a little bit on my own, but there's not much. When something is trapped in a soul gem, and then the energy is used for powering an enchantment, the remnants are sent here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why are they collecting these souls?
output: Lots of theories. Some say they feed on them like I feed on blood. Others think they use them as payment to an even higher power... almost like a currency. A very strange currency. Whatever they're doing with them, they've been harvesting for millennia. No telling how many souls are trapped here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And you were caught in the middle.
output: I was. Honestly, it took me up until now to figure out that my mother was really just as bad as he was. He was obsessed with power. She was obsessed with seeing him fail. It was just so... toxic. Maybe I could have seen this coming. We could all be better off now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Summon them you mean?
output: Exactly. It's a lost art. Most necromancers just raise up whatever bodies are nearby. A simple trick, really. Child's play. But bringing something from the Soul Cairn gives you something much more powerful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And if she doesn't?
output: Then we find out where she hid it. If she's still alive... well, as alive as she was before. Or is now. Or... you know what I mean.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you ever agree to her plan?
output: Look, I loved my father, but when he found that prophecy... that became his life. Everything else, even me and my mother... we just became clutter. I was close with my mother, but she just kept feeding me her opinions of him, and eventually I started believing them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do the necromancers communicate with them?
output: Well, that's usually the trick. It's possible to do it through a simple portal. But to finalize the deal, you have to travel here yourself... and most of them never come back.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've retrieved the <Alias=Item> from <Alias=Dungeon>.
output: Well done! I said you'd return victorious, Arkay wasn't so sure. Wield it bravely.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Understood.
output: Go with the Light.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this artifact?
output: "A powerful warhammer imbued with magic that places warding runes on the ground to obliterate it's wielder's foes." Sounds useful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this artifact?
output: A magical shield that when blocked with, surrounds it's wielder with a holy aura that harms the undead. Might come in handy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this artifact?
output: An axe imbued with magic fueled by the destruction of the unholy. With every victorious blow against an undead creature, its power grows. Arkay warns it's baneful charge abates with each dawn. Something to keep in mind, I suppose.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: I've been pouring over some of the tomes left here in the keep. Interesting stories, indeed. Seems the previous incarnation of the Dawnguard had, at one time, some interesting toys. Arkay and I think it could be a great advantage for us. You should look into retrieving it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any idea what I'll be up against?
output: What's that, Lord? Well, should I tell him?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any idea what I'll be up against?
output: What's that, Lord? Well, should I tell her?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any idea what I'll be up against?
output: Arkay says bandits. Or, wait... no, he says bandits.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any idea what I'll be up against?
output: Falmer, if I understand Arkay correctly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any idea what I'll be up against?
output: Arkay says you'll be facing forsworn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any idea what I'll be up against?
output: Vampires, perhaps?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any idea what I'll be up against?
output: Arkay says you'll be facing warlocks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You mean the Betrayed.
output: Yes. They swarmed the Chantry in vast numbers until we were completely overrun. We never really stood a chance. I assume that the Arch-Curate was corrupted by them when they found a way to breach the Inner Sanctum.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is that why you had retained your sight?
output: Correct. We only numbered perhaps a hundred at the time, so our presence remained a secret to the dwarves and the Nords. Ironically, our undoing came at the hands of our own people.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What turned your people into the Betrayed?
output: I've often asked myself that very same question. The blinding of my race was supposedly accomplished with a toxin. Certainly not enough to devolve them into the sad and twisted beings they've become.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Everyone couldn't have possibly agreed to that.
output: There were splinter groups that resisted the agreement, and even some that sought alternate alliances. But when it was all said and done, those elves were either slaughtered, vanished or gave up and took the dwarves' bargain.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It appears the Nords won.
output: In a manner of speaking. We had always maintained an uneasy alliance with the underground-dwelling dwarves, and when faced with extinction we turned to them for help. Surprisingly, they agreed to protect us but demanded a terrible price... the blinding of our race.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There are others here like you?
output: Vyrthur and myself are the only two snow elves that remain.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Come with me.
output: Let's go.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait here.
output: I'll hang back for a bit, but you're not leaving me behind. This is too important.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Understood.
output: Good. I knew I was sending the right man for the job.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Understood.
output: Good. I knew I was sending the right woman for the job.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So we're pinning the murder on the Dawnguard?
output: Precisely! The people will put pressure on the Dawnguard who are apparently murdering their fellows without provocation. Their focus will be shifted from us, giving us one less nuisance to deal with.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you mean by a "high profile" target?
output: You know, an important member of society. Someone attached to the Jarl's court, a merchant, a bard, a priest, someone with stature. That will make them all more upset to have one of their citizens slain, and under such flimsy pretense.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Understood.
output: Good.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you mean by "discreet."
output: What do you think I mean? Don't make a big scene. Don't get caught. The corpse is to be the message, not the attack.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've killed the Dawnguard masquerading as a <Alias=Target>.
output: Apparently you had blood in your ears when I said not to draw attention to yourself. If I wanted a messy kill I would have said so. But a kill is a kill, and it'll send a message to the Dawnguard, if not exactly the one we wanted.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And the wayshrines?
output: For the time being, they will remain open. If remnants of our kind who escaped the betrayal at the hands of the dwarves exist out there, perhaps they will find this place one day.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The wayshrines are part of the Chantry then?
output: Oh yes. They were an important part of the process here. They represented the steps the Initiates took on the path to total enlightenment. Sadly, the magic used to construct these wonders were lost long before I arrived here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Most snow elves?
output: Our empire had temples to some of the other deities: Trinimac, Syrabane, Jephre and Phynaster rounded out the rest. But those temples paled in comparison to the glory of the Chantry and its wayshrines.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What exactly does it do?
output: That part, I don't know. Once we have it, hopefully it'll be obvious.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does it have to do with the sun?
output: Auriel is one of the elven gods. He's with the rest of them in Aetherius. The way I've heard it, the sun represents the connection from our world to theirs. Supposedly, the bow draws its energy from the sun itself, which it why it shows up in that prophecy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Auriel's Bow?
output: Not much. If you read any history, it shows up from time to time, but it's a hard thing to track. As far as I know, though, it's never been held by a vampire. That would be a new one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's ironic that we're "helping" these priests.
output: Honestly, I don't think they care what a bunch of vampires would do with Auriel's Bow. They're pretty focused on the past. As long as we can get this "Vyrthur" out of the Sanctum, I think they'll be happy to just hand it over.

input: Come with me. (Persuade)
output: Fine. If it will get you to leave me alone. Lead the way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Come with me. (Persuade)
output: You've mistaken me for someone who cares about you and your problems. Find someone else.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How many do you need?
output: Hmmm, I'd say five of them would be enough.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could use help with the crystals around here.
output: Absolutely. I've spent a great deal of time perfecting an extract that increases the potency of soul husks. If you wanted to bring some to me, I'd be happy to provide you some of the extract. It should help resist the draining aura of the crystals.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What if you're wrong?
output: I would gladly accept my fate at their hands if it robs Harkon of victory.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He died by my hand.
output: Then I see nothing preventing my return to Tamriel. Allow me to gather some of my things and I'll head back to Castle Volkihar. And from the bottom of my heart, I thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have we angered the Ideal Masters?
output: Time is almost irrelevant to the Ideal Masters. I doubt very much that they'll hasten to exact revenge for freeing me from the ruins.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And if Harkon were slain?
output: If you think you can accomplish that feat, knowing hundreds before you have tried and failed, then I wish you the best of luck. But if this miracle were to somehow happen, I would gladly return to Tamriel.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Harkon is dead.
output: What? Are you certain?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: When will you return to Tamriel?
output: As I've told you before I'm a Daughter of Coldharbour... offspring to Molag Bal. Knowing that Serana shares that blessing with me, I'm already terrified that Harkon will get his hands on her.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have five soul husks here.
output: Excellent, here you are.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have five soul husks here.
output: Perfect. This should do it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have five soul husks here.
output: Okay. Hope this helps.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have five soul husks here.
output: All right. Here's the extract.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds powerful.
output: That's actually only a fraction of its potential. With Sunhallowed Arrows, you would be able to produce a much more spectacular effect... causing bursts of sunlight to envelop your foes. The sunbursts would certainly hurt anything, but is especially devastating to the undead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will you do then?
output: For the time being I will remain here, on the overlook and continue trying to keep the Sanctum free of the Betrayed. You're always welcome to return here at any time, of course.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can it do?
output: The bow draws its power from Aetherius itself, channeling it through the sun. Therefore, when an arrow is loosed from the bow, it produces a magical effect very similar to being burned by fire.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then I've contributed to your kind's extinction.
output: There's no need for that kind of talk. I said it was possible. It's also quite possible that there are some other isolated conclaves of snow elves nestled elsewhere on Nirn. I'll also assume Vyrthur didn't exactly give you the option to stay your hand.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Auriel's Bow?
output: The bow was said to be carried by Auri-El himself into battle against the forces of Lorkhan in ancient and mythic times. Its craftsmanship has no equal anywhere within Tamriel and possibly beyond.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Vyrthur said something about using blood?
output: Well, using an arrow with the bow that's been dipped in blood may cause it to function differently... corrupting its purpose. That's of course if you're foolish enough to try it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do I obtain Sunhallowed Arrows?
output: I can actually assist you in that regard. If you were to bring me some good quality elven arrows, I could imbue them with the proper incantations and rituals.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do I obtain Sunhallowed Arrows?
output: I'm afraid I'll need elven arrows if you want me to produce the Sunhallowed Arrows, and it seems you're all out of them at the moment.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do I obtain Sunhallowed Arrows?
output: Certainly. I can only do twenty at a time, but I see that won't be a problem in this case.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do I obtain Sunhallowed Arrows?
output: Absolutely. I can only do twenty at a time, so if you want the rest of your arrows blessed, let me know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will happen to the Chantry now?
output: While it would fill me with joy to see the Chantry back to its former glory, that time has long since passed. Now that my brother's dead, it's quite possible I'm the last of our kind.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you all right?
output: I think so. And thanks for asking.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I guess we should head towards your family's home, then.
output: Glad you're finally listening. Come on, let's move.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think we should part ways.
output: I'll be with the Dawnguard if you need me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is it now?
output: Fine, don't worry about it. When we get in, you won't have to babysit about me any more.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't see you with any better ideas.
output: Excuse me? I told you we should go to my family's home.  Maybe you're finally ready to list to me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is it?
output: I wanted to thank you for getting me this far. But after we get in there, I'm going to go my own way for a while.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any idea how to get out of here?
output: Your guess is as good as mine. This place looks pretty different from when I was locked away.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Hiding with the Dawnguard?
output: I doubt my mother would waste her time with those fools. Any other ideas? They probably would have tried to kill her, and that has a way of souring relationships.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How many more?
output: Well, unless my vision's playing tricks, there seems to be some sort of magical effect around you. Seems like we're on the right track. Otherwise, I don't have the faintest idea.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Damn moths! Why are they doing that?
output: Ha ha. They seem quite taken to you now that you're carrying some of the tree bark. I guess we should have seen this coming... Moth Priest, moths... they're apparently related in some way. Couldn't hurt to gather more I suppose.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Got any ideas about the knife?
output: Well, if I were a betting woman, I'd say it's a scraper of some sort. Mother had something similar back home when she was tending the courtyard gardens to scrape moss and fungus off of the trees. That one's far nicer though... almost ceremonial.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The <Alias=Boss> at <Alias=Dungeon> has been dealt with.
output: It may seem cruel that we hold our thin-blooded kin in low esteem. But our needs must come before theirs. You have done well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you mean by "discreet."
output: I hope you comprehend killing better than you comprehend speech. Don't. Get. Caught.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: I've learned the whereabouts of a troublesome Dawnguard member. You will track him down and dispose of him. But please, do be discreet. Our aim isn't to stir the nest, just to skin a rat, reminding them that they are the prey.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have killed the <Alias=Vampire> at <Alias=Dungeon>.
output: Good. I prefer to nip budding problems before they reach full bloom. I trust it wasn't too much of an effort on your part.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've killed the Dawnguard masquerading as a <Alias=Target>.
output: Excellent. I knew I could count on you. That's one less trouble maker to keep an eye on.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've killed the Dawnguard masquerading as a <Alias=Target>.
output: While that's one less trouble maker to keep an eye on, you could have been more discreet in your approach to the problem. I had thought better of you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: A cadre of lesser beasts has become a nuisance, taking too bold an approach to their feeding. The herd is becoming distressed, which makes it more difficult for us to slip in and out undetected. It is time to cull the weak.
