input: What can I do to help?
output: Speak with Florentius. He has something for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: One of the feral brood has joined a group of bandits, presumably with aims to grant the gift to the entire lot of them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: One of the feral brood has joined a group of nercromancers, presumably with aims to grant the gift to the entire lot of them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Now what?
output: The effect around you looks an awful lot like that huge column of light shining on the dais. Let's check that out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Never mind that... it worked!
output: After everything we've been through, it had damn well better work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That felt strange.
output: I could see it in your eyes. You looked about a thousand leagues away.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't worry, I'm fine.
output: I never trusted those damn scrolls. Who knows what those things could have done to you... just look at Dexion.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That was interesting.
output: Are you okay? Almost thought I lost you there... you went white as the snow.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The scrolls gave me its exact location.
output: Then let's get going. I want to get there before my father has a chance to track us down.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's in a place called Darkfall Cave.
output: Then it's almost over. We can finally put an end to this ridiculous prophecy. Where is this "Darkfall Cave?"

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's in a place called Darkfall Cave.
output: Then it's almost over. We can finally rewrite the prophecy as we see fit. Where is this "Darkfall Cave?"

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you join the Dawnguard?
output: Isran is the only one trying to do something about these vampires. I don't much like him, but I can't allow the people of Skyrim to be preyed upon by those monsters.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you join the Dawnguard?
output: I lost two wives to vampires. I will avenge them. It is good to know that I will not have to do it alone. I am glad this Dawnguard exists.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You've worked with Isran before?
output: I have. There was a time, years ago, when we were both members of the Vigilants, and both equally dissatisfied with them. Their hearts are in the right place, of course. But Isran and I were never comfortable. We left together, but that partnership didn't last very long. I didn't agree with some of his methods.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DLC1SoulCairnMerhcantHello
output: Well, look what we have here... someone with flesh on their bones.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the matter with you?
output: Let's just say I sold something to a guy who turned out to work for a whole coven of necromancers. How in the name of Zenithar was I to know the ingredients were phony? Do I look like someone that would double-cross a necromancer?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you join the Dawnguard?
output: Something bad happens, word spreads. More bad things happen, people worry. The more they worry, the more they talk about it. I've been hearing rumors for a bit now. I was glad to find out not only the bad rumors were true.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know where I can find him?
output: Florentius still worked with the Order from time to time. Last I knew, he was headed to Ruunvald. But then, we hadn't heard from anyone there in a few weeks. If he's moved on, perhaps the Vigilants there can tell you where he's gone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does Isran have a problem with him?
output: Isran has a problem with most people, if you haven't yet noticed. No, this was different. He never trusted Florentius, always thought him to be trying to get attention. I can't imagine that opinion has changed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you saying you want to learn more about me?
output: Not at this rate, no.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What about the scroll?
output: The reason I had it... and why I was down there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What about you?
output: The reason I was down there... and why I had the Elder Scroll.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this place?
output: An old jetty where boats would bring supplies to the castle. Once we moved in, it never got used, along with the rest of the undercroft. We'll need to watch our steps inside.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you think this would help? (Give Journal)
output: You've found her journal! Let me take a look at it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Nothing right now.
output: Oh sure, keep pestering me then, by all means.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Heavy armor. (25 husks)
output: This won't stop your soul from getting ripped out, but at least you'll look good when your corpse hits the ground.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: A sword. (25 husks)
output: A wondrous blade... ahhh, never mind. Just take the darn thing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Got anything left?
output: And what exactly are you going to pay me with? Take a look around. Gold doesn't exactly win you any friends around here. Very funny.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So that's how you got here.
output: You got it. Horse, wagon and all. Plopped here without so much as a word. I used to be one of the best traders in High Rock, you know. People would track me down just to see what I had for sale.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Light armor. (25 husks)
output: Well, I hate to see it go, but what am I gonna do with it here anyway?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DLC1SoulCairnMerhcantHello
output: Brought some soul husks or are you wasting my time?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: A battleaxe. (25 husks)
output: I can't believe I'm trading this for some dried up plants. Oh well, a sale's a sale.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did this area used to be?
output: Who knows? It was in shambles when we first got here. My father's never been much for building things, so it just stayed like this. The poor thing living here probably just fell out of favor upstairs.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It sounds like you already didn't like him much.
output: Like I said, we were never very close. Not a lot of father-daughter bonding if you know what I mean. But once we threw our lot in with Molag Bal... people just don't think about their families anymore. "Power takes precedence," he always said.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did you spend a lot of time down here?
output: I liked to explore. My parents almost never let me off the island, so yeah, I poked around down here a lot. It was a little... quieter... back then. Guess a little vampire girl was enough to scare off the rats.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did your mother keep gargoyles here?
output: Not that I ever saw. My mother had a bit of a thing for magical constructs. Not... not what you're thinking. She just found them fascinating.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It sounds like they were both being selfish.
output: Oh, they definitely were.  I just wonder if that meant it was my job to be giving.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It sounds like they were both being selfish.
output: Definitely. You must think my life has been so strange. It sounds like your family wasn't nearly as fractured as mine.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know this place?
output: I had always just assumed that the other tower was completely destroyed inside. My mother kept this a secret, even from me. She must have been up to something she thought was dangerous.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You shouldn't blame yourself.
output: You don't know what it's like, coming from a family like that. Everything eventually tumbles down to you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You shouldn't blame yourself.
output: I know that in my head. But I just can't help feeling bad about... the way things are. Sorry, I know you're trying to help. Thanks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That sounds pretty lonely.
output: It was. But I got used to it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It probably didn't have anything to do with you.
output: That's easy to say, but I definitely didn't help things.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You sound like you were a weird little kid.
output: I was. But I think I turned out ok.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't know, but she must be connected.
output: Why her? What significance does she have? We don't have enough information.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: She just wants to go home.
output: None of this feels right. We need to know more.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: They were trying to free a woman trapped in a crypt.
output: None of this makes any sense. What does she have to do with this?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why is that?
output: The Elder Scrolls vanished from the Imperial City around 175 of this era and have been scattered across Tamriel by forces unknown. If you want to find the remaining scroll, you'll have to consult with someone versed in magical knowledge. Perhaps at the College of Winterhold?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need the Elder Scroll that speaks of dragons.
output: I wish I could help. The scrolls have changed hands so many times, it's impossible to keep track. Normally, I'd send you to the Imperial City in Cyrodiil to seek answers at the Imperial Library, but that avenue no longer exists.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any clues about the other Elder Scroll?
output: Dexion said something about that scroll. What was it... something to do with dragons I think? Maybe we should try asking at the College of Winterhold. Sounds like something they'd know about.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait here.
output: Oh, you're off on your own for a while? All right.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Of course. Hasn't everyone?
output: No.  Don't try and impress me. It only leaves you looking foolish.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've never heard of it.
output: It is a rather well-kept secret.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Not exactly.
output: Damn. Well what do you know?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have news, but I wouldn't call it good.
output: Of course. Why did I suppose differently. Fine, tell me what you know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: They also have an Elder Scroll.
output: They what? And you didn't stop them? You didn't secure the scroll?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The woman was a vampire, and they wanted her back.
output: And so we've delivered her right to them. I should've kept her here until we were certain...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this place?
output: A shrine to Molag Bal, the mighty Daedra Prince who is father to all our kind. Our power is a blessing from him. It is he who first bestowed the gift of the ancient blood upon me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened? How did I get here?
output: My blood is potent. At first, the body is overwhelmed by it. After my bite, you collapsed and fell into a slumber. Now your flesh has acclimated to the new blood that courses through your veins.  I assure you, no harm was done. In truth, your strength surprises me. Not all mortals can withstand my embrace.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready to learn about my new powers.
output: With my guidance you will become a deadly instrument, striking terror in the hearts of mortals wherever you tread. Now, listen to my words and do as I instruct.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not ready yet. Give me more time.
output: You are a guest in this castle at my pleasure. I'll permit you to stay for now, but you're of no use to me like this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I am ready to receive the ancient blood.
output: Good. Do not offend me by losing it again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You made a pact with Molag Bal?
output: In an age long forgotten to history, I ruled as a mighty king. My domain was vast, my riches endless and my power infinite. And yet, as my mortal life neared an end, I faced a seemingly invincible enemy -- my own mortality. I pledged myself to Molag Bal, and in his name I sacrificed a thousand innocents. In reward, he gave everlasting life to myself, my wife and my daughter. And so I have defeated mortality itself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe your mother didn't trust you, either.
output: That's always a possibility. She was almost as obsessed as my father by the time she shut me in. But I can't worry about that now. We need the scroll, and she's our only lead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We can't waste time on cryptic clues.
output: If you have a better lead than this, I'm all ears.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Does Harkon even care about you anymore?
output: You know, I've asked myself the same thing. I thought... I hoped that if he saw me, he might feel something again. But I guess I don't really factor in at this point.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is it between you two?
output: Ever since he decided to make that prophecy his calling, we kind of drifted apart.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have Auriel's Bow.
output: The bow... you have Auriel's Bow! I've heard it described in tales, but I could never have imagined its beauty.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We're not sure, but they have an Elder Scroll.
output: By the Eight... All right. I'll hear out Isran, see if there's anything I can do to help. Where do you expect me to go?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I would guess it came from a daedric lord.
output: Exactly!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I want to hear it.
output: I guess... we kind of have to go way back. To the very beginning. Do you know where vampirism came from?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't know much about it.
output: The first vampire came from Molag Bal. She... was not a willing subject. But she was still the first. Molag Bal is a powerful daedric lord, and his will is made reality.  For those willing to subjugate themselves, he will still bestow the gift, but they must be powerful in their own right before earning his trust.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I admire your devotion.
output: Not many people understand the appeal. You keep surprising me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you all right?
output: I will be. Just give me a little time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you all right?
output: Don't... Just leave me alone for a bit.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you ever think about curing yourself?
output: A cure? Why even think of it that way?  I can't think of any reason I'd want to lose this gift. Especially after what I did to get it. It may have driven my family apart, but I'm still here, and I'm alive. I won't give this up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm a follower of Molag Bal, myself.
output: I have to admit, I'm impressed. I didn't think you had the spirit for it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It sounds like you weren't thinking clearly.
output: I'm not sure it's really your place to judge me. To judge us. My family has its problems, but they're our problems. Let's just... move on from here, ok?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How has it affected your family?
output: Well, you've met most of us. My father's not exactly the most stable, and eventually he drove my mother crazy with him. And it all ended with me being locked underground for who knows how long. It's definitely been a bad thing, on the whole.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you regret becoming a vampire?
output: Nobody's ever asked me that before. I... I don't know. I think... mostly I hate what it's done to my family.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you actually become a vampire, then?
output: The ceremony was... degrading. Let's not revisit that.  But we all took part in it. Not really wholesome family activity, but I guess it's something you do when you give yourselves to a daedric lord.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The daedric princes disgust me.
output: I know, I know, but just... anyway. Molag Bal is the original source of vampirism, and still grants it to his more worthy followers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Molag Bal created the first vampire.
output: Precisely.  Looks like you know your daedra. What you might not know is that for the most devoted and impressive followers, Molag Bal will give the gift anew, in its pure form.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Spare me the details.
output: The short version is that my parents and I... we were followers of Molag Bal.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: In Castle Volkihar?
output: Wait... that almost makes sense! All of the ingredients for our potions came from there. She used to say that my father couldn't stand the place. Too... peaceful. I used to help my mother tend a garden in the courtyard here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: She's asking me to take her home, to some castle.
output: I won't lie - if this were any other situation, I'd put her down just on the chance she might be a vampire. But this is something different. I'd say do what she wants. Take her home, and see who else is in this castle.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It seems they were looking for a woman who was sealed in a crypt.
output: That doesn't make much sense. Where is this woman? Who is she?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you have against the Vigilants?
output: Isn't it obvious? They're soft, the lot of them. Totally unprepared for any real threat. And yet I was the one ridiculed for trying to be ready for anything. "Too extreme", they called me. Well, that doesn't seem to have worked out in their favor, now has it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've brought the Elder Scrolls.
output: I'm afraid I won't be able to help you with the scrolls any longer, milady. Please, don't be angry with me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're blind!
output: Oh please, milady. Please... forgive me!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Go on.
output: Oh thank you, milady. Thank you!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: The Dawnguard will, no doubt, soon become even more of a nuisance now that Auriel's Bow has been recovered. We need to strike a crippling blow against them before they muster more men against us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can I do to help?
output: The Dawnguard will want the Bow, and they will fight us, hard, to get it. We should strike them first before they can muster a larger force.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've killed the Dawnguard leaders.
output: Excellent. That should prevent the problem from escalating. Though they are a rebellious and determined lot. While you've severed the snake's head, the body will likely writhe a while longer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've killed the Dawnguard leaders.
output: Good. That should slow them down. But, we haven't gotten rid of them completely. A body can rattle around confused long after it's head's been severed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Understood.
output: Good. They've holed up in an abandoned fort in the Reach. Killing their leaders should discourage them from an out and out war with us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Understood.
output: Good. They've holed up in an abandoned fort in the Reach. Kill their leaders. That should put a stop to a full out war.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We should check back with Isran.
output: I don't even know who that is...  And frankly, I need to get home to figure out what's happening.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We should check back with Isran.
output: Yes, he definitely sounds like he knows what to do. If you want to waste your time, that's fine. But I've got my own destination in mind. Maybe you could help me get there when you're done?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We should check back with Isran.
output: Maybe he knows what's going on. Look, I'm happy to help you run any errands you need to, but I've got my own destination. Could you help me get there whenever we're done?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm only here to kill you.
output: I see. Interesting that you can set aside your morals when it suits you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We need your help, Isran.
output: Indeed. The day hasn't been won while Harkon still walks Tamriel. But what of Serana? Can she be trusted to lift a blade against her own kind? Her own family?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: This is about more than killing vampires.
output: Ah, of course. The prophecy. You've come here to stop me from taking Auriel's Bow and shrouding the world in darkness.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I would never use Serana like that.
output: The vampire is eternal, and with immortality comes the revelation that these bonds never endure... it's fleeting, momentary at best.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We have the bow, he'll listen to us.
output: Have you been paying attention to everything that's happened? He'll betray us the second our backs are turned.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's run as far from him as we can.
output: There's nowhere to run. And I'm certainly not moving in with my mother, if that's what your implying.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, I'm here to prevent our annihilation.
output: Ah, I see you've been speaking to Valerica and she's convinced you that eternal night will plunge us into war with daytime dwellers. If only it were so. With the world in shadow, we would never tire, never weaken... more than a match for their pitiful armies.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What now, Isran?
output: It's time we take the fight to their door. Gather your things and rest well, my friend. We meet outside Castle Volkihar.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I trust her to do the right thing.
output: I suppose that's as much as I can hope for. Let me address the Dawnguard, and then we'll be off. The men deserve to know that we've finally gained the upper hand.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The bow belongs to me now.
output: Finally, a trace of honesty in our little conversation. How does it feel to hold the fate of the vampire in your grasp. Exhilarating, isn't it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then let's face him, together.
output: If we head back to the castle and kick the front door in, we're going to be knee-deep in his friends. Let's head back to Isran and let him see what we've got first. I'm betting he'll lend us a sword or two.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then we kill him, before he kills us.
output: I keep thinking that there's got to be another way, but he'll turn on us both the moment he gets the chance.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I would never harm Serana. She's too important to me.
output: Then my daughter is truly lost. She died the moment she accepted a mortal into her life.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe we can reason with him.
output: Have you been paying attention? It's obvious my father's well beyond reason.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: If we do, he'll have to die.
output: I've been thinking about this for a long time. It's... it's not easy. But I don't think we have much of a choice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Never.
output: Very well then, you leave me no choice!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We should honor our agreement with him.
output: Are you out of your mind? The moment you hand over the bow your usefulness ends. He'll kill you and then he'll take my blood for the damn prophecy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then let's face him, together.
output: Thank you. Somehow I knew you'd understand.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Enough of this!
output: Yes, quite. I'm growing weary of speaking to you and my traitorous daughter. I'll give you a single chance to turn over the bow to me. There will not be a second.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You said something happened to the Hall of Vigilants?
output: Yes. By destroying it, the vampires hoped to cripple our order's activities in Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DLC1SoulCairnMerhcantHello
output: What do you want now?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There must be something you want.
output: I'll tell you what. I appreciate what you're trying to do, so I'll play along. The only thing I see around here in abundance are soul husks. You know, those ugly fungus-looking things growing out of the ground. Bring me say... twenty-five of them, and you can rummage through what was left on my cart.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Got anything left to sell?
output: I might be just a soul now, but I'm still not going to give my stuff away. Bring me at least twenty-five husks and then we'll talk.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Got anything left to sell?
output: Sure, got plenty. What am I gonna' do with it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Got anything left to sell?
output: Well, I've been so busy, I dunno. What are you, kidding me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Got anything left to sell?
output: Of course I do. What do you want?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: A spell tome. (25 husks)
output: Sure. Here you go. Can't understand a word of it, maybe it will do you some good.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Fair enough. What do you have?
output: Odds and ends I've gathered over the years. Well, used to gather before all of this nonsense happened to me. Tell me what you're looking for and maybe we can make a deal... if you have the husks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Nothing right now.
output: No husks, no sale. Guess you have some scavenging to do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any interest in ancient falmer tomes?
output: Well, well. I haven't seen one of these beauties in a long time. A rare find in the original falmer language. You're damn right I'm interested. Question is, are you selling?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm going to hold onto it.
output: If you're holding out for more gold, it's never going to happen.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Deal. (Give Book)
output: Here you go.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let me think about it.
output: Suit yourself. I'm not going anywhere.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have another ancient falmer tome.
output: My offer is still a thousand. Did you want to sell?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Depends how much you're paying.
output: Well, considering no one else in Skyrim would buy something they couldn't possibly read, I'd say you don't have much of a choice. Tell you what, you bring me books like this, and I'll pay a thousand gold each. I'll even throw in a translated edition I have for free. Interested?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: There are some things I want to ask you about.
output: You have earned my trust, so I will share what I can.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's all I wanted to ask.
output: Very well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DialogueFerrySystemIdle
output: Windhelm eh? City of kings, they say. Hope you packed warm though.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DialogueFerrySystemIdle
output: Ah, Solitude. Best port in Skyrim. You should try the Spiced Mead while you're there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DialogueFerrySystemIdle
output: Dawnstar doesn't have much of a port, but the miners say its got rich ore veins.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: DialogueFerrySystemIdle
output: They say anyone who steps foot on that island will meet an early death... hope you know what you're doing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think we should part ways.
output: Good luck out there. Hopefully I'll see you again soon.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think we should part ways.
output: I'm surprised you think you can manage without me, but it's your choice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think we should part ways.
output: Oh. All right. Goodbye, then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think we should part ways.
output: You can't get rid of me that easily.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think we should part ways.
output: And go where? You can't just leave me alone whenever you feel like it. I'm coming with you, like it or not.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think we should part ways.
output: I disagree.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait here.
output: If you think I'm going to let you have all the fun, you're crazy. I'll let you lead ahead, but I'll be keeping an eye on you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait here.
output: Sorry, I'm not that easy to get rid of. If you want to run ahead, I won't stop you, but I'll be following.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait here.
output: I'll be here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Come with me.
output: Three's a crowd. Get rid of your other friend, and I'm yours.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Come with me.
output: Thought you'd never ask.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Come with me.
output: Whenever you're ready.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is it normal for Moth Priests to go blind?
output: Sadly, yes. It's the inevitable fate we agree to pursue when reading the Elder Scrolls. It generally doesn't occur until a Moth Priest is in his latter years, but in my case I simply wasn't preparing myself properly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then how do I even stand a chance?
output: You've come this far, and you've found several Elder Scrolls. Whether you believe it or not, the scrolls have a mind of their own. If they didn't want you to find them, they wouldn't allow it. Because of this, I strongly believe you were meant to hear the ancestral chorus. Only one way to find out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How does that help the Moth Priest?
output: By having the Ancestor Moths close to the Moth Priest, they can utilize the conduit and share the moth's augury. Only the most resilient of priests can do it this way... it takes years of practice to interpret the harmony.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for someone named Miraak.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No thanks. That sounds like a bad idea.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: Oh, nothing too dangerous. At least I think it will. Probably. Almost certainly. Of course, you never can tell. You would fight longer, feel stronger, that sort of thing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have the black book.
output: Excellent! Of course, I'm sure you can handle yourself. Of course you can. Of course. I'll just make a copy for myself. It's far too dangerous to carry the real book around. Now, take this for your efforts, and we'll call the matter closed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you found any other black books?
output: Yes. Hermaeus Mora is devious, but then so am I. Now, it's only a rumor of a whisper of a conjecture. But I think this is the place. Now, hurry. That book might contain the final secrets of Xarxes, for all we know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What were those things?
output: Some of the Redoran Guard have taken to calling them "ash spawn." Me? I don't care what they're called... all I know is they're a danger to Raven Rock and they need to be stopped.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do we get the book out of its case?
output: It won't be easy. The whole lower part of the city is flooded, which has shut down the boilers which supply steam to the reading room. If we can restore the steam supply, I'm certain I can open the book's protective case.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where are we headed?
output: The book is housed in the main dome. I sealed the door the last time I was here, as a precaution against thieves and other meddlers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your spell made me weaker once I got wet!
output: Wet, you say? I suppose... yes, I can see how that would have inverted the tether. Unfortunate. Couldn't you simply avoid water? No, no, that won't do. Can't have you forgo bathing... The ashlands can leave one a bit pungent and it's, eh, obvious you've been through them. Here, I'll just remove it. Here's a bit of coin. Should help mitigate your inconvenience.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who was Azra Nightwielder?
output: He was the original shadowmage. His advances in magic are legendary. Less well known is that he was also a pioneer in the field of enchanting staffs. Every staff of his that I have uncovered has led me to greater understanding. Today we would consider his techniques rudimentary, but the genius is still evident.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I help with your research?
output: You see, I'm a collector. Of staffs. Magical staffs. In particular, those made by Azra Nightwielder.  Through some divinations, I believe I've located one. If you retrieve it, I'll give you a staff of my own making. Perhaps later. For now I have a slightly more personal request. Nightwielder's creations don't really hold up in comparison to what can be made today, but they have a sentimental value for me. You understand.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do you think the attacks are from the Attius Farm?
output: I don't. All I know is that the ash spawn are coming from this direction, so this is as good a place to start as anywhere else. Good thing the farm's been abandoned for a long time. I'd hate to see what they would do to an unarmed farmer and his family.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could lend you a hand... for a price.
output: Hmm. I think I could talk the councilor into paying you, and I could use an extra pair of hands.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I discovered this note on one of the ash spawn.
output: This is strange. The note says it's from General Falx Carius, but that's impossible.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You suspect there's a motivation to their attacks?
output: Exactly. Something has to be directing them against us and we need to find out who, or what it is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Very well. Where do I begin?
output: We were searching the farm when the ash spawn ambushed us. Have a look around and see if you can turn up anything useful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How often do they attack?
output: We've had two other assaults on the Bulwark at different spots on the wall. I know it sounds crazy, but it's almost like they're becoming more organized and probing it for weaknesses.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are these "ash spawn?"
output: They started attacking the Bulwark a few weeks ago. My men were able to kill them, but they keep coming back. No one knows really. Superstitious folk say they're the risen forms of those that died long ago, but I'm not so certain.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd be glad to lend you a hand.
output: Good, I can use all the help I can get.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think I'll pass for now.
output: Very well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did that bring you to this old farm?
output: I was going to search for clues that might lead me to wherever they're coming from. I know it isn't the best place to start, but we know they've been coming from this direction.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, I'll lend a hand.
output: Finally. We were searching the farm when the ash spawn ambushed us. Have a look around and see if you can turn up anything useful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want me to do?
output: If General Carius is still alive, there must be something keeping him that way. I need you to head out to Fort Frostmoth and check it out. I'm going to head back to Raven Rock and prepare the men for further assaults.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you still having issues with the ash spawn?
output: I am. Have you reconsidered?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Impossible? Why?
output: Well, Carius was the Imperial garrison commander at Fort Frostmoth, but he died over 200 years ago when the Red Mountain leveled the place. There's no way he could still be alive.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not interested.
output: Suit yourself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's done.
output: What news do you bring from Fort Frostmoth?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Seems like a waste of time to me.
output: It's easy to criticize when you're just a visitor here. Since you're brimming with self-confidence, maybe you'd care to take over for me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I examined the Briarheart warrior.
output: Oh have you? Well, let me just extract those memories and I'll see if you found anything useful. Here, you deserve a bit of reward for your efforts... that was a lengthy trip for you, I'm sure! I promise that any unrelated memories I run across will be kept in the strictest of confidences.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this building?
output: This is a Telvanni tower. It's my citadel, grown from the spores of the giant fungus trees found in Morrowind. Back in the homeland, there are other Telvanni wizards that have them as well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is a heart stone?
output: When Red Mountain erupted almost two hundred years ago, it flung ash and rocks for hundreds of miles. Among the debris were heart stones. Even two centuries later, they still smolder with the heat of the mountain. These are the molten rocks that lay next to the Heart of Lorkhan for millennia. Some vestige of its power must have seeped into them. I do know that heart stones sometimes raise ash spawn from the bits of bone buried in the nearby ash.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a heart stone.
output: Excellent. I'll take it. Here. Have some septims.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do Briarhearts have to do with Heart Stones?
output: Well, I'm hoping to do something similar... if I could connect a living being to the forces of the Red Mountain well... that would be formidable. I've done some experiments in this area, but, well, my test subjects are far too fragile. I'm hoping to learn some of the Briarheart techniques, their methods. I would venture out myself, but long voyages and dangerous risks are precisely what people like you are for.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I help with your research?
output: I'm running low on heart stones. If you have any with you, I'll buy one. Otherwise, I can tell you where you might find one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I find a Briarheart warrior?
output: The Forsworn live in the hills on the western edge of Skyrim. From there, you're on your own. I'm given to understand that they are not difficult to find, if you gather my inference.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've got Azra's staff.
output: You didn't have to speak a word. I could sense it the moment you came in. You've proven your worth, and I'm as good as my word. Take this staff from my personal collection. I think you'll find it useful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What about them?
output: They are fierce warriors of the Forsworn tribes. They actually remove their own hearts, and replace them with large briar seeds. It puts their lifesparks in direct connection to the natural forces. I need you to examine one of them. Just investigate as much as you can.  I'm going to put this memory trace spell on you, so you won't have to worry about taking notes. I doubt you could know what was important anyway.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did you learn from the Briarheart?
output: The connecting soul thread is knotted three times, once for the heart, once for the spirit, and once for the body. The knot gives the connection a strength that may be the key that I've been looking for.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How is Drovas working out?
output: The man makes a dreadful cup of canis root tea. However, he seems to run the place well enough. Oh. Were you fishing for a compliment? A sign of gratitude? Don't waste your time. Those things are for the weak and foolish.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there a problem?
output: I've been having difficulties with my heart stone experiments. Have you heard of the Briarhearts?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there a problem?
output: Oh yes. You rather rudely walked away. As I was saying then, have you heard of the Briarhearts?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, I came here to learn Miraak's secrets.
output: All that he knows he learned from me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I will do as you command, my lord.
output: Yes, I know. And then Miraak's power will be yours as well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: I am Hermaeus Mora, the Gardener of Men, knower of the unknown, master of fates. You stand in my realm, mortal.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What if the Skaal refuse to give up their secrets?
output: My servant Miraak would have found a way to bring me what I want. So will you, if you wish to surpass him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I will talk to the Skaal and bring you their secrets.
output: I know you will. And then I will give you the knowledge that you seek.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So what's your price for the final Word of Power?
output: Knowledge for knowledge.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you want of me, my lord?
output: Your progress since obtaining my Oghma Infinium has been rapid. And now, I find you here, following in my servant Miraak's footsteps. You also are Dragonborn. You also seek to learn how to bend the world to your will.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me what you want, my lord, and I will bring it to you.
output: You please me, champion. Your loyalty will be richly rewarded.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't need your help. I'll learn Miraak's secrets on my own.
output: No. Look around you. You have done nothing here on your own. You could spend a hundred lifetimes searching my library, and you will never find what you seek.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't worry, I was just leaving.
output: No. Not yet. I have watched your progress through my realm with growing interest. You are following in the footsteps of my servant Miraak. Like him, you are Dragonborn, and seek the power that is your birthright.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I won't serve you, monster. I just want to defeat Miraak.
output: You will serve me, willing or not. All who seek after the secrets of the world are my servants.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He must have been someone important.
output: Indeed. I knew that the Dragon Priests were thought to have been powerful men of great will, but I had no idea. Well, I suppose I've seen everything I came for, and you kept up your end of the bargain. I promised payment, and here it is. Now I think I'll spend some more time studying this word wall. What a book this will make!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Somehow, reading this book took me to where he was.
output: This is a dangerous thing, then. We should return to my village, and show this to my father. Perhaps Storn can make sense of what is going on.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not really sure. I saw Miraak on a dragon.
output: Where? Where is he? Can we reach him? Can we kill him?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: This Miraak tried to have me killed.
output: Then you and I both have reason to see what lies beneath us. Let us go. There is nothing more I can do here. The Tree Stone and my friends are beyond my help for now. We need to find a way into the temple below.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Save them from what?
output: I am unsure. Something has taken control of most of the people of Solstheim. It makes them forget themselves, and work on these horrible creations that corrupt the Stones, the very land itself. My father Storn, our shaman, says Miraak has returned to Solstheim, but that is impossible.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: I am Frea of the Skaal. I am here to either save my people, or avenge them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have the ash sample.
output: Well done. Here are some septims for your troubles. If you come back in a day or two I should have the spell worked out. You can buy it from Talvas.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I help with your research?
output: Hmm. I do have a new spell I'm working on. I hope to be able to conjure ash spawn. If I could get a sample of ash from an ash spawn, that would be quite useful. I've made this special tool that will extract... well, you don't need to know the details. Just go harvest a sample. Of course, the creature will have to be dead first, but I trust that's something you can... bring about.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That sounds a little too risky.
output: That's unfortunate. I'll have to use Talvas again, and he's a bit of a screamer. Although... maybe this could solve two problems...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did you come here from Morrowind?
output: Yes. That was a lifetime ago. I was just a young girl when Red Mountain erupted. Master Neloth was already old. My mother put me on a boat to Skyrim. The last time I ever saw her, she was standing on the dock as my ship sailed away.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I suppose so.
output: Excellent. If this works, I'll prepare a version that you can cast yourself, if you ever wish to inflict... er, study silence.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I help with your research?
output: Well, I believe I've discovered a new form of silence. Some philosophers postulate seven orders of silence, but I believe there's an eighth. What do you say? If you allow me, I'd like to envelop you in the eighth form, to study the mental effects.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Telvanni? What are the Telvanni?
output: Together we form House Telvanni, one of the great houses of Morrowind. The great houses rule what is left of our once proud nation. The Telvanni are the master wizards of Morrowind. The greatest of us grow magical towers like this one from the mighty fungus trees.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think you owe me for that spell.
output: I suppose I do. It's too bad it wore off so quickly though. Unfortunately you don't appear to be suffering from any side effects. Anyway, take this for your time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The book was right where you said it would be.
output: In any case, this is truly amazing. I think I can adapt this into a sort of whirlwind vortex energy. Yes, yes. I'll write it out, and you can pick up a copy from Talvas in a few days. In the mean time, take this for helping me. Perhaps this particular source was worth more than I thought he was. Pity.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I help with your research?
output: Can you? Of course you can. What took you so long to ask? I've been trying to adapt Redguard magic to the ash. I think the key concept I'm missing is recorded in Afa-Saryat's book, Wind and Sand. I have some associates and correspondents who find things for me. One of them has a credible rumor on where this book might be. And I'd like you to find the truth of the matter.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where were they headed?
output: South and west. If your road takes you that way, perhaps you could search for any sign of Baldor. The Skaal would be grateful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did anything unusual happen around the time of his disappearance?
output: Hm, I do not remember Baldor acting strangely. Although, now that you ask, I did see something in the woods on the day he disappeared. I saw two elves in the far distance, dragging something behind them. Hunters often visit our lands, so I thought little of it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's missing?
output: It is Baldor Iron-Shaper. As our only smith, Baldor is very important to the village.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How were Rieklings able to overpower you?
output: With tenacity and numbers. Didn't help that we'd grown a little too comfortable up there. Too much mead. Too many stories. Too few battles.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I can't let you lead Thirsk.
output: I was afraid you might say that. Well, looks as though I'll have to prove my mettle against you now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll keep this quiet.
output: Good. See that you do. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a hall to lead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You'll go against Hrothmund's wishes?
output: Look what's happened to us so far under his watchful eye. He gave his blessing to all the leaders who brought us to this point. Anyway, he's dead and we're alive. It's time to begin a new tradition for Thirsk. And I'm going to do that. All I need is for you to back me up. You don't even need to lie... just don't tell anyone else what you heard here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why don't you go on ahead.
output: All right, then. I'll be waiting there whenever your honor wakes you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd be honored.
output: Well let's not waste time talking about it, then!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where are you going?
output: To Hrothmund's Barrow! I need to get his blessing again before we take up residence here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's next?
output: Ah! That was almost... exhilarating. How are you feeling?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your what?
output: My second! If we're going to take up residence here again, I need to get the blessing of Hrothmund again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you going to do now?
output: The only thing I can do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's going on here?
output: Well, look who's back. You ready to finally help us take out those Rieklings?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That was a little more than I expected.
output: Oh, come on now. I'm going to need you to perk up if you're going to come with me as my second.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What if you had one extra warrior?
output: Are you... offering to help? Some new blood should be enough to rouse these layabouts to actually fight again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are you feeling about that?
output: Ashamed. But I guess that was the point.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't think I can help you right now.
output: You need to either help us or stop coming around here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That was easy.
output: Good to hear! In fact... that's just the spirit I'll need from my second. Do you want to come with me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't know yet what he wanted. I left Apocrypha before I found out.
output: You ducked out of the middle of a conversation with old Mora himself? Mighty impertinent of you! And, since you need secrets that only Hermaeus Mora knows, it seems like a rather foolish thing to do. But I'm sure you know best.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He wants the "secrets of the Skaal" in exchange for teaching me the third Word.
output: Hmph. What secrets could they have worth keeping from old Mora? Sounds like a bargain to me. Hermaeus Mora learns some fascinating new ways to skin a horker, and you become the second most powerful Dragonborn that ever lived.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I learned the second Word of the Bend Will Shout.
output: No wonder the Dwemer were so interested in that book. It was indeed one that Miraak used to advance his power as Dragonborn. But I assume there's some bad news. It would be unlike Hermaeus Mora to allow anyone to gain such knowledge without exacting a price.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found myself in another place.
output: That's a fairly common experience, at least for those who remain coherent enough to report what they've seen. You were in Apocrypha. Or at least your consciousness was - your body remained here of course. You should read the book again until you reach what appears to be the "end" - then you will have fully understood the knowledge it contains.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I talked to Hermaeus Mora.
output: You're still acting surprisingly sane, too. What did he have to say? He must have wanted something from you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I talked to Hermaeus Mora.
output: What happened? What did you see? Different people have very different experiences when reading these books.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I talked to Hermaeus Mora.
output: Did you actually learn what you needed to know by reading that Black Book?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I spoke to Hermaeus Mora. He asked for the "secrets of the Skaal."
output: The Tree Stone is still corrupted... the land is still out of balance. But with the other five restored... it may be enough. It will have to be.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I hope you know what you're doing. (Give book)
output: That is my hope as well. I am trusting that you will make this sacrifice worthwhile.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you need?
output: Give me the book. I will read it, and speak to old Herma-Mora myself. I will make sure he lives up to his part of the bargain.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are the "secrets of the Skaal"?
output: Ancient lore, handed down from shaman to shaman since the All-Maker first gave Solstheim to the Skaal. How to talk to the wind, how to listen to the earth - these are our secrets. Nothing of power or mastery.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You mean you'll give him what he wants?
output: As shaman, it is my duty to guard these secrets, but also to decide when it is necessary to give them up. I believe that time is now. If I am wrong, may my ancestors forgive me. Yes. The Skaal also tell of the day when we must finally give up our secrets. When Herma-Mora finally wins.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I find this Ancarion?
output: They have a ship. They took me there and showed me the map. You will find it on the northern coast of the island. Please, do not let Ancarion make his weapons. Kill him or let him live, but take the map from him. It belongs with the Skaal.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Stalhrim? What's that?
output: Enchanted ice as hard as iron and cold as death. Stalhrim can be forged into deadly weapons, but the art is known only to smiths of the Skaal.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you hurt badly? Do you need healing?
output: No, no, my wounds are not serious. I don't think the elves were trying to harm me. Perhaps they intended to frighten me. At worst, I have a few bruises to show for my ordeal.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What brings you out here?
output: We brought ourselves out here, along with our shame.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, and I've brought you the map to the Stalhrim source.
output: I know you faced great danger to bring this map to me. There are no words to tell how glad my heart is. Thank you, brave one. I name you friend of the Skaal, and I will trust you with the knowledge of forging Stalhrim. If you bring Stalhrim here to my forge, you can use my tools to make what you will from it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What kind of a person should I look for?
output: Hmm. Excellent question.   Once word gets out, there will be a lot of people to choose from. Someone with a brilliant mind and robust physique that is blindly obedient would be ideal. Oh, and they need to know how to brew tea. Ulves always waters it down.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You can't just order me around.
output: Well, somebody needs to get me a new steward. It might as well be you. But if you don't want to help a master wizard of House Telvanni, possibly earning his favor, you're a fool.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Of course, Master Neloth. As you command.
output: Finally. Someone who recognizes my importance around here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Hey, I'm not your servant.
output: Obviously not, or you would have a cup of tea in your hands. I supposed you want to be asked nicely. Very well. Please, oh hero of Skyrim. Please find Varona. I shall be ever so grateful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have some things to sell.
output: I'm sure we can strike a bargain.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have some things to sell.
output: Haggling with you can be so...entertaining.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have some things to sell.
output: Let's make a deal.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have some things to sell.
output: I can hardly wait.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why don't you just make your own tea?
output: What? Make my own tea? I am a master wizard of the House Telvanni. Other people make tea for me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found what you wanted.
output: It's a bit dried up, but it will do. Here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found what you wanted.
output: A bit ripe, isn't it? Here. Take this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found what you wanted.
output: Nasty bitches, aren't they? Here's your fee.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found what you wanted.
output: Not bad for an amateur? Take this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found what you wanted.
output: You could have cleaned it. It's still bloody. Here's your money.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found what you wanted.
output: Hmm. Better than average quality. I'll take it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you need any help?
output: Well, I could use a daedra heart. Can't grow that in my garden.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you need any help?
output: Hmm. I'm running out of giant toes. I'll pay extra for one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you need any help?
output: As a matter of fact, I need a hagraven claw. I'll pay extra if you find one.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you need any help?
output: How about some vampire dust? Bring me some of that and I'll pay handsomely.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you need any help?
output: You got a briarheart? That's what I really need. Neloth keeps taking all of mine.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you need any help?
output: You find some void salts and you bring them to me. I'll beat anyone else's price.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you saying you want my help?
output: Bilgemuck run. Prize beast, run. You bring, he follow you. Yes? Fool tribe-kin, chase away. Bilgemuck fear.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you learn to talk?
output: Chief smart. Most Riekling dumb but chief smart.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is going on here?
output: We family. We strong, you stronger.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Bilgemuck is an animal of some kind? And you want it back?
output: Bilgemuck prize beast. You find, he follow. Bilgemuck love meat. Give meat, he follow. You go.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm sorry, this is all just too strange for me.
output: No strange. Strong. You strong, make us stronger. Help tribe-kin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I suspect Tilisu Severin is the culprit.
output: Tilisu? Are you sure?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why haven't you told Adril about this?
output: What makes you think I haven't? Any time Adril and the Redoran Guard made a move, the Ulens must have been one step ahead and didn't show up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd prefer not to get involved.
output: Without Councilor Morvayn, Raven Rock has no future. Keep that in mind next time you decide to help or not.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He's no longer a threat.
output: Then... it's finally over. What of the Redoran Guard I sent to assist you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do I get them to do that?
output: There's an Ulen Ancestral Tomb near the Temple. Someone's been leaving ash yam offerings on the altar inside. If you were to wait inside for whomever that is, I'm betting they'll have some of the answers you're looking for.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened to House Hlaalu as a result?
output: They had welcomed the Empire with open arms, and benefited from it. When everything was said and done, they were no longer recognized as a Great House and were dismissed from the Council.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about House Hlaalu?
output: Traitors. The lot of them. Their collaboration with the Empire may have given them unrivaled political and economic strength, but their hearts weren't with the Dunmer people.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He ordered the execution. It's on his head... not yours.
output: Now that's just ridiculous! As second councilor, it's my responsibility to protect Councilor Morvayn from harm.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What if they try to stop me?
output: If you have the evidence and it places your life in peril, I would expect you to do whatever you must to keep yourself alive. Here, this key should open the front door of the manor in case they've locked it. Good luck.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll let you get to it then.
output: Oh, no bother. We all have a right to be here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why don't you ask them to investigate?
output: Most of my contacts live leagues away from Solstheim. Sending the occasional message back and forth is all we can manage, and sometimes takes months or more to arrive. However, any information we can glean in times like this I consider vital to House Redoran's survival.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You feel an attack on the councilor is imminent.
output: I do. I've received some information from my sources that there could be elements of Ulen's house, House Hlaalu, already in Raven Rock.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Nothing unusual about them at all?
output: People have mentioned it's a bit odd about how close in age Mirri appears to be to her father, but that's hardly a cause for alarm. Just make sure that you find solid evidence. If I accuse them without it, I'll be the laughingstock of the colony.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me why you're really here.
output: What do you mean? I thought I was clear. I'm simply honoring a fellow departed Dunmer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did Vilur get caught?
output: He underestimated the Redoran Guard. They were organized and brought a swift end to the coup. Vilur tried to run, but he was caught by Captain Veleth himself. Vilur Ulen was executed a short time later and his remains placed in the Ulen Ancestral Tomb.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You have a better idea?
output: Actually, I do. If you want to catch those slippery slaughterfish, you need to let them come to you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You mentioned your "sources?"
output: I maintain a few contacts in other Dunmer settlements across Tamriel. Most hail from House Redoran, but there are a few from other houses.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You sound paranoid.
output: As second councilor, it's my responsibility to explore the possibility of any threat, no matter how paranoid it might seem.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: A benefit? How?
output: They're quite wealthy and they've been quite generous by sharing their fortune with the community. They've contributed coin, food, supplies... even helped repair a few of the buildings in town with their own hands.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You think he's mistaken?
output: No, I just think he's going about this the wrong way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Well, good luck with that.
output: Before you dismiss this entirely, I was hoping you might be able to lend a hand by investigating on the councilor's behalf.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your concern seems justified.
output: It may be justified, but it certainly isn't appreciated. Councilor Morvayn simply feels that I'm being paranoid.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can you tell me more about the Severin family?
output: Tilisu is wife to the family patriarch, Vendil. They have a single child, a daughter named Mirri. They arrived here ten years ago, and have been nothing but a benefit to Raven Rock ever since.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're lying. You're from House Hlaalu!
output: What kind of nonsense is that!? I'm simply honoring a fellow departed Dunmer, and you hurl baseless accusations at me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Vilur did this alone?
output: He arrived alone, but spread enough coin around to start changing people's minds. Half the bloody town joined his side. Can you believe that?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What will you do?
output: Summoning you here was part of my plan. I was hoping you'd be interested in investigating for me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why would the Ulens want him dead?
output: It's a private matter. Let's just say they seek revenge for the execution of one of their own... ordered by Councilor Morvayn himself. The problem is I don't have any solid proof that anyone from House Hlaalu is hidden among us... only my suspicions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You aren't an Ulen.
output: Since there aren't any Ulens left on this island, I've taken it upon myself to leave the traditional offering in their stead.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did Councilor Morvayn execute an Ulen?
output: Back in 95, Vilur Ulen came to Raven Rock with a plan to take over our town. The fetcher thought he could stir up the locals and use them against the Redoran Guard and then murder Councilor Morvayn when we weren't looking.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Adril Arano said you might be able to help me.
output: Well, well. Adril's got himself a spy, does he? Azura knows he needs all the help he can get. He's been chasing the Ulens for years now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How can I help?
output: I had a feeling you'd be willing to listen to me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So go search their house.
output: I'm not kicking down anyone's door until I have solid evidence in hand. If you're wrong about Tilisu, things would quickly go downhill around here and the real culprits might slip away. I can't afford for that to happen.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do Dunmer leave ash yams in their tombs?
output: When a Dunmer is laid to rest, the body is burned and returned to the ashen soil. Since the ash yam is born of the very same soil, it represents rebirth and renewal... the fact that life ends and begins anew.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where do I begin?
output: The best place to start would be Geldis Sadri over at the Retching Netch Cornerclub. If he provides you any leads, check them out before bringing them to my attention. I can't afford to make any mistakes. I need you to start out by being my eyes and ears... search Raven Rock and see if you can root out these traitors.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why haven't you acted on the information?
output: Raven Rock is a small settlement, so it's hard to accomplish anything in secret. If any of them is from House Hlaalu, I wouldn't be able to make a move without them knowing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He's in danger of being killed? How?
output: The Ulen Family of House Hlaalu, a rival Great House, has placed a deathmark on the councilor's head.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I did what had to be done.
output: Wonderful, simply wonderful! Councilor Morvayn will be quite pleased when he hears about this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I saw her in the Ulen tomb.
output: So Geldis's plan worked, eh? Everytime we tried it, no one would ever show up. If Tilisu's involved in any sort of plot to harm Councilor Morvayn, I'm going to need hard evidence to prove it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you doing here?
output: I presume the same thing you're doing... leaving an offering for the departed. Nice to see a fellow Dunmer following the traditional customs.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you doing here?
output: I presume the same thing you're doing... leaving an offering for the departed. Forgive my surprise, it's just that I wouldn't expect that sort of behavior from someone who isn't Dunmer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Thanks for the tip.
output: You can thank me if it works. Until then, I'd head to the tomb and wait until your visitor shows up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've decided to help you protect Councilor Morvayn.
output: I'm pleased you've reconsidered.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I presume that was their downfall.
output: Hlaalu deserved every bit of the hatred they received once the Empire released its grasp on Morrowind. Having past ties to the Empire immediately turned them into the scapegoat for the Dunmer people's suffering.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who else lives here?
output: Talvas is Master Neloth's apprentice. If you are interested in spells, he might be willing to sell you some. Elynea is our alchemist. She specializes in mushrooms and other types of fungus. Ulves runs the kitchens.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does it mean to be a member of your house?
output: In the mean time, we would keep a bed and chest here for you. For now, not much. But in a few decades when I return to Vvardenfell, you would be seen as Morrowind nobility.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you one of Neloth's apprentices?
output: No. Talvas is his apprentice. I'm his steward. I manage the day to day affairs of Tel Mithryn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this place?
output: Tel Mithryn. It's the home of Master Neloth. You may have heard of him. He's a famous Telvanni wizard.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you have to trade?
output: Here, take a look.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Slow down here. I don't want to hurt you.
output: Strong always fight strong. Old chief strong, me stronger. You stronger? Fight me!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I brought back your animal.
output: Bilgemuck follow you. Bilgemuck know strength. Tribe-kin stronger. You stay, help more.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Nords are dead.
output: You strong! All tribe-kin stronger with you. But... maybe you too strong. Too strong, want be chief.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let's go!
output: We fight!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't know about this...
