output: You know. We know. Come fight. We wait, but you, come fight.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You want me to kill people?
output: Bad people. They come, fight us. We fight back now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do we need to do now?
output: Bad Nords. Say Thirsk theirs. Live by water, bother tribe-kin. We fight. You strong. You help. No more bad Nords.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I brought your Scathecraw.
output: Good redgrass. Later, we burn. Now, final task. Then, you tribe-kin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this "redgrass"?
output: Here, like this. Go, bring two hands of redgrass. Be friend of tribe-kin.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're right. I want to be the new chief.
output: Strong always fight strong!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You want me to do something else?
output: Tribe-kin missing redgrass. Need for godspeak dance. You bring redgrass, we dance.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like you to carry some things.
output: Certainly, sir.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like you to carry some things.
output: Certainly, ma'am.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like you to carry some things.
output: I live to serve.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like you to carry some things.
output: I always dreamt of being a pack mule.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like you to carry some things.
output: I was hoping you'd say that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I read a book in Miraak's temple, and went somewhere. Miraak was there.
output: The legends speak of that place. Terrible battles fought at the temple. The dragons burning it to the ground in rage. They speak also of something worse than dragons buried within. Difficult to imagine, but if true...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: I'm not sure, but it is fascinating, isn't it? Perhaps it has some relation to what's going on here. Quite unexpected. I'm afraid I can't give you any answers. But there are ruins of an ancient temple of Miraak's toward the center of the island. If I were you, I'd look there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does it mean if we're both Dragonborn?
output: I am unsure. It may mean that you could save us, or it may mean that you could bring about our destruction. But our time here is running out. The few of us left free of control cannot protect ourselves for much longer. You must go to Saering's Watch. Learn there the word that Miraak learned long ago, and use that knowledge on the Wind Stone. You may be able to break the hold on our people there, and free them from control.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Miraak did claim to be Dragonborn.
output: That is what the stories say. You are Dragonborn as well, then. Perhaps you are connected.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I am indeed Dragonborn.
output: Then perhaps you are connected with him. The old tales say that he, too, was Dragonborn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does this all mean?
output: If you could go to this place and see him... Are you like Miraak? Are you Dragonborn? It means what I feared has come to pass. Miraak was never truly gone, and now has returned.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Varona is dead. I found her body on the road.
output: Dead? Oh, merciful ancestors! That blasted wizard couldn't be bothered to give her some protection for those trips. This is all his fault. Best tell Neloth. I'm sure he'll mourn for all of two seconds.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Varona is dead. I found her body on the road.
output: Dead? Truly? Oh, Varona. She didn't deserve this. This is a dark day for Tel Mithryn. Go tell Master Neloth. When I'm done here, I'll prepare her grave.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Varona is dead. I found her body on the road.
output: She's dead? Oh my. Master Neloth is not going to be happy to hear that. Maybe you should be the one to tell him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Ildari Sarothril?
output: Master Neloth's old apprentice? The one before me? I never met her. Master Neloth took me on because she died. I heard it was messy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Ildari Sarothril?
output: She was a headstrong one. Always pushing Master Neloth to teach her more. Her lust for power was her undoing. She let Master Neloth do some ritual thing to her. We buried her out back. That was some twenty years ago now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Ildari Sarothril?
output: Ildari? She was a beauty, she was. I tried to court her, but she had no interest in me. She was only interested in magic and power. She died in some experiment Master Neloth did on her. He claimed she wanted him to.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It looks like an ash spawn attack.
output: There are more and more of those things showing up around here lately. I suppose you'll have to find me a new steward. Try Raven Rock. They are in awe of me there. I'm sure almost anyone would be willing to serve me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your people are free.
output: So it is. You have proven yourself an ally to the Skaal, and so the Skaal shall be allies to you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've destroyed the Ash Guardian.
output: What a relief. Master Neloth surely would have punished me had he found out. I don't have any gold to pay you with, but I can give you this staff.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can you train me in Conjuration?
output: Yes, but don't tell Master Neloth. I'd have to give him your payment.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you work with Neloth?
output: Not so much with, as for. I am Master Neloth's apprentice. He's teaching me the art of sorcery.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this place?
output: This is Master Neloth's tower. He's a Telvanni Wizard.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What kinds of game do you hunt?
output: Deer, bear and horker provide most of what we need for skins and meat. Sometimes, when the wolves grow too bold and threaten the village, we must hunt them to cull their numbers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What else does a First Hunter do?
output: When we stalk large game, I lead our hunters in tracking the beast. It is also a way of saying that I am the most skilled hunter in the village. I doubt that an outsider could truly understand, but I hope my words have helped to answer your question.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How long have you been studying the Skaal?
output: Well, let me think... I suppose it's been nearly a year now. My goodness, how the time has flown!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're not one of the Skaal?
output: Oh no, most certainly not. I'm a historian. I'm here to learn about the history of Solstheim. Solstheim is a fascinating place, but we know so little about its past. There are many mysteries that remain unsolved.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who do you trade with?
output: Many hunters pass through our village, and sometimes the Dark Elves of Raven Rock visit us. They bring us things from their homeland that we can't find on the island, such as spices, fine cloth and ores that we cannot mine here. It's true we Skaal prefer a simpler life than some, but we do still enjoy a luxury from time to time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did you do in Skyrim, before you came back here?
output: Well, my mother used to say that I was born an angry child. It's true that my heart has always been restless, and fighting was the only way I could find peace. I was a soldier for a time, and then a mercenary, but I was never truly happy until I came here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who or what is the All-Maker?
output: You are an outsider, and I don't know if I can make you understand. I will try. The All-Maker is the maker of all things, and it is from the All-Maker that life flows like a great river. As all rivers must return to the sea, so all life returns in time to the All-Maker. I know our ways must seem strange to you, but the nine gods of the Empire are equally strange to us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is "oneness with the land?"
output: The Skaal hunt not for sport, but to survive. We believe that all creatures have a right to live as they will, and when we take what we need from them, we thank the beast for its gifts.  The less we disturb the land and the beasts within it, the more we respect the wishes of the All-Maker.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you become the leader of the village?
output: I was chosen by the people of the village when our last leader, Skaf the Giant, departed the cold world to join the All-Maker. I suppose I've always spoken my mind and tried to do what's best for the Skaal. That's why the others call me Fanari Strong-Voice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What wisdom can you share about hunting?
output: The first piece of wisdom I teach to any hunter of the Skaal is to ask the simple question, should I truly kill this beast? We take only what we need, and so we preserve the oneness with the land.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me more about your people, the Skaal.
output: We are Nords, much like those you'll find in Skyrim. Long ago our path diverged from that of our cousins on the mainland. We live as one with the land, for the land provides all that we need.  Also, like the Nords of old, we embrace the All-Maker. We do not worship the nine gods of the Empire.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me more about this book, then.
output: He came to us some time ago, asking about Black Books. I believe he knows a great deal about them. Perhaps too much. It is a dark thing, unnatural. I would have nothing to do with it. But the Dark Elf Wizard, Neloth... Seek him out to the south. Be cautious, Dragonborn. There is something else at work here. Miraak had this? This does not look like something of the Dragon cult.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's not enough. I need to stop Miraak now.
output: I cannot help with that. None here can. You will need the knowledge Miraak himself learned. You will need to learn more about this Black Book.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: Habichaaalakawaramalek.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's time for us to part ways.
output: Faaa rawala.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes. Let me show you.
output: Bafagra badee.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No. Never mind.
output: Hoo jah.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need you to do something.
output: Takafala gajoo?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait here.
output: Waaaah!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Follow me.
output: Sure thing, friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll do it.
output: Then may the All-Maker give you the strength of a great bear and make your will as firm as stone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Forget it.
output: I was foolish to expect compassion from an outsider.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: <Alias=Dungeon> is free of bandits.
output: Your kindness warms my heart as sunlight warms the skin on a cold day. The Skaal are once again in your debt, outsider.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I admit, this does sound suspicious.
output: Finally! Someone who believes me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did the letter say?
output: It describes a discovery that was made in the mine by some of the diggers. They wanted Gratian to take a closer look. The East Empire Company must have felt it was of great value, as they locked that section of the mine off from everyone else.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why are you telling me all of this?
output: Look, my wife nags that I'm too old to go traipsing around these mines chasing my story. Time's my enemy... it's caught up with me before I could find the answers that I'm looking for.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I assume it's rare.
output: I don't think I've come across more than a chunk or two in my lifetime, and smithing's my trade. If you're looking to learn more, you should head over to the Skaal Village. Someone there's bound to know more about it than I do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You were right all along. (Give journal)
output: Let me see that! Ha, I knew it! Gratian's death wasn't because of a rockfall, it was just a story to keep people away from the tombs. Now that I have his journal in hand, I can get some closure from the East Empire Company. Make them pay for lying to everyone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I still think you're crazy.
output: Sigh. I don't care what you, or anyone else thinks about me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Perhaps I could help.
output: Hmph, maybe. Been difficult trusting people lately, they think I'm crazy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who was your great-grandfather?
output: Gratian Caerellius. He spent his entire life exploring ancient ruins across Tamriel and he died in these very mines almost 200 years ago.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is stalhrim a type of ore?
output: Calling stalhrim an ore is like calling my forge a campfire. Some folks say it's "enchanted ice," but I think there's more to it than that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Fine, you keep it.
output: Now you're finally talking some sense. A mining tool belongs in a mining family. Just tell him I lost it or something.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's dangerous here for an old man.
output: Ask most of the folks around here and they'd agree with you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So you do need my help.
output: I do. I want to know what happened to Gratian, and what the East Empire Company is keeping from all of us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's an Ancient Nordic Pickaxe?
output: It's the only tool tough enough to crack stalhrim, is what it is. Not many of those beauties left in the world... forging them is a lost art. The one Crescius "borrowed" came from the Skaal Village up north. I, uh, traded them some goods for it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let me think about this.
output: Good. Now let me get back to what I was doing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Busy doing what?
output: Why should I tell you? I don't even know who you are.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've returned.
output: You're back! Please, tell me what you found.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm just exploring.
output: Exploring, huh? Most folks think this place isn't worth the effort.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can't you just get the guard to find Crescius?
output: Um, I prefer to handle these things on my own. Look, if you see Crescius, tell him to give me that pickaxe back and I'll pay you for the trouble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It doesn't belong to you.
output: Oh, very well. Here. Tell him I hope he drops the thing on his foot.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any idea of where to start?
output: Gratian kept a journal of notes about his discoveries. If you can find his... remains, I'm hoping it will help. Here's everything I have. The letter, the key. Please, do this for me so I can finally regain the respect that I've lost.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What sort of a secret would be hidden here?
output: A secret the East Empire Company swept under the rug two centuries ago. It killed my great-grandfather, and left Raven Rock with a worthless and tainted mine.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why all the fuss over a simple pickaxe?
output: No, no, no. This isn't just your run-of-the-mill pickaxe... I'm talking about an Ancient Nordic Pickaxe. They don't exactly grow on trees, you know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Glover wants his Ancient Nordic Pickaxe back.
output: The damn fool doesn't even deserve to have it! The pickaxe was made for mining, not selling. I'll bet he stole it from the Skaal in the first place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's your proof?
output: My wife and I were cleaning out our home, and we came across some of my great-grandfather's things locked in an old chest. I found an unsent letter he'd written to the East Empire Company, and a key.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the matter?
output: You haven't seen Crescius Caerellius have you? That foolish old man's taken my pickaxe again!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Good luck with that.
output: Thank you. Now, I believe I owe you a little more than a debt of gratitude for all that work you did. Here... it's not much, but it's the best an old, retired miner can do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The key is to the locked section?
output: It is. Well, I assume it is. I haven't been able to find the entrance.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have your Ancient Nordic Pickaxe.
output: So you finally tracked down old Crescius, eh? Quite a character, isn't he. Tell you what. Since you went through all the trouble of finding it for me and all, you keep it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: East Empire Company?
output: You never heard of them? They're the largest trading company in Tamriel, originally chartered by the Emperor of Cyrodiil himself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: This is hardly proof of anything.
output: Now you're starting to sound like everyone else.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did he die?
output: East Empire Company called it "a terrible accident," claiming that he was lost in a rockfall, but I know better.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: After all that, why?
output: I just wanted to remind that codger you can't just go around taking things from other people. Now that you've delivered the message, I'm satisfied. Besides, that pickaxe hasn't done me any good in years. Maybe you can put it to good use.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can't you make them stop?
output: Make them stop? Oh no, certainly not. At least not yet. Not until I've figured out what is going on. Imagine the power of being able to command entire villages to do your bidding. Imagine what I could do with that power.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where is everyone?
output: They are off working on their pillar. Happens every night.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then where's his great-grandfather?
output: I'm sure he's down there somewhere, buried under a mountain of rubble like the East Empire Company claims. My greatest fear is that my stubborn mule of a husband will end up suffering the same fate.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm guessing you don't agree with Crescius's story.
output: Poor Crescius is aging and I believe it's addled his mind. As the years have passed, it's gotten worse. He's become obsessed with his theories of conspiracy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm not sure the dragons are about you.
output: Really? When this is over, you'll have to tell me all about it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No.
output: Then this will be over soon for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes.
output: Good. Then let us see who truly has the soul of the Dov.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Perhaps you should return to Morrowind.
output: I assure you, if I could convince Adril to do that, I'd be on the next ship back to Blacklight. Unfortunately, Adril and Councilor Morvayn are very close friends, and they will never abandon one another... despite my feelings.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why are you so suspicious of visitors?
output: I have to be. As Second Councilor, the security of Raven Rock is my primary concern.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: But you said Redoran leads the Council.
output: Well of course. With four other houses on the Council, someone has to keep the rabble organized. Our house leads the Council by virtue of our preeminence in battle, wisdom, and ancestral glory.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Council? You mean there's no Jarl?
output: They embody a council made up of five Great Houses: Telvanni, Dres, Indoril, Sadras and Redoran. This isn't Skyrim, outlander. A group of powerful and influential Dunmer families have been ruling Morrowind for millennia.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You worry much on your husband's behalf.
output: He's in grave danger, and yet he continues to place himself in harm's way. When I fall asleep at night, all I can do is hope he'll still be there when I awaken. This island was never meant for us. There's too much death here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is House Redoran?
output: We're the mightiest of the Great Houses and we lead the Council, the ruling body of Morrowind. You've never heard of House Redoran?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's the unusual armor you're wearing?
output: Ah, this is bonemold armor... quite impressive, wouldn't you say? It's fashioned from actual bone that's been reinforced with a resin-like material and then shaped to form the armored plating. It might appear brittle, but I'd wager it could stop the blow of a weapon better than iron or steel.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's your husband?
output: Adril Arano, Second Councilor of Raven Rock. How I hate that title... damn fool's going to get himself killed over it someday.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why have such elite soldiers on this island?
output: To protect Councilor Morvayn, of course. He has quite a few friends on the Council back in Morrowind and they wanted to ensure his safety while he was here. Other than that, I'm not at liberty to discuss it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You must owe him quite a bit.
output: Our bond is our strength. We've always been at each other's side and nothing will ever change that. We've fought quite a few battles together, and saved each other's lives on more than one occasion.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Raven Rock the only settlement on the island?
output: Well, there's a small enclave of Nords to the north at Skaal Village. They pretty much keep to themselves, and we both like it that way. Then there's Tel Mithryn to the east. The Telvanni live over there... sort of a strange lot, but since we're both from Morrowind, we get along. Other than that, Solstheim is crawling with bandits and Reiklings, but that's to be expected living on the frontier like this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Doesn't sound that impressive.
output: Hmph. Well, beauty's in the eye of the beholder, I suppose.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you friends with Councilor Morvayn?
output: I've known the councilor since we were both quite young. We rose the ranks in House Redoran together. When word arrived in Blacklight that the Councilor's father had passed, I was asked to sail to Raven Rock with him as his second. It meant passing on better opportunities at home, but I didn't want to leave his side.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you rule all of Solstheim?
output: Solstheim is theoretically under my rule, but without revenue from the mine, I lack the resources to actually govern anything but Raven Rock itself. Not that there's much beyond the confines of our town anyway.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It sounds like quite a sight.
output: I haven't seen the city in over fifty years. Even for a Dunmer, that seems like an eternity.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are the Redoran Guard?
output: All of the soldiers in this town are Redoran Guard... some of the best warriors that House Redoran has to offer. I've spent quite a few years honing their skills and I can assure you they're not just your average city guard.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where are you from originally?
output: Adril and I lived in Blacklight, the capital city of Morrowind. House Redoran has improved Blacklight substantially over the last thousand years... its grandeur rivals that of Mournhold itself. The Rootspire where the Council of Great Houses meet is something to behold.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Has security been an issue?
output: This isn't exactly the city of Blacklight. We're on the frontier out here, and we've had more than a fair share of troubles. After all we've been through together, I refuse to let Councilor Morvayn down.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You haven't told him how you feel?
output: I'm the wife of a Second Councilor and certain things are expected of me. The most important is that I stand by Adril, no matter how I feel. And I intend to do that until we get off this miserable rock.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds rather complicated.
output: Hmm. Pity that one of our own people doesn't fully grasp our ways.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds rather complicated.
output: Yes, I imagine it would to someone not of our people.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: Miraak? The name sounds familiar... Or does it? I can't remember.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: Why do I recognize that name? It sounds so familiar... Did I have a dream about someone named Miraak?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: I don't think so, though it sounds like a name I've heard before...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: I think so, but I can't remember how I know him. Or maybe I'm wrong. I'm not sure.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: That's not someone who lives in Raven Rock, I don't think... but it sounds so familiar.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: Miraak... I'm sure I've heard that name before. Haven't I? Was it in a dream?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: Do I? I was going to say no, but somehow I feel like I do. Does that make any sense?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: I think so, but from where? I can't recall.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: I recognize the name, but... I don't know how I know it. It sounds so familiar.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: No, I... Wait. Maybe. I don't know how I know that name...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: I think so, but I'm not sure where I heard the name.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: I think maybe I had a dream about someone with that name...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: Did I know someone by that name? Someone... Someone that wanted something...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: No. Wait... I recognize the name, but I'm not sure why.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: Miraak... It sounds very familiar. Not someone here, but... I'm not sure I can recall.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: Hmm. Sounds like something from a dream, and yet it might be more. Strange.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: I might know someone. Or maybe not. I can't remember...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: Why does that sound so familiar? There's no one here by that name, and yet I swear I've heard it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: I... I'm unsure. I swear I know the name, but cannot place it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you know someone called Miraak?
output: Do I? What a strange thing. It sounds so familiar, and yet I cannot place the name.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: I'm not sure. Perhaps I'm just remembering something wrong.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: I don't know. I keep thinking of the Earth Stone... Something to do with that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: I hear that name, and I see a temple, here on Solstheim. What could that mean?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: I'm not sure. I think so, but the only thing that comes to mind is a shrine near the Earth Stone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: Maybe... I can't help but think of some sort of temple here on the island. Why would that be?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: I just can't be sure. I... I don't think I like talking about this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: No, I'm sure of that. And yet... I think I had a dream of a temple, and he was there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: It's difficult... Something about it doesn't feel right. A... A temple, here on the island. That's all I can recall.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: It's so strange. I feel like it's from a dream. Something about the Earth Stone, and a shrine... That's it. That's all I can think of.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: I... I'm not sure. I don't want to talk about this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: I don't know why, but I'm thinking about a temple, here on the island. Maybe it was just a bad dream.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm here about the Stalhrim map.
output: So you know my purpose here, then? I suppose you must have found that dullard of a blacksmith. Unfortunately for you, my mission here is also a secret. To protect it, I have no choice but to silence you. Now, give me one good reason that I should not kill you where you stand.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, otherwise he'll teach me nothing. You can trust me. (Persuade)
output: I might not trust you, but I will trust your greed. Very well, take the map. Return here with Stalhrim weapons and armor, and I will pay you a fair price for them. Tell the blacksmith whatever lie you will. We have no further need of him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, otherwise he'll teach me nothing. You can trust me. (Persuade)
output: You expect me to just hand you the map, so you can deliver it to the blacksmith and laugh at the foolish Thalmor you so easily outwitted? You have made a grave miscalculation, and now you will pay the price!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The smith said he'd teach me how to make Stalhrim weapons.
output: And you will sell them to me. I suppose I'll have to give you the map first?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You want Stalhrim weapons, and I think I can help you get them.
output: Here to make me an offer, then? Very well, what do you have in mind?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The blacksmith won't talk. You're wasting your time (Persuade)
output: I admit, we are not making the progress I'd hoped. Perhaps you are right, this venture might be more trouble than it's worth. Very well, you have convinced me. We will depart the island shortly and seek our weapons elsewhere.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The blacksmith won't talk. You're wasting your time (Persuade)
output: You dare to question me? That insult will be your last!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Leave this island now, or your life is forfeit. (Intimidate)
output: I can see that is no idle threat. Very well, we will depart the island once we have loaded the ship. No weapon is worth dying for, not even a weapon forged from Stalhrim. Here, give this map to the blacksmith. I have no further need of it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Leave this island now, or your life is forfeit. (Intimidate)
output: You dare threaten me? For that insolence, I will flay the flesh from your bones!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How long have you been a sea captain?
output: I've been sailing the Northern Maiden across the Sea of Ghosts for nearly twenty years now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What exactly is "ash-grown food?"
output: The Dunmer have been growing food in the ashlands for thousands of years. It was born out of the necessity to survive in the harsh climate of our homeland. And now, with the constant eruptions of the Red Mountain, it's more important than ever.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ridiculous? Why?
output: Solsthiem is still rich in ebony ore. I know there's more down there... I can smell it. I come from three generations of miners, and I'm telling you that the East Empire Company was wrong. They just didn't want to spend the coin trying to find it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your inn has an unusual name.
output: There's actually a funny story behind the name, friend. A few years ago, I was walking down by the docks and I noticed a Dunmer staggering along with a bottle of sujamma in hand. He was one of my patrons, and liked to drink heavily, so I wasn't exactly surprised.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why?
output: In all honesty, it came down to a disagreement between what I believe and what Elder Othreloth believes. I'd prefer not to get into the details, but let's just say our opinions about the current status of the Tribunal vary widely.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are there any other Imperials in Raven Rock?
output: Those cowards left decades ago. Every single damned one of them. The moment the ebony mine dried up, they pulled up stakes. Ridiculous!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're a priest at the Temple?
output: Far from it. In fact, I'm no longer welcome there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who taught you that?
output: I had a friend over there, a dark elf named Vanryth... a very talented armorsmith. Spent a lot of time with the guy swapping smithing techniques. Learned a heck of a lot, including how to repair bonemold. After he moved on to greener pastures, I decided to pack up, move out here and put those lessons to the test. Been here ever since.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How has Raven Rock needed your help?
output: As you can imagine, the eruption of the Red Mountain took an awful toll on Solstheim. Hunting for game has been scarce, and the waters are apparently too tainted for fishing. According to Councilor Morvayn, my husband's been Raven Rock's most important food source for decades.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: This is where you met?
output: It was. After refusing to allow anyone to bring him food, Councilor Morvayn ordered his door to be knocked down before Crescius starved to death. I was a Temple priest at the time, and they had me use my healing arts to restore strength to his ailing body. I stayed for a while and cared for him, then... I suppose we fell in love.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you end up in Raven Rock?
output: A fine question, and the one that I hear most often from visitors to our town. I wish I had a more romantic tale to tell, but I was simply seeking my fortune and chose Raven Rock to ply my trade. Besides, knowing how to repair bonemold armor wasn't very useful in Riften.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where did you get all these items?
output: Gjalund over at the docks brings me most of my supplies, and the rest comes from bartering with the people in town. Oh, Glover Mallory gets me a few things once in a while. He usually has the most amazing deals that I can't pass up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you leave Morthal?
output: When word reached us that a settlement of Dunmer was forming on Solstheim, we were thrilled. It's been difficult, but I'm not regretting it one bit. In fact, I'm glad we've been able to stay and help. It wasn't long before we became homesick... we were the only Dunmer in Morthal.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why didn't he move somewhere else to find work?
output: Our home has been in his family for over two hundred years. Leaving would have been like abandoning precious memories. Instead, he stayed on Solstheim and spent most of his life prospecting for a new ebony source. Sadly, it never surfaced. A decade ago, this drove him into a deep depression. He shut himself inside his home and refused to come out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What exactly do you sell here?
output: The question you should be asking is "what don't I sell here" because I have pretty much any supplies you might need. If it's not a weapon, potion or armor, then it's likely that I have it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Now I get it.
output: True story, friend. True story.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do the Dunmer bury their dead?
output: The Dunmer race doesn't bury their dead, or leave them to rot inside a stone sarcophagus. When a Dunmer passes, his body is given to fire, so he might return to the ash from whence he came. The Dunmer don't believe that death is the end, we believe that it's the beginning.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Okay.
output: Bah, you're just like the rest of the folks around here. Mark my words... the East Empire Company will return to Raven Rock, and when they do, I'll be at the top of their list.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The false Tribunal?
output: Sotha Sil, Almalexia and Vivec represent what was... beings who won the Dunmer people's hearts with their actions, but blinded them just the same. They were aberrations, false prophets. They used their status as heroes to shield the True Tribunal from our minds. But now that they've been destroyed, the light can finally shine upon the House of Reclamations.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where did you learn your alchemy skills?
output: After we left Morrowind, we found ourselves in Skyrim. We wandered around a bit and ended up in Morthal where we took temporary residence with Lami, the town's alchemist. I was fascinated by her work, and over a period of a few years she taught me quite a bit.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did the netch do?
output: Well, the bottle broke on the netch, and it must have swallowed its contents because it started floating sort of tilted. Finally, it stopped and began to quiver. A few moments later, the foulest liquid to ever assail your nostrils spewed from its maw. I've seen plenty of drunks in my day, and I'll tell you right now that netch was sick.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What exactly are the "Reclamations?"
output: The Reclamations are the True Tribunal... the daedra that consecrate the Dunmer people: Azura, Mephala and Boethia. We call them the True Tribunal because they have reclaimed their place in our hearts from the false Tribunal that came before.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is magic involved?
output: No. Only the Telvanni have the ability to weave living growth from the ash. This simply takes the right ingredients, the right tools and a lot of patience.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you meet Crescius?
output: To understand how we met one another, you have to appreciate what he's going through. Crescius is a third-generation miner... all his life, he's lived and breathed nothing else. By the time Crescius came of age, the ebony mine in Raven Rock was shut down. He took that quite hard.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did your mother die?
output: We lived in a settlement perhaps a league from the border of Black Marsh, the homeland of the Argonians.  Even though the Argonian Invasion ended a long time ago, there are still a few scale-skin clans that live within our borders. To put it simply, they attacked our settlement and slaughtered almost everyone. It was horrible.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You have friends at the East Empire Company?
output: Oh, absolutely. In fact, I've corresponded with Vittoria Vici herself more than once. You know, the lady who runs the East Empire Company Warehouse in Solitude... the biggest warehouse they have in Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Doesn't sound unusual.
output: Ah, but you see this particular Dunmer was as naked as the day he was born and singing badly at the top of his lungs. As I'm watching this spectacle, a netch floats over the Bulwark towards him.  The man looks straight up at the netch... yells "have a drink" and tosses the bottle... and it never hit the ground.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you always served as a ferryman?
output: Not at all. I used to fish the waters around Solstheim. Made a damn fine living at it, too. But over the years, the ash from Red Mountain poisoned the sea up there and the fishing became difficult. If it weren't for my supply runs to Raven Rock, I'd have likely sold my ship by now and moved back to Riften.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are sales that bad out here?
output: Bad? What if I told you that you're the first person that's even considered looking at my wares today. I've half a mind to contact my friends at the East Empire Company and see if they need an extra hand in Windhelm.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: It was very strange. Was I... building something? A shrine, down on the beach near the Earth Stone? I'm not sure.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: Maybe I'm just confused. I can't be sure.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: I don't know... I feel strange just thinking about it. A temple, maybe? Here on the island? Something about a temple...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: I can't be sure. I know I've heard that name, but it... it doesn't feel real. Does that make any sense?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: I remember a temple on Solstheim, and working to build something. It... it was not a pleasant dream.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you tried to stop this?
output: Certainly not! Doing so would interfere with whatever is going on, and I would be unable to see how this all turns out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are these people doing?
output: Building something, clearly. And yet they don't seem to have much to say about it. I'm very interested to find out what happens when they finish.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's going on here?
output: What brings you to Raven Rock?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll cleanse the tomb for you.
output: Thank you, wanderer. That would be most kind. Here, this key should open the door to the tomb.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could gather some for you.
output: That would be splendid! I'd be more than happy to give you something for the effort.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is it difficult commanding the Redoran Guard?
output: It can be. Even the most experienced warriors can fall prey to petty distractions. They usually didn't amount to much, but they make my job that much harder.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why can't you use the tomb?
output: Those foul vermin... the abominations we call ash spawn have risen from the ashes of our own ancestors. They're befouling the memories of our forefathers by defiling their remains.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're selling quite a few exotic ingredients.
output: Yes, I'm proud to say that I grow or harvest most of it myself. I only wish I had a better source for netch jelly. Those creatures are difficult to track down since it's so dangerous beyond the Bulwark.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found the Emberbrand Wine stash.
output: Good, this will help me keep things running without having to worry about a bunch of soldiers falling asleep on duty. Here, take this for your trouble.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are the Ancestral Tombs?
output: They are where we inter our dead. They are sacred places, meant to honor their passing. Sadly, we've been unable to use the Ancestral Tomb beneath the Temple as of late, and have resorted to other locations to scatter the remains.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Any idea where I can begin?
output: They're too smart to have left it in the Bulwark. I'd search one of the abandoned houses on the outskirts of town.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: They'll show up eventually I suppose.
output: Yes, I suppose they might. Ah well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It'll turn up sooner or later.
output: I certainly hope so.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could help spread the word.
output: I was kind of hoping you'd say that. Here, take these samples of the sujamma and spread the word. If you get rid of all of them, there's something extra in it for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have that netch jelly for you.
output: Goodness, it must have been quite difficult tracking those creatures down out there. Here, take these. They should help you during your journeys.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've given out the Sadri's Sujamma as requested.
output: Perfect! All that's left now is to go ahead and wait for the patrons to come in. As promised, here's a little something for yourself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: So what's the specialty of the house?
output: The finest sujamma to cross your lips, friend. My own personal formula that I call "Sadri's Sujamma." In fact, I've just added some new ingredients to the mixture that I think makes it taste better than ever. All I need to do is get the word out that it's ready and they'll flock here for it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have some netch jelly right here. (Give 5 netch jelly)
output: My goodness, you're quite resourceful aren't you? This is all I can offer in return for this. I hope it's enough.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could track the stash down for you.
output: You would? That would be helpful. I just don't have time to do it myself right now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm all out of Sadri's Sujamma.
output: Here's a bit more. Hope you're not drinking this stuff yourself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Temple's tomb has been cleansed.
output: Spirits be praised! I'm hoping you didn't suffer much at the hands of those foul beings. Please, accept this as a token of my thanks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds risky.
output: Well, I have these other ingredients for sale for now. It'll have to do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: Good old Geldis is always managing to keep our spirits up... and our eyesight hazy. Thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: What? Oh. No thank you. I need to keep my head clear.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: Oh, how kind. Thank Geldis for me, won't you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: Sorry, I'm always on duty and I don't wish to have my brain addled by Geldis's strange concoctions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: Oh, wonderful. Anything to keep the spirits up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: Get that vile liquid away from me!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: Sorry, Geldis won't allow me to drink while I'm working at the Netch.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: Geldis needs to bottle this up and send it to the mainland instead of wasting his time out here... his drinks are outstanding. Thanks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: At least my father will let me drink whatever I want without complaining. Tell Geldis I appreciate it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: Perfect! I was just thinking about heading over for a drink. Thanks for saving me the trip.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: Hmph, he's begging for patrons again, eh? Well, I suppose I could have just a bit.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: Well that sounds lovely. Thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: Not today, too many things on my mind.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: Sure, got nothing better to do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: Well, tell Geldis that Mirri says she really appreciates it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: Always a pleasure to taste anything Geldis comes up with.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: I should mix some of this into my next potion... who knows what would happen!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: No! I can't! It may be poison!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: The day I refuse sujamma from Geldis is the day I sprout wings and fly off of this rock.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: There's nothing finer than dark elf sujamma... like nectar it is.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: Take that swill and pour it down a well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Well, good luck with that.
output: Yes, indeed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Petty distractions?
output: Some of my own men have become quite accustomed to a spirit they called "Emberbrand Wine." Despise the stuff myself. It's powerful and tremendously addicting... I've seen men fail to finish even a single flask. If I knew where they were stashing the bottles, I'd put an end to it myself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Still buying East Empire Pendants?
output: Absolutely. Here's your payment.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: She has a right to do what she pleases. (Persuade)
output: I suppose you're right. If she wants to spend her life at the bottom of an ale mug, it's her right. Tell her she'll welcome back anytime.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: She has a right to do what she pleases. (Persuade)
output: No, sorry. It isn't right.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're welcome at the Retching Netch anytime.
output: Well then, I suppose I'm off to do what I do best. Here. This was something I carried around in happier times. Maybe you can find a use for it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can you find them?
output: Well, well. Seems you're proving fairly useful for an outlander. Here's your coin. Keep bringing me more, and I'll keep paying you for them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can you find them?
output: They could be anywhere on the island. The mines might be a good place to start. If you find any while you're exploring Solstheim, bring them here and I'll pay you for them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you ban Bralsa Drel from your inn?
output: Have you seen the poor girl? She's a mess. She used to be richer than Councilor Morvayn and she's spending it all drowning her sorrow. As much as I love making coin, I can't watch her do that anymore. I won't.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's an East Empire Pendant?
output: It's an amulet that was made exclusively for the East Empire Company. They gave them to their workers as an incentive at one point... a kind of reward for extra effort. They're no longer being made, so they've become collectible. I'd love to get my hands on a few of them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let me think about this.
output: Trust me, I've seen my share of hardcases, and she's doing this to herself for no reason. She could be someone again if she was given the chance.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sorry to hear that.
output: Sure, I bet you are. Everyone's always sorry.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you sell any special mining gear?
output: Mining gear? No. However, I used to sell East Empire Pendants until I ran out of them. Popular little item.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could talk to him for you.
output: If you can get that stubborn mule to let me into the Netch, I'll make sure you get what's coming to you. You can try...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe this will change your mind. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: Well, there's morals, and then there's money. In this case, money wins. Tell Bralsa she's welcome here anytime.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe this will change your mind. (<BribeCost> gold)
output: It's going to take more than that to change my mind.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Used to? What happened?
output: That fetcher Geldis won't even allow me inside. Said I was bad for business. If I want to spend my last bag of coins getting drunk, that's my business. What does he care?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let her back in, or you answer to me! (Intimidate)
output: Okay, okay. There's no need to get violent. If Bralsa wants to come back, she's welcome here... I swear.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let her back in, or you answer to me! (Intimidate)
output: I'm not afraid of you. She's not coming in here, and that's that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why should I pity you?
output: Doesn't everyone pity the hopeless? Look at me... I'm no better than a beggar. I used to be a miner, a good one too. I made more gold digging up ore in a month than some people earn in a lifetime. When the mine dried up, I was lost. I have no other trade, so I spend my time drinking my fortune away at the Retching Netch... or I used to anyway.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Just tell me where the book is and I'll go get it.
output: I'm afraid it isn't that simple. If it was, I would have the book already.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Black Books have something to do with Hermaeus Mora?
output: You didn't know? Hmm, I thought it was obvious.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do we need these cubes?
output: I thought I made myself clear the first time. The boilers in the Great Hall provide steam to the reading room upstairs, which we need in order to open the book's protective case. We need a total of five cubes - one to operate the pumps in the Great Hall, the other four to activate the boilers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It was an honor to stand with her.
output: Yes, I remember how I felt being there with her the first time, before we were wed. I hope to see you more around the hall, friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll keep out of your way.
output: See that you do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm ready.
output: Let's not waste any time, then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We're going to fight his ghost?
output: No, no, nothing like that. He doesn't need to battle us to know us. He's always watched over Thirsk, and sees us from beyond. And in my case, since he's already deemed me worthy, it will just be a matter of him remembering why he blessed me before. Really, all you need to do is watch.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Hrothmund said the next Thirsk chief is a long way off.
output: Well, then. I'll do my best to keep the hall together until that day comes.  Now, look... I understand you were just defending yourself. And because you helped us retake the hall, I'll look past it this once. But I wouldn't show my face in here again, if I were you. Do we understand each other?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's going to happen in there?
output: It's pretty simple. Hrothmund's axe is in there with him. Anyone who attempts to take hold of it has their spirit judged by Hrothmund himself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: She attacked me and I had to defend myself.
output: Ah. I see. I hope she... fought well.  Was it... did Hrothmund recognize anyone else? Was it you? Is that why...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this place?
output: The burial place of Hrothmund, who founded Thirsk.  He brought a group of true warriors away from the soft life of the Skaal, to know the wilderness, to feel the sting of cold and of steel. I know that... sounds a little silly. It's just the way it's written in the books, and that phrase has always stuck with me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't know what happened to her. (Lie)
output: Well, let's hope she makes it back soon. This lot doesn't have much patience with me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's not that simple. Bujold was rejected by Hrothmund.
output: Are you being serious? How... how did she take it?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You need to know the truth. She was rejected by Hrothmund.
output: I don't think you know how dangerous it is to say what you've just said.  This is a serious accusation. I'm sure Bujold can straighten it out for us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm back.
output: How did things go out there? Where is Bujold?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm back.
output: Bujold says you served well. Before we were married, I was her second on the first trip to the barrow.  Hrothmund knows strength, in this world and the next.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do I need this Word of Power to defeat Miraak?
output: Even dragons submit to Miraak's Voice. Without that power, you cannot face him. So say I, Hermaeus Mora, master of the tides of Fate.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have a letter from your brother. (Give letter)
output: This is by his hand, for certain.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any idea where he might have gone?
output: He set off from here so long ago, it's hard to say. Could be in Hammerfell for all I know. If you happen to cross his path, be wary. He was a fierce warrior as a man. If he fell prey to his more bestial side, he could be deadly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Of course, the village to the north.
output: A long time ago, a man named Hrothmund left the Skaal to form his own tradition. Warriors in the wild, living like the Nords of old. They would hunt, they would fight, and the mightiest among them would rise up as leader. But those days are behind us, now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's a werebear?
output: Twisted beasts, a curse of Hircine. True bears are noble and great creatures of the wild. But the daedra have no skill for creation, so they befile the All-Maker's workings. I've heard tell of men who, by curse or by heart's desire, become transformed into one of those vile things. It is a pitiable fate. And one that I fear has fallen to my brother.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is Thirsk?
output: Do you know of the Skaal?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened?
output: Rieklings. Those filthy vermin... they came in numbers. Waves of the things. One at a time, they're pests, but with this many... And so here we are, out of our home.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I just got out of there as fast as I could.
output: I didn't take you for a coward. But until we know the limits of our courage, we don't really know ourselves.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened to your brother?
output: This... this is my brother's handwriting. This was his.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened to your brother?
output: I wish I could tell you.  He had a wild gleam in his eye, more than most. In my darkest times, I fear he fell in among the werebears of the glacier.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you mean?
output: We used to be proud warriors of Thirsk Mead Hall. There, up on the hill. But we let that sweet life get the better of us. We grew soft, and...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Hard to be sure. He put up a strong fight.
output: Well, the truth is my brother really died long ago.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How long have you been First Hunter?
output: In days past, my brother Torkild and I would share the hunt, but that was... long ago.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What was left of him.
output: Good.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you been exiled?
output: I wouldn't call it that. We've just got a bit of an infestation, is all. Down here to catch our breath, and then we'll be back in the hall once I get the rest of these up to move.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is the Skaal?
output: The Skaal is a group of Nords who live up to the north of here. They're always talking about their connection to the natural world. It's a lot of nonsense to me, but they seem to get by.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you need?
output: Here is the foul book that killed Storn. Take it away from here. Throw it into the sea. It is evil.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I understand. I'll talk to Storn.
output: Good. Although I do not think he will help you. These secrets are sacred to us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Aren't you his apprentice? He must have taught you his secrets...
output: You will not convince me to betray Storn's trust. Talk to him. He will decide the matter.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need the "secrets of the Skaal" in order to defeat Miraak.
output: You must talk to Storn, then. As shaman, he is the keeper of such lore. I have learned some of what he knows, but it is not my place to divulge anything to an outsider.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: I... I can't. I just can't be sure. I think maybe he had something to do with a temple. A temple here on the island. Does that help?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: I... I don't know. It almost feels like a dream. Something about a temple on the island...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: I don't think so. I'm not... The name has something to do with the Earth Stone, I think. But I'm not sure what.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What does that mean?
output: I'm not even sure... I can picture a temple, here on Solstheim. Must've been a bad dream.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He's no longer commanding the ash spawn.
output: Councilor Morvayn was offering quite a bounty for assistance with this matter. I'd say you've more than earned it. Then Raven Rock will no longer be attacked by those creatures.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found this letter.
output: Let me see that. Judging from these writings, General Carius was under the impression that the fort was still active as it was 200 years ago. What turned him into one of the undead appears to remain a mystery for now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have some information about Fort Frostmoth.
output: You should bring this information to Captain Veleth as soon as possible. You should bring this information to Captain Veleth as soon as possible. You should bring this information to Captain Veleth as soon as possible.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think I've solved your ash spawn problems.
output: Excuse me? How can you be so certain?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He'll no longer send ash spawn to Raven Rock.
output: Councilor Morvayn told me to give this to you if you made it back in one piece... and you got rid of General Carius. Better than a soldier's pay, so you should be thankful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I killed General Carius.
output: I had my suspicions that he was undead. How else could he have survived for over 200 years? It's a shame. There are quite a few tales of General Carius's exploits, including the founding of Raven Rock.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any insights to share about this puzzle?
output: Have you tried to walk on the plates without stepping on the same one twice?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any insights to share about this puzzle?
output: Well, there's a warrior, an archer and a mage. Perhaps each statue is meant to represent a different method of combat.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you have any insights to share about this puzzle?
output: Hmm... Perhaps something is meant to go into the fire?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Have you known Bujold a while?
output: All my life. She's my big sister. Don't worry, most people can't tell we're related.  But... she's always trying to be the one in charge, and feeling terrible when something goes wrong.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's her husband?
output: Kuvar. He thinks we've all gotten a little too soft. I can see what he means looking at Elmus, but the rest of us still have our edge.  At least, I think so.  And... don't tell Elmus I said that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: People seem pretty tense around here.
output: You don't know the half of it.  Bujold's just embarrassed, I think. Doesn't help that her husband is one of the loudest complainers. She's always been quick to shame.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How long have you been down here?
output: Longer than I would have liked.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: An infestation of what?
output: Rieklings. You must have passed by the hall on your way down here? Well, it's been overrun. We're just out here temporarily, to regroup.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you a warrior?
output: I wouldn't be at Thirsk if I wasn't. These days I focus a little more on the creature comforts of the hall, though. The food, the drink, the stories. It drives Kuvar mad, but someone has to do it or the place would be a little... cold.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you one of the warriors from Thirsk?
output: That depends on who you ask. I fight. I protect the hall. I bring in meat. And I think I could take on most of the tree lovers up in the Skaal Village. But because I'd rather drink a mug of mead at night instead of training until I drop, Kuvar calls me a layabout. Wish he would just lighten up.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He lives in a giant mushroom?
output: In Morrowind, the Telvanni grow buildings from special fungus spores. Master Neloth grew one here to be his home. Don't ask me how.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is the Tree Stone?
output: It is an ancient stone of power, a connection to the All-Maker. There are other stones around Solstheim. I fear for what has happened to them... It represents one of the aspects of nature, a part of the All-Maker's creation.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You're here by yourself?
output: There are few of us left unaffected by this curse. My father Storn, the shaman, protects them in the village.  If I cannot find a way to save them, there is no hope for our people. I fashioned an amulet to guard me against whatever has taken hold of the Skaal, but it is the only one of its kind.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are you getting along here?
output: Neloth is a real task master. And the tea. The thrice damned tea! I don't think I'll ever learn to make it properly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You should pay me what you can. (Persuade)
output: Well... I... Oh, fine. Here. This is all I have.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You should pay me what you can. (Persuade)
output: I don't see why. He's your problem now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How about you take half? (Intimidate)
output: Uh... yeah. That sounds good. Half. I think that will work.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How about you take half? (Intimidate)
output: How about I don't. You don't scare me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's in it for me?
output: So gaining the favor of a Telvanni wizard isn't enough? I suppose I'll have to pay you. Heroes. They get greedier every century.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you owe Mogrul money?
output: I already told you, Mogrul can't touch me now. Whatever is between you and Mogrul is your problem.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you need?
output: I think he knew what would happen. He saw his death in that book.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you need?
output: Do not let his death be for nothing. Go and stop Miraak.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you need?
output: I do not blame you. I know he chose this. I just wish he had seen another way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you need?
output: Leave me to mourn my father. I have no more words for you now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You were able to get the forge working again?
output: Those things had filled it up with slop for their beasts. Elmus helped me wash it out, but the fire still smells terrible. It's not as good as it used to be, but I still am, at least.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you plan to stick around here, then?
output: Kuvar isn't enough to frighten me off. He makes a lot of noise, but at the end of the day, he wants what we all want. Peace, and a warm drink.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How much mead is left?
output: Enough for now. But I'll either need to get some more barrels or start importing more if we're going to make it through next winter. Last thing you want is the mead to run out just as the fire dies!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Will you ever go back to Hrothmund and try again?
output: I don't think we need that old ghost anymore. Whoever leads us next can go plead with him if they want to, but I'd rather make a tradition of my own. Hrothmund was a great man, but he wasn't a god or a paragon. We're alive, he's not, and we'll look to ourselves for strength.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you going to do now?
output: We're going to rebuild. The hall, and ourselves. In some form or another.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you going to be able to lead this place, still?
output: I'll lead those who will follow. And most of these are the following sort. So yes, I think we'll be all right.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me more about Thirsk.
output: Now that we're back where we belong, I'm hoping we can get ourselves back to what Thirsk deserves. We're colder than the snow and harder than steel. We wrap ourselves in both to remind us of the world we face. At least, that's my hope. We've all learned lessons at the expense of this recent unpleasantness.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do you feel about Bujold?
output: Sad to see her go, of course. But Bujold wouldn't have gotten as far as she did if she wasn't strong. She'll... she'll be ok.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do you feel about Bujold?
output: I can't believe Kuvar would do that. To his own wife! I'll head out looking for her eventually. We'll wander the wilderness together. Just have to get some things in order here, first.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do you feel about Bujold?
