output: In the end, she was one of the better leaders we've had, but if she didn't deserve it anymore, I guess that's that. It's too dangerous out here. We can't waste time worrying about having a liar in our midst. Lying is the first step to cowardice, after all. I hope she finds what she needs out there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where do you get your raw materials?
output: I have friends in Raven Rock, and a few among the Skaal. There's not much metal on the island itself, but we can find what we need, when we need it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Would I be able to collect a bounty?
output: Don't get ahead of yourself. All you are going to do is wear this ring and walk around Tel Mithryn. If you find something, then we can talk about bounties and rewards.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you want to be the new steward of Tel Mithryn?
output: And leave my farm? No thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there a bounty on her then?
output: Why is it always about money? Yes, yes. I'll find something around here to pay you with. Now go.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I can see this is going nowhere. Good luck with all that.
output: Luck won't help. I need something to pry these things out of my head.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Secrets? What kind of secrets?
output: The secret kind!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's in your head?
output: Secret hidden things!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Whoa. Not so close.
output: Good idea. They might leak out. Don't want them crawling into your head, too. Like me. They're in my head. Right now. Saying things.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ummm... Are you alright?
output: No! That's what I'm trying to say. The secrets. They're in there. In there deep. Can't get them out. They're in my head!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Bye.
output: Why won't anyone listen to me?! Listen to me! They're in my head!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Slow down there. What are you going on about?
output: You don't believe me. No one does. They don't want to. I don't want to either. But I can't help it. They're in my head!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where did you find this Black Book?
output: Oh, no. I didn't find it. It found me. Here. I'll show you. See. Right there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where did you find this Black Book?
output: But don't go there. You don't want these things in your head. You don't. You don't!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Alright then. Where did you learn these secrets?
output: The Black Book. It shoved them in there. With black slick fingers. My fingers are too short. I can't get them out!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why would someone want to kidnap Baldor?
output: Well, there is one reason that comes to mind.  Baldor is the keeper of an ancient tradition, the forging of Stalhrim. It is an art we Skaal hold sacred. If someone wanted to make such weapons, they would have to get that knowledge from Baldor.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where will you go now?
output: First I'm going to leave this place, as fast as I can. Then I'm going to get on the first boat to the mainland. Good luck to you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did she do with the prisoners?
output: Horrible things. Experiments...and worse. I'm the last one. The others are all dead now. If you find her, don't make her end quick.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ildari? What can you tell me about her?
output: We were digging in these mines when she found us. She was hurt so bad. We took pity on her and nursed her back to health. She repaid our kindness by attacking us in the middle of the night. Those of us that didn't die were made prisoners.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is this the map you're referring to?
output: By the All-Maker, yes! That is the very one! I can only assume you took this from Ancarion's corpse. I must take this back to Skaal Village right away. When you return to the village, come and meet me at my forge. I will reward you for this great deed you have done.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Shall we do some business?
output: What do you have for me?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I suppose I could lend a hand.
output: We were searching the farm when the ash spawn ambushed us. Have a look around and see if you can turn up anything useful. Good, I could use a pair of extra hands.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Geldis Sadri wants you to try his new drink.
output: Sorry, never touch the stuff.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't think they'll give up willingly.
output: Good. I'm going to send two of the best Redoran Guard we have to take them down. I want you to assist them any way you can.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Thank you, councilor.
output: Now. I'm certain Adril was prepared to reward you appropriately for everything you've done. However, since a bit of coin hardly seems like enough... I've decided to provide something more substantial.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found evidence proving the Severins's guilt.
output: Then we finally have them! All that remains now is chasing them down, and bringing them to justice.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You wanted to speak to me, councilor?
output: What you've done for me... for all of Raven Rock... goes far beyond what I would have expected from a traveler to our town. For this, you have my deepest gratitude.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm back!
output: Well, what happened? Were you able to track down Vendil? Out with it!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Slain by the Morag Tong.
output: Damn it. I was hoping to protect our people by sending them, not end up with casualties. To think that Vendil would stoop so low as to hire those fetchers... I'm glad you killed him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Haven't I done enough?
output: If even one of these House Hlaalu s'wits escapes, they won't just be after Councilor Morvayn. You've proven devastating to their plans and they'd stop at nothing to hunt you down. It's time to take the fight to them, and finish this.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll head there immediately.
output: See that you do. We can't afford to let these traitors slip away.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Oh?
output: Since the Severin family... or whoever they were...turned out to be criminals, their property is now forfeit. As Councilor, I hereby award you Severin Manor and everything contained within. You've earned your citizenship here, and I hope you'll consider staying with us as a member of our community.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did I overhear that someone is missing?
output: Oh, I doubt it. Deor has always been quick to worry. Go and speak to him if you like, but do not be surprised if you end up in a wild fox chase. It would not be the first time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did he say what it was about?
output: All he wanted me to do is track you down and send you to him. Look, this is important... even more important than wiping out the ash spawn. Please, go speak to the second councilor as soon as possible.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did you need something from me?
output: I'm sorry to bother you, but Second Councilor Arano asked me to come find you. He said it's quite urgent.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Captain Veleth sent me.
output: Thank you for coming. After everything you've already done for Raven Rock, I hate to ask for more but I can't risk Councilor Morvayn being killed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where can I find a heart stone?
output: Every time the Red Mountain belches, more of them land here. Look around for impact craters, exposed rock, that sort of thing. You may need to pick away at it to pry the heart stone itself loose, but you look... strong.  Good luck.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Could you repeat that inscription?
output: Certainly. The translation was "All men must die, often by their own means."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Could you repeat that inscription?
output: Yes, of course. It said "A sacrifice will bring you closer to that which you seek."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Could you repeat that inscription?
output: Most certainly. The translation was "Continue along the path, don't tread where you've been."

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did the letters say?
output: Crescius's great-grandfather worked for the East Empire Company. The letters mention some sort of discovery he was sent to investigate. There's really nothing remarkable in the letters. I don't know what he's so excited about.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why is he exploring the mine?
output: He's convinced himself that there's some sort of conspiracy involving the East Empire Company and the mine's closure. We came across some old letters that belonged to his great-grandfather in our house and he believes every word written in them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What were you arguing with Crescius about?
output: That foolish old man thinks he's thirty years younger than he is. He's going to get himself killed traipsing around the mine.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you sure Gratian's death wasn't an accident?
output: Look, I know I don't have much to go on. I have that unsent letter, and that's really it. But I also have a miner's instinct that's run in my family from before Gratian was even born. I may sound like a crazy old man to you, but I'm telling you, the tunnels here are solid... they would never collapse like that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You don't agree with Crescius?
output: My beloved is almost eighty years old and I think the shock of finding one of his ancestor's things has left his mind a bit... confused. I love him dearly, and I support everything he does, but I can't let him chase this silly idea or he may end up joining Gratian in a rocky grave.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened to him?
output: There was a horrible accident, and he was killed when one of the tunnels collapsed. They were never even able to go down there and recover the body... the East Empire Company sealed that section off to prevent any more tragedies. Crescius is convinced it's a story cooked up by the company to cover up something else, but I don't know.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who was Crescius's great-grandfather?
output: Gratian Caerellius. He was an explorer for the East Empire Company. They'd send him all over Tamriel when they had difficulties in a mining operation. Poor man... can you imagine doing all that dangerous work just to end up dying at your own doorstep?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Miraak?
output: Much of what was known has been lost to the ages. He was Dragonborn, and yet he served the Dragons. Then he turned against them, becoming something they feared. He was defeated long ago, but it seems he was never destroyed. A priest in their order, highly esteemed and very powerful.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you mean, 'free your people from control?'
output: Some dark influence wields power over them, forces them to forget themselves and act against their nature. At first it was only during the night, but now every moment is spent building some strange shrine around the Wind Stone. I believe if the shrine can be destroyed, the Skaal will be free once more.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do I need to learn a Word of Power?
output: Miraak is behind what is happening to our village, and so the knowledge he has gained as Dragonborn is at the heart of it. You are Dragonborn as well. You too can wield this power, perhaps to a better end.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your people are free.
output: It would seem so. And you are to thank for it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What if she's right and I don't find anything?
output: Then I'll settle down peacefully and never set foot in this mine again. I've been waiting for this moment for a long time... even before I discovered Gratian's old things. I just hope both of you don't mistake my enthusiasm for insanity.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why were you arguing with Aphia?
output: She thinks that old age has addled my mind... that I'm seeing things when there's nothing to be seen. I realize she cares about me, but she has to understand that I can't rest until I find out what happened to Gratian.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me about your family.
output: Our home has stood in Raven Rock since the colony was founded. Gratian helped build it with his own two hands. After Gratian died, he left behind a wife and a son... my grandfather, Rellicus. Rellicus lived there for quite a long time, working in the other sections of the mine until he was slain by reavers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And you've been alone ever since?
output: Until I met my darling Aphia, yes. I suppose you could have called me a bitter old hermit... now I'm just old.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then it dried up.
output: Unfortunately, yes. I only had enough coin saved to send one of us back to the Imperial City, so I sent my mother alone. I wanted her to see her homeland before she died.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Ridiculous? Why?
output: Well you know it as well as I do. Raven Rock Mine wasn't empty at all... it's still rich in ebony ore. I came from three generations of miners, and I couldn't get anyone to believe me. Well we showed them, didn't we!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And your parents?
output: When I was old enough, I began working in the mine hoping to make my fortune and eventually move to the Imperial City. I never knew my father... my mother and I always lived alone. I asked her about him many times, but she seemed angry and refused to speak about him, so eventually I let it go.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why aren't you affected like everyone else?
output: I have gone to some pains to ensure that I am immune to many forms of control.  I cannot say for certain which is currently protecting me, but it bears further investigation at some point.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He's dead, but I at least found the formula.
output: I told him not to head up there. Sounds like the bloody fool got what he deserved. Here, I want you to take this key. Head inside my house and unlock the door in the basement. Help yourself to whatever you like inside. I won't be using it anymore.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm back.
output: Any luck tracking down Esmond?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll get that formula back for you.
output: You do that, and I'll make sure you're set up right. You won't be disappointed.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where's Esmond Tyne now?
output: Well, before he ran off, he was talking some nonsense about trying to fence goods to the rieklings at Castle Karstaag. I told him he was crazy to even think about talking to those vicious little buggers, but he wouldn't listen. I'd bet a fat purse of coin that he's either dead or hiding out up there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did you do?
output: A fellow Breton who went by the name Esmond Tyne showed up on my doorstep about a fortnight ago. He noticed the shadowmarks like you did, and I thought he was one of us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Thieves Guild has a problem out here?
output: Don't look at me like that. I'm all alone out here, with no one to watch my back. And besides, it's really my problem anyway. I caused it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He stole something from you, right?
output: That he did. Right out from under my nose. Can you believe it? It's my own formula for improved bonemold. Took me years to perfect.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Nothing at all?
output: Eager to make some coin, eh? That's the spirit. I'll tell you what. The Guild's got a problem out here that I've been trying to deal with for years, but haven't been able to handle.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He's well.
output: Good to hear. Damn layabout never even bothers to send his own flesh and blood a letter saying how he's doing. Can you imagine? Anyway, I suppose you're looking for work. Well, I've got bad news. This place is dryer than a damn bone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I noticed the shadowmark by your door.
output: Well, well. It's been a long time since someone from the Guild's bothered to make their way out here. So tell me... how's my brother Delvin? Still spending his nights at the Ragged Flagon trying to win Vex's heart?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Not now.
output: Suit yourself. I'll be here if you change your mind.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes. (<Global=DLC2CostToSail> gold)
output: You've got yourself a ship. We'll cast off immediately.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why sail there at all then?
output: They still pay me for supplies and passage and I can always use the coin. Still interested in heading over there?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How much will it cost me?
output: I'll give you a fair price. Not many people headed over there these days. If you ask me, I can't blame them. Things aren't what they used to be out there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need passage to Solstheim.
output: If you're looking for passage to Solstheim, you won't find a finer vessel than the Northern Maiden.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: A daedra?
output: Powerful and malevolent entities who make their home on the plane of Oblivion. Some of the more powerful among them can exert their influence within our world, and when they do, men inevitably suffer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What did you make of that stone structure everyone was building?
output: Yes, that was a most disturbing experience. But to answer your question, the architecture was strange, almost otherworldly. Given that, and the considerable power it must have taken to affect our minds so completely, it would suggest the work of a powerful mage. Either that, or perhaps a daedra. If so, then may the nine protect us.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: And the Skaal don't mind being studied?
output: Well, not so far. They think I'm a bit strange, but they seem to tolerate me. In fact, they've been very accommodating. Hospitable, even. They seem happy to talk about their traditions and history.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Solstheim?
output: Surprised you've never heard of it. It's an island northeast of here. Has a small dark elf town called Raven Rock and a handful of Nords living in Skaal Village. People don't usually sail over there unless they have a particular reason. It can be a pretty rough place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've found your missing Folio.
output: You have? You have no idea what this means to me... to my family. Reclamations bless you! Well, you've certainly proven your worth around here to me. Please, accept this gift as a token of my appreciation!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Actually, I already have it. (Give Folio)

output: Offer to help and then change your mind because I mentioned the reavers? Hmph, some sellsword you are.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: Thank you, you have no idea how much it hurts losing such a precious heirloom!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do you know?
output: One of the sailors survived. Poor thing crawled all the way to Raven Rock on his hands and knees. Before he died, he told the Redoran Guard about the wreck and warned us that it was going to be crawling with reavers.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Was it aboard a ship?
output: Yes, the "Strident Squall" or something like that. The damn thing sunk right off the coast of Solstheim. Can you imagine?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: We make a good team. Why not join me for a while?
output: Join you? You mean leave the village to journey with you and fight at your side? I'm flattered, but the village is my home. It's very rare for one of the Skaal to leave, and I have responsibilities here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is your role among the Skaal?
output: As shaman of Skaal Village, I serve as both a guide and a healer, as well as a keeper of traditions. I also remind the Skaal to live as one with nature and to honor the will of the All-Maker, so that we'll be worthy to join him in death.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's time for us to part ways.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about these Black Books?
output: Our traditions do not speak of them. But they and Miraak are connected. You read a Black Book, and saw him. But beware. You are now walking the same road as Miraak. And the book's power comes from the same dark source as that which corrupted the Wind Stone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do you think this Neloth can help me find Black Books?
output: He also is searching for them. In fact, he has already found one. He showed it to me when he came here. It was very like the one you found in Miraak's temple. A thing of dark magic, not of the All-Maker.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Other Stones?
output: I can feel it. The balance of the living land has nearly been restored. But while the Tree Stone remains under Miraak's influence, the natural order remains out of balance. And all can be undone if Miraak exerts his will again. You must continue on your path, and gather the knowledge you need to defeat him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Other Stones?
output: Yes. There are six sacred Stones - Wind, Water, Earth, Beast, Sun, and Tree. Through them the Oneness of the land is maintained. Frea saw that the Tree Stone now stands imprisoned in Miraak's new temple. I doubt you can free it until his power is broken. But you may be able to cleanse the other Stones. Even if this does not stop Miraak, it surely will delay his return.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened when I Shouted at the Wind Stone?
output: The power of the Stone had been corrupted. It was the source of the influence that had taken control of the Skaal. Your Shout broke whatever evil will controlled the Stone, and restored its true nature as a conduit of the All-Maker's gifts. Freeing the other Stones will diminish whatever dark influence is spreading across Solstheim.

input: No, what is it?

Even the legendary sandstorms of Vvardenfell's Molag Amur Region were said to barely make a dent in them. Of course, that's all ash now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: The blast from the volcano wiped most of them out. Found Dusty here in a small cave on Vvardenfell. Silt Strider cocoons are pretty tough.

Only you can send me to Sovngarde with honor. Make your preparations. When you are ready, come find me at my last vigil.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: Don't be ridiculous. Of course I can. The question is, should I? I suppose if it's going to be done right, I'll have to do it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: I could, but I won't. It wouldn't do to have you become better than me after all.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: You've brought warmth to my heart, outsider, and I'm in your debt. Please accept this as a token of gratitude. Once again, you've proven yourself an ally to the Skaal.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: She's not exactly young anymore.
output: Ah, well, I suppose she'll always be that fiesty little girl I used to know. Of course, when you reach my age, you'll find that the word "young" is a very relative term.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: She wants this placed at her mother's grave.
output: Ah yes, Bera's silver necklace. It was a wedding gift and she rarely took it off. I'll be glad to oblige. What a touching gesture, to display the symbol of her devotion in such a way. Tell Morwen I'll be happy to grant her request. I am sure it will bring joy to her mother and father as they walk in Aetherius.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Morwen of Skaal Village sent me to ask a favor of you.
output: Morwen, you say? Now there's a name I haven't heard in a long time. Left to join her mother's people on Solstheim, as I recall. I knew her parents quite well, you know. Bera and Ulfarr were good people, very much in love. Now, what can I do for young Morwen?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you need?
output: I came across a few of my mother's old things not long ago. Among them was a necklace that my father gave to her when they were married. I believe she would want it placed upon her tombstone in Falkreath, as a symbol of her undying love and the great sacrifice she made for it. If you find yourself in Falkreath, please give this amulet to the priest Runil and tell him that I sent you. He will understand. I don't have much to give in reward, but return to me when the task is done and I'll do what I can. Thank you, Skaal-friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did your mother leave the village?
output: A trade ship from Skyrim struck ice off the coast near the village, and the Skaal took in the surviving sailors. My mother fell in love with one of the sailors - my father - and eventually returned with him to Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: But you told me House Hlaalu was disliked.
output: The Ulen family being a part of House Hlaalu didn't matter. It's Dunmer tradition for the ashes of the deceased to be placed in an ancestral tomb. Valin Ulen and his son's remains were both laid to rest there because that's what he'd requested.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do the Ulens have a tomb in Raven Rock?
output: Vilur Ulen wasn't the first Ulen to live in Raven Rock. His father, Valin Ulen, was one of the first Dunmer to settle here. When Valin died, his family provided the funds to construct the tomb. Unlike his son Vilur, Valin was a good man. He contributed to the community and was quite respected.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did the Dunmer survive this at all?
output: House Redoran took charge and was slowly able to build an army. It took years, but it became a force to be reckoned with. When the Argonians invaded years later, House Redoran's army was able to prevent them from sweeping across all of Morrowind. It would be fair to say that House Redoran literally saved the Dunmer people from destruction.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do the Dunmer hate the Empire?
output: During the Oblivion Crisis, gates to the plane of Oblivion opened all over Morrowind. The Empire pulled most of its forces out of Morrowind to deal with the gates in their own homeland, leaving us virtually defenseless. We had no standing army at the time, just uncoordinated pockets of resistance.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't need some bucket of scrap metal following me around...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why not return to Morrowind?
output: Oh, believe me... I'd be on the first ship off of this miserable island if I could. But I'm not sure I could do that to my father. I think it would break his heart. We've already lost my mother, I don't want to leave him alone.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You don't like it on Solstheim?
output: Don't like it? I hate it! Every day it's the same thing. We open the shop, we hardly sell a thing, we close the shop and go to sleep. What kind of a life is that?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What's being built outside of town?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Your mother tells me that you want to leave the village.
output: That's right. I want to go out into the world and earn great glory. I want to hunt the deadliest creatures and claim vast riches. I am weary of living in this village. I want to do something with my life other than farm, fish and hunt deer. I know it must be hard for an adventurer such as you to understand this, but we Skaal live very boring lives.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I could talk to him.
output: You would do that? I know he would listen to you. You've been out there in the wide world. You know its perils. Yes, perhaps you can convince him. I would be grateful if you would do this thing, outsider.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who's your son?
output: His name is Nikulas. He's a good lad, strong and loyal. I only wish he wasn't so eager to leave the village. I've tried to tell him that the world beyond our lands is dangerous and cruel, but he won't listen.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I do understand. In fact, I'm willing to help you get started.
output: You are? I admit, I was not expecting to hear that.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The world is dangerous, and you're not ready for it. (Intimidate)
output: Well, I know there is some danger, of course, but I didn't think it would be that bad. If the risk is truly so great, I will train with Wulf Wild-Blood and hone my skills. Perhaps in three or four winters, I will truly be ready.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The world is dangerous, and you're not ready for it. (Intimidate)
output: There is no fear in my heart. My father's blood flows in my veins, and he was a mighty warrior. I will face any danger.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Take this. Just give your mother some more time. (<bribecost> gold)
output: Yes, you're right. She still mourns for my father, and having me near brings her comfort. You have my oath that I will not leave the village until my mother is ready to let me go.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Take this. Just give your mother some more time. (<bribecost> gold)
output: I am grateful for your offer, outsider, but I am Skaal. All that I need, I was born with.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You'd abandon your mother when she needs you most? (Persuade)
output: There is truth in your words. She has not been herself since my father's death.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: I know that it would be difficult for her, at least for a time, but I am a man now. I have the right to choose what life I will.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

output: You will find him on the deck. Any hint of treachery, and your life is forfeit.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why would the Thalmor abduct you?
output: I do not know this word Thalmor, but if you mean the elves, they were trying to learn the secrets of forging Stalhrim. Their leader, an elf named Ancarion, has a map. He says that it shows the location of a hidden source of Stalhrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I helped a man in need, that's all.
output: Modest as well as brave. Most admirable! I can see why the Skaal think highly of you. Yes, I think you're just the adventurous sort I need. I have a job offer for you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Let me guess, you need me to do something dangerous.
output: Quite right! Quite right! This, however, is paying work. Allow me to explain.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you think this place has any connection with the Skaal?
output: I've been thinking about that, and I believe it does. I believe it was the ancient ancestors of the Skaal who built this tomb for their master, the Dragon Priest they called the guardian. In all likelihood, these people were ancient Nords who came with the Dragon Priest to live here on Solstheim. Separated from their people on the mainland, they developed a distinct culture that became the Skaal we know today. Of course this is all just theory and conjecture. It is likely we will never know the truth.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What have you learned about this place?
output: This is clearly a tomb, if a rather elaborate one. I would guess it was built for a Dragon Priest who achieved great fame in his time. It seems he was held in high regard by both men and dragons, because he defeated a traitor named Miraak. Perhaps Miraak was also a Dragon Priest, probably a contemporary of this guardian. He must have turned against his own order. After his defeat, Miraak was banished to Solstheim and the guardian was made his jailer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why all the traps and puzzles?
output: A good question. Partly to keep unwanted intruders away, I suppose. They might also have been meant as tests, to ensure that only the truly worthy can reach the main burial chamber. Who can say, really? The motives of the Dragon Priests are as inscrutable as those of the Dragons they worshipped.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: The Argonians invaded Morrowind?
output: Quite a while ago, yes. They cut a bloody swath across most of the southern region of Morrowind. Nobody seems certain why it happened... an attempt at expansion, revenge for the enslavement of their people or perhaps both. Whatever the case may be, thousands of Dunmer needlessly lost their lives and many more were exiled from their homeland.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do your titles mean?
output: Councilor Morvayn is House Redoran's representative on Solstheim. As second councilor, it's my job to support him and make certain his rule is enforced.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Still buying East Empire Pendants?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Still buying East Empire Pendants?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Still buying East Empire Pendants?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Still buying East Empire Pendants?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's your mess. You clean it up.
output: You won't help me!? Master Neloth is going to kill me. Assuming he doesn't make me into a test subject again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why don't you destroy it?
output: I need to keep Master Neloth distracted so he doesn't find out what I did. There is no telling what he would do to me. While you are taking care of the creature, I'll try to figure out what went wrong.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did the Ash Guardian get loose?
output: I am embarrassed to admit that it was my fault. Master Neloth refused to teach me the Ash Guardian spell. So I read his spell book on my own and learned it. Something went wrong when I cast it. The creature is attacking everything in sight.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where do you get your goods?
output: Sometimes things fall off the back of a cart. I find them, clean them up and resell them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: Who am I? Buy something or keep moving. Who are you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
