instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You appear to be in dire straits. What happened?
output: I was one of the wealthiest miners in town... I could haul up almost three or four times what the average digger could. I never saw the end coming like it did... the mine running out of ebony. Unlike most of my fellow miners, I was too foolish to save enough coin for that day. The rest I spent on sujamma to drown my sorrows. Councilor Morvayn was kind enough to allow Rirns and I to live in one of the abandoned buildings. At least it keeps the ash out of our eyes.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You appear to be in dire straits. What happened?
output: I was one of the Redoran Guard under Captain Veleth's command. A few years ago, I was out on patrol with two other men when we were attacked by some ash spawn. They sprung from the ground with no warning and killed one of my companions instantly. I was so frightened, I ran all the way back to Raven Rock. Unfortunately, I'd left the other guardsman behind and he never made it. Captain Veleth discharged me from service. There isn't a single night that passes where I don't regret what I did, but it's too late for that now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are things now that the mines are open again?
output: At this rate, I'll be able to put a roof over my head in just a few months. Couldn't be better. The sections that are being opened up have revealed some huge deposits of ebony. Old Crescius has a nose for exactly where to dig. If they'd only listened to him years ago, the town wouldn't have been in such dire straits.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are things now that the mines are open again?
output: I may not be an expert at it yet, but it's good to be back to work and have some coin in my pockets. Bralsa's been nice enough to show me how to swing a pickaxe. She's an old hat when it comes to digging up ebony.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are things now that the mines are open again?
output: With the mines open, Raven Rock has become a significant colony of the Dunmer people again. I've been able to convince my superiors at House Redoran to send me the resources they've been denying now that we're deemed more important. Soon, we'll have a steady supply of workers and materials to keep things going for years to come.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are things now that the mines are open again?
output: Things are picking up... for now. All I'm wondering is how long it'll take for House Redoran to begin ignoring us again if the mine runs out of ore for a second time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are things now that the mines are open again?
output: I've been made the foreman of the mine thanks to everything you did down there. It's good to get the old nose working again. I missed sniffing out the ebony deposits and getting my hands dirty. Best of all, Aphia isn't so cross when I go down there any more!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are things now that the mines are open again?
output: You might think it's all perfume and roses now that the mine's open, but all I see is a new security problem on our hands. Making sure those shipments of ebony make it safely from the mine to the shipping docks is my new order of the day. And with Solstheim crawling with reavers and Azura-knows what else, I can't risk any attacks on Raven Rock.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are things now that the mines are open again?
output: How do you think? It's a blessing. I've got regular paying customers again, thirsty workers at the end of the day, and more coin than I can count.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are things now that the mines are open again?
output: I've always had a steady stream of work thanks to the Redoran Guard, so it hasn't affected me much. However, I've seen the smile on people's faces and there's hope around here once again... something we've been lacking for a long time.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How are things now that the mines are open again?
output: I've had to muster some more men to protect the mine, but I don't really have a problem with that. Second Councilor Arano is concerned that once word reaches the reavers that the mine has reopened, they might think about paying us a visit. I say let them try. My men are ready for them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why do you think your brother became a werebear?
output: He never felt the call of the All-Maker as I do. As we all should. We seek to live in peace with the land, but he had an eye for dominance and strength. For unnatural strength, you need look no further than the beasts of this island, mangled by the daedra. It's not a fate I would wish on anyone. And not what I wanted for my brother.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you practicing a spell?
output: Yes. I'm trying to summon an Ash Guardian. I'm just having trouble deciphering Master Neloth's handwriting. I don't mean to be rude, but I need to concentrate.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Herma-Mora? Why do you call him that?
output: That is our name for him - the Demon of Knowledge. He has always been our enemy.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why would Hermaeus Mora want your secrets?
output: We know him as Herma-Mora, the Demon of Knowledge. It is in his nature to hoard secrets to himself. Their value to him is of no consequence. The very fact that the Skaal have kept knowledge from him has merely increased his desire to have it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll restore the remaining Stones if that will help.
output: It may. It should. And I will think on what you ask of me, to decide if it is necessary, or just another of Herma-Mora's tricks.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who is Hermaeus Mora?
output: Have you? The actual Oghma Infinium? That's... I've searched for it myself for many years without success... But he is subtler than most of the other Daedric Princes, as you would expect of the prince of knowledge and fate. You seem to have escaped the fate of many who find themselves ensnared forever by the lure of his secrets. Or... perhaps not. Well then, you should know better than anyone that Hermaeus Mora is not to be trifled with.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He said it's the only way he'll teach me the final Word of Miraak's Shout.
output: So it falls to me to be the one to give up the secrets to our ancient enemy. I do not know if I have the strength to face him. With Miraak's corruption of the Stones... the Oneness of the land is disrupted, and our connection to the All-Maker is broken.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: He said it's the only way he'll teach me the final Word of Miraak's Shout.
output: So it falls to me to be the one to give up the secrets to our ancient enemy. I do not know if I have the strength to face him. The Tree Stone is still corrupted... the land is still out of balance. But with the other five restored... it may be enough. It will have to be.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I spoke to Hermaeus Mora. He asked for the "secrets of the Skaal."
output: No... I am still too weak to face him. It will take all my strength if I am to force him to hold to his bargain. You must cleanse the other Stones so that I can draw power from the All-Maker.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I spoke to Hermaeus Mora. He asked for the "secrets of the Skaal."
output: Hermaeus Mora... old Herma-Mora himself. So he is the source of Miraak's power. Of course. And now he comes again for what we have long kept from him. We have many tales of Herma-Mora trying to trick us into giving up our secrets to him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you need?
output: No... he is too strong...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you need?
output: There is nothing else to say. I am in the All-Maker's hands now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Here you go. (<Global=DLC2CostToSail> gold)
output: Come back when you actually have the gold.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes. (<Global=DLC2CostToSail> gold)
output: I don't sail for free. Come back when you can actually pay me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you do for Master Neloth?
output: I am his mycologist. He may have grown Tel Mithryn by himself, but I nurture it. Mushrooms and fungi are my life's work. When I saw Tel Mithryn I knew I had to be here. I've learned so much since then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did you grow this tower?
output: Me? No. That's Master Neloth's doing. I wasn't even born then. It's Telvanni magic at its best. He brought the cuttings with him from Morrowind and used sorcery to grow them.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: As the Archmage of Winterhold, you and I should share our secrets.
output: Winterhold? That small college that is falling into the Sea of Ghosts? You're the one that recovered the Staff of Magnus. Impressive. Talvas should finish his apprenticeship in a couple of decades. Come see me then. I think I could teach you a trick or two.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You must be almost as powerful as Savros Aren of Winterhold.
output: Savros? Ha! He wouldn't be fit to be my apprentice. Of course he does have a knack for wards that would be handy to learn. If you see him, let him know that I might be willing to take him on as my apprentice. For a price of course.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've heard of the House Telvanni of Morrowind.
output: Of course you have. Everyone has heard of the master wizards of Morrowind. We are one of the great houses that rule Morrowind.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You must be a very powerful wizard.
output: I am likely the greatest wizard you will ever meet. Who else do you think could create a staff enchanter? If you make yourself useful around here, I might just let you use it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do we do now?
output: If you have released the Wind Stone and broken the hold on my people, perhaps you can do the same for the rest of Solstheim. I doubt it will fully stop whatever Miraak is doing, but it may slow his progress.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How do I know I can trust you, demon?
output: My word is as true as fate, as inevitable as destiny. Bring me what I want, and I will give you what you seek.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait here.
output: Right, then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Nikulas has agreed to stay.
output: May the All-Maker bless you with many sons and daughters, outsider. Once again you have shown that you are a true friend of the Skaal. I wish that I could give you a reward that is equal to the joy in my heart, but I don't have much to offer one who has so much already. Perhaps these will prove useful to you. These herbs are unique to the island, and their like cannot be found elsewhere.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Maybe you should let him go.
output: Perhaps someday I will have to, but for now I need Nikulas here. You see, his father, my husband, was recently lost to us. Nikulas is all that I have left in this world. I know it is selfish of me to say so, but I cannot lose him. Not while I still grieve. Also, I know his heart. Nikulas is reckless and foolish, like most young men. He cannot understand what awaits him in the wide world.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you have for sale?
output: I've got the best selection of mushroom and fungi.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you have for sale?
output: I probably have some potions around here that might interest you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you have for sale?
output: Every type of fungus in Solstheim or Skyrim. Oh, and a few other ingredients and potions.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: Whatever you say, boss.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's time for us to part ways.
output: Well, then, I'm going to head back and get myself a drink. Maybe I'll see you soon.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need you to do something.
output: Just let me know what needs doing.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Follow me.
output: I owe you that much.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes. Let me show you.
output: Go on, then.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No. Never mind.
output: Suit yourself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Do you need help with your research?
output: I suppose that depends. Are you willing to be an experimental subject?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Telvanni? What are the Telvanni?
output: You've never heard of the great houses of Morrowind? House Telvanni is the house of the master wizard, one of the ruling houses of Morrowind. Master Neloth is one of the oldest and most respected members of House Telvanni.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Well, this is your lucky day. (Give formula)
output: Well, I'll be. That's the one. What happened to Esmond?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Tell me of your people, the Skaal.
output: We have lived on Solstheim for many generations. Our people are tied to the land itself. We try to serve the All-Maker, to live in balance with nature, instead of exploiting it as others would.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What do you know about Miraak?
output: His story is as old as Solstheim itself. He served the dragons before their fall from power, as most did. A priest in their order. But unlike most, he turned against them. He made his own path, and his actions cost him dearly. The stories say he sought to claim Solstheim for himself, and the dragons destroyed him for it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I have to know what Miraak knows if I want to stop him.
output: Miraak? The one all the townsfolk are always chanting about?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes. You may have noticed he's trying to return to Solstheim.
output: Well, I knew something connected with Hermaeus Mora was spreading its influence across the island. I wasn't sure that it was in fact the same entity as this legendary namesake of the central temple. Although the villagers seem quite convinced.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's right.
output: Is this somehow connected to your search for Miraak?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That's right.
output: What could you know of them?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Interested in me, are you?
output: I cannot deny it. You remind me of all the things I miss about Skyrim, and my heart beats a little quicker when you are near. Do you feel the same?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Miraak is behind what's happening to your people.
output: How do you know this?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've seen Miraak.
output: Really? How?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I couldn't have defeated Miraak without Storn's help.
output: Then... it was the All-Maker's will, as he said. I know I should not doubt it. But it is good to hear, all the same. Thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Storn didn't die for nothing. Miraak will never threaten Solstheim again.
output: Thank you. Whatever your other reasons for acting, you have done the Skaal a great service. We will not forget what you've done.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's over. Miraak is dead.
output: Then my father's sacrifice... it was not in vain. He died to free us. Tell me... was it the only way? Did he need to die?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why won't the book you have here help me?
output: Oh, it clearly is not associated with the same power that has overtaken the island. And I'm not talking about Hermaeus Mora. These Black Books are all his, of course. No, what you're looking for is a specific book. Presumably because Miraak's power derives from it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I know.
output: Herma-Mora forced you to serve him in order to defeat Miraak. Do not let him lure you further down that path. The All-Maker made you Dragonborn for a higher purpose. Do not forget that. Walk with the All-Maker, Skaal-friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You have a Black Book?
output: Yes. I haven't been idle while this fascinating madness engulfed Solstheim. But my book isn't what you're looking for. I'm quite sure it is unconnected with this Miraak. But I do know where to find a Black Book that can help you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Hermaeus Mora wouldn't have helped me without Storn's sacrifice.
output: Yes, his "help" which did not require him to kill my father. Such is the way of Herma-Mora, the eternal enemy of the Skaal.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Isn't Miraak your ally? Why help me defeat him?
output: He has served me long and well. But he grows restless under my guidance. His desire to return to your world will spread my influence more widely. But it will also set him free from my direct control. It may be time to replace him with a more loyal servant. One who still appreciates the gifts that I have to offer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I killed Miraak. But Hermaeus Mora is still out there.
output: It was Miraak who threatened Solstheim. With him gone, Herma-Mora has been foiled once again. Tell me, though... my father's death... was it necessary? Was there no other way to destroy Miraak?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I hear you know where to find Black Books.
output: Oh yes. They're not hard to locate once you know how to look for them. I have one here that I've been using to locate more.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Hermaeus Mora killed Storn, remember. Not Miraak.
output: I know. The Skaal will not forget this. Storn's death will become another of the many tales of Herma-Mora's treachery.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Very well. (0 gold)
output: Looks like you've already have someone with you. If you want me to come along, you'll have to ask them to leave.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Very well. (0 gold)
output: Lead the way.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Consider yourself hired. (<global=hirelinggold> gold)
output: Unless you have enough coin on you, I'm not going anywhere.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Consider yourself hired. (<global=hirelinggold> gold)
output: It looks like you already have someone with you. If you want me to join, you'll have to part ways with them first.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Consider yourself hired. (<global=hirelinggold> gold)
output: Then let's be off!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sure, what is it?
output: As shaman of the Skaal, I am charged with the spiritual well-being of my people. While you are not of the Skaal, you are Skaal-friend, and so I give you this warning.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You don't seem very grateful.
output: I don't recall asking you to kill Miraak. That was your own project. And I'm not even mentioning the fact that now we'll never know what would have happened when Miraak returned. Although... from all indications he could have proved a serious nuisance. So, yes, I am grateful that you dealt with him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You don't need to worry about me.
output: I wasn't worried. Just interested. I don't get to observe first-hand many people who've spoken to Hermaeus Mora.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No, nothing interesting. I just killed Miraak and saved Solstheim.
output: Well, that is what you hero types do, isn't it? I wasn't expecting anything less.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Don't you want to know what happened with Miraak?
output: Who? Oh him. Well, I assume you killed him. Or Hermaeus Mora turned on him when you looked like the winning bet. Or a bit of both. Miraak's influence has vanished from Solstheim. So I assumed you had handled things. Why, did something interesting happen?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What are you looking for?
output: Incipient madness. Loss of self-awareness. Black spots in the whites of the eyes. Any of the documented indications of Hermaeus Mora's permanent influence. Hmm, no, you look fine. Well, at least no different than when I first saw you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: I am Hermaeus Mora. I have been watching you since you defeated Miraak. Your progress is most impressive.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Who are you?
output: I am Hermaeus Mora. I have been watching you since we last spoke, and I am pleased with your progress.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I don't need your advice.
output: I understand. Walk with the All-Maker, Dragonborn.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there anything else?
output: Now all that's left are these Black Books, waiting for another ambitious fool to be lured into Hermaeus Mora's clutches. Speaking of which... I think I've located another book, if you're interested. Here, let me show you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there anything else?
output: Now all that's left are these Black Books. It's a shame I haven't located any more. So much more to be learned.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: No. Never mind.
output: You're the boss.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes. Let me show you.
output: Very well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need to trade some things with you.
output: If it'll help us get moving quicker, sure.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Follow me.
output: About time. Let's go.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Wait here.
output: You're going ahead without me? Suit yourself...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: It's time for us to part ways.
output: Oh fine, go on... leave me here. When you decide to return to your senses, you know where to find me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need you to do something.
output: What do you have in mind?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I found some Ashfire Mead. (Give mead.)
output: Oh, that's the stuff all right. You're a good friend to Thirsk, and to me. I thank you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is there anything that would make being down here more bearable?
output: Well, the easy answer, of course. Mead!  Actually, now that I think of it, I have been missing the Ashfire. It's a special brew that we make at Thirsk. If you could... somehow... get up there and grab a bottle, I'd be a long way towards forgetting how miserable it is down here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've got some juniper berries. (Give berries.)
output: Oh, perfect. Just the right ripeness, too. Good work, friend.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How is the mead?
output: We lost most of the batches we had brewing when... before those things were here. One is just ready to take its turn, though, and it's about time to add some of the flavorings.  You can't find them on Solstheim, but if you find yourself back in Skyrim, I wouldn't mind you bringing some juniper berries. They add a different kind of sweetness. Tart. Makes the flavor more round.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How is the hunting going?
output: To tell you the truth, I've been a little distracted. I've got this... idea. I want to make a reminder. So we never forget what happened the last time we got soft. I want to ring the whole hall with their little spears. Mocking us, from the past. Making us work harder. Fight better. The only problem is, I'm going to need a lot of spears. A lot. So, if you could find a bunch of them for me, that would make it easier on me.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've brought the materials you wanted. (Give stalhrim and ebony.)
output: Just in time, too. Kuvar was starting to give me some grief about his new armor. This will do the trick nicely. You come back if you ever want some fancier armor yourself, now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you getting back to work?
output: Cleaning out the forge was the easy part. But those blasted rieklings made off with most of my materials. And I can't forge air.  You tend to wander around, don't you? If you come across any stalhrim or ebony in your travels, bring them back to old Halbarn. Help each other out.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've got a lot of Riekling spears. I hope it's enough. (Give spears.)
output: Oh, I'm sure it will be. Give them here, and I'll get to work soon!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Raven Rock is purely a Dunmer settlement?
output: Raven Rock started out as an Imperial settlement, but the Empire decided to abandon it just as my people were first setting foot here. They left the town a shambles... but when House Redoran took over, we turned it around and it became ours. And even if it's been a struggle to make this island livable, we're proud to call it home.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: That could still happen, couldn't it?
output: Hah! Not if Fanari has anything to say about it. When it comes to being chieftain, she is like a wolf with her jaws clamped tight upon a fresh kill. But that's alright. The Skaal need a shaman and I know that is my place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: But what? What is it?
output: It is not right that I should say this, because I must honor my father's wishes, but this is a path I never chose. I always thought that I would be a great hunter, or even the village chieftain.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: For a shaman, you fight pretty well. Who trained you?
output: It was Skaf the Giant, our former chieftan, who taught me the ways of battle. He was a great bear of a man, and a fearsome warrior. I used to be terrified of him when I was a little girl. I was a restless and angry child, and Skaf taught me swordplay so that I could, as he used to say, "put that fire to good use." He was a great man and a good leader. I miss him dearly.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you sure you're ready to be Shaman of the Skaal?
output: I have been preparing for it all my life. There is no question that I'm ready, but...

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sooner or later, death comes for us all.
output: We Skaal do not fear death. We know we will return to the All-Maker and be born anew. Life never truly ends. Death is just a passage from one form to the next.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Then why stay here? Why not live somewhere safer?
output: We are bound to this land, like a great pine with roots that run as deep as the tree is tall. I know it must seem strange to you, but for us, the thought of leaving our village is equally strange. The land and the Skaal are one. There is no other way to say it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where is your mother?
output: She died when I was very young. She was caught in a terrible snowstorm while returning home from gathering firewood. You must understand that, for the Skaal, life is a constant hardship. We take nothing for granted. We cannot afford to. Between the wolves, the weather and the threats in the south, even a simple task like gathering wood for the fire can turn deadly in an instant.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll just take the staff.
output: That's definitely safer. I'm not sure I'll risk summoning an Ash Guardian again myself. Too easy to forget about the heart stone!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like to learn the Ash Guardian spell.
output: All right. But remember, don't cast this without a heart stone! Otherwise the guardian will attack everyone, including you.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've destroyed the Ash Guardian.
output: Please, you have to help me. Master Neloth is not patient or understanding. At all.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I've got it. Don't cast Ash Guardian without a heart stone.
output: That's right. Don't be like me and have to learn the hard way. Here's the spell tome, and a heart stone so you can try it safely.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Is Master Neloth a good teacher?
output: Um. Well, he is a very great wizard. It's a great honor for him to have taken me as his apprentice. To be honest, it's horrible. He's very unpleasant and hardly teaches me anything. Sometimes he uses me in his experiments. Even so, I pick up a lot from just watching him.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Just looking for work.
output: You've picked one of the worst places in Morrowind to do that, but suit yourself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'm looking for Miraak. Do you know him?
output: Miraak... I... I'm not sure that I do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Until?
output: Until we ended up tracking him to one of the largest bandit encampments I'd ever seen. My patron took one look at me, and made the most menacing grin I'd ever seen. At that moment, I knew I'd never see him again. No amount of money would ever be worth that kind of death.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why did you work for him then?
output: Simple... he paid well. Very well. Anyway, we'd just cleared a ruined fort somewhere outside of Whiterun and when we got outside, we saw one of them galloping away on horseback. Well, my boss wasn't about to let him get away, so we pursued... on foot, for three days.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: How did you end up on Solstheim?
output: Long story, but I don't see the harm in sharing it with you. My last patron was a true Nord. He was dressed in animal skins, had tattoos on his face...  a real traditional type, if you know what I mean. He had an insatiable bloodlust and was extremely stubborn... one of the toughest employers I've ever had.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: None of your business.
output: That's the kind of attitude that's going to land you in prison, but I'll let it go for now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened to the mine?
output: It used to be one of the richest ebony mines in Morrowind, but it dried out years ago. Now, we're barely holding on out here. Without the mine, Raven Rock doesn't feel like it can last much longer.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened?
output: Hmm. Your eyes appear to be completely back to normal. Interesting.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: A Netch?
output: The giant air-floaters from the dark elf lands. Only the brave dare to hunt them, only the strong survive them. The giant air-floaters from the dark elf lands. Only the brave dare to hunt them, only the strong survive them. Come. Test yourself against the beast with us. We all will share in the glory of the hunt! Come. Test yourself against the beast with us. We all will share in the glory of the hunt!

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Good luck.
output: Luck? Luck will play no part today. We will earn our victory or return to the All-Maker. Luck? Luck will play no part today. We will earn our victory or return to the All-Maker.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Sounds fun. I'll join your hunt.
output: Well met, friend. May we all fight or die well. Well met, friend. May we all fight or die well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Bye.
output: Fight or die well. Fight or die well.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Think you'll win the fight?
output: A warrior expects nothing, and therefore is ready for anything. A warrior expects nothing, and therefore is ready for anything. If our aim and our hearts are true, the All-Maker will grant us strength. If our aim and our hearts are true, the All-Maker will grant us strength. If not, today is as good a day to die as any other. If not, today is as good a day to die as any other. Either way, they will sing songs of our bravery around the campfires for many years. Either way, they will sing songs of our bravery around the campfires for many years.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Can I dig for ebony in Raven Rock Mine?
output: Of course! In fact, Councilor Morvayn has given you the full run of the place. Help yourself to whatever you like. We're all in agreement that you're entitled to as much as you can carry.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I was attacked by some cultists who came here on your ship.
output: Now hold on! That wasn't my fault... I didn't know they were going to attack anybody. I don't even know how I got here.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need passage to Solstheim.
output: I already told you, I'm not going back to Solstheim.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I need passage to Solstheim.
output: If you're looking for passage to Solstheim, too bad. I'm not going back there anymore.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You owe me. Those cultists you brought here tried to kill me. (Persuade)
output: Alright, you have a point. Taking you back to find out who sent them is the least I can do. Besides, maybe you can put a stop to whatever's going on over there. I owe them a bit of payback myself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You owe me. Those cultists you brought here tried to kill me. (Persuade)
output: Look, I'm sorry about your troubles, but I've got to look out for myself. I'm not going to risk it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Solstheim? Where's that?
output: Surprised you've never heard of it. It's an island northeast of here. Has a small dark elf town called Raven Rock and a handful of Nords living in Skaal Village. But I'm not going back there. There's something wrong about that place.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Are you the captain of the Northern Maiden?
output: Sure. Yeah. That's me. Why? Who sent you?

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll pay you double your usual rate. (Give <Global=DLC2CostToSailx2> gold)
output: Well... a man's got to make a living, after all. Fine. We'll cast off immediately.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll pay you double your usual rate. (Give <Global=DLC2CostToSailx2> gold)
output: That's a tempting offer... when you actually have the gold, I might be willing to consider it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'll be back.
output: Whatever you want. The answer isn't going to be any different later though.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What happened?
output: There's been something strange happening on Solstheim for a while, but this... this is something else. I hope you get to the bottom of it.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: People are trying to kill me. I'm not taking no for an answer. (Intimidate)
output: Hold on, now. I'm just a simple sailor. I never wanted to get mixed up in any of this. Alright, I'll take you. But we leave immediately.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: People are trying to kill me. I'm not taking no for an answer. (Intimidate)
output: Yeah, well, and I don't want them trying to kill me. So the answer is still no.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Yes, you are. You're taking me to Solstheim.
output: Have you been listening to me? I'm not going back there.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I think this belongs to you. (Give Glover's Letter)
output: I... I can't believe it. All those years on the farm, and my mother never told me about any of this. Words can't even begin to describe how much I appreciate you bringing this to me. Here, take this. I used to carry it for good luck, but I think you deserve it more than I do.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: You think someone is out to get you?
output: I don't know. But I mean to find out. I still have some research to do before I'll know anything for certain.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Morrowind?
output: Red Mountain dominates the island. Every now and then ash and debris from an eruption land on our shores.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Morrowind?
output: You are too young to remember the Nerevarine. He defeated Dagoth Ur and saved us all from the blight.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Morrowind?
output: When the city of Vivec was destroyed, it took decades for us to rebuild. We are still but a shadow of our glorious past, but some day we will rise again.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Morrowind?
output: The ignorant think it is only a place of ash and lava. It had rolling green plains and swamps and verdant hills too.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Morrowind?
output: There is the big island of Vvardenfell, and the coastal mainland. House Telvanni has it's properties on Vvardenfell. I've never been to the mainland myself.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Morrowind?
output: It is the only place where silt striders can be found. Although I managed to transplant a few here when I arrived.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What can you tell me about Morrowind?
output: It's the homeland of the dunmer. The lesser races call us dark elves. We built great works there, like Vivec and Ald'ruhn. Many of them are destroyed now, either by Red Mountain or the argonian invasion.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Where is Master Neloth?
output: He's off doing research in Raven Rock. I think. He told me all about it, but I can't seem to recall the details right now.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Why don't you destroy it?
output: I, uh... I'm going to be reading the spell book. Maybe it can tell me how to banish the Ash Guardian.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: What is this place?
output: Tel Mithryn. It's the home of Master Neloth. You may have heard of him. He's a famous Telvanni wizard. He's not here right now. I think he's in Raven Rock.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: I'd like passage back to Skyrim.
output: Can't say I'd mind heading out of here. I still need to get paid, of course.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.
input: Did she ever return here?
output: Sadly, no. She died in Falkreath, where I was born.

instruction: Generate dialogue in the style of Skyrim.

input: Who are you? What are you doing here?
